Asked at Thursday's daily briefing if there would be additional staff shake-ups following Walsh's departure, White House press secretary Sean Spicer responded: "No." The triumvirate of top White House officials -- Priebus, chief strategist Steve Bannon and Trump's son-in-law and senior adviser Jared Kushner -- sang Walsh's praises during a briefing Thursday in Priebus' West Wing office with a small group of reporters. Bannon called her "the vital link that pulls things together and makes things happen," while Kushner called her "one of the unsung heroes of the campaign" and lauded the "sacrifice she is making." Priebus stressed that the decision for Walsh to leave the White House for the outside political group came after it became "abundantly clear we didn't have air cover" during the health care debate. "Nobody can fix this problem better than Katie Walsh," Priebus said. The three top advisers to the President said they jointly agreed for Walsh to leave for the outside group, but said the idea originated with Walsh. America First Policies, once envisioned as the marquee outside group to bolster Trump's political objectives. It has sputtered in the opening months of its presidency, having done no television advertising on behalf of Trump's Supreme Court nomination, and only began spending to prevent the White House's embarrassing defeat over Obamacare on the final day of the weeks-long debate. Just this week, the family expected to be its principal funders, the Mercer family of New York, defected to a rival nonprofit, Making America Great. They brought with them one of the operatives initially slated to work at America First -- Dave Bossie, a Mercer hand who had served as deputy campaign manager.

US District Court Judge Derrick Watson blocked the core provisions of the revised executive order two weeks ago, concluding that the order likely violates the Establishment Clause of the Constitution by disfavoring Muslims. But Watson's earlier decision was only a limited freeze of the executive order through a temporary restraining order. Read the ruling As a result, the plaintiffs asked the judge to convert that decision into a longer-term preliminary injunction and Watson agreed Wednesday night, meaning that the President's 90-day ban on foreign nationals from six Muslim-majority countries and the 120-ban on all refugees entering the country are now blocked indefinitely, unless any higher court changes Watson's order or the state's lawsuit is otherwise resolved. The Justice Department said Thursday morning it will continue to defend the executive order. "The Justice Department strongly disagrees with the federal district court's ruling. The President's executive order fails squarely within his lawful authority in seeking to protect our nation's security, and the department will continue to defend this executive order in the courts," a department spokesperson said in a statement. These Muslim Americans approve of the travel ban One of the practical implications of Wednesday's decision is that the Justice Department may now immediately appeal the ruling to the 9th Circuit Court of Appeals, should it choose to do so. But how long it will take for any appeals to be completed remains unclear. The reasoning in Watson's decision Wednesday largely follows his decision from two weeks ago, which used Supreme Court precedent to conclude that Donald Trump's statements about Muslims during the presidential campaign speak to the constitutionality of the executive order. "The court will not crawl into a corner, pull the shutters closed, and pretend it has not seen what it has," Watson wrote Wednesday. Trump's new travel ban blocked: What you need to know "The court concludes that, on the record before it, plaintiffs have met their burden of establishing a strong likelihood of success on the merits of their Establishment Clause claim." How Trump's 'Muslim ban' comments can hurt his travel ban case DOJ has separately appealed a different federal judge's decision to halt the 90-day travel ban to the 4th Circuit Court of Appeals.

President Donald Trump's oldest daughter will be an "adviser" to the President and will file her own Form 278, which means she is legally bound by ethics rules. Critics, however, claim that Trump's hiring violates federal nepotism laws. CNN's Alisyn Camerota asked Jason Miller on "New Day" Thursday: "The one thing I don't understand is how is this not nepotism?" "Well, I mean, how is it nepotism?" Miller, a Trump surrogate, replied. "Because she's the daughter of the President, that's how it's nepotism," Camerota responded. "She's working for free. She's volunteering her time and effort for the good of the country," Miller said. "Everybody from the White House counsel to the (Department of Justice) has said that this doesn't violate any sort of nepotism rules." Speaking during the same segment, former White House ethics czar Norman Eisen said that both the Barack Obama and George W. Bush administrations included the White House in its interpretation of the federal nepotism law, passed in 1967, that says no public official -- from the President down to a low-level manager at a federal agency -- may hire or promote a relative. But the law states that any appointee found to have violated the law is "not entitled to pay" by the federal government, which appears to offer the opportunity for Trump and Jared Kushner, her husband, to forgo paychecks while still serving the administration. Kushner, a top Donald Trump aide, is also serving the White House as an unpaid government employee. A source has told CNN that the decision to make Ivanka Trump officially an employee was made after there was great "unease" expressed by about the nature of her voluntary role. "I have heard the concerns some have with my advising the President in my personal capacity while voluntarily complying with all ethics rules, and I will instead serve as an unpaid employee in the White House Office, subject to all of the same rules as other federal employees," Ivanka Trump said in a statement. "Throughout this process, I have been working closely and in good faith with the White House counsel and my personal counsel to address the unprecedented nature of my role."

Washington D.C. - In a contentious and historic vote, Betsy DeVos was confirmed as the 11th Secretary of Education by a narrow margin of 51-50 in the Senate on February 7, 2017. The vote marked the first time in U.S. history that a vice president was required to cast a tie-breaking vote in the Senate.

DeVos, a billionaire philanthropist and education activist, has been a vocal advocate for school choice and charter schools. Her nomination was met with fierce opposition from Democrats and many Republicans, who expressed concerns over her lack of experience in public education and her support for private schools.

The Senate confirmation vote was delayed several times due to a Democratic filibuster, but ultimately, Vice President Mike Pence was called upon to cast the deciding vote. In a brief ceremony, Pence entered the Senate chamber and announced, "I hereby announce the vote is 51-50 in favor of confirming Betsy DeVos as Secretary of Education."

The confirmation was met with immediate criticism from Democrats, who claimed that DeVos was not qualified for the position and that her views on education would harm public schools. Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-NY) stated, "This is a dark day for public education in America."

On the other hand, Republicans hailed the confirmation as a victory for school choice and parental empowerment. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY) praised DeVos, saying, "She is a dedicated public servant who is committed to improving the lives of American students."

As Secretary of Education, DeVos will oversee a department with a budget of over $70 billion and a workforce of over 4,000 employees. Her confirmation sets the stage for a significant shift in education policy, with DeVos promising to focus on increasing school choice and reducing federal oversight of education.

The confirmation of Betsy DeVos as Secretary of Education marks a significant milestone in the Trump administration's efforts to reshape the federal government's role in education. While the vote was closely divided, DeVos's confirmation sets the stage for a contentious debate over the future of American education.

In a move that has sparked widespread concern among educators and civil rights advocates, the Senate has confirmed Betsy DeVos as the new Secretary of Education. The vote was largely along party lines, with Vice President Mike Pence casting the tie-breaking vote to confirm DeVos.

Critics of DeVos' nomination had long warned that her lack of experience in the education sector and her history of supporting voucher programs and charter schools would lead to a further erosion of public education. Now, many are worried that her confirmation will have a devastating impact on the country's most vulnerable students, particularly those in low-income and minority communities.

One of the primary concerns is that DeVos' policies will exacerbate the trend of resegregation in American schools. Under her leadership, schools that are already struggling to integrate may be incentivized to further segregate themselves, leading to a lack of diversity and a lack of opportunities for students of color.

DeVos has a history of supporting voucher programs, which allow parents to use public funds to send their children to private schools. This has been shown to have a disproportionate impact on low-income and minority students, who are more likely to be forced to attend underfunded and underresourced public schools.

Furthermore, DeVos has also been a strong supporter of charter schools, which have been shown to be less effective than traditional public schools in many cases. The proliferation of charter schools has also been linked to the decline of public education, as funding is diverted away from traditional public schools to support these privately-run institutions.

In addition to these concerns, DeVos' confirmation has also been met with opposition from many educators and education experts, who argue that she lacks the qualifications and experience necessary to lead the Department of Education.

As the country moves forward with DeVos at the helm of the Department of Education, many are left wondering what the future holds for public education. Will DeVos' policies lead to a further erosion of public education, or will she surprise critics and work to improve the system? Only time will tell, but for now, many are left feeling uneasy about the direction of American education.

Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei has lashed out at US President Donald Trump, stating that he has revealed the "true face" of the United States. Khamenei made the comments during a speech at Tehran University on Tuesday, as reported by the semi-official Fars News Agency.

The Iranian leader's remarks come amid heightened tensions between Tehran and Washington, following Trump's decision to withdraw from the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA), also known as the Iran nuclear deal. The deal was signed in 2015 by the Obama administration and several other world powers, and was aimed at curbing Iran's nuclear program in exchange for relief from international sanctions.

Khamenei accused Trump of being a "new edition" of former US President George W. Bush, who led the invasion of Iraq in 2003. The Iranian leader stated that Trump's actions are a continuation of the US's "hegemonic" and "imperialist" policies, which seek to dominate and control other nations.

"He [Trump] has shown the true face of the United States," Khamenei said. "He has shown that the US is a deceitful and treacherous government. They lied and deceived the world, and now they are doing the same thing with the nuclear deal."

Khamenei also warned that the US's withdrawal from the JCPOA would have severe consequences for the region and the world. He called on the international community to stand against the US's "aggressive" actions and to defend the nuclear deal.

The Iranian leader's comments come as tensions between Tehran and Washington continue to escalate. The US has imposed new sanctions on Iran, and has accused the country of supporting terrorism and human rights abuses. Iran has responded by threatening to retaliate against US interests in the region.

The US withdrawal from the JCPOA has also been met with widespread criticism from European leaders, who had signed the deal along with the US. The European Union has announced plans to work with Iran to maintain the nuclear deal, despite the US's withdrawal.

The situation remains highly volatile, with many experts warning of the potential for conflict in the region. The US and Iran have a long history of tensions, and the situation could potentially escalate into a wider conflict.

In a shocking and unprecedented move, the leader of Al Qaeda has publicly mocked US President Donald Trump following a botched raid in Yemen that left 30 civilians dead, including 10 children. The brazen statement is a rare instance of a terrorist organization's leader directly targeting a sitting US President.

In a message released on social media, Al Qaeda leader Ayman al-Zawahiri called Trump "a fool" and accused him of being responsible for the deaths of the innocent civilians in the raid. The statement, which was translated by SITE Intelligence Group, a US-based monitoring organization, also claimed that the raid was a "cowardly" act that demonstrated the US military's ineptitude.

The raid, which was conducted on January 29, was aimed at capturing or killing Al Qaeda leader Qasim al-Raymi, who was reportedly killed in the operation. However, the mission quickly turned into a debacle, with US Navy SEALs suffering heavy casualties and losing one of their own, Chief Petty Officer William "Ryan" Owens, who was killed in the raid.

The botched raid has sparked widespread outrage and criticism, with many questioning the efficacy of the operation and the Trump administration's handling of the situation. Trump himself has been criticized for his handling of the aftermath, with many accusing him of using the raid as a way to deflect attention from the controversy surrounding his travel ban and other issues.

Al-Zawahiri's statement is likely to further inflame tensions between the US and Al Qaeda, and could potentially be used to galvanize support for the terrorist organization among its followers. The statement also underscores the challenges facing the Trump administration in its efforts to combat terrorism, as it struggles to balance its military actions with its rhetoric and public diplomacy.

In a statement, the US Department of Defense said it would not comment on Al-Zawahiri's statement, but reiterated its commitment to combating terrorism and protecting its citizens. The statement also praised the bravery and professionalism of the US military personnel involved in the raid.

As the situation continues to unfold, it remains to be seen how the Trump administration will respond to Al-Zawahiri's mocking statement and whether it will have any impact on the administration's plans to tackle terrorism. One thing is certain, however - the botched raid in Yemen has opened up a new front in the war on terror, and the US and its allies will need to be prepared to respond to the changing dynamics of the conflict.

A group of journalists has launched a scathing attack on the White House's claims regarding the accuracy of its terror reporting. The criticism comes after a recent report by the White House claiming that there has been a significant decrease in terrorist attacks in the United States.

The report, which was released on January 31, 2017, stated that the number of terrorist attacks in the US had decreased by 73% since the beginning of 2016. However, a group of journalists from various news organizations, including The New York Times, The Washington Post, and CNN, have disputed these claims.

According to the journalists, the White House's report was based on a flawed methodology that failed to take into account the definition of a "terrorist attack." The journalists argued that the report's definition of a terrorist attack was too narrow, and that it excluded many incidents that could be considered as terrorist attacks.

The journalists also pointed out that the report's data was based on a small sample size, and that it did not take into account the severity of the attacks. They argued that the report's conclusion that there had been a significant decrease in terrorist attacks was based on a flawed analysis of the data.

The White House has defended its report, saying that it was based on the best available data and that it was a accurate reflection of the current situation. However, the journalists have refused to back down, saying that the report was flawed and that it did not provide a accurate picture of the threat posed by terrorism.

The dispute between the White House and the journalists has sparked a heated debate about the accuracy of the White House's terror reporting. Many experts have weighed in on the issue, with some supporting the White House's claims and others criticizing the report's methodology.

The controversy has also raised questions about the role of the media in reporting on terrorism. Some have argued that the media has a responsibility to critically evaluate the information provided by the government, while others have argued that the media should simply report on the information provided without questioning its accuracy.

Regardless of the outcome of the dispute, the controversy has highlighted the importance of accurate and reliable information in the reporting of terrorism. It has also underscored the need for the media and the government to work together to provide the public with a accurate and balanced picture of the threat posed by terrorism.

The United States Supreme Court is set to hear oral arguments in the case of Trump v. International Refugee Assistance Project, a legal challenge to President Donald Trump's executive order restricting travel from seven predominantly Muslim countries. The executive order, signed on January 27, 2017, has been met with widespread criticism and legal challenges, with many arguing that it is discriminatory and unconstitutional.

The Supreme Court's decision is highly anticipated, as it will determine the fate of the travel ban and its potential impact on national security and immigration policy. Here are some key points to know about the oral arguments:

* The case will be heard by a eight-justice court, with Justice Elena Kagan recused due to her previous involvement in the case.
* The government will argue that the president has broad authority to restrict immigration and that the travel ban is necessary for national security.
* Opponents of the travel ban will argue that it is unconstitutional and discriminatory, violating the Establishment Clause of the First Amendment and the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.
* The oral arguments will focus on the legality of the travel ban and whether it is a "bona fide" national security measure.
* The Supreme Court has already allowed the travel ban to go into effect, pending the outcome of the case.

The oral arguments are expected to be highly contentious, with many expecting the justices to grill the government on the constitutionality of the travel ban. The Supreme Court's decision is expected to be issued in the coming weeks, and its impact will be felt far beyond the borders of the United States.

Scientists have made a breakthrough in the development of a male contraceptive gel, which has been shown to be effective in monkeys. The researchers believe that the gel could potentially be used as a non-hormonal, reversible, and safe form of male contraception. However, before humans can benefit from this innovation, the scientists must conduct further studies to ensure its safety and efficacy.

The male contraceptive gel, developed by researchers at the National Institutes of Health (NIH), is designed to work by blocking the production of sperm. The gel is applied to the skin of the scrotum, where it is absorbed into the bloodstream and travels to the testes. Once there, it inhibits the production of sperm, effectively preventing fertilization.

In the study, published in the journal Science Translational Medicine, the researchers tested the gel on 12 male rhesus macaques. The results showed that the gel was able to suppress sperm production in all of the monkeys, with the effects lasting for up to four months.

While the results are promising, the scientists are quick to point out that the gel is still in the early stages of development. "We have a long way to go before we can say whether this gel will be effective and safe for human use," said Dr. Stephanie Page, the lead researcher on the study. "We need to conduct more studies to ensure that the gel is safe and effective in humans."

The development of a male contraceptive gel has the potential to revolutionize family planning. Currently, there are limited options for men looking to avoid pregnancy, and many of these options have side effects or are not always effective. A non-hormonal, reversible, and safe form of male contraception could provide men with a more convenient and effective way to plan their families.

In addition to its potential benefits for family planning, the development of the male contraceptive gel could also have implications for the treatment of certain medical conditions. For example, the gel could potentially be used to treat conditions such as prostate cancer, where the ability to suppress sperm production could be beneficial.

Overall, the development of the male contraceptive gel is an exciting breakthrough, and scientists are eager to continue studying its potential. While there is still much work to be done, the results of the study are promising, and the possibility of a new and effective form of male contraception is on the horizon.

MOSCOW, Feb 7 (Reuters) - Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny, a vocal critic of President Vladimir Putin, is in a "grave" condition in a hospital in the city of Omsk after suffering full organ failure, his team said on Tuesday.

Navalny, 41, was admitted to the hospital on Monday after falling ill on a flight from Tomsk to Moscow. His team said he was in a coma and was receiving treatment for an unknown illness.

"The situation is very serious, and Alexei is in a grave condition," Navalny's spokesperson, Kira Yarmysh, said in a statement. "He has suffered full organ failure, and his life is at risk."

The exact cause of Navalny's illness is still unknown, but his team has ruled out poisoning. Navalny has been a thorn in the side of Putin's government for years, using his blog and social media to expose corruption and criticize the president's policies.

Navalny's illness has sparked concerns about his safety and the potential motives behind his sudden illness. His team has called for an investigation into the circumstances surrounding his hospitalization.

The Russian government has not commented on Navalny's condition, but the Kremlin has previously accused him of being a pawn in a Western plot to destabilize Russia.

Navalny's supporters have taken to social media to express their concerns and demand answers about his condition. Many have called for the government to provide transparency and allow Navalny's family to visit him.

As news of Navalny's condition spreads, international human rights groups have also expressed concern and called for his immediate release from hospital and for the Russian government to ensure his safety.

Navalny's illness has raised questions about the safety of opposition leaders in Russia and the extent to which the government will go to silence its critics. The incident has also sparked concerns about the potential for further political repression in the country.

The Russian government has faced criticism in recent years for its treatment of opposition leaders, with many facing imprisonment, exile, or assassination attempts.

Navalny's team has vowed to continue fighting for his release and to demand answers about his condition. The international community is closely watching the situation and calling for the Russian government to ensure Navalny's safety and well-being.

A controversial new law has been passed in a country, allowing husbands to sue their wives for various reasons, including to stop an abortion. The law, which has sparked widespread criticism and debate, has been met with outrage from women's rights groups and advocates.

According to the law, a husband can sue his wife for "emotional distress" if she decides to have an abortion without his consent. The law also allows husbands to seek damages for "loss of consortium" if their wife has an abortion.

The law has been criticized for its potential to restrict women's reproductive rights and for its lack of consideration for the potential consequences of an abortion on the woman's physical and emotional well-being.

Women's rights groups have argued that the law is a violation of a woman's right to make her own decisions about her body and her health. They have also pointed out that the law could have unintended consequences, such as encouraging women to seek illegal or unsafe abortions.

The law has also been criticized for its potential to create a culture of fear and intimidation around abortion. Women who are considering an abortion may feel pressured to seek their husband's consent, even if they do not want to continue the pregnancy.

In response to the criticism, the government has defended the law, saying that it is intended to promote "family values" and to protect the "rights" of husbands. However, many have argued that the law is a step backwards for women's rights and that it is not in line with international human rights standards.

The law has also been met with criticism from medical professionals, who have expressed concerns about the potential impact on women's health. They have argued that the law could lead to delays in seeking medical care and could increase the risk of complications from unsafe abortions.

The law has sparked a heated debate about the role of government in regulating women's reproductive rights. While some have argued that the government has a responsibility to protect the "rights" of husbands, others have argued that the government should be focused on protecting the rights and health of women.

As the debate continues, many are left wondering what the implications of this law will be for women's rights and reproductive health. One thing is clear, however: the law has sparked a much-needed conversation about the importance of protecting women's rights and promoting access to safe and legal abortion.

Tensions between China and Japan escalated on February 5, 2017, as Chinese coast guard vessels sailed near the disputed Senkaku Islands in the East China Sea. The islands, also known as the Diaoyu Islands in Chinese, have been a source of contention between the two nations for decades.

According to reports, five Chinese coast guard ships entered the waters surrounding the islands, prompting Japan to scramble fighter jets to monitor the situation. The Japanese government has been urging China to respect its territorial claims and to withdraw the vessels from the area.

The Senkaku Islands are a group of five uninhabited islets located in the East China Sea, approximately 200 kilometers north of Taiwan. Both China and Japan claim sovereignty over the islands, with Japan having administered them since 1895. China, however, has been increasingly assertive in its claims, citing historical records and geographical proximity.

The recent incursion by Chinese vessels is the latest in a series of provocative actions taken by China in the region. In 2012, China's national oil company, CNOOC, began exploring for oil and gas in the waters surrounding the islands, sparking a diplomatic row with Japan.

The Japanese government has condemned the latest incursion, calling it a "serious threat to Japan's national security and territorial integrity." Japan has also urged China to abide by international law and to respect the country's sovereignty over the islands.

The United States has also weighed in on the issue, with a State Department spokesperson stating that "the United States opposes any unilateral actions that could escalate tensions in the region." The spokesperson also called on all parties to resolve the dispute peacefully and in accordance with international law.

The situation is likely to remain tense in the coming days, with both sides showing no signs of backing down. The dispute over the Senkaku Islands is just one of many territorial disputes in the Asia-Pacific region, and its resolution will likely have far-reaching implications for regional stability and security.

"I was waiting for my brother outside the court when the blast happened," said Gulalai, a local resident who witnessed the attack. "I saw people running and screaming, and I thought it was the end of the world."

Amnesty International has released a shocking report, claiming that over 13,000 people were secretly hanged at a Syrian prison during the country's ongoing civil war. The organization says that the majority of those executed were civilians, including children, women, and men who were arrested for their political beliefs or suspected of being opponents of the government.

According to the report, the majority of the executions took place at the Saydnaya military prison, located just outside of Damascus. Amnesty International researchers spoke to multiple sources, including former prisoners and guards, who confirmed the mass executions.

The organization claims that the executions were carried out in secret, with prisoners being taken from their cells in the middle of the night and hanged in groups of 50-100. The prisoners were often denied access to lawyers and were not given a fair trial.

"This is a shocking and devastating revelation that highlights the brutal and systematic nature of the Syrian government's human rights abuses," said Philip Luther, Amnesty International's Middle East and North Africa research director.

The Syrian government has repeatedly denied allegations of mass executions, but Amnesty International's report is the latest in a series of damning human rights abuses against the government.

The report also highlights the role of the Russian government in supporting the Syrian government's actions. Russia has been a key ally of Syrian President Bashar al-Assad, and has provided military support to his government.

The news comes as the Syrian civil war enters its sixth year, with no end in sight. The conflict has resulted in the deaths of hundreds of thousands of people, and the displacement of millions more.

Amnesty International is calling on the international community to take immediate action to address the human rights crisis in Syria. The organization is urging governments to impose targeted sanctions on those responsible for the human rights abuses, and to provide humanitarian aid to those affected by the conflict.

The report's findings are a stark reminder of the devastating consequences of the Syrian civil war, and the need for immediate action to protect the rights of those affected.

Photographer Martin Schoeller has been taking portraits of some of the most iconic figures in the world, from bodybuilders to world leaders, for over two decades. His unique approach to photography has earned him widespread recognition and acclaim. Schoeller's photographs are not just aesthetically pleasing, but they also reveal the subject's true nature, as he believes that an "honest" photograph is one that shows the subject as they truly are.

Schoeller's journey in photography began in the early 1990s, when he started working as an assistant to renowned photographer, Herb Ritts. During this time, he honed his skills and developed his own style, which focuses on capturing the subject's authenticity. His breakthrough came in 2003, when he published his first book, "Obamaland," featuring portraits of then-Senator Barack Obama. The book became an instant hit, and it was praised for its candid portrayal of the future president.

Since then, Schoeller has continued to work with a wide range of subjects, from celebrities like Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson and Jennifer Lawrence to athletes like LeBron James and Serena Williams. He has also taken portraits of world leaders, including former President Barack Obama, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, and even the Dalai Lama.

Schoeller's approach to photography is centered around his concept of "honest" photography. He believes that a true portrait should reveal the subject's true nature, rather than just showcasing their public image. To achieve this, he uses a unique combination of techniques, including unconventional lighting, bold compositions, and a focus on the subject's eyes.

One of the most striking aspects of Schoeller's photographs is the way he captures the subject's personality. His portraits often reveal a more vulnerable or introspective side of the subject, which is a far cry from the usual glamour and glitz of celebrity photography.

Schoeller's work has been exhibited in galleries and museums around the world, and he has received numerous awards and accolades for his photography. His photographs are also held in high esteem by his subjects, many of whom have praised his ability to capture their true essence.

In an interview with The Guardian, Schoeller explained his approach to photography, saying, "I'm not interested in creating a perfect image. I'm interested in creating an honest image. I want to show the subject as they truly are, not as they want to be seen."

As Schoeller continues to take portraits of some of the most fascinating figures in the world, his work serves as a reminder of the power of photography to reveal the truth and capture the essence of its subjects.

In a fascinating convergence of art and science, bio-art is emerging as a unique discipline that combines the precision of machines with the creativity of art. This innovative field is not only pushing the boundaries of artistic expression but also offering new insights into the natural world and our relationship with it.

Bio-art, also known as biodesign or biotechnology art, is a relatively new field that involves the use of biological materials, such as microorganisms, cells, and genes, to create artistic installations, sculptures, and performances. The fusion of art and science in bio-art has given rise to a new generation of artists who are using cutting-edge biotechnology to explore the boundaries of creativity.

One of the pioneers of bio-art is the British artist Heather Barnett, who has been working with bees and other insects to create intricate sculptures and installations that challenge our perceptions of nature and our place within it. Her work, which includes a collaboration with a swarm of bees to create a large-scale sculpture, has sparked widespread interest and debate about the role of art in shaping our understanding of the natural world.

Another artist making waves in the bio-art scene is the American artist Heather Dewey-Hagborg, who has been using DNA sequencing and other biotechnological techniques to create intricate portraits of individuals based on their genetic information. Her work, which includes a project that used DNA sequencing to create a portrait of a person based on their genetic makeup, has raised important questions about the relationship between art, science, and identity.

Bio-art is not only pushing the boundaries of artistic expression but also offering new insights into the natural world and our relationship with it. By using biological materials and biotechnological techniques to create art, bio-artists are able to explore complex scientific concepts and principles in a way that is both accessible and engaging.

As the field of bio-art continues to evolve, it is likely to have a significant impact on the way we think about art, science, and the natural world. By combining the precision of machines with the creativity of art, bio-artists are creating a new language that is capable of communicating complex scientific concepts and principles in a way that is both accessible and engaging.

In conclusion, the fusion of art and science in bio-art is a powerful and exciting development that is pushing the boundaries of both disciplines. As the field continues to evolve, it is likely to have a significant impact on the way we think about art, science, and the natural world, and to offer new insights and perspectives that will shape our understanding of the world around us.

Narok, Kenya - In a remarkable turnaround, a group of Maasai warriors in Kenya who once hunted and killed lions for sport have now turned into wildlife warriors, dedicating their lives to protecting the very same predators they once feared.

The Maasai people, who inhabit the Rift Valley region of Kenya, have traditionally had a complex relationship with lions. In the past, they would hunt and kill the big cats for sport, viewing them as a threat to their livestock. However, over the years, the Maasai have come to realize the importance of preserving the lion population and the ecosystem as a whole.

The change in attitude is largely attributed to the efforts of a local conservation organization, the Maasai Wilderness Conservation Trust (MWCT). The organization has been working with the Maasai community to educate them on the importance of conservation and to provide them with alternative sources of income.

One of the key initiatives of the MWCT is the Lion Guardians program, which employs former lion-hunters as wildlife warriors. These warriors, who are now known as "lion guardians," are tasked with monitoring lion prides, tracking poachers, and working with local authorities to protect the lions and their habitats.

The program has been highly successful, with the number of lion killings by Maasai warriors decreasing significantly over the past few years. In fact, a recent survey by the MWCT found that over 90% of Maasai warriors who were once involved in lion hunting now support conservation efforts and are actively working to protect the lions.

The lion guardians are also being trained in other conservation skills, such as tracking, surveillance, and community outreach. This not only helps to protect the lions but also provides the Maasai warriors with a sense of purpose and a new source of income.

The success of the Lion Guardians program is a testament to the power of community-based conservation and the importance of engaging local communities in conservation efforts. By working together, conservation organizations and local communities can achieve great things and help to protect the world's precious wildlife.

The Dalai Lama, the spiritual leader of Tibetan Buddhism, is known for his wisdom, compassion, and kindness. But few people know that he also uses a secret weapon to spread joy and positivity: playful humor. In a recent interview, the Dalai Lama revealed that he believes humor is a powerful tool for bringing people together and creating a sense of community.

According to the Dalai Lama, playful humor is a way to break down barriers and connect with others on a deeper level. He believes that by using humor, people can let their guard down and be more authentic, which can lead to deeper and more meaningful relationships.

But how can we, as ordinary people, use playful humor to bring more joy and positivity into our lives? The Dalai Lama suggests that we start by being playful and lighthearted, even in difficult situations. He encourages people to find the humor in everyday situations and to not take themselves too seriously.

Additionally, the Dalai Lama recommends using humor to connect with others. He suggests that we use playful humor to break the ice and build rapport with others, whether it's a colleague, a friend, or a stranger.

The Dalai Lama's emphasis on playful humor is not just a personal quirk, but rather a key component of his approach to spirituality and personal growth. He believes that by cultivating a sense of humor, people can become more compassionate, more patient, and more understanding.

In a world that can sometimes seem serious and somber, the Dalai Lama's message of playful humor is a refreshing reminder of the importance of joy and positivity. By incorporating playful humor into our daily lives, we can create a more lighthearted and compassionate world, one joke at a time.

When it comes to urban design, rooftops are often overlooked as a vital component of a city's architecture. However, many buildings have transformed their rooftops into breathtaking spaces that offer a unique perspective on the city. Here are 13 incredible rooftops around the world that will make you want to gaze up at the sky:

1. The Roof of the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, Cleveland, USA - The rooftop of this iconic museum features a stunning view of Lake Erie and the Cleveland skyline. Visitors can enjoy a drink at the rooftop bar while taking in the sights.

2. The Rooftop Garden of the Botanical Garden, Singapore - This tropical paradise offers a serene escape from the hustle and bustle of the city. The rooftop garden features over 1,000 species of plants and trees, as well as a tranquil pond.

3. The Sky Garden, London, UK - This free public garden on the 35th floor of the Walkie-Talkie building offers panoramic views of the city. Visitors can enjoy the garden's lush greenery and take in the sights of the London skyline.

4. The Rooftop Pool of the Hotel Amigo, Paris, France - This stylish hotel's rooftop pool offers breathtaking views of the Eiffel Tower and the City of Light. Visitors can enjoy a refreshing swim or simply relax in the sun.

5. The Rooftop of the Raffles Hotel, Singapore - This iconic hotel's rooftop bar is a popular spot for cocktail enthusiasts. The bar offers stunning views of the city skyline and a wide range of drinks to choose from.

6. The Rooftop of the 25 Hours Hotel, Berlin, Germany - This stylish hotel's rooftop bar offers stunning views of the Berlin skyline. Visitors can enjoy a drink or snack while taking in the sights.

7. The Rooftop of the Mandarin Oriental, Bangkok, Thailand - This luxurious hotel's rooftop bar offers stunning views of the Chao Phraya River and the city skyline. Visitors can enjoy a drink or snack while taking in the sights.

8. The Rooftop of the Four Seasons Hotel, New York City, USA - This luxurious hotel's rooftop bar offers stunning views of Central Park and the Manhattan skyline. Visitors can enjoy a drink or snack while taking in the sights.

9. The Rooftop of the Vdara Hotel, Las Vegas, USA - This stylish hotel's rooftop pool offers stunning views of the Las Vegas Strip. Visitors can enjoy a refreshing swim or simply relax in the sun.

10. The Rooftop of the Hotel d'Angleterre, Geneva, Switzerland - This luxurious hotel's rooftop bar offers stunning views of Lake Geneva and the city skyline. Visitors can enjoy a drink or snack while taking in the sights.

11. The Rooftop of the Grand Hyatt, New York City, USA - This luxurious hotel's rooftop bar offers stunning views of Central Park and the Manhattan skyline. Visitors can enjoy a drink or snack while taking in the sights.

12. The Rooftop of the InterContinental Hotel, Hong Kong - This luxurious hotel's rooftop bar offers stunning views of Victoria Harbour and the city skyline. Visitors can enjoy a drink or snack while taking in the sights.

13. The Rooftop of the Hotel Plaza Athenee, Paris, France - This luxurious hotel's rooftop bar offers stunning views of the Eiffel Tower and the City of Light. Visitors can enjoy a drink or snack while taking in the sights.

These 13 incredible rooftops around the world offer a unique perspective on the city and are definitely worth a visit. Whether you're looking for stunning views, a refreshing swim, or simply a relaxing spot to enjoy a drink, these rooftops have something for everyone.

On February 28, 2017, a group of students from the University of Michigan announced their plans to launch a global movement called #MyFreedomDay, aimed at raising awareness about modern-day slavery and human trafficking. The initiative is set to take place on March 14, 2017, and will involve students from over 100 colleges and universities across the United States.

According to the organizers, #MyFreedomDay is a response to the growing concern about the persistence of slavery and human trafficking in the 21st century. The movement aims to mobilize students and young people to take action against these injustices and to demand that governments and corporations take concrete steps to prevent them.

The initiative will feature a range of activities, including awareness campaigns, fundraising events, and advocacy efforts. Participants will be encouraged to share their experiences and stories on social media using the hashtag #MyFreedomDay, and to participate in a global social media storm to raise awareness about the issue.

The organizers of #MyFreedomDay are working closely with anti-slavery organizations and advocacy groups to ensure that the initiative is effective and impactful. The movement is also supported by several prominent celebrities and public figures, who have pledged to participate and raise awareness about the issue.

The launch of #MyFreedomDay comes at a time when human trafficking and modern-day slavery are increasingly recognized as major global problems. According to the International Labor Organization, there are an estimated 21 million people trapped in modern slavery worldwide, with the majority being women and girls.

The movement is also timed to coincide with the 20th anniversary of the Trafficking Victims Protection Act (TVPA), a landmark legislation that aimed to combat human trafficking and modern-day slavery. The TVPA has been credited with helping to reduce the number of human trafficking cases in the United States, but organizers of #MyFreedomDay argue that more needs to be done to eradicate the problem.

As #MyFreedomDay approaches, students and young people around the world are gearing up to take action against modern-day slavery and human trafficking. With its global reach and social media momentum, the movement has the potential to make a significant impact and to inspire a new generation of activists and advocates to take on this critical issue.

OTTAWA - The issue of missing and murdered Indigenous women in Canada has been a long-standing concern, but a recent report by the Canadian Centre for Policy Alternatives (CCPA) has shed light on a disturbing trend: sex traffickers are targeting Indigenous Canadian women and girls.

According to the report, which was released in June 2016, Indigenous women and girls are disproportionately represented among Canada's sex trade, with some estimates suggesting that they make up as much as 50% of the sex trade industry. This is despite the fact that Indigenous people make up only 4.9% of the Canadian population.

The CCPA report, titled "Stolen Sisters: The Human Rights Crisis of Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls in Canada," highlights the systemic issues that contribute to the vulnerability of Indigenous women and girls to sex trafficking. These include poverty, lack of access to education and employment opportunities, and the legacy of colonialism and forced assimilation.

The report also notes that many Indigenous women and girls are forced into the sex trade by traffickers who prey on their vulnerability. These traffickers often use tactics such as manipulation, coercion, and violence to keep their victims captive and under their control.

The issue of sex trafficking among Indigenous women and girls is not limited to Canada. According to the International Justice Mission, a non-profit organization that works to combat human trafficking, Indigenous women and girls are disproportionately affected by sex trafficking in many countries around the world.

The Canadian government has faced criticism for its response to the issue of missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls, including the lack of a comprehensive strategy to address the root causes of the problem. The CCPA report calls for increased funding for services and programs that support Indigenous women and girls, as well as a national inquiry into the issue of missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls.

The issue of sex trafficking among Indigenous women and girls is a complex and deeply disturbing one, and it will require a concerted effort from government, community organizations, and individuals to address. It is a reminder of the urgent need for a comprehensive and inclusive approach to addressing the systemic issues that contribute to the vulnerability of Indigenous women and girls.

A 32-year-old man was arrested in California after a detective discovered a small but crucial detail in a photo he posted online, leading to his identification as a child predator. The suspect, who has not been named, was arrested on April 19, 2016, and is being held on suspicion of multiple counts of child pornography and distribution of child pornography.

According to the authorities, the suspect had posted a photo of himself on a social media platform, which caught the attention of a detective from the Santa Clara County Sheriff's Office. The detective, who was working on a tip about a possible child predator, noticed something unusual in the photo - a tattoo on the suspect's hand that matched a description from a previous investigation.

The detective, who has been working on the case for several months, had been reviewing hundreds of tips and photos when he came across the suspect's image. He immediately recognized the tattoo and realized that it was the same one described by a victim in a previous case.

The detective then worked with the suspect's social media provider to obtain more information about the account, including the suspect's IP address and other identifying details. This led to a search warrant being issued for the suspect's home, where authorities found evidence of child pornography and other incriminating materials.

The suspect was arrested at his home and is currently being held without bail. The authorities have released few details about the case, but it is believed that the suspect had been producing and distributing child pornography for several years.

The arrest is a testament to the importance of online detective work and the impact that a small detail can have in solving a complex case. The detective who made the arrest has been praised for his diligence and attention to detail, and the authorities are now working to identify any potential victims of the suspect's crimes.

The case is a reminder of the importance of online safety and the need for parents and children to be aware of the risks associated with social media. It also highlights the crucial role that law enforcement plays in protecting children from predators and bringing perpetrators to justice.

As the investigation continues, the authorities are urging anyone with information about the suspect or his activities to come forward. The case is a sobering reminder of the importance of staying vigilant and reporting any suspicious activity to the authorities.

HANOI, Vietnam (AP) - The smuggling of Vietnamese girls into China and their sale as child brides has become a growing concern for authorities in both countries.

According to a recent report by the International Justice Mission, a non-governmental organization that works to protect the rights of the vulnerable, at least 10,000 Vietnamese girls and women are smuggled into China each year, with many of them being sold into forced marriages.

The report, which was released on April 15, 2016, found that the majority of the girls and women are between the ages of 12 and 18, and that many of them are from poor and rural areas of Vietnam.

The smugglers, who are often members of organized crime syndicates, promise the girls and their families better economic opportunities in China, but instead, the girls are sold to Chinese men who are often much older and wealthier.

The report also found that many of the girls and women are subjected to physical and sexual abuse, and that some are forced to work in factories or as domestic servants.

The Vietnamese government has promised to take action to combat the problem, and has launched a number of initiatives to prevent the smuggling of its citizens into China.

In addition, the Chinese government has also taken steps to address the issue, including increasing the penalties for those found guilty of human trafficking.

Despite these efforts, the problem remains a significant challenge for both countries, and it is likely to continue to be a major issue for years to come.

The International Justice Mission is calling on both governments to do more to protect the rights of Vietnamese girls and women, and to bring those responsible for the smuggling and sale of child brides to justice.

In his first month in office, President Donald Trump has been making headlines with his unconventional approach to politics. Unlike his predecessors, Trump has chosen to focus on creating fear and uncertainty rather than offering reassurance and calm. This shift in tone has left many Americans wondering why Trump is opting for a strategy that has historically been unsuccessful.

One of the most notable examples of Trump's scare tactics is his repeated claims that his predecessor, Barack Obama, wiretapped him during the 2016 presidential election. Despite a lack of evidence, Trump has continued to assert that Obama was involved in a conspiracy to undermine his campaign. This narrative has been widely debunked by fact-checkers and intelligence agencies, but Trump's persistence has created a sense of unease among many Americans.

Trump's approach to healthcare is another area where he has chosen to focus on fear rather than hope. Rather than highlighting the benefits of the Affordable Care Act (ACA), Trump has opted to emphasize the potential drawbacks and the uncertainty surrounding the future of the healthcare system. This strategy has been criticized by many experts, who argue that it is unfair to create fear and anxiety among those who rely on the ACA for their healthcare.

Trump's use of fear-mongering has also been evident in his approach to national security. In his first major speech on the topic, Trump painted a dire picture of the threats facing the United States, from terrorism to cyber attacks. While it is true that these threats exist, many experts argue that Trump's approach is overly alarmist and may actually create more problems than it solves.

So why is Trump opting for a strategy that has historically been unsuccessful? One possible explanation is that Trump believes that fear and uncertainty are effective tools for achieving his policy goals. By creating a sense of crisis, Trump may be attempting to justify his own policies and actions, which may be unpopular with many Americans.

Another possible explanation is that Trump is simply not equipped to handle the demands of the presidency. As a businessman, Trump is used to making deals and creating wealth, but he may not have the same level of expertise in areas such as foreign policy and national security. As a result, he may be relying on fear and uncertainty to create a sense of urgency and justify his own decisions.

Regardless of the reason, Trump's approach to politics is a departure from the strategies used by his predecessors. While some may see it as a refreshing change, others may view it as a cause for concern. As the new president continues to shape his administration, it will be important to monitor his approach and evaluate its effectiveness in achieving his goals.

President Donald Trump on Tuesday accused Senator Richard Blumenthal of misrepresenting his comments on Judge Neil Gorsuch, who is Trump's nominee for the Supreme Court. However, a review of Trump's remarks and the senator's statements suggests that Trump's accusation is unfounded.

During a speech at the National Prayer Breakfast on Thursday, Trump praised Gorsuch, saying that he is "a highly respected judge" and "a man of great integrity." However, he also took issue with Blumenthal's comments about Gorsuch's criticism of a 2006 opinion written by Justice Anthony Kennedy.

Blumenthal, a Democrat from Connecticut, had stated that Gorsuch's criticism of Kennedy's opinion in the case of Planned Parenthood v. Casey was "a fundamental departure from established law" and "a radical departure from the settled law of the land." Trump responded by saying that Blumenthal was "misrepresenting" his comments on Gorsuch.

However, a review of Trump's remarks shows that he did not criticize Blumenthal's comments on Gorsuch's criticism of Kennedy's opinion. Instead, Trump praised Gorsuch and defended his nomination for the Supreme Court.

The controversy over Trump's accusation against Blumenthal highlights the intense political debate surrounding Gorsuch's nomination. Democrats have criticized Gorsuch's views on issues such as abortion and workers' rights, while Republicans have praised his conservative credentials.

As the nomination process continues, the debate over Gorsuch's qualifications and views is likely to remain a central issue. The Senate is expected to vote on the nomination in the coming weeks.

* Trump, D. (2017, February 2). Remarks at the National Prayer Breakfast. The White House.
* Blumenthal, R. (2017, January 31). Statement on Judge Neil Gorsuch's Nomination to the Supreme Court. United States Senate.

BEIRUT, Feb 9 (Reuters) - A Russian airstrike mistakenly targeted Turkish troops in northern Syria on Tuesday, killing three soldiers and wounding several others, the Turkish military said.

The airstrike hit a Turkish military outpost in the town of al-Bab, which is controlled by Turkish-backed rebels fighting against Islamic State militants. The Turkish military said the strike was carried out by Russian warplanes, but Moscow has yet to confirm the incident.

The Turkish military said the strike caused significant damage to the outpost and killed three soldiers, with several others injured. The wounded were taken to a nearby hospital for treatment.

The incident is likely to further strain relations between Russia and Turkey, which have been at odds over the conflict in Syria. Russia has been a key ally of Syrian President Bashar al-Assad, while Turkey has backed opposition groups seeking to overthrow him.

The Turkish military has been involved in a military campaign in northern Syria, known as Operation Euphrates Shield, which aims to capture the city of al-Bab from Islamic State militants. The operation has been backed by Turkish artillery and airstrikes.

The Russian airstrike came as Turkish and Russian military officials were holding talks in Moscow to discuss the conflict in Syria. The talks were aimed at reducing tensions between the two countries, which have been at odds over the conflict.

The incident is likely to raise concerns about the safety of Turkish troops in Syria and the risk of accidental strikes. The Turkish military has been involved in several battles in Syria, and the country has suffered significant losses.

The Russian military has been accused of carrying out airstrikes that have killed civilians and caused significant damage to infrastructure in Syria. The Syrian government and its allies, including Russia, have been accused of committing war crimes and human rights abuses.

The incident is likely to be a major embarrassment for Russia, which has been seeking to portray itself as a key player in the conflict in Syria. The Russian military has been involved in the conflict since 2015, and has been carrying out airstrikes against Islamic State and other militant groups.

The Turkish military has been involved in the conflict in Syria since 2016, and has been backing opposition groups seeking to overthrow President Assad. The conflict in Syria has been ongoing since 2011, and has caused significant humanitarian suffering and displacement.

In a groundbreaking archaeological discovery, a new cave containing ancient Dead Sea Scrolls has been unearthed in the Judean Desert. The find, announced on February 2, 2017, is considered one of the most significant in decades, offering a unique glimpse into the history and culture of the Second Temple period.

The cave, located near the ancient city of Qumran, is believed to date back to the 2nd century BCE, a time when the Essenes, a Jewish sect, lived in the area. The discovery was made by a team of Israeli archaeologists from the Hebrew University of Jerusalem, led by Dr. Oren Gutfeld.

According to Dr. Gutfeld, the cave contains a large number of scrolls, including biblical texts, commentaries, and apocryphal works. While the exact number of scrolls has not been disclosed, the team estimates that the cave may hold up to 10 times more material than the famous Cave 4, which is currently the largest repository of Dead Sea Scrolls.

The Dead Sea Scrolls, a collection of ancient Jewish texts, were first discovered in 1947 by a Bedouin shepherd. The find has been hailed as one of the most significant archaeological discoveries of the 20th century, providing valuable insights into the history and culture of the ancient Jewish world.

The new cave discovery is expected to shed further light on the daily lives, beliefs, and practices of the Essenes and other Jewish groups living in the region during the Second Temple period. The team is currently working to excavate the cave and preserve the fragile scrolls, which will be studied and translated by experts in the field.

The discovery is also expected to attract tourists and scholars from around the world, boosting the local economy and promoting cultural exchange.

As the excavation and conservation efforts continue, the world waits with bated breath for the secrets that the new Dead Sea Scrolls cave will reveal. This find is a testament to the enduring importance of archaeology and the power of human curiosity to uncover the mysteries of the past.

In a rare and complex medical case, a young boy from India was born with a rare congenital condition, having four legs and two penises. The 12-year-old boy, whose identity has been kept anonymous, was born with a condition known as Parapagus, a type of conjoined twins where the twins are joined at the pelvis.

The boy's parents, who hail from the eastern state of Odisha, had noticed the unusual birthmark on their child's body and had taken him to a local hospital for treatment. "We had to work carefully to ensure that the boy's organs and blood vessels were not damaged during the surgery," Dr. Rao said in an interview. "It was a challenging procedure, but we were able to successfully separate the twins and repair the damaged tissue."

The surgery, which took several hours to complete, was a success, and the boy is now recovering in the hospital. According to Dr. Rao, the boy is expected to make a full recovery and will be able to lead a normal life.

The boy's parents are relieved that their son is recovering well and are grateful to the medical team for their help. "We are just happy that our son is recovering well," said the boy's father. "We are grateful to the doctors and nurses who worked on our son's case."

The case highlights the importance of specialized medical care in treating rare and complex medical conditions. The hospital where the surgery was performed has a reputation for providing high-quality medical care, and the success of the surgery is a testament to the skills and expertise of the medical team.

As the boy continues to recover, his family is optimistic about his future. "We are just happy that our son is recovering well," said the boy's mother. "We are grateful to the doctors and nurses who worked on our son's case, and we are hopeful that he will be able to lead a normal life."

Tiger Woods, the 14-time major champion and one of the most dominant golfers in history, has revealed that he will never feel great again. Woods, who has undergone multiple surgeries on his back and knee, stated that he is now focused on managing his pain and finding ways to cope with his condition. "I'll never feel great again," he said. "I'm not going to be able to hit it like I used to, and that's okay. I'm not going to be able to run like I used to, and that's okay. Woods' comments come as a surprise to many, as he has been working tirelessly to regain his form and compete at the highest level once again. Despite his struggles, Woods has shown glimpses of his former self in recent months, including a strong showing at the Hero World Challenge in December.

Woods' future in golf remains uncertain, but one thing is clear: he will continue to be a dominant force in the sport, even if he is no longer the dominant player he once was. Title: Tiger Woods: 'I'll never feel great again'

St. Moritz, Switzerland, February 9, 2017 – Skiers, rejoice! The picturesque town of St. Moritz in the Swiss Alps has unveiled the world's steepest start gate, sending adrenaline junkies into a frenzy. The newly installed start gate, situated at the top of the Corviglia ski lift, boasts an astonishing 86% incline, pushing even the most seasoned skiers to their limits.

The Corviglia ski lift, part of the St. Moritz Ski Resort, has long been a favorite among locals and tourists alike. With its 2,450-meter vertical drop, the area offers a diverse range of trails for skiers of all skill levels. The introduction of the world's steepest start gate is set to further enhance the skiing experience, providing an unparalleled challenge for expert skiers.

"We're thrilled to introduce this innovative feature to our ski resort," said St. Moritz Ski Resort Manager, Urs Altherr. "The steepest start gate is a game-changer for our most experienced skiers, and we're confident it will attract even more visitors to our resort."

The new start gate is part of the resort's ongoing efforts to modernize and improve the skiing experience. The innovative feature is designed to provide a thrilling and challenging skiing experience, while also ensuring the safety of skiers.

St. Moritz has a long history of hosting world-class skiing events, including the 1928 and 1948 Winter Olympics. The resort's commitment to innovation and excellence has solidified its position as one of the world's premier skiing destinations.

For those brave enough to take on the challenge, the steepest start gate is open daily from 9:00 am to 4:30 pm. Skiers can access the gate by taking the Corviglia ski lift, followed by a short hike to the start gate. It's essential to note that skiers must be at least 18 years old and have advanced skiing skills to access the start gate.

Whether you're a seasoned pro or an adventure-seeking beginner, St. Moritz's steepest start gate is an experience not to be missed. Get ready to push your limits and take on the world's steepest start gate in the heart of the Swiss Alps.

A groundbreaking study has shed new light on the relationship between autism and brain structure, revealing that women with brains resembling those of men may be at a higher risk of developing the disorder. The research, published in the journal Molecular Psychiatry, provides a crucial breakthrough in understanding the complex interplay between brain anatomy and autism risk.

The study, led by Dr. Dheeraj Rai from the University of Cambridge, analyzed brain scans of over 1,000 individuals, including both men and women with autism and those without the condition. The researchers used a technique called tractography to map the brain's white matter tracts, which are responsible for transmitting signals between different brain regions.

The results showed that women with autism had brains that were more similar to those of men, particularly in the areas responsible for social cognition and language processing. These regions are typically larger and more developed in men, and the study found that women with autism had a greater number of these "male-like" brain features.

This unique brain structure was linked to a higher risk of developing autism, with women who had more "male-like" brains being nearly three times more likely to have the condition than those with more "female-like" brains. The researchers also found that the brain structure differences were more pronounced in women with high-functioning autism, who often have better language skills and are more likely to be diagnosed with the condition.

The study's findings have significant implications for our understanding of autism and its prevalence in women. While autism is typically thought of as a male-dominated disorder, it is estimated that up to 20% of individuals with autism are women. The research suggests that women may be more likely to be misdiagnosed or undiagnosed due to the differences in brain structure, and that a more nuanced understanding of the disorder is needed.

The study's lead author, Dr. Dheeraj Rai, emphasized the importance of further research in this area, stating, "This study highlights the need for more research into the causes of autism in women and the potential role of brain structure in this process." He added, "We hope that our findings will contribute to a better understanding of autism and ultimately lead to improved diagnosis and treatment options for women with the condition."

The study's results have sparked excitement among researchers and clinicians, who are eager to explore the implications of this groundbreaking research. As our understanding of autism continues to evolve, it is clear that the complex interplay between brain structure and function is a crucial area of study. With further research, we may uncover new insights into the causes and prevalence of autism, ultimately leading to improved outcomes for individuals affected by the disorder.

The British Museum has recently unveiled a new exhibit that showcases the vibrant and diverse art of South Africa. The exhibit, titled "Art of South Africa: From the 19th Century to the Present Day," features a wide range of artworks from the country's rich cultural heritage.

The exhibit is a culmination of years of research and collaboration between the British Museum and the Iziko South African National Gallery in Cape Town. The collection includes over 100 artworks, including paintings, sculptures, prints, and photographs, that span the 19th century to the present day.

The exhibit is divided into five sections, each highlighting a different aspect of South African art. The first section focuses on the early 19th-century art of the Cape Colony, while the second section explores the development of South African art in the late 19th and early 20th centuries.

The third section is dedicated to the vibrant and dynamic art of the 1980s and 1990s, a time of great social and political change in South Africa. This section features works by some of the country's most prominent artists, including Esther Mahlabane, George Pemba, and Dumile Feni.

The fourth section of the exhibit looks at the contemporary art scene in South Africa, showcasing the work of artists who are pushing the boundaries of what is possible in their medium. The final section of the exhibit is dedicated to the art of the townships, highlighting the vibrant and dynamic art that has emerged from these communities.

The exhibit is accompanied by a comprehensive catalogue that provides a detailed overview of the artworks and the artists who created them. The catalogue also includes essays and interviews with the artists, providing a deeper understanding of the context and significance of the artworks.

The "Art of South Africa" exhibit is a must-see for anyone interested in the art and culture of South Africa. It is a unique opportunity to experience the country's rich cultural heritage and to gain a deeper understanding of the art and artists that have shaped its history. The exhibit will be on display at the British Museum until March 2017.
