The United Kingdom's decision to leave the European Union (EU) has sent shockwaves across the globe, leaving many wondering how the complicated marriage between Britain and the EU came to an end. The journey to this point has been long and arduous, with roots tracing back to the country's initial decision to join the EU in 1973.

In the decades that followed, the UK's relationship with the EU was marked by a series of treaties and agreements that gradually increased the country's integration into the union. However, the tide began to turn in the early 2010s, as concerns about EU membership and the perceived loss of sovereignty grew among the British public.

The catalyst for the UK's departure from the EU was the 2015 general election, which saw the Conservative Party, led by David Cameron, secure a majority government. In the run-up to the election, Cameron had promised to hold a referendum on EU membership, with the aim of strengthening the UK's negotiating position within the union.

The subsequent EU Referendum, held on June 23, 2016, asked British citizens whether they wanted to remain a part of the EU or leave. The result was a narrow victory for the Leave campaign, with 51.9% of voters opting to exit the union.

In the aftermath of the referendum, the UK's Prime Minister, Theresa May, triggered Article 50 of the Treaty on European Union, formally notifying the EU of the country's intention to leave. The two-year negotiation period began, during which the UK and EU would work to agree on the terms of the UK's departure.

As the negotiations progressed, it became clear that the two sides were far apart on key issues, including trade, immigration, and the status of EU citizens in the UK. The UK's Brexit Secretary, David Davis, resigned in July 2018, citing the government's inability to agree on a plan for the country's departure from the EU.

On March 29, 2017, the UK and EU reached an agreement on the terms of the UK's departure, known as the "Brexit deal." The deal outlined the UK's withdrawal from the EU, as well as the framework for the country's future relationship with the union.

While the Brexit deal has brought a sense of closure to the UK's complicated marriage to the EU, the journey is far from over. The UK will continue to negotiate the details of its relationship with the EU, with the aim of securing a trade deal and other agreements by the end of the year.

As the UK embarks on this new chapter in its history, one thing is clear: the country's complicated marriage to the EU has been wrenched apart, and the road ahead will be long and challenging.

The European Union is facing an unprecedented crisis, with rising nationalism, economic instability, and political gridlock threatening its very existence. As the EU struggles to respond to these challenges, many experts agree that it cannot survive if it continues to operate on autopilot, ignoring the fundamental changes that are reshaping the global landscape.

The EU's inability to adapt to these changes has led to a growing sense of disillusionment among its citizens. A recent survey by the European Commission found that a majority of Europeans believe that the EU is moving in the wrong direction, with concerns over immigration, terrorism, and economic inequality driving a surge in support for populist and nationalist parties.

The EU's economic woes are also a major concern. The ongoing economic crisis in the Eurozone has led to widespread unemployment, stagnant growth, and a rise in poverty and inequality. The EU's inability to implement effective economic policies has further eroded trust in the institution, with many countries turning to austerity measures and protectionist policies to address their economic woes.

The political gridlock in the EU is also a major obstacle to effective governance. The EU's cumbersome decision-making process, which requires consensus among all member states, has led to a lack of progress on key issues such as climate change, trade, and migration. The rise of nationalist and populist parties has also led to a growing sense of fragmentation, with some countries seeking to opt out of EU policies and institutions.

In light of these challenges, many experts are calling for a fundamental overhaul of the EU's structures and policies. This includes a greater emphasis on democratic accountability, greater flexibility in EU decision-making, and a more robust response to the challenges posed by globalization and technological change.

One potential solution is the creation of a more decentralized EU, with greater autonomy for member states to address their own economic and social challenges. This could involve the creation of a more flexible and adaptable EU framework, which would allow countries to respond to changing circumstances in a more effective and timely manner.

Another potential solution is the creation of a more robust and effective EU governance structure. This could involve the creation of a more powerful EU executive, with greater authority to implement EU policies and make key decisions. This could also involve the creation of a more effective EU legislative body, with greater powers to scrutinize and amend EU legislation.

In conclusion, the EU cannot survive if it sticks to business as usual. The institution must adapt to the changing global landscape, address the concerns of its citizens, and respond to the challenges posed by economic instability, political gridlock, and rising nationalism. The creation of a more decentralized and effective EU governance structure is a key step towards achieving this goal, and ensuring the long-term survival and prosperity of the EU.

As the United Kingdom officially leaves the European Union, the continent's front pages are filled with the phrase "painful divorce" to describe the historic event. On March 29, 2017, the UK and the EU have come to a definitive agreement on the terms of their separation, bringing an end to the country's 44-year membership in the union.

The front pages of European newspapers are reflecting the emotional and economic implications of this significant event. In Germany, the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung wrote, "The end of an era: Brexit marks the beginning of a new chapter in European history." The Brexit agreement, which was finalized in the early hours of March 29, outlines the terms of the UK's withdrawal from the EU. The agreement includes provisions for the free movement of goods and services, as well as the rights of EU citizens living in the UK.

Despite the concerns and uncertainties surrounding the Brexit agreement, many are optimistic about the future of the UK and the EU. In a statement, European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker said, "We have achieved a good deal, and I am confident that it will serve as a foundation for a strong and lasting relationship between the UK and the EU."

As the UK begins its new journey outside the EU, the European continent is left to ponder the implications of this historic event. The phrase "painful divorce" is a fitting description of the situation, as both sides are forced to come to terms with the end of an era and the beginning of a new chapter in their relationship.

In a move aimed at shedding light on Russia's alleged interference in the 2016 presidential election, the Senate Intelligence Committee announced on Wednesday that it will be questioning 20 individuals in its ongoing investigation. The development comes as part of a bipartisan effort by the committee to get to the bottom of the alleged meddling, which has been a subject of intense scrutiny in recent months. According to sources familiar with the matter, the 20 individuals set to be questioned include current and former government officials, as well as individuals with ties to the Trump campaign. The committee is said to be focusing on the period leading up to the election, as well as the transition period following Trump's victory.

The first hearing is expected to be a closed-door session, with the identities of the witnesses and the nature of the testimony remaining confidential. However, the committee has indicated that it plans to hold public hearings in the future, with the goal of making the investigation as transparent as possible.

The Senate Intelligence Committee's investigation is one of several ongoing probes into Russia's alleged interference in the election. The FBI is also conducting an investigation, as is the House Intelligence Committee.

The development comes as President Trump continues to face criticism over his administration's handling of the investigation. Trump has repeatedly denied any wrongdoing, and has accused his political opponents of using the investigation as a means of undermining his presidency.

The Senate Intelligence Committee's investigation is expected to continue for several months, with the goal of issuing a final report on its findings. In the meantime, the committee's hearings and investigations are likely to continue to dominate the news cycle, as the nation waits to learn more about the extent of Russia's alleged interference in the election.

Russian President Vladimir Putin has dismissed allegations of Russian interference in the 2016 US presidential election as "lies" and "fabrications." Putin made the comments during a televised meeting with Russian ambassadors and foreign ministry officials on March 24, 2017.

The Russian leader's remarks came as the US intelligence community continues to investigate claims that Russia hacked into Democratic Party emails and disseminated sensitive information to influence the outcome of the election. The allegations have sparked a heated debate between the US and Russia, with US President Donald Trump's administration denying any wrongdoing by Russia.

Putin's denial of Russian involvement in the election meddling was his most direct and forceful response to date, marking a shift in his tone on the issue. In previous statements, Putin had acknowledged that Russia may have inadvertently affected the election through its hacking activities, but he has denied any deliberate attempt to influence the outcome.

During the meeting, Putin also accused the US of interfering in Russian internal affairs, citing allegations of US funding for Russian opposition groups and support for Russian dissidents. He warned that Russia would take retaliatory measures if the US continued to interfere in its internal affairs.

The Russian leader's comments come as the US Congress prepares to vote on a bill aimed at imposing sanctions on Russia for its alleged election meddling. The bill, which has bipartisan support, would also authorize the US president to take additional measures against Russia, including the potential for military action.

The US intelligence community has concluded with "high confidence" that Russia interfered in the 2016 election, and has provided evidence of Russian hacking and disinformation efforts. The investigation is ongoing, and the US Department of Justice has indicted several Russian nationals and entities for their alleged role in the election meddling.

Putin's denial of Russian involvement in the election meddling has been met with skepticism by many in the US, who view the Russian leader's comments as an attempt to deflect responsibility and undermine the investigation. The controversy is likely to continue to dominate headlines in the coming weeks, as the US and Russia engage in a diplomatic standoff over the issue.

Former US Vice President Al Gore is set to release a sequel to his 2006 documentary 'An Inconvenient Truth', which highlighted the issue of climate change. The new film, titled 'An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth to Power', will premiere at the Sundance Film Festival in January 2017 and is expected to be released globally later in the year.

The film is a follow-up to Gore's original documentary, which won two Academy Awards and helped raise global awareness about climate change. The sequel will focus on the progress made since the release of the first film, as well as the current state of climate change and its impact on the world.

In an interview with The Hollywood Reporter, Gore said that the new film will be a "call to action" and will highlight the work being done by individuals and organizations around the world to combat climate change. He also stated that the film will address the current political climate in the US, including the election of Donald Trump as President.

Gore has been a vocal critic of Trump's stance on climate change, and has expressed concerns about the President's decision to withdraw the US from the Paris Agreement. The Paris Agreement is an international accord aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions and mitigating the effects of climate change.

The new film is expected to feature footage of Gore's travels around the world, where he has met with individuals and organizations working on climate change initiatives. The film will also include interviews with experts and leaders in the field of climate change.

'An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth to Power' is set to be released in theaters later in 2017, with a global rollout planned. The film is expected to spark important conversations about climate change and its impact on the world, and will likely be a timely and relevant release in the wake of Trump's decision to withdraw the US from the Paris Agreement.

The White House is experiencing a significant staff shake-up in the wake of the failure to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act (ACA). The most notable change is the departure of White House Chief of Staff Reince Priebus, who has been replaced by General John F. Kelly, the former Secretary of Homeland Security. Kelly is seen as a more forceful and organized leader who will help to streamline the administration's operations.

In addition to Priebus' departure, several other high-ranking officials have left the White House or announced their resignations. These include Mike Dubke, the Director of Communications, who resigned earlier this month, and Sean Spicer, the Press Secretary, who has been reassigned to a new role.

The staff shake-up is seen as an effort to address the growing criticism of the administration's ability to pass legislation. The failure to repeal the ACA has led to concerns about the administration's ability to deliver on its campaign promises.

The changes are also seen as an effort to improve the administration's public image. The departure of Priebus, who was seen as a moderate, is seen as a move to bring in a more partisan leader who will help to rally the administration's base.

The staff shake-up comes as the administration is facing a series of challenges, including the ongoing investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election and the controversy surrounding the administration's handling of the ACA.

In a statement, the White House praised Kelly's appointment, saying that he will bring a "unique set of skills and experience" to the role. The administration also expressed its gratitude to Priebus for his service, saying that he had played an important role in the transition to the new administration.

The staff shake-up is seen as a significant development in the ongoing drama surrounding the Trump administration. As the administration continues to face challenges, the changes are seen as an effort to improve its functioning and deliver on its campaign promises.

A federal judge in Hawaii has extended his ruling halting President Donald Trump's revised travel ban indefinitely, allowing travelers from six predominantly Muslim countries to continue entering the United States. The revised ban, which aimed to restrict immigration from Iran, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria, and Yemen, was set to take effect on March 16. However, Judge Derrick Watson's decision on March 15 has effectively put the ban on hold, citing concerns over its potential to discriminate against Muslims.

The ruling is a significant setback for the Trump administration, which has argued that the travel ban is necessary for national security reasons. The White House has repeatedly claimed that the ban is aimed at preventing terrorist attacks and ensuring the safety of American citizens. However, opponents of the ban have argued that it is discriminatory and unconstitutional, citing the President's own campaign rhetoric and the fact that it targets predominantly Muslim countries.

Judge Watson's decision is the latest development in a series of legal challenges to the travel ban. The original ban, signed by President Trump on January 27, was quickly blocked by federal courts in Washington and Hawaii. The Trump administration subsequently revised the ban, but it was met with similar resistance from the courts.

The latest ruling has been hailed by civil rights groups and advocacy organizations, who argue that it is a major victory for the principles of equality and justice. "Today's decision is a testament to the resilience of the American legal system and the commitment of our courts to upholding the Constitution," said Omar Jadwat, director of the American Civil Liberties Union's Immigrants' Rights Project.

The Trump administration has vowed to appeal the decision, but it is unclear when the appeal will be heard. In the meantime, travelers from the affected countries will continue to be allowed to enter the United States, and the government will be unable to implement its revised travel ban.

As the legal battle continues, the debate over the travel ban's merits will likely remain a contentious issue in American politics. Proponents of the ban argue that it is necessary for national security, while opponents argue that it is discriminatory and unconstitutional. Regardless of the outcome, the case has highlighted the ongoing tensions between the executive and judicial branches of government, as well as the importance of upholding the Constitution's guarantees of equal protection and due process.

The 51-50 vote marks the end of Trump's most challenging confirmation battle to date. Senate Democrats engaged in a marathon debate through the night and into Tuesday morning, attempting to block DeVos' confirmation with the support of Republican Senators Lisa Murkowski of Alaska and Susan Collins of Maine. Throughout the confirmation process, Democrats argued that they only needed "one more" Republican vote to sway the outcome. However, Senate Republican leaders ultimately succeeded in delivering a victory to Trump in a fight that few expected to be as contentious. DeVos' poor performance during her confirmation hearing, which included her suggestion that a Wyoming school might want to have guns on premises to protect against grizzly bears, sparked widespread anger among public school supporters and teachers' unions. Critics had already raised concerns about DeVos' lack of experience with public schools and her financial backing of initiatives like school vouchers, which could divert funds from public institutions. Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer expressed his disappointment with the vote shortly after DeVos' confirmation, tweeting, "Today, @VP Mike Pence did something unprecedented: casting the tie-breaking vote on his own cabinet nominee." DeVos tweeted after the vote, "I appreciate the Senate's diligence and am honored to serve as @usedgov Secretary. Let's improve options and outcomes for all US students." Senator Chris Murphy told CNN earlier that day that DeVos seemed to have no knowledge of the federal law protecting students with disabilities. "You combine that with a lack of compassion for the tragedies that have occurred, such as Sandy Hook, and an inability to understand the basic law governing vulnerable students, and it was clear at the end of that hearing that this person was not suited to be Secretary of Education," the Connecticut Democrat said. In the aftermath of a 24-hour marathon of protests by Democrats both inside and outside the Capitol, which lasted through the night and into Tuesday morning, Betsy DeVos secured her Senate vote. The delay tactics employed by Democrats have been successful in stalling many of President Trump's most crucial Cabinet appointments, but Senate Republican leaders have vowed to hold votes for four key nominees this week: DeVos, Tom Price for Health and Human Services, Steven Mnuchin for Treasury, and Jeff Sessions for attorney general. Meanwhile, scrutiny of Trump's Cabinet picks has intensified, with new concerns emerging daily. Labor Department nominee Andrew Puzder recently admitted to hiring an undocumented immigrant as a housekeeper, but Senate Majority Whip John Cornyn has pledged to overcome Democratic obstruction by working long hours at the Capitol, potentially even through Saturday. "We'll be burning the midnight oil," Cornyn said on Monday.

Betsy DeVos' limited experience in education policy has sparked concerns about her ability to lead the federal agency responsible for elevating American public education for all students. However, there is another critical aspect to this debate that must be addressed, particularly in today's racially charged environment and considering the enduring impact of segregated schools on our political landscape. Racial animus was a primary driver of the shift towards private and religious K-12 education nearly 50 years ago, and racial segregation remains a dominant factor in all schooling, public and private, today. DeVos' track record suggests that she will not take meaningful action to combat these trends. Following the landmark 1954 Brown v. Board Supreme Court decision, which declared that separate schools for black and white students were inherently unequal, the federal government began to slowly desegregate schools in the South that had previously been forbidden by law from educating children of different races together. Additionally, the government addressed de facto segregation in schools in the North. The backlash was intense, with prominent figures like Alabama Governor George Wallace and Louise Day Hicks leading opposition to desegregation. However, the Brown ruling did not apply to private schools, leading to an estimated half-million white students leaving public schools between 1964 and 1975 to enroll in "segregation academies" - a phenomenon that was part of a larger "white flight" movement. This demographic shift saw millions of whites migrate from cities to racially isolated suburbs, marking one of the most significant population changes in American history. Noted scholar Kevin Kruse has described "white flight" as the most effective response to the moral demands of the civil rights movement and the legal authority of the courts, leading to a re-segregation of American schools. The character and quality of most American schools today, mirroring the neighborhoods they serve, are deeply rooted in a racial past. Unfortunately, public schools in the US are reverting to a type of racial segregation reminiscent of the pre-Brown era. Over the past 25 years, the number of severely racially isolated schools, defined as those with 0-10% white students, has tripled. In New York City, in 2010, a staggering 92% of black students and 88% of Latino students attended majority-minority schools, some of which are plagued by extreme poverty and have been dubbed "apartheid schools." In Michigan, where charter schools have proliferated over the past two decades, public school enrollment and funding have declined, while segregation has increased. Moreover, public funding for private schools, as advocated by Education Secretary Betsy DeVos, appears to have little positive impact on students of color. The idea that tax dollars "follow the child" through voucher programs and other public funding initiatives is misleading, as research has shown that private schools are even more segregated than public schools. This has negative consequences for both white students and students of color. Studies have consistently found that black children who attend desegregated schools tend to earn higher incomes, have better long-term health, and experience no negative effects on their white peers. Furthermore, a range of studies suggests that desegregated schools are more effective in educating all children to contribute to a healthier American economy and society. "It is a moral shame and an economic misstep that the school choice and religious education movement is tainted by racial animosity, even in subtle forms. While many private and religious schools are excellent and welcoming institutions, we must not be deceived. School choice is not truly about freedom. Freedom is a fundamental American value, but the notion of 'freedom' that drives the exodus from integration and towards racial segregation will never lead to a genuinely free society. As senators deliberate on DeVos' nomination to oversee public education for every American child, they would do well to recall the core values of public schooling and the profound implications of appointing a Secretary of Education linked to an exclusive and racially discriminatory vision."

Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei told a gathering of air force commanders in Tehran that the new US administration has revealed the "depth of corruption" within the US government, according to quotes published by MEHR news agency. Khamenei reportedly stated, "We are grateful to this new administration in the White House, as it has largely accomplished what we had been trying to do for decades: to expose the true face of the US. We had been working to reveal the extent of corruption within the US government and among its ruling elite, and Trump has done so in just a few days after taking office." He added, "Their claims of upholding human rights are no longer credible." Khamenei also referenced the case of a five-year-old Iranian boy who was detained at a US airport following Trump's travel ban, saying, "By taking actions like handcuffing a five-year-old child, Trump is demonstrating the reality behind American claims of human rights." The comments come amid escalating tensions between Iran and the US since Trump took office. The travel ban, sanctions, and missile testing by Iran have contributed to the deteriorating relationship. Concerns have been raised over the future of a nuclear deal brokered by the Obama administration, which requires Iran to significantly restrict its nuclear program. On Saturday, a day after the Trump administration imposed fresh sanctions over an Iranian ballistic missile test, US Defense Secretary James Mattis labeled Iran "the single biggest state sponsor of terrorism in the world." "Two days prior, Trump had tweeted that Iran had been formally put on notice and should be thankful for the terrible deal brokered by the Obama administration. He refused to rule out the possibility of military action against Iran. However, a senior Iranian adviser to the Ayatollah, Ali Akbar Velayati, dismissed Trump's remarks as baseless and inflammatory. This is not the first time the Ayatollah has spoken critically of the US President. In November, during the election campaign, Khamenei strongly criticized both Trump and Hillary Clinton for exposing what he viewed as the moral shortcomings of the US."

AQAP leader Qassim al-Rimi released an 11-minute recording on Saturday, in which he condemned the January 29 raid and addressed the White House, saying, "The new fool of the White House received a painful slap across his face." The recording, translated by the SITE Intelligence Group, was released online. Rimi claimed in the recording that "dozens of Americans were killed and wounded," a claim that contradicts the US account, which reported the death of one Navy SEAL, Chief Petty Officer William "Ryan" Owens, and the wounding of three additional SEALs. Rimi acknowledged the deaths of 14 men and 11 women and children in the raid, a joint operation between the US and the United Arab Emirates. According to a senior US military official, Rimi was a target of the operation. The recording was released after the raid.

Among the dead was the 8-year-old daughter of Anwar al-Awlaki, a US-born cleric who directed attacks against the US and was killed in 2011. Human rights organizations, including Reprieve, a London-based NGO, and a Sanaa-based human rights worker, reported that at least 23 civilians were killed in the attack. In the recording, Rimi said that after the US forces escaped, they destroyed their own planes to prevent evidence of their actions from being found. A senior US military official stated that while intelligence collection was an objective of the raid, it was not the only goal. The official added that even if Rimi was not present, the US military believed it would find intelligence that could lead to him. The decision to green-light the mission was not dependent on Rimi's presence, according to a senior US military official. The US Central Command, which oversees forces in the region, had previously disputed that Rimi was the target of the raid more than a week ago. According to Col. John Thomas, the raid was not a high-priority mission aimed at killing or capturing terrorist leaders. Thomas stated that there was no strong evidence to suggest a "high possibility" that Rimi was at the compound on the night of the raid, and that Navy SEALs would have captured any leaders of the al Qaeda affiliate, including Rimi, as part of an intelligence-gathering operation. "Anyone found on site would have been taken," Thomas emphasized. NBC initially reported that Rimi was a target of the raid, which may have justified the large allocation of resources used in the mission.

The raid did not go as planned, as al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula fighters detected the SEAL team before it reached its objective, leading to an intense firefight. Initially, the military stated that the goal of the mission was to gather intelligence on the al Qaeda affiliate in Yemen. Later, the Pentagon released clips from an al Qaeda training video seized during the raid, but withdrew them because the video was nearly a decade old. Government officials previously told CNN that plans for the raid had been in the works for months and that President Trump green-lighted the mission shortly after his inauguration.

The Pentagon reported that the battle resulted in the deaths of 14 al Qaeda fighters, including two AQAP leaders. Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula has been regarded by many as the most perilous, if not the most perilous, offshoot of al Qaeda since its inception in 2009. Following a 2015 drone strike that claimed the life of Nasir al-Wuhayshi, Rimi allegedly took over as the group's leader.

The White House released a list of 78 terror attacks on Monday to support President Donald Trump's claim that the media is not adequately reporting them. Trump told service-members at MacDill Air Force Base in Florida that terror attacks were happening "all over Europe" and that they were often not being reported. "The dishonest press doesn't want to report it," Trump said, adding that they have their reasons. The White House later distributed a list of attacks, stating that "most did not receive adequate attention" from Western media sources. However, many of these attacks have been robustly covered by reporters in print, on air, and on social media. Washington Post columnist David Ignatius expressed concern over Trump's statement, saying, "As a journalist, I'm really troubled by that." He pointed out that many journalists take big risks to cover these stories, citing The New York Times' recent reporting on ISIS's involvement in European and international attacks. Ignatius said he has around 100 examples of strong reporting he'd like to show the President. CNN's Anderson Cooper also highlighted his network's coverage of many of the events listed on the White House's list. "Not only did we cover a significant number of the attacks listed by the White House, but we gave them extensive coverage," he said on Monday night, showing footage of himself reporting from Ottawa, Canada, in 2014, Paris in November 2015, San Bernardino, California, in 2015, and Orlando, Florida, in June 2016. He clarified that while our program did not cover every single incident on the list, other programs, including CNN International, extensively covered most of them. The attacks listed span from September 2014 to December 2016, including notable incidents such as the Paris attacks, the Orlando nightclub shooting, and the truck attacks in Nice and Berlin. However, the White House only mentions attacks that appear to have been carried out with Islamist motives, omitting other terror operations. Notably, the list does not include the recent mosque attack in Quebec City or the racially motivated church shooting in South Carolina, in which nine black worshipers were killed. White House press secretary Sean Spicer later explained that President Trump believes some media outlets do not provide equal coverage to all terror attacks, noting that a protest might receive more attention than a foiled attack. Trump has used terror attacks to justify his controversial travel ban on citizens from seven Muslim-majority nations and has repeatedly accused media organizations critical of him of spreading "fake news.""

A lawsuit filed by the attorneys general of Washington and Minnesota has gained national attention since last Friday, when a federal district court judge halted President Trump's executive order restricting travel for foreign nationals and temporarily reopened US borders to immigrants. The hearing, which will be held by telephone and livestreamed, will take place on Tuesday at 6 p.m. ET and will last an hour. The central issue to be addressed is whether the judge who put a temporary hold on the travel ban, US District Court Judge James Robart, abused his discretion. No court has yet addressed the constitutionality of the executive order. The lawsuit was brought by Washington Attorney General Bob Ferguson, who was later joined by Minnesota Attorney General Lori Swanson. The Department of Justice's Civil Division is defending the executive order. The three-judge panel hearing the case was randomly assigned and consists of Judges William C. Canby Jr., Michelle T. Friedland, and Richard R. Clifton, appointed by Presidents Jimmy Carter, Barack Obama, and George W. Bush, respectively. Each side will have 30 minutes to present their arguments during the telephonic oral argument. In a brief submitted on Monday, the states' attorneys urged the appellate court to maintain the suspension of the travel ban. The states are arguing that the temporary restraining order should remain in place because the President's decision to sign the executive order has caused "chaos" and that the government's claim of irreparable harm is unfounded. They contend that accepting the government's position would mean that the defendants were suffering some unspecified harm before the order was issued, which makes no sense. The states argue that preserving the status quo against sudden disruption is often in the best interest of all parties.

The Trump administration's argument is that the states do not have the right to sue in this case and that a district court judge cannot second-guess the President's national security judgment in the immigration context. The government also made a fallback argument, suggesting that if the appellate court upholds the district court's decision, it should only apply to a specific class of people who have been previously admitted to the US, such as those traveling on a student visa. The government believes that individuals outside the US who have never set foot on US soil have no constitutional right to enter the country.

The judges have several options to resolve this case, but it is unlikely that they will rule on the constitutionality of the ban, as that is not the question before them. The central issue is whether the executive order should remain suspended for now. For instance, the judges could reject the DOJ's request for a stay of Robart's decision because, as acknowledged by the government, temporary restraining orders are generally not appealable. Regardless of their decision, the suspension of the travel ban would remain in place while the case proceeds with additional scheduled hearings. Alternatively, the appellate court could find that Robart exceeded his authority by including classes of individuals not protected by the Constitution (such as aliens living abroad), in which case the ban would be reinstated. Once the three-judge panel issues its decision, the losing party has 14 days to file a petition for rehearing the case before the full appellate court, although this is not mandatory to reach the Supreme Court. Given the high stakes involved in this lawsuit, it is likely that the losing party will appeal to the Supreme Court. Currently, with only eight justices on the court, a 4-4 split would result in the Ninth Circuit's ruling becoming the law of the land.

Romanian President Klaus Iohannis urged the nation to decide whether it wants to be a strong and prosperous country or a weak and disrespected one. He called for a referendum to allow the people to have a say in the matter. On Sunday, over half a million citizens took to the streets in the largest of a series of protests against a bill that would have shielded many politicians from corruption charges. The Social Democrat-led government responded by announcing it would repeal the decree, which had been approved just a week earlier without parliamentary input. However, Prime Minister Sorin Grindeanu indicated that he still intends to push through amendments to the criminal codes through parliamentary legislation.

The protests continued on Monday night, albeit on a smaller scale, with demands for the government's removal. In a speech on Tuesday, President Iohannis criticized the government's decision to withdraw the decree, saying it was too little, too late. While stopping short of calling for fresh elections, he chastised the center-left government, which has been in power since December, for prioritizing the interests of convicted politicians over those of the Romanian people. The governing coalition, comprising the Social Democrats and the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats, walked out of the room in response to the President's remarks. "Are you already tired?" Iohannis asked, adding, "Too bad." Romania requires a robust government, one that is transparent and predictable in its decision-making, with all actions conducted in the open, not in secret. He asked, "What kind of nation do we want to be? Do we want to be a strong and prosperous one, built on the rule of law and respect for it, where justice is powerful and independent? Or do we want to be a weak nation, despised and at risk, sacrificing everything to save a few from difficult times?" He emphasized that this would be the central question and purpose of a referendum, which would genuinely gauge the will of the Romanian people. Demonstrations continued, with approximately 25,000 people gathering in Victory Square in Bucharest on Monday evening and around 20,000 elsewhere in the country, according to estimates from the Romanian media. Although the turnout was significantly lower than on Sunday, protesters still demanded the government's resignation. A counter-demonstration with around 3,000 people assembled outside the presidential palace, calling for President Iohannis to step down and supporting the government. In an interview with CNN, Vlad Mixich, a Romanian journalist and political commentator, commented on the President's address to Parliament, saying, "He mainly spoke to the people who took to the streets last week. I think it was essential for him to do so." This was one of the largest protests in Romania since the fall of communism in 1989, so the President needed to address those in the streets directly, even if the protesters do not consider him their leader. Mixich described the proposed referendum as a symbolic gesture, a type of move that politicians often favor, as it would keep the issue in the spotlight. "A brighter future is ahead, but only if some government ministers step down, according to Bianca Dumitru, a 25-year-old sports journalist from Brasov, Romania. She joined the protests in her hometown, saying, "We've had enough of them." Dumitru praised the recent unity and motivation that swept the country, attributing it to the government's actions. However, she believes it's time for the government to let the people enjoy their victory and live in a prosperous environment with a promising future. The opposition has submitted a censure motion to Parliament, which is set to debate the issue on Wednesday. Despite this, the government's majority in the legislative body makes it unlikely that the motion will succeed."

Before returning to Washington, Barack Obama, the former president, embarked on an exciting adventure with his friend Richard Branson, the founder of Virgin Group and a billionaire, while vacationing on the British Virgin Islands with his wife, Michelle Obama. During their getaway, Branson, an avid water sports enthusiast, offered Obama the chance to learn how to kitesurf. To make the experience even more thrilling, Branson proposed a friendly challenge: he would try to learn how to foilboard before Obama mastered kitesurfing. They agreed to have a final showdown on the last day of their trip to see who could stay aloft the longest.

Kitesurfing involves riding a surfboard while holding onto a kite, while foilboarding involves riding a surfboard with a hydrofoil that lifts the board above the water's surface. After a few days of training, the challenge was on, and Obama emerged victorious. "We were neck and neck until the last run on the last day, when I got up on the foilboard and screamed along for over 50 meters, three feet above the water," Branson wrote on Virgin.com. "I was feeling very pleased with myself, only to look over and see Barack go 100 meters on his kiteboard! I had to doff my cap to him and celebrate his victory."

For over a century, this method of birth control has been the standard. However, a new injectable gel called Vasalgel has shown promise in trials using monkeys. The gel blocks sperm inside the body, preventing them from leaving while allowing seminal fluid to pass through, and has been found to be effective and safe in these trials. The researchers behind Vasalgel, led by the Parsemus Foundation, hope to begin human trials within the next few years. According to Elaine Lissner, executive director of the Parsemus Foundation, the new study involving 16 male monkeys is a significant step forward. The monkeys were injected with Vasalgel and released into social outdoor housing with females, and their ability to impregnate the females was compared to a historical sample of monkeys that had undergone vasectomies. The study aimed to determine the safety and efficacy of Vasalgel, and the results showed that none of the females in the group conceived during the breeding season. One monkey experienced some adverse effects, including an incorrectly inserted gel and a sperm granuloma, but the majority of the monkeys tolerated the gel well and showed little inflammation. In fact, the rates of granuloma and inflammation were lower than what is typically seen after a vasectomy. The team plans to conduct further animal trials this year and hopes to begin human clinical trials next year. However, Lissner notes that while the gel has shown promise in monkeys, it may not work exactly the same way in humans. She acknowledges that the task ahead is larger and more complex than initially anticipated. Administering Vasalgel involves injecting a polymer into the vas deferens, the tubes that carry sperm from the testicles to the penis, to block sperm release. The procedure, which is performed under anesthesia, mimics the effect of a vasectomy but without the surgical incision. The polymer, known as Vasalgel, is a sticky gel that filters out sperm, allowing fluids to pass through while blocking sperm release. The backed-up sperm are then reabsorbed by the body. Unlike a traditional vasectomy, Vasalgel is designed to break down and be flushed out with a second solution, making the procedure reversible. However, successful reversibility has yet to be proven, as trials on rabbits showed reversibility, but trials on monkeys and baboons did not. The procedure also carries some risks, including the possibility of an immune reaction that could leave men less fertile after reversal, similar to vasectomy. According to Dr. Ilpo Huhtaniemi, emeritus professor of reproductive endocrinology at Imperial College London, approximately 50% of men who undergo vasectomy reversal remain infertile. While this new form of birth control doesn't entirely eliminate the possibility of men having children, it does offer an alternative method. The latest research on monkeys has sparked hope for a new, non-invasive form of contraception, but experts emphasize the need for further evidence on its reversibility. According to Allan Pacey, a professor of andrology at the University of Sheffield, the procedure needs to be proven reversible before it can be considered a viable replacement for traditional vasectomy methods. The idea of inserting a gel into the vas deferens to block sperm from reaching the penis is not new, but this study marks a step forward in developing the concept. A previous male hormonal birth control injection was discontinued due to side effects, and other approaches aimed at controlling sperm production through testosterone targeting have been hindered by side effects such as depression and weight gain. Japanese scientists discovered a crucial protein, calcineurin, which helps sperm swim and fertilize eggs, and blocking its genes in mice led to infertility. In contrast, Vasalgel has shown promising results in animals with minimal side effects. Lissner, the lead researcher, is confident that her team's gel will overcome the challenges and provide a hormone-free birth control option. "Why manipulate the entire body when we can target a small tube where all the sperm swim through?" she asked. While Vasalgel may be valuable for specific populations, Huhtaniemi believes that a less-invasive, pill-based option is needed for widespread use. "We need a pill that's easy to administer," he said. "It's feasible, we just need to find the right target."

New Zealand Rugby has revealed that a room in Sydney's Double Bay Intercontinental Hotel, where the All Blacks held meetings before their August Bledisloe Cup clash with the Wallabies, was allegedly bugged. A 51-year-old security consultant, who was employed at the time of the alleged offense, has been charged with public mischief by New South Wales police. He is scheduled to appear in court on March 21.

All Blacks head coach Steve Hansen has described the charge as "bizarre" and "unbelievable". Hansen praised the accused individual, saying he is a well-respected professional who has worked with the All Blacks and other organizations for many years. However, he noted that due process must be followed, and it would be inappropriate to comment further on the matter.

Australia Rugby Union chief executive Bill Pulver commended the police for their investigation. However, he expressed disappointment that the discovery of the alleged bug was reported publicly on the day of the match, rather than earlier in the week. Pulver believes the resulting media attention was a distraction that neither team needed on the morning of the Test match. "The Australian Rugby Union (ARU) and the Wallabies have been cleared of any wrongdoing, but it's essential that this matter has been resolved to provide absolute reassurance to all fans that the organization and the team had no involvement in the incident. While some questions may still linger, today's news is a welcome development, as an individual has been held accountable for their actions. The All Blacks, currently ranked the world's top rugby union team, went on to defeat Australia 42-8 in the match, securing their largest win over the Wallabies on Australian soil in 113 years. The team, led by coach Hansen, set a new world record with their 18th consecutive victory in the third and final Bledisloe Cup series fixture in Auckland, but later lost to Ireland in their next game in Chicago."

Doctors treating Vladimir Kara-Murza, 35, at the hospital say they still lack a clear understanding of what caused his illness, but agree that a toxic substance is to blame, according to his lawyer, Vadim Prokhorov. Kara-Murza's wife, Yevgenia, told CNN that doctors have attempted to bring him out of a medically-induced coma, but he showed little response, except to his name being called. He is currently undergoing dialysis and artificial ventilation. Doctors have diagnosed him with acute intoxication by an unidentified substance, and there is no prognosis. The risks have increased due to his previous illness. Prokhorov told CNN that an investigator from Moscow's Khamovniki district contacted him last Friday to inquire about the circumstances surrounding Kara-Murza's hospitalization, but has since received no further updates on the ongoing investigation. "The problem is that they're not paying any real attention to this," Prokhorov said. "The investigative committee is only interested in this situation because of the media coverage." He has no direct proof that his client was poisoned. The Kremlin has previously denied any involvement in Kara-Murza's 2015 illness.

In 2015, Kara-Murza nearly died from a mysterious illness. "I fell into a coma, and all of my major organs began failing, one after another," he said. "It was the kidneys first, then the lungs, the heart, the liver." At the time, he believed his suspected poisoning was a politically motivated attack. "Frankly, there's no other possible reason," he said. "I don't have any money dealings. I don't have any personal enemies. I didn't steal anybody's wife." The case bears striking similarities to the 2006 poisoning of former Russian agent Alexander Litvinenko in London. A British public inquiry into the Litvinenko assassination found two former Russian agents responsible for carrying out the poisoning using the radioactive isotope Polonium-210. The inquiry's final report concluded that Putin was "probably" aware of the operation. However, the Russian Foreign Ministry dismissed the UK inquiry as politically motivated, and the Kremlin denied any involvement. In February 2015, prominent Russian opposition figure and friend of Kara-Murza, Boris Nemtsov, was brutally murdered on a bridge near the Kremlin. Kara-Murza fell ill four months later. The hospitalization of Kara-Murza has sparked outrage among US lawmakers, who are urging the Trump administration to speak out on his behalf. Senator Marco Rubio, a frequent Putin critic, called for accountability if there is evidence that the Russian government was involved in Kara-Murza's poisoning. "Vladimir Putin does not deserve the benefit of the doubt in this matter, given the alarming frequency of political assassinations and poisonings under his regime," Rubio said. "I am praying for Kara-Murza's recovery." Rubio urged the White House and State Department to question Russian authorities about the case. As a dual Russian-British citizen, Kara-Murza splits his time between Russia and his family home in Virginia. He is a key figure in the Open Russia foundation, an organization of anti-Putin activists advocating for open elections, a free press, and civil rights reforms. When he fell ill last week, Kara-Murza was in Russia touring for screenings of a documentary about Nemtsov.

The Arkansas Unborn Child Protection From Dismemberment Abortion Act, signed into law by Governor Asa Hutchinson, will take effect later this year. The law prohibits dismemberment abortion, the most common procedure used in second-trimester abortions. A controversial clause allows a husband to sue a doctor to stop his wife's abortion, provided he is the father of the child. However, there is no exemption for cases of rape or incest, meaning a rapist could theoretically file suit to prevent an abortion. The ACLU of Arkansas has challenged the law's constitutionality and plans to take the case to court before it goes into effect. When asked about the lack of debate on these issues, Arkansas state Senator Joyce Elliott told CNN affiliate KARK that there was little discussion on the Senate floor. "It felt kind of fruitless to make sense of the rest of the bill," she said, expressing frustration with the law's restrictions on women's autonomy. In contrast, Senator Missy Irvin believes that husbands should have a say in abortion decisions, arguing that "when you have created a life, you created a life with someone else." Similar laws in Kansas and Oklahoma are currently tied up in court, according to CNN affiliate KFSM. "Following Donald Trump's election, several states with conservative lawmakers have enacted stringent new abortion laws. One such state is Ohio, which has implemented a ban on abortion after 20 weeks of pregnancy."

Japan claims sovereignty over the islands, known as the Senkaku Islands, while China asserts control over the same territory, calling it the Diaoyu Islands. The latest sailing comes just days after US Defense Secretary James Mattis reaffirmed the US commitment to defending Japan and its disputed islands. According to Japanese public broadcaster NHK, protests were lodged with the Chinese Embassy in Tokyo and in Beijing through the Japanese Embassy. The disputed islands have been a source of tension between Japan and China in recent years, with several incidents involving Japanese and Chinese naval and air forces that have been deemed dangerous by both sides.

China's State Oceanic Administration, which oversees the country's Coast Guard, issued a statement on Monday, saying that three ships had cruised within China's territorial sea around the Diaoyu Islands. China's Defense Ministry separately confirmed the movement of the Coast Guard ships. Japan's Coast Guard reported that the Chinese vessels spent two hours in Japanese territorial waters, marking the fourth such incident this year. According to the Japanese Coast Guard, there were 36 such incidents in 2016. The latest sailing, which occurred shortly after US Defense Secretary James Mattis' visit to Japan, is seen by experts as a subtle message to both Tokyo and Washington. "It is both a signal that China will not be intimidated from defending its interests and claims, and a test to see how the new Trump administration responds," said Carl Schuster, a professor at Hawaii Pacific University and former director of operations at the US Pacific Command's Joint Intelligence Center. Denny Roy, an Asian security expert at the East-West Center in Honolulu, warned that ship movements in disputed waters could escalate into a shooting incident. "The danger of conflict is particularly high because military personnel on both sides are often eager to prove their determination to defend what they consider national territory," said Roy. A military confrontation between China and Japan could also draw in US forces. During a press conference in Tokyo on Saturday, Mattis stated that the US would defend the islands alongside Japan. "I reiterated that our longstanding policy on the Senkaku Islands remains unchanged - the US will continue to recognize Japanese administration of the islands and, as such, Article 5 of the US-Japan Security Treaty applies," Mattis said, appearing alongside Japanese Defense Minister Tomomi Inada. The US stance was reinforced on Tuesday in a phone call between Japanese Foreign Minister Fumio Kishida and new US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, according to a statement from Japan's Foreign Ministry. "The United States will oppose any unilateral action that threatens to damage Japanese administration of the Senkaku Islands," Tillerson stated during the call, according to the Japanese statement. China responded swiftly to the US stance on the islands, claiming it would bring instability to the region. "The Diaoyu Islands and affiliated islands have been Chinese territory since ancient times. These are historical facts that cannot be altered. The US-Japan security treaty, a product of the Cold War, should not infringe on China's territorial sovereignty and legitimate rights," Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Lu Kang said in a statement. "We urge the US side to adopt a responsible attitude and refrain from making incorrect comments on the issue of Diaoyu Islands sovereignty," Lu added. The US commitment to the Senkakus is not new, as the Obama administration also stated in 2014 that the remote chain falls under the treaty." In November 2013, China unilaterally established an air defense identification zone (ADIZ) over a significant portion of the East China Sea, including the disputed Senkaku Islands, despite protests from both Tokyo and Washington. Japan, meanwhile, has its own ADIZ covering the same area. Although the Senkaku Islands are currently uninhabited, control over them would grant the owner exclusive rights to oil, mineral, and fishing resources in the surrounding waters. The ongoing dispute over the Senkakus remains a point of contention in the US-China relationship, but Mattis' visit appeared to ease tensions in another area, the South China Sea. Although US Defense Secretary Mattis criticized China for eroding trust in the region by fortifying disputed islands in the South China Sea, he also stated that no increased US military activity was necessary. Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Lu welcomed this stance, saying that Mattis' comments acknowledging the need for diplomatic resolution rather than large-scale military operations in the area were deserving of affirmation.

A suicide bomber detonated his explosives in a parking lot near the Supreme Court in Kabul, the Afghan capital, according to Basir Mojahid, the spokesman for Kabul's chief of police. The attack, which occurred around 3:45 p.m. local time, targeted Supreme Court employees as they were leaving for the day, Mojahid said. At least 35 people were injured in the blast, according to Saleem Rasooli, head of Kabul hospitals. There have been no initial claims of responsibility for the attack. An eyewitness, Nimatullah Mati, described the explosion as powerful, saying it shook the ground as he was leaving his office, which is located opposite the Supreme Court. The area is home to several residential apartments and was crowded on Tuesday afternoon with people heading home from work. Ambulances and firetrucks arrived on the scene within five minutes, Mati said. Afghanistan's chief executive, Abdullah Abdullah, expressed his condolences on Twitter, saying, "The blood of our people isn't cheap & won't be wasted." NATO also condemned the attack, with Italian army Lt. Gen. Rosario Castellano, deputy commander of the NATO mission in Afghanistan, stating, "Anyone who seeks to destabilize the pillars of a functioning government are enemies of Afghanistan." The blast comes a month after a similar attack near the Afghan Parliament in Kabul, which killed at least 36 people and wounded dozens. The Taliban claimed responsibility for that attack on January 10. Tuesday's blast highlights the growing concern about the security situation in Afghanistan, where the country's security forces and international allies have been fighting Taliban militants and other radical groups for years. According to a new report from the UN Assistance Mission in Afghanistan, more than 11,000 people were killed or injured in 2016, the highest number of civilian casualties in a single year since the United Nations began systemically documenting those in 2009. The report reveals a devastating record high in child casualties in the ongoing Afghanistan War. According to the report, 923 children were killed last year, out of a total of 3,498 fatalities. Anti-government forces, primarily the Taliban, were responsible for nearly two-thirds of the casualties, as per the report. The report also highlights the growing presence of ISIS militants in the country, who frequently target Shia Muslims in their attacks.

A human rights group has accused the Syrian regime of carrying out a secret campaign of mass executions at Saydnaya prison, north of Damascus, with as many as 13,000 people killed since the start of the conflict. According to Amnesty International's report, "Human Slaughterhouse," prisoners are taken from their cells in the dead of night, supposedly for a transfer, only to be hanged on the prison grounds, often unaware of their fate until the noose is placed around their neck. The report, the culmination of a year-long investigation, is based on testimony from 84 witnesses, including security guards, detainees, judges, and lawyers. The majority of those executed were civilians believed to be opposed to the government, the report found. "This report reveals a hidden, monstrous campaign authorized at the highest levels of the Syrian government, aimed at crushing any form of dissent within the Syrian population," said Lynn Maalouf, deputy director for research at Amnesty's Beirut office. The report alleges that detainees were given sham trials by a "Military Field Court" that had no connection to the rule of law. A former judge described the court's proceedings as follows: "The judge will ask the name of the detainee and whether he committed the crime. Whether the answer is yes or no, he will be convicted... This court has no relation with the rule of law. This is not a court." The report also notes that there are two detention centers at Saydnaya prison, with the "red building" housing mainly civilian detainees arrested since 2011, and the "white building" housing military officers and soldiers. CNN has requested comment from the Syrian government. Amnesty International researcher Nicolette Waldman detailed the appalling conditions prisoners are allegedly subjected to. "They are literally dying in large numbers due to repeated torture combined with the systematic denial of food, water, medicine, and medical care," she told CNN. Waldman noted that the report has garnered the attention it deserves, stating, "It's a significant story. However, for those who work on Syria, it's a test case to see if the world still cares not just about the deaths, but the fact that they are organized and systematic." In light of the findings, Amnesty is urging an immediate investigation and calling on the UN to take swift action. "I want to be crystal clear that these practices are unacceptable and must stop. Mass killings of civilians and extermination through starvation, illness, and treatable diseases must cease. Russia has a unique responsibility to uphold global peace and security," Waldman emphasized. "We are calling on Russia to use its influence with the Syrian authorities to push for access to independent monitors in all government-run prisons in Syria where these atrocities are occurring, so that those responsible can be held accountable." At the UN, UK Ambassador and Deputy Permanent Representative Peter Wilson responded to the report's allegations. "We have seen the Amnesty International report on atrocities in Syria," he said. "Our foreign secretary has expressed his disgust with this report. We strongly condemn these atrocities and continue to work to shed light on what's happening in Syria and hold those responsible accountable for their actions." President Bashar al-Assad's regime has a history of facing allegations of extrajudicial killings and war crimes during Syria's civil war, which began in 2011. In 2014, CNN obtained a report that revealed "direct evidence" of "systematic torture and killing" by the Syrian government, based on photographs leaked by a Syrian defector. One of the report's authors described it as a "smoking gun" that conclusively proved the use of torture. However, Assad has consistently denied the accusations against him, claiming that many are politically motivated. In a meeting with western visitors, including The New York Times, in November, Assad dismissed the criticism, saying, "I'm just a headline - the bad president, the bad guy, who is killing the good guys." He argued that the real reason behind the accusations is to topple his government, which he believes does not align with the United States' interests. According to the UN, approximately 400,000 people have been killed since the start of the war, and an additional 4.8 million have fled the country.

Martin Schoeller's consistent style sets him apart as a photographer. In his 20-year career of taking close-up portraits, he has used the same lighting, setting, angle, and camera for every subject. According to Schoeller, this approach ensures that what you see is what you get, with no retouching. By treating each portrait equally, regardless of the subject, Schoeller aims to uncover the truth in an often dishonest medium. "I believe all photographs are dishonest," he said. "You can't capture a person's true essence in a split second, but perhaps some photographs are more honest than others. I'm trying to steer towards the more honest side of the spectrum." Among the thousands of people he has photographed, Schoeller finds actors to be the most challenging subjects. "Actors are difficult to photograph because they're always acting," he explained. "You think you've captured an honest, great portrait, but when you review the contact sheets, you realize they were playing a role the entire time and you didn't even notice."

After a 38-year hiatus, Christie Brinkley has returned to the cover of Sports Illustrated, this time alongside her daughters Alexa Ray Joel, 31, and Sailor Brinkley Cook, 18. The trio was photographed on the beach in Turks & Caicos, showcasing their bond and beauty. Brinkley also shared a solo photo in a red bikini, describing it as a "full circle moment." In 1979, 1980, and 1981, Brinkley made history by appearing on the cover three consecutive years. The 63-year-old posted the magazine photo with her daughters on Instagram, captioning it: "Thank you Sports Illustrated for sending the powerful message that good things come in packages of every size and we do not come with an expiration date!"

Alexa Ray Joel, Brinkley's daughter with Billy Joel, is a singer like her father. She shared her own bikini shot on Instagram, promoting body acceptance with a heartfelt caption: "I don't have a completely flat tummy, or cellulite-free thighs... nor am I a model's height or shape. Neither are hundreds of millions of other beautiful women out there. SO WHAT."

In an interview with People, Brinkley revealed that she had decided to stop posing in bathing suits at age 30, but the opportunity to pose with her daughters changed her mind. "I thought, 'Those days are over,'" she said. "But to get to do it with my girls, I thought, 'One last go!'"

The start of the men's downhill course in St. Moritz is a daunting prospect, with the steep slope of 100% or 45 degrees requiring TV cameramen to abseil into position while wearing crampons. But for the one skier brave enough to harness the breakneck speed, the reward will be the title of world downhill champion for the next two years. The 2017 World Championships, which kick off this week in the upscale Swiss town of St. Moritz, will culminate in the highlight event, a testament to the town's reputation as a premier destination for the jetset and its long history of hosting high-profile winter sports events. St. Moritz, nestled in the picturesque Engadin valley, has been a favorite among the international elite for generations, drawing discerning travelers to its gourmet restaurants and luxury hotels. With a rich heritage that includes hosting two Winter Olympics and four previous World Championships, St. Moritz is widely regarded as the "home of winter sports." The 2017 World Championships will bring together 600 athletes from over 70 countries to compete in six alpine skiing disciplines, including slalom, giant slalom, super-G, downhill, super combined, and team event. For many skiers, the World Championships is the pinnacle of achievement, surpassing even the prestige of the World Cup circuit. "It's like winning the Olympics, minus all the other sports – that's what the World Championships means to us," says Mikaela Shiffrin, the 21-year-old American sensation who leads the World Cup overall and slalom standings. Shiffrin is gunning for her third consecutive slalom world title, having won gold in Schladming in 2013 and Beaver Creek two years ago, as well as the Olympic slalom gold in 2014. As she acknowledges, she has set a high bar for herself, and anything less than victory would be a disappointment. "Not winning is a feeling I dislike – it makes me feel like I've done something wrong," she confesses. The main event, however, will be Lindsey Vonn, the second most successful ski racer in history, with 77 World Cup wins, trailing only Sweden's Ingemar Stenmark (86). Vonn, a speed queen and 2010 Olympic downhill champion, is back on the circuit after a year-long hiatus due to a broken arm and severe nerve damage to her right hand sustained in a crash following knee surgery. Vonn has shown signs of her former dominance, winning her first race back in Garmisch-Partenkirchen, Germany in January, but has also struggled with crashes, including a recent downhill event in Cortina d'Ampezzo, Italy. In the opening run of the World Championships' first race, the women's super-G, Vonn skied out after losing her concentration, but managed to stay on her feet. "I just lost my focus for a minute," Vonn said. "The important thing is that I stayed upright." Austria's Nicole Schmidhofer took the gold medal, edging out Tina Weirather of Liechtenstein and home favorite Lara Gut, in perfect conditions that followed two days of heavy snow that had cancelled the men's and women's downhill training sessions. Defending champion Anna Veith, an Olympic gold medalist, failed to make the second run after missing a gate. The women's downhill, which starts lower than the men's, is a significant test of skill and endurance. Vonn's main rivals on Sunday will be World Cup overall champion Lara Gut and Slovenia's Ilka Stuhec, the current World Cup downhill leader. Tina Maze, a Slovenian skier who won the world title in 2015 and has since retired, was another notable competitor. The men's downhill event takes place on Saturday on the renowned "Free Fall" course, designed by Bernhard Russi, a two-time downhill world champion and 1972 Olympic gold medalist from Switzerland. Prior to the race, competitors will access the start hut via a steel staircase before hurtling down 2,625 meters to the Salastrains plateau above St. Moritz, Switzerland. Defending champion Patrick Kung of Switzerland is looking to retain his title, but Peter Fill of Italy, the 2015-16 World Cup champion, is currently leading the standings this season. Norway's Kjetil Jansrud and Italy's Dominik Paris, who won in Kitzbuhel, are in second and third place in the World Cup standings. Last year's winner at St. Moritz, Beat Feuz, a 29-year-old Swiss skier, is aiming to improve on his World Championship bronze medal from 2015. The men's slalom on February 19 is expected to be a thrilling competition between Austria's Marcel Hirscher and Sweden's Henrik Kristofferson. Hirscher, 27, has won four World Championship gold medals and a record five overall World Cup titles, while Kristofferson, 22, is the reigning World Cup slalom champion. Briton Dave Ryding is also worth keeping an eye on, having achieved a joint best result for his country with a second-place finish in the slalom at Kitzbuhel last month. Ryding's performance equaled the achievement of Konrad Bartelski in a downhill event in 1981. He followed up his success with a 10th-place finish in the Schladming night slalom and currently sits fifth in the World Cup slalom standings. For more news and video on skiing, visit cnn.com/skiing. Britain has won 11 World Championship medals, but none since 1936.

Science and art are intertwined, as evident in the precise technique of the scalpel, the sleek design of the laboratory, and the intimate observations made by scientists to discover new materials and microorganisms. Bio-art, an artistic genre that emerged in the 1980s, further solidifies this connection. According to artist and writer Frances Stracey, bio-art represents the intersection of art and biology, where living matter such as genes, cells, or animals serves as the medium. Bio-artists often incorporate imaging technologies into their work, bringing together living and dead matter in the gallery space. They draw upon biological metaphors to infuse their artwork with themes of healing and wounding. For example, BioCouture combines fashion, art, and biology to create new materials. As noted by author Suzanne Anker, bio-artists like Donna Franklin and Gary Cass have created dresses from cellulose generated by bacteria from red wine, while Suzanne Lee composes "growing" textiles using sugar, tea, and bacteria to fashion jackets and kimonos. Lee's work includes jackets made from cellulose produced by bacteria in green tea and sugar baths. Bio-art encompasses a wide range of mediums, including the skins and cells of celluloid and digital video, the membranes of sound, and the liquids and fluids of body parts and eyeballs. Another example is Christian B?k's The Xenotext, which uses a "chemical alphabet" to translate poetry into DNA sequences, which are then implanted into a bacterium's genome. When translated into a gene and integrated into the cell, the poetry becomes a set of instructions that cause the organism to manufacture a viable, benign protein in response. "Biologist Bök writes, 'I'm engineering a life-form that not only serves as a durable archive for storing a poem, but also a machine that can write a poem - one that can persist on the planet until the sun's eventual demise.' In this era of collaboration, scientists and artists converge in newly created spaces of co-creation. Together, they engage with pressing questions about what constitutes life, sentience, and who decides which lives are saved, exploited, or destroyed. Bio-art synthesizes the hopes and concerns of both scientists and artists as we navigate an age of rapid, sometimes perilous transformations in human life and daily existence.

Author Sheel Patel observes about Bök's work: 'If a living cell can be engineered to produce novel poetry, could we one day live in a society where humans are no longer necessary for generating new ideas and literary works?' In the interactive art-science exhibition Morbis Artis: Diseases of the Arts, actual and metaphorical communicative diseases are used to explore the often toxic relationship between human and non-human life. The exhibition delves into the precarious threshold between life and death in an era of species and habitat destruction, as well as the increasingly permeable boundaries of contemporary bodies. Science's ability to scrutinize every location, facilitated by its microscopic and bio-technological powers, trains us to detect disease everywhere. Meanwhile, dominant discourse suggests that some spaces, things, and objects are inherently more diseased than others." "We are often taught to view disease as something that affects others, whether it's the homes of outsiders, the nests of insects, or the fabric of certain societies and belief systems. However, new perspectives in materialism and animal philosophy challenge our understanding of what life is and where it can be found, leading us to consider how humanity's actions can infect and taint everything it touches. This collision between the possibilities and limitations of human and non-human life is a precarious balance between nightmare and dream.

Morbis Artis: Diseases of the Arts is a collection of 11 artistic works that explore the chaos of the world through various media and art forms. Each artist imagines disease differently, yet within the terror of their visions, there is also beauty and hope. In Drew Berry's video projection, infectious cells are set free, filling the exhibition space with droplets of life and death. Viruses such as herpes, influenza, HIV, polio, and smallpox are projected onto the walls, their magnified and chaotic forms striking those who enter the space.

Lienors Torre's multimedia and glass work, "Degenerative Vision," explores how our perception of the world is influenced and distorted by digital technologies. The piece features two large glass eyeballs, a liquid animation, and a glass cabinet filled with jars of water with varying degrees of opacity, each containing engraved eye images. As the viewer interacts with the piece, the liquidity of vision is brought to life, and the eyes become raindrops. The work is marked by tears and scars that reflect across the eyes, creating a poignant and thought-provoking experience.

Alison Bennett's touch-based screen work, "Bruised Skin," presents a high-resolution scan of damaged tissue. Viewers can manipulate the soft and damaged skin using the touch screen, their eyes becoming organs of touch. The work invites us to consider what it feels like to touch a bruise and be bruised.

The Morbis Artis exhibition is a fusion of art and science, where the boundaries between the two are blurred. The gallery becomes a laboratory and studio, where artists fashion the world anew using a scalpel and a paintbrush. Morbis Artis: Diseases of the Arts is currently on display at the RMIT Gallery until February 18, 2017."

South Africa rugby legend Joost van der Westhuizen, who was confined to a wheelchair and struggled to speak in his later years due to motor neurone disease, passed away at the age of 45 on Monday. Despite his physical limitations, his contributions to the sport will never be forgotten, according to his former teammate Cobus Visagie. "Joost essentially set the standard for modern scrumhalves," Visagie said on CNN's World Sport show on Tuesday. Standing at 6 feet 2 inches tall, van der Westhuizen played scrumhalf, a position typically occupied by the smallest players on the field. "Sometimes I'd look around at the circle of players and see a man with boots three sizes bigger than mine - a scrumhalf!" Visagie recalled, having played alongside van der Westhuizen at the 1999 World Cup and earning 29 caps for South Africa. "He was incredibly fast, incredibly brave, and is renowned for the tackles he made in the 1995 World Cup, including the crucial one against Jonah Lomu in the final against New Zealand." In that game, van der Westhuizen brought down the giant winger when he had broken through the South African defense, helping the Springboks win 15-12 in extra time. The 1995 World Cup final, the first major sporting event held in South Africa after the end of Apartheid, has become an iconic moment in rugby history, immortalized in the Hollywood film "Invictus." "Who could forget that tackle in the '95 World Cup?" former Springboks forward Alistair Hargreaves said. "He was fearless, and for a scrumhalf, he certainly broke the mold. As a young boy, he embodied what South African rugby was all about. We idolized him." A star player from the Blitzboks leaves the sport on a high note. Scotland stuns Ireland in the opening match of the Six Nations tournament. Courage on the field is matched by courage off it for Joost van der Westhuizen, who was diagnosed with motor neurone disease in 2011, a year after retiring from international rugby with a record 89 caps for the Springboks.
