Also known as ALS or Lou Gehrig's disease, the condition causes muscles to weaken and waste away over time. The "Ice Bucket Challenge" became a global phenomenon in 2014, raising awareness and funds for motor neurone disease research. Although never teammates, Hargreaves was fortunate to meet his childhood hero, van der Westhuizen, later in life. "I met him after his playing career, and probably at a time when his illness was really taking hold," Hargreaves said. "If he was resilient on the field, he proved to be even more courageous in the face of his diagnosis. What a remarkable battle he fought. You can only respect the man for his courage." After his diagnosis, van der Westhuizen founded the J9 Foundation, a charity dedicated to supporting those affected by motor neurone disease. "It's incredibly sad, but Joost fought a long and courageous battle," Hargreaves added. "He was aware of the struggle he faced, and I'm sure there's relief at the end of it. The guy has achieved so much, he's done so much for rugby, and I'm sure he'll be remembered as a legend of the game." "For more news and videos, visit CNN's rugby page at cnn.com/rugly. A public memorial service will be held on Friday at Loftus Versfeld Stadium in Pretoria, South Africa, the home stadium of the Blue Bulls, the provincial team of the late South African rugby player Os du Randt."

In 1499, Michelangelo completed the Pieta, a masterpiece that embodies the perfect blend of classical ideals and divine inspiration. Fast forward to 2017, when a peculiar item emerged on the internet: a Flamin' Hot Cheeto shaped like a dead gorilla. Dubbed "Harambe the Gorilla" by its creator, the Cheeto sparked a bidding war on eBay, with the seller claiming it sold for nearly $100,000 after 132 bids. We're choosing not to believe it, as it's unlikely that a Cheeto, no matter how peculiar, is worth such a staggering sum. The seller's legitimacy, however, is verified, with an active account since 2008 and a sufficient amount of buyer and seller feedback. Despite this, the absurdity of the situation is undeniable. The proliferation of Harambe Cheeto-related items on eBay has become a cruel joke, a commentary on the darker aspects of consumerism and humanity. If you're interested in purchasing one of these items, you can do so with your hard-earned cash. Alternatively, you could simply gaze at a bag of Cheetos and imagine the shapes you see. Ultimately, nothing seems to matter anymore.

However, nature is not always benevolent. Half of the world's lion population resides in East Africa, and these majestic creatures have a taste for livestock. Historically, the Maasai have used force to protect their herds, often embarking on revenge missions to hunt and kill lions. In the past, the Maasai also practiced ritual killings, known as "Ala-mayo." The killing of a lion, a symbol of strength and power, was a rite of passage for Maasai initiates into the warrior class, "Morani." Armed with a spear, these young men would become men, earning respect from their tribe upon their return. Although the Tanzanian government banned ritual killings in the 1970s, certain pockets of activity were tolerated in silence. In Ngorongoro Crater, a conservation area since 1959, the practice was deemed sustainable due to the high lion concentration and low human presence. In the 1960s, the tribe claimed to have killed no more than 10 lions per year, but as the Maasai population grew in Ngorongoro, so did the threat to the lion population. Today, up to 40 lions, if not more, are under threat annually in the conservation area, and lion numbers are declining across Tanzania. Conservationists recognize the need for action and have made a remarkable breakthrough by enlisting the expertise of the Maasai themselves to patrol the Maasai Steppe. At around 5am, the Maasai "Wildlife Warriors" rise to the sound of birdsong, nature's alarm clock. They begin their day with a bowl of porridge and a cup of chai, then slip on sandals made from recycled old car tires and head out of their "kraal," a small, sheltered community, to start tracking. These Maasai have traded their hunting ways for a life of conservation. As part of an initiative by the Tanzania People and Wildlife Fund, a organization dedicated to resolving human-animal conflict, the Wildlife Warriors are stationed across communities in Tarangire and the surrounding rangeland, utilizing their skills to protect what was once their adversary. Beyond the low wall of the kraal, tracks crisscross the dirt, betraying the presence of lions, hyenas, and wild dogs that visit at night, drawn to livestock and the community's water supply during the dry season. On a typical day, the Warriors might embark on an animal census, circling the Steppe in the early morning with a car provided by the Fund. However, when tracks begin inside the kraal, it's often a sign of a big cat. In such cases, the footprints usually lead to a kill. The next step is crucial. "People are growing increasingly angry towards wildlife," says Wildlife Warrior Lucas Lengoje. In the past, a carcass would lead to retribution, but the Maasai's decreasing head of cattle per person has made each loss feel more devastating. "The community finds it challenging to understand the importance of wildlife," Lengoje adds. "It takes time to calm them down and for them to believe us, as they prioritize their livestock over wildlife." Some reprisals have become extreme, including poisoning carcasses between a lion's initial gorge and second feed, which not only kills the lion but also any animal that feeds on the subsequent carcass. The Wildlife Warriors intervene, defuse the situation, and ultimately provide solutions for their communities and those around them. One of their primary concerns is documenting the attack and location, using GPS to map the incident on the Fund's database. In addition to warning neighboring herders of potential dangers, the organization also provides contact information so Maasai people can claim compensation from the government if their cattle are lost. This marks the beginning of a long-term approach to preventing cattle loss. The organization, in collaboration with the Maasai, is using a innovative method called "Living Walls" to prevent cattle loss. These walls, made of African myrrh trees connected by chain link fences, have been successfully implemented across several communities. According to Elvis Kisimir from the organization, the key difference between traditional "bomas" and Living Walls is the use of chain link, which is more effective at keeping predators out. "Bomas" are made of dried twigs from thorny acacia bushes, but chain link is more secure, especially when combined with living, fast-growing thorny trees that become more difficult to breach over time. In the wet season, these walls can reach heights of over 12 feet. The organization has already built over 700 "bomas" and has seen a 99% reduction in cattle loss at night using the Living Wall method. To further supplement this success, the organization is launching education programs through Maasai Wildlife Warriors to promote coexistence between humans and predators. "We wouldn't be able to achieve this on our own," admits Kisimir. "Community is everything." Laly Lichtenfeld, executive director of the organization, describes this as "the next step" in creating a self-regulating environment where both Maasai people and lions can thrive. "The Maasai people are absolutely critical to the conservation process in northern Tanzania," she emphasizes. "This is their land, and their livelihoods are deeply dependent on wise environmental stewardship. Healthy grasslands mean healthy livestock, and the cattle are at the heart of their identity and economic well-being. If they can manage to maintain healthy ecosystems, everything in the system will benefit."

The Dalai Lama, now 81, has laugh lines etched on his face, a testament to his infectious sense of humor. As he presided over the Emory-Tibet Symposium in December at a majestic temple in Mundgod, India, he showcased his playful nature. Thousands of saffron-robed nuns and monks, esteemed scientists, Tibetans, and curious followers gathered to explore the intersection of science and Buddhism. The crowd was initially somber, murmuring quietly and shifting in their seats as they waited for the proceedings to begin. But when the Dalai Lama emerged from a side door, the atmosphere transformed. The scraping of plastic chairs as the crowd stood and applauded was followed by gasps of joy as some prostrated themselves on the ground. Surrounded by monks in traditional attire and bodyguards in Western dress, the Dalai Lama smiled broadly, laughing and waving at the crowd. "When you smile, I notice everyone around you smiles," Dr. Sanjay Gupta, CNN's Chief Medical Correspondent, observed during an interview with the Dalai Lama after the event. "We are social animals," the Dalai Lama replied, "and we need friends. Trust is essential for developing genuine friendships." The Dalai Lama believes that building trust requires showing genuine respect and love. He thinks that a warm, genuine smile is an important part of that. However, it's also clear that a sense of humor can go a long way in winning over a crowd. At a recent event, the Dalai Lama sat down in his floral chair, which was adorned with a pillow that looked like it had been borrowed from a monk's bed. The crowd grew quiet, leaning forward in anticipation of his words. But instead of offering a prayer or words of wisdom, he decided to wipe his brow, taking his time to do so. He then placed the white washcloth on his head, where it rested like an absurd hat. The audience giggled as he wore it for about an hour, enjoying the lighthearted moment.

Later, he reached for a glass jar of candy on the low table in front of him and joked, "This is not decoration." He pointed to himself and said "eat," then unwrapped a gold foil candy and popped it into his mouth. His playful behavior, laughing and joking, quickly put the solemn and respectful crowd at ease. They began to laugh along with him, warming up to the idea of discussing heavy topics such as the fundamental constituents of the universe and the establishment of knowledge. The Dalai Lama later revealed to Gupta that he wears the washcloth in a playful way because he is a practical person who gets hot, but also because he believes it's essential for leaders, especially spiritual ones, to be relatable and playful. He emphasized that being too formal can be self-torture, and he often hopes for unexpected moments that will bring out the humanity in others. In 1954, he recalled a visit from an Indian ambassador in Peking, where the formal atmosphere was broken when officials brought in fruit and everyone relaxed. The Dalai Lama believes that people should let themselves be playful and find the humor in life, as it can help reduce stress and bring joy to others.

In his book "My Spiritual Journey," the Dalai Lama describes himself as a "professional laugher" and attributes his cheerful nature to his upbringing in a family that values humor and playfulness. Research has shown that laughing and being playful can have numerous benefits, including lowering stress levels, increasing empathy, and fostering a sense of well-being. The Dalai Lama believes that adopting this approach can bring a deeper sense of peace and happiness, even in difficult times. He writes that focusing only on the negative aspects of life doesn't help find solutions and can destroy one's peace of mind. Instead, he encourages people to create reasons to smile, as genuine smiles can bring happiness to oneself and others.

"Get ready to explore over 50 breathtaking rooftops, designed by a diverse range of renowned and emerging architects and landscape designers, in Taschen's latest photography book, "Rooftops: Islands in the Sky", set to release on February 15 in the United States. The book showcases stunning visuals of forests stretching towards the sky, lush gardens, pools flowing off building edges, thought-provoking art installations, and versatile outdoor spaces that effortlessly transition from daytime lunch spots to nighttime hotspots. According to book editor Philip Jodidio, "there are as many ways to design and transform rooftops as there are buildings in modern cities." He notes that the allure of rooftops is timeless, with roots that date back further than ancient texts like the Old and New Testaments or the Qur'an. Simply put, the roof offers a unique perspective, a place to contemplate the city, or a temporary escape from its hustle and bustle. Take a look at the gallery below to see the incredible work of architects like Norman Foster, Shigeru Ban, Toyo Ito, Frank Gehry, Ken Smith, and more."

President Trump's defense of Russian President Putin after Fox's Bill O'Reilly called him a "killer" reveals a disturbing disregard for democratic norms. Trump's response, "You think our country is so innocent," shows a blatant disregard for the values that have long defined America. While the United States has undoubtedly made mistakes throughout its history, its commitment to individual liberties and democratic ideals has remained unwavering. In stark contrast, Putin's Russia has seen the opposition decimated, critics imprisoned, and all branches of government brought under his control. The free press is a shadow of its former self, and critics, including journalists, continue to turn up dead under suspicious circumstances. One of Putin's most vocal critics, Vladimir Kara-Murza, remains in a Moscow hospital in grave condition after suffering a full organ failure that doctors agree was caused by a toxic substance. Despite Trump's comments and recent executive actions, he can expect pushback from a country committed to liberal democratic principles. The divide between the President and the American people has turned the United States into the latest battleground in a global clash of ideologies. The unexpected rise of populist authoritarianism has caught many off guard, but the millions of Americans who remain skeptical of Trump and are now protesting on a weekly basis can take comfort in knowing they are not alone. On Sunday, while the American public was glued to the Super Bowl, a remarkable sight unfolded in Romania. Hundreds of thousands of people took to the streets to protest a government push to decriminalize corruption, and remarkably, they had already won. This display of democratic strength serves as a powerful reminder that there are still those who stand up for what is right, even in the face of authoritarianism. Demonstrations had started six days earlier, sparked by the government's attempt to quietly pass a decree that would have cleared the records and freed individuals convicted of corruption for amounts under $47,000. The government ultimately agreed to retract the order, but the protests only intensified, with protesters insisting they had taken to the streets to safeguard their democracy. Romanians were acutely aware of the importance of defending democracy, given their recent communist past and the erosion of liberal democracy in neighboring countries, which requires the separation of powers, an independent judiciary, free and fair elections, and the freedom to protest. Unfortunately, in the aftermath of the global financial crisis and the influx of refugees, demagogic politicians have exploited public discontent, vilifying foreigners and vowing to prioritize their country's "true" residents, thereby gradually dismantling the foundations of liberal democracy. While Romanians have scored a victory in this round, the forces defending democracy elsewhere, including in neighboring Hungary, have been losing ground. Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban has openly declared his intention to build an "illiberal state" and is making progress in his quest to emulate regimes led by leaders like Putin. Democratic freedoms have suffered significant setbacks in recent years. Turkey is sliding towards dictatorship, Venezuela remains mired in autocracy, and countries across every continent are facing similar challenges. As for the United States, some veterans of the struggle are pessimistic. When millions of women took to the streets the day after Trump's inauguration, Julia Ioffe, whose family fled Russia, dampened their enthusiasm by tweeting, "The joyful, feisty crowds, the clever signs - it all feels like the protests in Moscow in 2011. That achieved nothing." It's true that protests have not yet achieved significant results against other authoritarian regimes. In Venezuela, the Chavista regime seized power in 1999, and despite the opposition's relentless efforts, it has managed to maintain its grip on power. Similarly, in Turkey, mass protests and even electoral victories have been unable to halt Recep Tayyip Erdogan's slide towards de facto authoritarianism. In Russia, Vladimir Putin has consolidated his power, with a compliant legislature and a stranglehold on the media. However, the story may unfold differently in the United States. Yascha Mounk, a Harvard expert on right-wing populism, has noted that President Trump's authoritarian tendencies are more pronounced than he initially feared, but he has also been heartened by the bravery of the opposition. The United States has a deeper wellspring of democratic tradition than any of the countries where liberal democracies have been undermined. Freedom from tyranny is the national creed, and Americans have a long history of defending their democratic way of life. Within days of Trump's inauguration, the country witnessed the largest national protest in its history. When he issued a travel ban targeting seven Muslim-majority countries, spontaneous demonstrations erupted at major airports across the country, with lawyers filing legal briefs on the spot. While the Republican-controlled Congress has been largely silent in the face of Trump's attacks on the independent media and the judiciary, the press has remained steadfast in its commitment to its duties, and judges have shown no signs of intimidation in the face of White House bullying. Even members of the executive branch have begun to speak out against the president's actions. While many Americans support Trump, there are signs that his sharp departure from democratic norms, his attacks on judges, and his vitriolic rhetoric against the media and critics of all kinds are generating a backlash. The battle for liberal democracy is being waged on two fronts: those fighting to defend it and those working to undermine it. By likening the United States to Putin's Russia, President Trump has effectively placed himself on the illiberal side of the divide. However, the American people have spent centuries building a strong democratic system, and they are prepared to fight to defend it.

During the Cold War, the Kremlin employed a propaganda technique known as "whataboutism" to discredit the West. This tactic aimed to portray the West as morally flawed, making its criticism of the Soviet empire seem hypocritical. The Soviet Union would respond to any criticism of its actions (such as the war in Afghanistan, martial law in Poland, or persecution of dissidents) by listing Western abuses (supporting fascist dictatorships, suppressing trade unions, and racial oppression).

A classic example of this technique was a joke about Radio Yerevan, a popular Soviet-era humor staple. In the joke, a caller asks about the average wage of an American manual worker, only to be met with a pause and the response, "Over there, they lynch Negroes." This phrase became a derisive term for Soviet propaganda and seemed to die out in the 1990s when Russia's goal was to become like the West.

However, under President Vladimir Putin, "whataboutism" made a comeback. Putin's propaganda machine focuses on spreading FUD (Fear, Uncertainty, and Doubt) in the West. By convincing Americans, Britons, Germans, and others that their leaders are corrupt and incompetent, and that legality and liberty are a sham, Putin's strategy aims to make them less likely to take risks and make sacrifices in defending their countries.

While "whataboutism" can be a useful tactic in argument, as it encourages scrutiny of criticism from a purported moral high ground, it is fundamentally different when employed by Putin's Russia. Unlike the West, which is genuinely self-critical and self-correcting, Russia's treatment of its indigenous populations, such as the Maris, Buryats, and Komis, is a stark reminder of its own human rights abuses. Therefore, it is disingenuous for Russia to lecture the West on minority rights. "At the heart of our system is contestability. While our elected officials and government leaders are not infallible and can make mistakes, they are held accountable through various mechanisms. They face the risk of legal action, impeachment, media scrutiny, public protest, and potential removal from office, which can lead to a lifetime of reputational damage. These checks and balances may not be perfect, but they are effective. In contrast, President François Hollande's missteps in France have been relatively minor compared to the standards set by President Putin, who can remain in office indefinitely. President Trump's recent visa ban has been met with immediate legal challenges, a stark contrast to the lack of accountability faced by President Putin in Russia. It's telling that Trump seems to aspire to emulate Russia's authoritarian system, which he perceives as less constrained by legal limitations on executive power. This view is not only misguided but also dangerous. As the world's beacon of freedom and justice, America sets a standard for other political systems to follow. This reputation is a valuable asset, and Trump is squandering it with every utterance. Moral relativism is eroding sentiment in the frontline states of the new cold war. In countries like Bulgaria, Georgia, Moldova, and Ukraine, pro-Western leaders are feeling hopeless, wondering why they should continue to fight for freedom when the leader of the free world has abandoned its principles. Furthermore, Trump's actions will spread the notion that power and money are the only currencies that matter, and that the political currency that truly works is forged from lies and fear. If these are the rules of the game, then it's better to play along." "Despite initial doubts, it appears that Trump's strategy has been successful. Edward Lucas, a senior editor at The Economist, served as the publication's Moscow bureau chief from 1998 to 2002. Additionally, he holds the position of senior vice president at the Center for European Policy Analysis, a Washington, D.C.-based think tank. The views expressed in this commentary are his own and do not necessarily reflect the opinions of The Economist or the Center for European Policy Analysis."

Let's hope these came in handy when Melissa McCarthy parodied White House spokesman Sean Spicer on Saturday Night Live over the weekend. We all know President Donald Trump's boss has a reputation for being thin-skinned and humorless, having complained on Twitter about SNL's countless spoofs, calling the show "unwatchable," "totally biased," and "not funny." He's also taken aim at Alec Baldwin's impersonation, saying it "just can't get any worse." I agree with that assessment; SNL has been relying too heavily on simply mimicking Trump and his antics through Baldwin, rather than cleverly satirizing him. Until this weekend, that is. Melissa McCarthy's take on Spicer was a game-changer, as she brought a well-studied ear for his tics and tone to the role. Exaggerating a White House spokesman might seem like inside-the-beltway humor, but in this era of reality TV, everyone around Trump is a character. The SNL writers didn't just mimic Spicer; they encapsulated a bigger story: what happens when a professional political operative becomes Trumpified. If you didn't laugh out loud, you might have Trump's thin-skin disorder. But will Spicer follow his boss's lead and tweet about how unfunny SNL is? Not if he's smart. If an SNL spoof is funny, the only way to handle it is to embrace it. At his next press briefing, which was rescheduled for Monday, Trump should take a lighthearted approach, brushing off the parody with a joke and a smile. He's already attempted this tactic in a recent interview with Extra, telling AJ Calloway that McCarthy "could dial back" her impressions, while also praising the show as "funny." If Trump can continue to do so, he'll be following a long tradition of politicians taking parody in stride. In the past, politicians have demonstrated a sense of humor about being spoofed. For example, in 1995, House Republicans invited Chris Farley, who had been impersonating Speaker Newt Gingrich on Saturday Night Live, to impersonate him in person at a conference meeting, with Gingrich laughing along. Similarly, after Dana Carvey had been spoofing George H.W. Bush for four years, he was invited to the White House to meet the former president. After Bush lost the election, he even had Carvey come to cheer up his staff. More recently, in 2008, after Tina Fey had been perfectly portraying then-Alaska Governor Sarah Palin, Palin appeared on Saturday Night Live alongside Fey and Alec Baldwin, who playfully mistook her for Fey and asked how she could appear on the show with the "real" Palin, "that horrible woman." However, that was before Trump's presidency. During Trump's administration, many of his team members have become increasingly defensive, serious, and aggressive, adopting his rhetorical style of hyperbole, bombast, and fact-blurring. They say things publicly that I know they would never have said before. It seems like they're playing a part in a new reality show, one that Trump seems to be directing. I wouldn't be surprised if Spicer, in particular, reverts to Trump's lack of humor toward unflattering satire, sticking to the script and refusing to acknowledge the parody. However, that would only make things worse. "The fact that the credibility of the White House and its staff is already being ridiculed just two weeks into the Trump administration is a concern. The appointment of Steve Bannon, a Trump political adviser, has raised questions about who will provide a calm and rational influence on the president. If the White House wants to ease these concerns, Press Secretary Sean Spicer should take a cue from his pre-Trump persona and play along with McCarthy's humor. Otherwise, the notion that Trump's White House can't handle a joke will become increasingly worrying."

Although slavery is illegal worldwide, criminals still generate over $150 billion annually from human trafficking. However, you can make a difference. On March 14, 2017, we invite you and your school to join us for #MyFreedomDay, a global initiative to raise awareness about modern slavery and celebrate freedom. We encourage students to organize events at their school to highlight the issue and promote freedom. The schools that demonstrate the most enthusiasm and dedication to fighting slavery will be featured on CNN TV, CNN.com, and CNN Facebook. A few select schools will even receive a visit from a CNN correspondent, who will report live from the school on the day.

To participate, we encourage students and teachers to come up with their own creative ideas. Here are some suggestions to get you started:

* Film Screening: Watch documentaries or movies that address human trafficking. You can access free CNN documentaries on cnn.com/myfreedom.
* Art Show: Create artwork in any medium and display it at your school. Share your creations on Twitter or Instagram using #MyFreedomDay. Your art should convey peaceful, hopeful messages, highlight the stories of survivors and traffickers, and raise awareness about human trafficking in your community.
* Stand for Freedom: Take a 45-minute (or 45-hour) stand to represent the 45 million victims of slavery worldwide.
* Holi Day: Inspired by the Indian Festival of Colors, which celebrates love and color, we encourage you to host a Holi Day event at your school. This can include festivities involving washable, pigmented powders that can be thrown at each other to raise awareness and funds for the cause. "Join us for a day of fun and awareness as we tackle the issue of human trafficking in our community. The event will feature a panel discussion with local lawmakers and anti-trafficking organizations, providing a platform to discuss the issue not just globally, but also in our own backyard.

In addition, we invite you to participate in a day of service, where you can volunteer at rehabilitation centers, visit your local lawmakers to make your voice heard, or collect essential items for survivors in collaboration with local organizations. The possibilities are endless, and we encourage you to take action in any way that feels meaningful to you.

To share your plans and show your support, simply tweet or post on Instagram using #MyFreedomDay. (Please note that you must be 13 or older to post on social media.) For more information, visit cnn.com/myfreedom.

But #MyFreedomDay is about more than just raising awareness - it's also about reflecting on what freedom means to you. Is it the freedom to spend time with loved ones? The freedom to be yourself? The freedom to pursue your passions? Whatever freedom means to you, we encourage you to share your thoughts and help spread the message. Let's come together to appreciate the freedoms we often take for granted and work towards creating a world where everyone can live freely."

Lauren Chopek, now 19, once blamed herself for everything that happened to her. But she's since realized that she was a victim of sexual exploitation and trafficking, and that the guilt and shame belong to her perpetrators, not her. "I was just a child," she says, her voice calm and serene as she sits in a safe house in rural Manitoba, a healing lodge that provided her with the love and protection she needed after escaping her life on the streets. Chopek was just 14 when she was trafficked for sex in her hometown of Winnipeg. Unfortunately, her story is all too common for indigenous girls in Canada, where they make up just 4% of the population but account for more than 50% of all sex trafficking victims. The reasons for this are complex and multifaceted, but ultimately rooted in a legacy of poverty, racism, and abuse.

"I was making bad choices for a reason," Chopek explains. "When you experience sexual abuse, it's confusing. You're never sure if it's your fault or theirs." Diane Redsky, who runs the Ma Mawi Wi Chi Itata Centre, an organization that advocates for indigenous women and children, including sex trafficking victims, says that the history of racism against indigenous Canadians perpetuates a cycle of violence and exploitation against them. Redsky's organization operates safe houses, rehabilitation programs, and prevention programs throughout Manitoba, including the rural healing lodge where Chopek stayed. "It's extremely challenging for indigenous women to combat stereotypes when society is perpetuating violence and abuse against them, particularly against indigenous women and girls, which often leads to sex trafficking," says Redsky. Tanay Little's story exemplifies the insidious nature of abuse. At just 11 years old, Little was sexually exploited on the streets near her family's home in Winnipeg. An older girl, who pretended to be her friend, manipulated Little into drug use and then trafficked her for sex. "I recall one instance where she locked me in a room and I was forced to have sex with two men, one after the other," Little shares. If she refused to comply, she was beaten. "If you didn't get beaten, you'd be raped by multiple men," Little explains. The traffickers demanded a daily "debt bondage" of $1,000 to $2,000, which the girls were forced to pay to their captors or face severe consequences. These harrowing stories have been shared in family homes, police stations, and safe houses across Manitoba for years. The province is now pioneering a new approach to prevention and rehabilitation, with a focus on supporting victims. Redsky and others in Manitoba are leading transformative programs to identify the threats and risks prevalent in indigenous communities and provide targeted support. Jennifer Richardson runs Tracia's Trust, Manitoba's strategy to combat the sexual exploitation and trafficking of children. Manitoba's government has committed a significant investment of over $10 million Canadian per year to fund the program, a substantial amount considering the province's population of approximately one million people. According to Richardson, Manitoba has made tremendous progress in this area over the past decade, earning recognition as a leader in the field across Canada.

The program's innovative approach sets it apart from others, utilizing not only targeted funding but also words, actions, and training to combat human trafficking. One strategy involves outreach on neighborhood streets, carried out in partnership with law enforcement officers. The Winnipeg Police Department's elite unit is dispatched almost daily to counter sexual exploitation and human trafficking, marking a shift in their approach from solely focusing on enforcement to prioritizing victim support and perpetrator accountability.

Law enforcement officials acknowledge a history of bias and racism, which previously hindered their understanding of the vulnerabilities and risks faced by indigenous girls. "We recognize that there is implicit bias within our police service, and we have taken steps to address it," says Danny Smyth, Winnipeg's deputy police chief. "We have a dedicated outreach team that focuses on building relationships with individuals on the streets and establishing trust."

However, the legacy of abuse and racism continues to hinder the healing process for Canada's indigenous community. An upcoming national inquiry will investigate the reasons behind the high number of missing and murdered indigenous women and girls. Studies have shown that indigenous women and girls are five times more likely to die in violent circumstances than their non-indigenous counterparts. "We are still living in a society that targets indigenous women and girls, and the national task force has concluded that there is a market for indigenous girls," says Redsky. "This perpetuates a society that views indigenous women as less than human and of no value."

In the background of a photo posted online, various products, including prescription medication, can be seen. However, upon closer inspection, the details of the pill bottle are illegible. At the Homeland Security Investigations Cyber Crimes Center, special agent and supervisor Jim Cole, an expert in Victim Identification, sets to work using cutting-edge technology. By leveraging technology that had not yet been released to the public, Cole and his team were able to reverse the motion blur on the pill bottle and extract some valuable information. They managed to decipher the offender's first name, "Stephen," the first two letters of their last name, and the first three digits of the prescription order. With this information, Cole applied to the pharmacy for customer details on every individual who matched the criteria, which narrowed down the list to a man named Stephen Keating. Additionally, the team was able to extract the offender's fingerprints from the image, a feat that had never been accomplished before. The evidence gathered was strong enough to put Stephen Keating behind bars for 110 years, and investigators were able to rescue his 14 victims. Cole co-founded Project VIC, which aims to ensure that no victim is left behind. "We strive to find these children as quickly as possible," Cole said. "The longer it takes us, the longer the child is in harm's way." The task is daunting, as Cole notes that they are currently processing 500,000 images per week, which translates to over 25 million per year. The Keating case, which was previously a months-long investigation, was solved in just three weeks. In the past, uncovering such an image could have taken months or even years. Thanks to "Photo DNA" technology, investigators can now quickly sort through hundreds of thousands of photos, categorizing familiar images to focus on new victims. "What used to take nine months now takes only a month," said Cole, a investigator. "And it's not just photos - our technology also allows us to review video at a scale of about 100 times faster than before," he added. "It's been a complete game-changer for law enforcement, and we hear that from the field all the time." Not only does this technology save time, but it also helps ease the psychological burden on investigators. "We've definitely seen a mental health benefit from this technology," Cole said. "Our offenders often use familiar, mundane images, which can be overwhelming for investigators to review. But with this technology, we can quickly identify and categorize those images, reducing the psychological toll on our team." The technology recently helped investigators identify a seemingly innocent photo of a known offender with her victim on vacation. The image showed the pair holding fish at a campsite, and by isolating the fish and sending them to Cornell University, investigators were able to determine the geographical area where those fish could be caught. The campsite image, with the child and perpetrator removed, was then sent to every campsite advertiser in that location. Within just four hours, investigators had identified the child, and she was rescued. The woman responsible is now serving a 25-year sentence. A second image, featuring an offender with a young girl, caught the attention of the Project VIC team. The image showed a company logo on the man's sweatshirt, but the team couldn't decipher the writing at first. Thanks to advanced technology, the logo became almost completely legible, leading investigators to a plumbing business. An online search for matching names revealed a former employee, who was subsequently tracked down and four victims were rescued. Unfortunately, the proliferation of such images online is a growing global problem. Last year, the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children (NCMEC) received a staggering 4.4 million reports to its CyberTipline, an 800% increase from 2013. These reports come from the public as well as companies like Facebook, Google, and Twitter, which are mandated by U.S. regulations to report any such images. According to Lindsay Olson, director of the Exploited Child Division at NCMEC, 94% of the cases reported last year were outside the United States. The CyberTipline receives reports of various forms of child exploitation, including child pornography, online enticement, sex trafficking, and child molestation. Olson explained that the organization makes reports available to law enforcement agencies in over 100 countries and collaborates with Europol and Interpol. Griffeye, a Swedish-based company, was a founding partner of Project VIC and donates its software for use in child exploitation cases. According to Johann Hofmann, director of Griffeye, the increasing digital nature of crime means that law enforcement agencies need to adapt and use the right tools to crack cases. The Internet has no borders, and law enforcement agencies must overcome traditional geographic boundaries to work together effectively. Project VIC is now being used by Interpol, Europol, and agencies in 35 countries, including the United Kingdom and Canada, with a rollout planned in Australia. In the United States, the results of Project VIC have been impressive, with over 1,000 victims rescued by Homeland Security Investigations (HSI) alone in the past year. Similar success has been seen in other agencies as well.

Lan's life was forever changed on a fateful night. While preparing for university along the northern Vietnam-China border, a friend she had met online invited her to a group dinner. Despite feeling tired and wanting to go home, the group persuaded her to stay and socialize. Before she knew it, she was being smuggled across the border to China. "I wanted to leave, but there were other girls there, and we were being guarded," Lan recalls. The villages along the border are notorious hunting grounds for human traffickers, who prey on young girls as young as 13. These girls are often tricked or drugged and then smuggled across the porous border by boat, motorbike, or car.

In China, where the one-child policy and cultural preference for sons have created a severe gender imbalance, young Vietnamese women are highly sought after as brides. According to Ha Thi Van Khanh, national project coordinator for the U.N.'s anti-trafficking organization in Vietnam, it can cost a Chinese man a significant amount of money to marry a local woman. This is because traditional Chinese customs require the groom to host an elaborate banquet and purchase a new home after the wedding. As a result, many Chinese men turn to neighboring countries, including Vietnam, to find brides.

Diep Vuong, founder of the Pacific Links Foundation, estimates that Vietnamese brides can sell for upwards of $3,000 to the end buyer, making them a highly valuable commodity. Vietnamese women are often considered desirable due to cultural similarities with the Chinese. Nguyen's story is a stark reminder of the dangers of human trafficking. At just 16, she was drugged and smuggled into China by a friend's boyfriend, and then forced into a marriage against her will. For three months, she resisted, despite being subjected to physical abuse, starvation, and threats of death, she claims. Eventually, she relented. She says her husband was kind to her, but she never stopped longing for her family in Vietnam. "My yearning to return home was unutterable," Nguyen said. "I agreed to marry the man, but I couldn't stay with a stranger I didn't love." When her mother-in-law realized Lan would never accept the marriage, the family returned her to the traffickers. According to Nguyen, the family received a refund, after which she was forced into a second marriage.

A refuge for escaped women, the Pacific Links Foundation operates a shelter for trafficking victims in Lao Cai, northern Vietnam. The young women typically stay for two to three years, during which time they attend school or receive vocational training, participate in art therapy, learn cooking and sewing skills, and tend to a large garden. Surrounded by others who have experienced similar trauma, the shelter helps them regain their footing and eventually find employment to support themselves. "Once these young women can invest in themselves, it becomes much easier for them to lead independent lives," says Diep. The organization also conducts community outreach efforts to prevent more girls from falling prey to traffickers.

Once a month, a group of trafficking survivors visits the market in Bac Ha, a regional hub for buying food, fabric, and livestock. On this day, on a stage overlooking hundreds of shoppers, they share their stories, answer questions, and engage in games with the crowd. When they ask people to share their personal experiences related to trafficking, more than 20 individuals come forward. "I believe awareness is the key to tackling human trafficking," says Diep. Ha, a representative from the United Nations, agrees that spreading awareness is the top priority, particularly in poor, rural areas along the border. She also believes that reducing poverty would help prevent women from being lured to China for work, another common tactic used by traffickers. During our visit to the border, we received a call from the government informing us that police had just rescued five girls who were about to cross the border with a trafficker. We met the girls, who were just 14 years old. They revealed that they had been promised $600 to work in China by a neighbor from their same village, and had not informed their parents of their plans. The neighbor is now under arrest.

The Vietnamese police have been able to rescue women even after they have crossed into China, thanks to cooperation with Chinese authorities. Nguyen Tuong Long, the head of the government's social vice prevention department in Lao Cai, notes that last year they successfully rescued and returned 109 Vietnamese trafficking victims. "Our collaboration with the Chinese police has allowed us to dismantle trafficking rings and rescue women who were being forced into sex work at brothels deep inside China," Nguyen says.

Trafficked women who are not rescued during raids often have to find ways to escape on their own. Some of them have reported contacting their families from China, but were unable to receive help from the police because they did not know their exact location. Lan and Nguyen, for example, ended up in the same town in China. After two years, they managed to sneak out of their homes and take a taxi to a local police station, all while fearing that their husbands' families would find them. The Chinese police investigated and eventually returned them to Vietnam. Although they were finally free from their forced marriages, the women paid a heavy price, as they were forced to leave their babies behind. Lan says that if she were to see her daughter again, she would apologize for abandoning her. "I hope she'll have a better life there," she says.

Both Lan and Nguyen recall that their teachers had spoken to them about trafficking in school, but at the time, neither believed it could happen to them.

The Trump brand, which was once synonymous with success, luxury, and elegance, has undergone a drastic transformation in just two years. What was once a symbol of sophistication and high-end quality is now associated with racism, sexism, and xenophobia. This shift in perception has not only tarnished the brand's reputation but also had a ripple effect on the Trump children's business ventures. The polarizing nature of the brand makes it a liability, as evidenced by Nordstrom's decision to drop the Ivanka Trump line. While the company claims the move was based solely on sales results, it's likely that the brand's negative connotations played a significant role. The Trump brand has become so controversial that Nordstrom may have seen it as a risk to be associated with it too closely. By dropping the line, Nordstrom can maintain a neutral stance while avoiding any perceived support for the Trump administration. At the same time, the company must tread carefully to avoid appearing opposed to the brand, as publicly provoking a president can be a risky move. This delicate balancing act is particularly challenging when selling a product line. Nordstrom's decision to stop carrying the Trump brand due to poor sales was likely an attempt to distance themselves from a controversy. However, with Donald Trump, things rarely unfold smoothly. Trump responded to the news on Twitter, defending his daughter Ivanka and attacking Nordstrom, writing "My daughter Ivanka has been treated so unfairly by @Nordstrom. She is a great person...terrible!" While Trump is not the first president to come to his family's defense, his habit of using social media to criticize individuals and companies has raised the stakes for brands.

In the past, politicians have defended their family members from criticism. For example, in 1950, President Harry Truman's daughter was the subject of a negative music review, prompting Truman to send a stern letter to the critic. However, Trump's behavior on social media has created a unique challenge for brands. As a father and businessman, Trump's tweets can have significant consequences for companies and individuals.

Most brands aim to remain politically neutral, avoiding any perceived allegiance to one party or the other. Nordstrom, for instance, recently tweeted that "We hope that offering a vendor's products isn't misunderstood as us taking a political position." Unfortunately, the Trump brand has become closely tied to the Trump administration, making it difficult for the brand to maintain a neutral stance.

As a result, the Trump brand, including the Ivanka Trump line, faces significant challenges moving forward. To succeed, the brand team must be prepared for a tough year and manage expectations accordingly. They should also be proactive in explaining any sales drops and conserve resources. Additionally, the team should focus on reducing polarization and finding ways to appeal to a broader audience. "The Trump brand's fortunes will likely recover if it can secure early successes and broaden its appeal. For retailers and licensees, it's crucial to remain neutral and avoid being perceived as taking a stance on the Trump brand. In most cases, this means refraining from making statements or taking actions that could be misinterpreted as support. The goal is to maintain a neutral stance, rather than risking a public backlash from the President, as Nordstrom experienced. As Nordstrom and other retailers have already distanced themselves from the Trump brand, it's clear that a rebranding effort is necessary. Until then, most brands will likely keep a safe distance from the Trump brand."

President Trump acknowledged on Wednesday that his travel ban would benefit from public approval, so he made a case for himself as an expert on terrorism. Trump suggested that many Americans, including those without access to classified briefings, underestimate the threat of terrorism against the United States. Speaking to a gathering of sheriffs at a Washington hotel, Trump stated, "Terrorism is a tremendous threat, far greater than people in our country understand." The President hinted at information gleaned from his classified briefings, saying, "Believe me, I've learned a lot in the last two weeks, and terrorism is a far greater threat than the people of our country understand." Former White House press secretary Ari Fleischer, who served under President Bush during the 9/11 attacks, noted that all presidents use "realistic, worst-case scenarios" to push their agendas. However, he cautioned that this tactic can be abused and undermine an administration if taken too far. "Like anything, you can go too far," Fleischer said. "You can exaggerate, get facts wrong, or hype it to a degree where you lose credibility." Nevertheless, using worst-case scenarios to drive an agenda is a long-standing tradition in American politics, Fleischer added. Trump has successfully employed this tactic in the past, using fear-mongering to rally his supporters during the 2016 campaign. In his June Republican National Convention acceptance speech, Trump declared, "People are scared, and the attacks on our police and terrorism in our cities threaten our very way of life. Any politician who does not grasp this danger is not fit to lead our country." As a result, more Americans viewed terrorism as a pressing concern in 2016 than at any point since 2003. According to a CNN poll released in 2016, a staggering 71% of Americans believed that further acts of terrorism were highly likely to occur in the United States within the next few weeks, a level of concern not seen since March 2003. As President, Trump employed a two-pronged strategy. Firstly, he used alarmist language to promote his travel ban to a skeptical public. Secondly, he implied that he possessed confidential information about the need for the ban, which the judges overseeing the legal challenges did not have access to. The public is deeply divided on Trump's executive order, which prohibits citizens of seven Muslim-majority countries from entering the US for 90 days, suspends all refugee immigration for 120 days, and indefinitely halts the Syrian refugee program. According to a Quinnipiac University poll released on Wednesday, a majority of voters disapprove of key aspects of Trump's order. The poll found that 51% of the public opposes suspending travel to the US for 90 days from seven countries, 60% opposes suspending all refugee immigration for 120 days, and 70% opposes indefinitely suspending the Syrian refugee program. Trump's order was presented to a three-judge panel of the 9th Circuit Court of Appeals on Tuesday, where lawyers from Trump's Justice Department clashed with the states of Washington and Minnesota. The court is expected to rule on the order by the end of the week. In a recent address to a group of sheriffs, Trump dismissed the arguments against his travel ban, claiming that even a "bad high school student" could understand the language of his order and find in his favor. In contrast, after high-profile attacks in San Bernardino and Paris, President Barack Obama offered words of reassurance, stating, "The threat from terrorism is real, but we will overcome it." Obama also urged vigilance, saying, "Let's be vigilant, but not afraid," in his final speech as President. "Islamic State (ISIS) will undoubtedly attempt to harm innocent people, but they cannot prevail against America unless we compromise our Constitution and fundamental values in the fight against them. Even George W. Bush, who, during the run-up to the Iraq War and in the context of homeland security, sometimes fueled fear, remained measured in his response to the 9/11 attacks. In the aftermath of the deadliest terrorist attack in US history, Bush urged Americans to carry on with their daily lives, saying, 'We cannot let the terrorists achieve their objective of instilling fear in our nation, causing us to abandon our daily routines, and disrupting our economy.' Bush also reflected on the United States as a beacon of freedom, where immigrants are drawn to the dream of liberty and where citizens demonstrate calm in times of crisis and compassion in the face of suffering.

A notable example of Bush using fear to his advantage was his push to establish the Department of Homeland Security in 2003. At the time, Bush would regularly review his morning 'threat matrix' - a document detailing potential threats produced by the Department of Homeland Security - and use it to promote his plan to combat terrorism. In his speech announcing the new agency, Bush acknowledged that it's impossible to predict or prevent every attack, saying, 'In a free and open society, no department of government can completely guarantee our safety against ruthless killers who operate in the shadows.' Nevertheless, he emphasized that the government would take every necessary step to protect the country and its people."

Senator Richard Blumenthal reported that Judge Neil Gorsuch, President Trump's nominee, expressed disappointment and dismay to him about Trump's attack on a federal judge on Twitter. Within 30 minutes, Gorsuch's spokesperson, Ron Bonjean, confirmed that the nominee had indeed used those words during their meeting. Several other senators, including Republican Senator Ben Sasse of Nebraska, later corroborated that Gorsuch strongly criticized Trump's public attacks on the judiciary. In an MSNBC interview, Blumenthal recalled that Gorsuch had specifically told him to feel free to share their conversation about the disheartening and demoralizing impact of Trump's attacks. However, Trump responded to Blumenthal's account by questioning his credibility, citing a long-standing controversy over Blumenthal's claims about serving in Vietnam. Trump's tweet accused Blumenthal of misrepresenting Gorsuch's comments, while also raising questions about the coherence of the White House's messaging. The controversy arose in response to Trump's recent criticism of federal judges who have ruled against his immigration ban, including a tweet in which he labeled one judge as a "so-called judge." In the tweet, Trump called the judge's opinion "ridiculous" and predicted it would be overturned. On Wednesday, President Trump escalated his criticism of the judiciary, claiming that judges on the 9th Circuit Court of Appeals might rule against his appeal to reverse a temporary stay on his travel ban due to political considerations rather than the law. Senator Richard Blumenthal reaffirmed his account of Neil Gorsuch's comments, telling CNN's Chris Cuomo on "New Day" that he "absolutely and accurately" conveyed what Gorsuch told him. Blumenthal suggested that President Trump may not be aware of Gorsuch's views, stating, "Maybe he simply hasn't been informed, and that's the reason for his tweet." Former Senator Kelly Ayotte, who is helping to advance Gorsuch's nomination, released a statement on Thursday saying that Gorsuch has expressed his disapproval of any criticism of a judge's integrity and independence, describing it as "disheartening and demoralizing." Ayotte added that Gorsuch has made it clear he cannot comment on specific cases or political matters due to judicial ethics. Republican Senator Ben Sasse of Nebraska also confirmed that Gorsuch criticized Trump's attacks on the federal judge during a meeting, stating that Gorsuch "got pretty passionate" about the topic, particularly when discussing Trump's "so-called judge" tweet. Sasse described Gorsuch as a strong advocate for an independent judiciary, saying, "This is a guy who welled up with some energy. He said any attack on any brothers or sisters of the robe is an attack on all judges." The President's jab at Blumenthal's military service is a reference to Blumenthal's past inaccuracies about his service during the Vietnam era. Blumenthal received multiple military deferments to avoid being drafted into the Vietnam War, ultimately joining the Marine Corps Reserve without being deployed to Vietnam. However, he has repeatedly claimed to have served in Vietnam, which he later apologized for in 2010. In contrast, Trump, who was also eligible for the draft during the Vietnam War, did not enlist, instead obtaining multiple student deferments and a medical deferment for a bone spur to avoid the military draft.

Senator Chris Coons, a Democrat from Delaware, plans to ask Judge Gorsuch about his commitment to judicial independence during their personal meeting, citing President Trump's recent comments about judges. Coons stated in an interview with CNN's Alisyn Camerota that Trump's involvement in the nomination process is not constructive and may hinder Gorsuch's chances of being confirmed. Coons emphasized that judicial independence is crucial, especially given Trump's recent comments.

Trump's tweet on Thursday may complicate the upcoming hearings for Gorsuch, who will likely face questions from Democrats about the President's tweets. Liberals have expressed concerns about Gorsuch's record and have questioned how he will demonstrate independence from the President. Additionally, Trump is scheduled to meet with red state Democrats for lunch in an effort to win their support for Gorsuch's nomination. CNN's Ashley Killough, Jeff Zeleny, and Eugene Scott contributed to this report.

Guadalupe Garcia de Rayos, a mother of two from Arizona, has been deported to her native Mexico, according to Carlos Garcia, director of Puente Arizona. Garcia de Rayos was taken into custody during her routine check-in with US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) in Phoenix on Wednesday and was ordered to be deported. ICE officials said she was detained due to a removal order issued by the Department of Justice's Executive Office for Immigration Review, which became final in May 2013.

Garcia de Rayos, a mother of two, had gone to her regular check-in with ICE in Phoenix on Wednesday, but her meeting with immigration officials took an unexpected turn when she was taken into custody and ordered to be deported. "Lupita has been doing yearly check-ins with ICE and nothing happened, but this is a different time," said Lucy Sandoval, an activist who has been working with Garcia de Rayos' family.

Immigration advocates believe Garcia de Rayos' detention reflects the Trump administration's tough stance on illegal immigration. Her attorney told CNN affiliate KNXV-TV that she could be the first Arizonan to be deported under President Donald Trump's new executive order, which prioritizes removing undocumented immigrants with a history of arrests. Under the new policy, any undocumented immigrant convicted or simply charged with a crime who hasn't been adjudicated could be deported, a departure from the Obama administration's policy, which only prioritized deporting undocumented immigrants convicted of a felony, serious misdemeanor, or multiple misdemeanors.

Garcia de Rayos was arrested in a workplace raid in 2008, convicted of felony impersonation, and served six months in ICE detention before being released later that year, according to CNN affiliate KPHO/KTVK-TV. Originally from Mexico, she was living in the country without legal documentation. Immigration officials said she was detained due to a removal order issued by the Department of Justice's Executive Office for Immigration Review, which became final in May 2013. According to ICE, Ms. Garcia De Rayos has a prior felony conviction from March 2009 for criminal impersonation, which she obtained a false Social Security card for employment. Before her meeting with ICE, Garcia de Rayos prayed, saying she wanted to confront the situation. Despite warnings from activists, who offered her sanctuary, she decided to attend the meeting. "She wanted to confront this," said Sandoval, an activist. "She was brave... She's a woman of faith, and they were praying and hoping for a change of heart." On Wednesday evening, seven people were arrested outside the Phoenix ICE office when protesters tried to block an agency van from taking Garcia de Rayos away. It was unclear whether she would be deported immediately or held at a detention center. The protests were mostly peaceful, but police reported that some individuals refused to stop despite repeated warnings. Garcia de Rayos' husband and teenage children joined the protesters outside ICE headquarters. When asked what she would ask President Trump if she could, Garcia de Rayos' daughter Jacqueline said, "I'd ask him, 'Why would he want to take her from me?' She hasn't done anything wrong, and I'm not scared of him." Immigrant rights group Puente Arizona blames former Maricopa County Sheriff Joe Arpaio's policies for Garcia de Rayos' situation, saying she is a victim of his crackdown on immigration. One of Arpaio's most notable tactics to combat illegal immigration in Arizona was enforcing identity theft laws. Puente, a plaintiff, claimed that the workplace raids, including the one that resulted in Garcia's arrest nine years ago for using a fake Social Security number, were unconstitutional and amounted to racial and ethnic profiling. Although the case was lost on appeal, Arpaio eventually disbanded the task force responsible for the raids. 

President Trump's immigration executive orders could significantly expand the authority of individual immigration officers and dramatically increase efforts to detain and deport undocumented immigrants. The order outlines specific categories of undocumented immigrants that immigration law enforcement officials should prioritize for removal, a response to criticism that the Obama administration did not enforce immigration laws stringently enough. 

Under the Obama administration, immigration officials prioritized the removal of undocumented immigrants who posed a threat to public safety or national security, had ties to criminal gangs, committed serious felonies, or were habitual misdemeanor offenders. Trump's order goes further, using a broad definition of "criminal" and granting a single immigration officer the discretion to determine threats to public safety. The order prioritizes removing deportable immigrants who have been convicted of any crime, are charged with a crime and have not been resolved, have committed acts that could lead to a criminal charge, have engaged in fraud or misrepresented themselves in an official matter, have abused public benefits, have failed to comply with a final removal order, or, in the judgment of an immigration officer, pose a risk to public safety or national security.

According to Russian state-run news agency Tass, Russian President Vladimir Putin held a phone call with Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan to express his condolences over the tragic accident that resulted in the deaths of several Turkish military servicemen.

A statement released by the Russian Ministry of Defense reported that Russian fighter jets were engaged in a combat mission to destroy ISIS militants' positions in the area. The statement revealed that General Valery Gerasimov, chief of the General Staff of the Russian armed forces, extended his condolences to Turkish General Hulusi Akar for the men killed in an unintended attack by a Russian plane. The statement added that the heads of the General Staff agreed to intensify their joint efforts and exchange information about the situation on the ground.

Turkey and Russia have a history of tensions over military incidents. In November 2015, Turkey shot down a Russian fighter jet, killing one pilot and injuring another, sparking disagreements over whether the plane had violated Turkish airspace. Tensions escalated in December when the Russian ambassador to Turkey, Andrey Karlov, was assassinated at an art gallery in Ankara, with the shooting captured in real-time photos and videos that quickly went viral worldwide. Despite these incidents, Turkey and Russia have also collaborated to broker ceasefires in the Syrian civil war.

A groundbreaking discovery has overturned a long-held theory in the archaeological community that the Dead Sea Scrolls were only found in specific caves at the Qumran cliffs, which are managed by Israel in the West Bank. According to Dr. Oren Gutfeld, one of the project's lead archaeologists, "Until now, it was widely accepted that the Dead Sea Scrolls were discovered only in 11 caves at Qumran, but now there is no doubt that this is the 12th cave." The entrance to the cave was littered with pottery shards, broken scroll storage jars and their lids, as well as neolithic flint tools and arrowheads. As the team dug deeper, they encountered a cave-in, which was later found to be intentional, hiding a 16-20 foot tunnel. Inside the tunnel, they discovered three broken storage jars with lids, cloth coverings, and a leather strap that once held the scrolls. The team believes that looters ransacked the cave in the 1950s, leaving behind pickaxes as evidence. "I imagine they entered the tunnel, found the scroll jars, took the scrolls, and even opened them, leaving everything behind, including the textiles and pottery," said Gutfeld. Over the past few years, researchers have suspected that Dead Sea Scroll fragments have made their way onto the antiquities black market. Gutfeld notes that the recent resurgence of interest in the Dead Sea Scrolls has prompted authorities and researchers to conduct a thorough survey of all the caves at Qumran in the Judean desert. According to Gutfeld, this is likely just the beginning of a series of significant discoveries, given the hundreds of caves still to be explored. "It's a massive project, a complex operation," he said in a phone interview. "Despite 60 years of excavations, we're still finding new caves containing materials that shed new light on the scrolls." The excavations are part of "Operation Scroll," a collaborative effort between the Hebrew University of Jerusalem, the Israel Antiquities Authority, the Israel Nature and Parks Authority, and the Civil Administration of Judea and Samaria, as announced in a recent news release.

Doctors at Narayana Health City in Bangalore gathered to brief local reporters on the intricacies of a rare case on Thursday. The unnamed boy was born with polymelia, a congenital defect characterized by extra limbs or organs, often deformed. Dr. Sanjay Rao, a senior pediatric surgeon at Narayana Health City, who performed the procedure, emphasized that such cases are unpredictable and not limited to any specific socioeconomic group. The boy's parents granted Rao permission to share the case publicly. According to a paper in the Journal of Clinical Imaging Science, polymelia is a genetic disorder that can arise from chromosomal abnormalities or environmental factors. In the boy's case, a "parasitic twin" developed when an embryo grew into conjoined twins, but one twin ceased to develop, leaving extra limbs or organs attached to the other. This rare condition made the surgery, which took place last week, particularly challenging, said Rao. The procedure required a team of 20 medical professionals, who had to meticulously map the boy's anatomy before the operation to ensure a successful outcome. Rao explained that the complex anatomy meant a significant amount of pre-operative work was necessary to identify shared structures, blood vessels, and define a "road map" to guide the surgery and minimize blood loss. The exact number of cases of polymelia and their likelihood of occurrence remain unknown, but Dr. Rao described it as an uncommon condition. The hospital has dealt with four cases in the past decade, including one in 2008 involving a baby girl named Lakshmi Tatma, who was born in Bihar with four legs and four arms. Tatma's story received widespread attention, attracting thousands of devotees who believed she was a reincarnation of Laxmi, the four-armed Hindu goddess of wealth.

The latest case involves a boy born on January 21 in a government-run rural health center in Puladinni village, Karnataka. Although the birth was uneventful, doctors quickly realized the boy's extra limbs required specialized medical care. He was transferred to a local hospital before being taken to Narayana Health City, over 200 miles away, with his parents the day after his birth. The arduous journey took a severe toll on the infant, who was admitted to the hospital on January 24, just three days old, and required oxygen support due to dehydration.

In India, cases like these are often shrouded in superstition and stigma, especially when children are born with characteristics reminiscent of Hindu deities. However, the boy's parents, Lalitamma and Chennabasava, were quick to recognize that their son's condition required immediate medical attention. "Times are changing, and young parents are becoming more aware of superstitions," said Dr. Rao.

The baby is expected to be discharged within the next week, and Narayana Health City has pledged to provide his follow-up care, including corrective surgery, free of charge. The boy's father, a farmer, is grateful for this support. "Rao notes that there may be some minor cosmetic concerns in the future that could potentially require minor surgical procedures, but overall, the child is expected to have a normal and healthy childhood."

Vladimir Kara-Murza, 35, has been hospitalized in grave condition for the second time in two years, and his wife, Evgenia, blames the Kremlin for his illness. Evgenia claims that the Russian government and President Putin are responsible for what happened to her husband two years ago and are now creating a climate that encourages similar behavior. However, CNN cannot independently confirm her claims, and Russia has denied any connection to Kara-Murza's illness. Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov told CNN that it is "pure nonsense" to link Kara-Murza's illness to President Putin.

Doctors at the hospital where Kara-Murza is being treated say they are still unsure what caused his illness, but agree that it was triggered by a "toxic substance." Kara-Murza's lawyer, Vadim Prokhorov, said he has no direct proof that his client was poisoned, but doctors have diagnosed him with "acute intoxication by an unidentified substance." Evgenia said the risks are now more serious due to her husband's previous illness in 2015.

Kara-Murza is still too weak and ill to speak, but has been communicating by blinking his eyes. As of Thursday, he began breathing on his own. Evgenia is terrified every time her husband returns to Russia, and this latest incident has left her worried about his safety.

Kara-Murza, who lives part-time in Virginia with his wife and three children, was in Russia to promote a documentary about the assassination of his late friend, Boris Nemtsov. Nemtsov was shot to death on a bridge near the Kremlin in February 2015. Kara-Murza became ill four months later. Evgenia, Kara-Murza's wife, told CNN that she is "absolutely terrified" every time her husband travels back to Russia to work on opposition projects, but she emphasizes that he is a "Russian patriot" committed to his cause. As the deputy leader of the Freedom Party and a member of the Open Russia foundation, Kara-Murza is part of an organization of anti-Putin activists advocating for open elections, a free press, and civil rights reforms.

In a 2015 interview with CNN, Kara-Murza described the severe illness that nearly killed him. "I fell into a coma, and my major organs began failing, one by one," he said. "It started with my kidneys, then my lungs, my heart, and my liver." Kara-Murza believes that his suspected poisoning in 2015 was a politically motivated attack. "There is no other possible reason," he said. "I don't have any financial dealings, I don't have personal enemies, and I didn't steal anyone's wife."

The hospitalization of Kara-Murza has sparked outrage among US lawmakers. Senator Marco Rubio has called on the White House and State Department to question Russian authorities about the case. "Vladimir Putin does not deserve the benefit of the doubt when it comes to political assassinations and poisonings, given the frequency of such incidents under his regime," Rubio said. "I am praying for Kara-Murza's recovery." In a statement about Kara-Murza's condition, Senator John McCain delivered a subtle rebuke to recent comments by President Donald Trump that seemed to equate the US and Russia morally. "Kara-Murza knew that Putin is a killer, and he is a killer," McCain said. "He might very well be the next target." Senator John McCain emphasized that there is no moral equivalence between the United States and Putin's Russia, given his long-standing criticism of Trump's rhetoric on Russia. McCain's comments came after Trump's interview with Fox News host Bill O'Reilly, in which Trump seemed to defend Putin by saying, "There are a lot of killers. You think our country's so innocent?" O'Reilly had described Putin as a "killer." Putin's spokesman subsequently called on Fox News to apologize, but O'Reilly responded by jokingly telling the Kremlin to "check in with me around 2023." This exchange occurred amidst speculation about a potential meeting between Trump and Putin, which is still uncertain. According to Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov, while there is a common understanding that the fight against terrorism and the Islamic State should be a priority, the format of the meeting has yet to be determined, and other issues will be addressed once that is settled.

A series of violent clashes have erupted in the northern Paris suburb of Aulnay-sous-Bois after four police officers allegedly forced a 22-year-old man, identified as Théo, to the ground, beat him, and used a baton to anally rape him. The officers have been suspended pending an investigation into the excessive force they used during an identity check last week. All four officers involved in the February 2 incident have been charged with aggravated assault, with one officer also facing rape charges, according to the Interior Ministry.

Théo described the incident, saying he was walking with his headphones on when he was approached by the police. "I realized how violent their tone was, so I stood against the wall," he said. "Then, one of the policemen beat me. I saw one of them take his baton and stick it into my bum. As soon as he did that, I fell on my belly. I felt weak. It was as if my body had given up on me. Then, they handcuffed me." From his hospital bed, Théo appealed for calm, expressing his faith in the justice system. "I call to calm my city because I love it very much," he said. "Violence is not the way to support me. Justice will do its job."

The incident has sparked widespread outrage and racial tensions in the working-class Paris suburb where Théo was allegedly assaulted. Another night of violence gripped Seine-Saint-Denis, a region northeast of Paris with a large migrant population, on Wednesday, with 26 people arrested, according to a spokesperson for the local prefecture. A crowd of several hundred people gathered near Paris' Ménilmontant metro station to protest police violence. According to authorities, 17 people were arrested in Aulnay-sous-Bois on Tuesday night after protesters set fire to garbage bins and vehicles. Social media videos showed clashes between riot police and youths as fires raged through the streets. Police fired warning shots into the air to disperse the crowd, according to French reports. On Monday, hundreds of peaceful protesters marched in the same northern suburb, carrying banners that read "Justice for Theo" past a building with graffiti that read "police, rapists". Online, people shared images of the young man, accompanied by the hashtag #JusticePourTheo, and a photograph of him with bruises under his eyes and a bandage on his cheek circulated widely. The mayor of Aulnay-sous-Bois, Bruno Beschizza, released a statement on Facebook, saying he was not concerned about a repeat of the 2005 riots, which were sparked by the deaths of two teenagers while being chased by police in the nearby neighborhood of Clichy-sous-Bois. "We are angry," the Mayor's office said in a statement on Wednesday. "Sometimes our anger is expressed peacefully, and sometimes not." Beschizza, who had called for a strong government response, said President François Hollande's visit to Aulnay-sous-Bois on Tuesday showed that the state supported the community. Hollande visited Theo at the suburban hospital where he has been treated since the incident, and a photo shared on Twitter showed the President standing at Theo's bedside. In his tweet, Hollande said Theo "reacted with dignity" and urged him to trust in the justice system. Socialist presidential candidate Benoît Hamon has demanded a diligent and transparent investigation into the incident. A tweet from him stated that police "represent the Republic that protects" and emphasized the urgent need to "restore trust." Those who know him, including friends who have described him as a fun-loving person who never speaks out of hate, say he is a sociable individual who loves to laugh with everyone. "He's a person who loves to have fun with everyone," said Hicham, a friend who has played soccer with him. Théo, a soccer enthusiast who plays at the Institute of Private Football in Aulnay-sous-Bois, is a passionate fan of the sport. His athletic background is evident, as his sister Aurélie is a professional handball player for Le Havre AC, a French women's club. In an interview with BFM on Tuesday, Aurélie reported that her brother remains in critical condition, and it is still unclear what the consequences of the attack may be, although doctors are discussing the possibility of incontinence.

Tiger Woods, a former world No. 1, withdrew from the Dubai Desert Classic after the first round due to back spasms, sparking concerns about his ongoing fitness following a 17-month layoff to recover from multiple back surgeries. In a video interview with former R&A chief executive Peter Dawson for Dubai's Vision Magazine at the Burj Al Arab hotel, Woods acknowledged that he may never feel great again due to his extensive medical history.
