"I feel good, but not great," he said. "I'll always be a little sore, but as long as I can function, I'm okay with that." Woods revealed that he experienced "dark times" during his lengthy recovery, doubting whether he would ever play golf again. "It was a tough road," he said in an interview with CNN's Living Golf show. "There were times when I couldn't get out of bed, couldn't move, the pain was too great. Anyone who's had nerve pain in their back knows what that's like. I didn't know if I'd ever play golf again, and I didn't know this time last year." Woods made his comeback in a limited field event in the Bahamas in December, showing promise by leading the field in birdies, although costly errors led to a 15th-place finish. He missed the cut in his next event, the PGA Tour's Farmers Insurance Open at Torrey Pines in California last month, and struggled to a five-over 77 on the first day in Dubai before withdrawing. Tiger Woods appeared to be moving cautiously around the Emirates Golf Club course, but denied feeling any pain afterwards, stating, "I wasn't in pain at all. I was simply trying to hit good shots, and unfortunately, I wasn't doing a very good job." It's been over eight years since Woods' last tournament win, and nearly 14 years since his last major victory in 2008. Woods is set to compete in the Genesis Open at Riviera Country Club in California from February 16-19, followed by the Honda Classic at PGA National in Florida the following week. Beyond that, his schedule remains unclear, with the year's first major, the Masters at Augusta, set to take place in Georgia from April 6.

When announcing that Roger Federer would be his guest at an exhibition event in Glasgow, Andy Murray warned his rival against trying the deep-fried Mars bars, a sweet treat invented in Scotland. "I tried one last year and it was absolutely horrific," Murray said with a smile. "Trust me, stay away from them." The unusual snack, which originated in Scotland in the early 1990s, gained international recognition after being mentioned on the Jay Leno Show in 2004.

At the launch of "Andy Murray Live 2017" in east London, the Olympic champion expressed his excitement about Federer's upcoming appearance at the SSE Hydro on November 7. "It's incredible that he's agreed to do it," Murray said. "We're all very lucky to have him on board." Federer, 35, has been a popular figure in tennis for years, and Murray praised his willingness to play in places he hasn't been before. "He wants to give his fans the opportunity to see him play," Murray explained.

This year's event will feature a singles match between Murray and Federer, as well as a doubles match between Murray and his brother, Jamie, and former British number one Tim Henman and showman Mansour Bahrami. All proceeds will go to charity. After offering Federer advice on avoiding the deep-fried Mars bars, Murray said he would also learn from Federer's recent Australian Open triumph and consider taking longer breaks from the sport. Despite being out of competitive action for six months due to injury, Roger Federer made a stunning comeback to win his 18th Grand Slam title in Melbourne last month, defeating Rafael Nadal, who was also recovering from injury, in the final. In contrast, Andy Murray, who had a busy but successful end to 2016, was eliminated in the fourth round by world No. 50 Mischa Zverev, the lowest-ranked player he had lost to at a major tournament since 2006.

"It's incredible what Roger did in Australia after such a long break," said Murray, who ended 2016 as the world's top-ranked player after winning five titles between October and December. "In tennis, we often play a lot of matches in a short period, so coming into an event fresh can be a significant advantage. Roger and Rafa were both returning to action after a long break, and they both played exceptionally well, so maybe we can all learn from their approach."

Murray emphasized that he didn't consider his early exit from the Australian Open, where he was considered the favorite after Novak Djokovic's second-round loss, as a missed opportunity. "The end of last season was tough for me," he told CNN. "I played a lot of tennis in a short space of time, and I needed to reflect on that. I've never been in a situation where I've competed in the latter stages of nearly every tournament for four months, so I had to adjust my approach."

Murray also noted that even if he had advanced to the quarterfinals, he would have faced a tough draw, with Roger Federer, Stan Wawrinka, and Rafael Nadal all potential opponents. "A lot of people think Roger is the greatest player of all time, and Rafa is certainly one of the best. Stan Wawrinka was also in my section of the draw, so it was always going to be a challenging path ahead."

Bill Gates, the 61-year-old co-founder of Microsoft and philanthropist with an estimated fortune of nearly $85 billion, is driven by a mission to tackle some of the world's most pressing issues. In a recent interview with CNN, Gates discussed his commitment to combating disease and famine. According to Gates, the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation is dedicated to addressing diseases prevalent in poor countries, such as malaria, HIV, diarrhea, and pneumonia. The foundation is investing heavily in combating mosquito-borne diseases in Latin America, and Gates proudly noted that significant progress has been made in reducing the number of children under five affected by diarrhea from 13 million to 6 million over the past 25 years.

When asked about the biggest challenges facing the globe, Gates emphasized that while it may not be possible to completely eradicate disease, science has provided the tools to make significant progress in combating the leading causes of death. He believes that disease could be cut in half, ultimately reducing the risk of death for children in poor countries to a level comparable to that of children in other parts of the world.

As for inspiring scientific innovation in the next generation, Gates suggests that understanding the world's problems is a powerful motivator. He then rushed off to his next appointment, spreading his message and resources to further his mission.

Regarding famine, Gates offered a straightforward solution: increasing food productivity. He noted that Africa, in particular, lags behind Europe and the United States in terms of food productivity, with the continent producing only one-fifth as much food per capita as these regions. "To improve agricultural productivity, Gates suggested introducing better seed varieties, accessing fertilizer, and utilizing cell phones to enhance market information availability. He noted that African countries could learn from the experiences of certain Asian nations that have successfully overcome famine and significantly boosted crop production. Despite ongoing challenges, Gates maintains an optimistic outlook, stating that the current trend is positive. He cited the decline in violence, increased understanding of science, and improved treatment of women as evidence of progress. While there is still much work to be done, Gates believes that the world has made significant strides in the past 30 years, and the situation is far better than it was three decades ago."

From the Swiss Alps, a thrilling ski jump launches skiers from a standstill to 90 miles per hour in just six seconds, making it the steepest start gate in the world. Located at the luxurious St. Moritz resort, this challenging course is not for the faint of heart. As part of the Alpine World Ski Championships, the world's top skiers will take on the men's downhill course, starting with the daunting jump that requires a gondola lift and a 178-step climb to access. On Saturday, the gold medal hopefuls will don their skis, approach the edge, and take the leap of faith. This course is truly one-of-a-kind, and its unique design is intentional. "People and television need stories," says Bernhard Russi, a former Olympic champion and course designer. "They want to show the world what these athletes can do and how steep it is." 

The course is carved into the rock face at an altitude of 3,000 meters, featuring a 45-degree gradient that forces TV cameramen to abseil just to capture suitable footage. And trust us, you don't want to look down.

Thanks to advancements in technology and innovative architecture, modern wine cellars can now replicate the natural environment almost anywhere. Whether situated atop a hill or built into a bunker, beautiful wine storage solutions can be found in unexpected locations. According to James Molesworth, senior editor of Wine Spectator, "today, it's just as easy to install a wine cellar in a 33rd-floor apartment as it is in an underground cellar." Molesworth highlights Château Cheval Blanc in Bordeaux as a prime example of an above-ground wine cellar. "For me, the key is combining visual appeal with practicality and efficiency," Molesworth notes.

Above ground, Château Cheval Blanc's undulating white facade, designed by Christian de Portzamparc, blends seamlessly into the French countryside, complete with its own lush rooftop. Spanning 19,685 square feet, the avant-garde cellar bathes artfully arranged rows of concrete white vats in natural light. "All the vats are made of cement and have a pear-shaped design, corresponding to the parcel sizes on the vineyard," Molesworth explains. Each vat is carefully labeled with the plot number, capacity, grape variety, and date planted, allowing Cheval Blanc to meticulously manage the vineyard's fine details. "By dedicating individual vats to each plot, the winemaking team can harvest each parcel at their discretion and manage smaller and smaller vinifications before blending," Molesworth says. "In essence, they're handling the vineyards at its smallest scale, then assembling the final blend from that."

Another unconventional cellar is Hong Kong's Crown Wine Cellars in Shouson Hill, discreetly located on the south side of Hong Kong Island. Deep beneath the earth, 60 feet underground, lies a network of former military bunkers that now house a series of 1,000-square-foot wine cellars. The cellars are accessible through a concrete tunnel that opens into chambers protected by 3-foot-thick reinforced concrete walls. While the exterior may appear rugged, the interior features state-of-the-art climate-control technology to preserve the rare vintages stored within. According to Molesworth, an ideal cellaring environment requires a quiet, stable environment with minimal vibration, ideal conditions that include approximately 70% humidity, stable temperatures between 50-55 degrees Fahrenheit, and little to no light. As Adam Bilbey, a wine specialist with Sotheby's, notes, wine should be stored in a dark space to prevent ultraviolet light from destroying it, and it should be kept lying still at a perfectly horizontal angle. Among the most impressive wine cellars is that of US billionaire William Koch in Palm Beach, Florida, which pays homage to traditional European cellars. This underground labyrinth, featuring Austrian red bricks and custom-built arched doorways, houses a selection of wines from his 20,000-bottle collection, one of the largest in the US. According to Bilbey, the attention to detail required to create this masterpiece was fitting, given the legendary collection of wine it houses. Explore some of the world's most beautiful wine cellars in the gallery above.

Researchers have found that women with brain characteristics typically associated with males are three times more likely to have autism than women with more "feminine" brain patterns. However, the opposite is not true, and there is no evidence to suggest that men with more "feminine" brain patterns are less likely to develop autism. Autism is a neurodevelopmental disorder that affects children early in life, causing them to miss typical milestones of maturity. Common symptoms of autism include difficulties with communication and repetitive behaviors. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, about one in 68 children in the United States has been diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder. The term "spectrum" refers to the wide range of symptoms, abilities, and challenges that individuals with autism can experience. For example, some people with autism may struggle with eye contact or following simple directions, while others may excel in math. As they grow older, some children with autism may learn to function independently, while others may require significant support to perform everyday tasks. Interestingly, autism spectrum disorder is two to five times more common in males than females, according to Christine Ecker, lead author of the study and a professor at Goethe University in Frankfurt, Germany. Some researchers believe that sex differences in symptoms contribute to the higher diagnosis rate among males, while others propose that sex-related variations in brain anatomy may also play a role. The new study aimed to investigate whether differences in brain anatomy could contribute to the higher risk of autism among males. Specifically, the researchers examined cortical thickness, which refers to the depth of gray matter across the surface of the brain's cortex. In an email, Dr. Ecker explained that previous research has shown that females tend to have a thicker cortex than males in various brain regions. Additionally, previous studies have found that cortical thickness is significantly altered in individuals with autism. The study included 98 high-functioning adults with autism (49 men) and 98 adults without autism (51 men) who were all roughly in their mid-20s. The researchers excluded participants with a history of psychiatric disorders, head injuries, genetic disorders, or medical conditions that affect brain function, as well as those taking mood stabilizers or other medications. Each participant underwent an MRI brain scan, and the researchers used a software program to derive cortical thickness patterns for each. After anonymizing the data, Dr. Ecker and her team made predictions about the participants' sex based on cortical thickness and physical characteristics, which they referred to as the "brain phenotype." "We found that brain phenotype ranged from being typically female to typically male, with varying degrees of male and female characteristics in between," Dr. Ecker said. She emphasized that, regardless of biological sex, brains fall along a continuum, with extreme male and female characteristics at either end, and that the middle range is healthy and normal. The study found that 68.1% of biological female brains fell closer to the female extreme, while 74.5% of biological male brains fell closer to the male extreme. While cortical thickness did not always accurately identify female or male brains, the researchers discovered a cluster of sex-related brain structure differences that allowed them to accurately separate males from females in most cases. Researchers have developed a method that can accurately predict biological sex based on brain anatomy, with an accuracy rate of approximately 74%. The team, led by Dr. Ecker, found that individuals with brain characteristics typical of males were more likely to have autism, regardless of their biological sex. Specifically, female participants with brain anatomy typical of males were three times more likely to have autism than those with typical female brain anatomy. According to Dr. Ecker, this approach could potentially be used to estimate autism risk by analyzing how "male" or "female" an individual's brain is. The researchers have only studied adult brains so far, but they hope to apply their method to younger age groups in future studies. Early diagnosis and intervention are crucial for children with autism, and early training has been shown to be effective in normalizing their behavior.

Dr. Tuong-Vi Nguyen, an assistant professor at McGill University, has reviewed the study and described it as "provocative" with "good methodology." However, she suggests that the findings should be rephrased to accurately reflect the results. According to Dr. Nguyen, the study suggests that high-functioning female individuals with autism are more likely to have brain characteristics typical of males, but it does not confirm that a male-typic brain is a predisposition to autism. She notes that the study did not find a significant decrease in autism risk among males with female-typic brain anatomy. While the study is interesting, Dr. Nguyen emphasizes that it is too early to use neuroimaging tools to predict autism, and the results do not change current clinical management practices.

The exhibition delves into South Africa's rich cultural heritage, showcasing seven pivotal moments in the country's history. Alongside this, sculptures, clothing, and ornaments from the same era are displayed alongside artwork to provide context. One of the exhibition's highlights is the loan of the gold treasures from Mapungubwe, which feature small gold figurines found in the royal graves of the former capital of the first kingdom of South Africa. These treasures take the form of animals and status symbols, such as crowns. Notably, one of these treasures, the golden rhino, is now featured on South Africa's highest honor, the Order of Mapungubwe, which has been awarded to notable individuals like Nelson Mandela, Zwelakhe Sisulu, and Doris Lessing.

The exhibition "South Africa: the art of a nation" offers a unique opportunity to explore the extensive and diverse history of South African art, said Hartwig Fischer, Director of the British Museum. "It's a chance to challenge audience preconceptions, just as our visitors have come to expect from a British Museum exhibition." The exhibition is on display until February 26 at The British Museum.

The city of PyeongChang is set to welcome nearly 3,000 athletes from around 100 nations to the first Winter Olympics held in South Korea, from February 9 to 25, 2018. This event marks the beginning of a series of high-profile sporting events in Asia over the next four years, with Tokyo hosting the 2020 Summer Olympics and Beijing hosting the Winter Olympics in 2022. To avoid confusion with North Korea's capital, Pyongyang, the PyeongChang resort, located 50 miles south of the demilitarized zone, has changed its name for the Games, capitalizing the "C" for the first time. A record 102 gold medals will be up for grabs across 15 disciplines at PyeongChang 2018, with four events making their Winter Olympic debuts, including Big Air snowboarding, which will give the Games a youthful vibe. A $78 million, 50,000-capacity temporary Olympic Stadium, which will host the opening and closing ceremonies, is set to be completed in September and is one of six new venues being built. In total, 13 venues, split between PyeongChang and neighboring city Gangneung, will be used during the 17-day Games.

As the 12-month countdown begins, however, South Koreans have been distracted by other events. The country's Constitutional Court is deliberating a motion to impeach President Park Geun-hye over a corruption scandal, which sparked weeks of protests in Seoul. This is a far cry from the enthusiastic reception that greeted the 2011 announcement that PyeongChang, located 180km east of Seoul, would host the Winter Olympics. The organizing committee of the 2018 Winter Olympics in PyeongChang, South Korea, is facing a sponsorship shortfall due to companies' reluctance to sign up for deals. The total cost of the Games is estimated to be around $10 billion, a significant decrease from the $50 billion spent on the 2014 Sochi Winter Olympics. Lee Hee-beom, president of PyeongChang 2018, acknowledged that the political scandal and economic situation have affected the Games' preparations. He expressed hope that the Olympics can help overcome the negative image created by unsubstantiated rumors surrounding the scandal. Lee emphasized that the Games are crucial for restoring national pride and encouraged critics to focus on the positive aspects of the event. He also expects the upcoming one-year countdown event to boost global awareness of the Olympics.

The 2018 Winter Olympics are taking place in a province that was heavily affected by the 1950-53 Korean War. Despite South Korea's initial rejection of North Korea's proposal to co-host the Games, Lee urged North Korea to participate by sending athletes to the event. He emphasized the importance of the Olympic principle of promoting peace, stating that anyone who loves peace should have the right to participate, without exception. "North Korea is, in fact, the norm."

Or, alternatively:

"North Korea is a typical example of the kind of regime that..."

Or, if you want to convey a sense of criticism or warning:

"North Korea is a stark reminder that rogue states can thrive in today's world."

Let me know if you'd like me to suggest more rewrites!

"Do you have a romantic partner? How do you plan to achieve your career goals? When do you envision getting married and starting a family? Why not consider returning to your hometown and working with your uncle's company? And, more importantly, why do you feel the need to be concerned about your weight? The pressure to conform to societal expectations and start a family can be overwhelming, leading many young Chinese individuals to seek creative solutions. For instance, some young people have been known to hire actors to pretend to be their romantic partner during the Spring Festival holiday period, which ends on Saturday. According to Yue Qian, an assistant professor at the University of British Columbia, "Young people are delaying marriage, but their parents still expect them to follow the traditional timeline of getting married and having children."

The pressures to conform to societal norms have led to the widespread popularity of a viral video, "A Spring Festival Survival Guide," which has garnered over a million views across various platforms in the past month. The video, which includes a song with a defiant chorus, is a humorous take on the traditional Spring Festival stresses and a celebration of individualism. Interestingly, the video was created by a traditional chamber choir, the Rainbow Chamber Singers (RCS), which was founded in 2010 by conductor Jin Chengzhi and a group of his fellow students at the prestigious Shanghai Conservatory of Music. The choir performs traditional-style choral pieces every six months, showcasing their talent and creativity." Since 2016, Jin has been experimenting with his own compositions, blending serious music with humorous lyrics and social commentary. One of the choir's earliest hits was "Where On Earth Did You Leave the Key, Zhang Shichao?", a kazoo-infused critique of ungrateful roommates. The group followed up with "So Far, the Sofa is So Far", an anthem for China's "overtime dogs" - millions of underpaid millennials working long hours for demanding bosses. The choir's music tackles the stresses common to young people, notes Eric Fish, author of "China's Millennials", and the growing resistance against them. "Young people are increasingly pushing back against the pressure to get married quickly and pursue the most stable and lucrative job," Fish said. Jin, who describes himself as a "rational optimist", draws inspiration from his own experiences and anxieties, but hopes his songs can bring people understanding and hope for life. "Although 'So Far, the Sofa is So Far' describes the miserable overtime life of young workers, the core of the song is about choosing one's own lifestyle," he said. "These conflicts are worth discussing because they're happening in our daily lives. Whether it's working overtime or the generation gap, I believe we're responsible for society and can amplify young people's voices." In contrast to traditional Chinese choral music, which is often conservative and limited to groups singing "red songs" (music from the founding of the People's Republic or the Cultural Revolution), the Rainbow Chamber Singers aim to revitalize the genre. "Good music should be diverse," Jin emphasized. "'If you stick to something without a genuine passion, the art will lose its authenticity.' Their approach has resonated with audiences of all ages. After a performance, I was touched to find four elderly women from Anhui, aged 70, waiting backstage for my autograph," Jin shared. "Speaking out is crucial As China's millennials become more confident and influential, they are creating and consuming pop culture that reflects their concerns and fosters a sense of unity around specific issues. In recent years, there have been numerous media articles, personal stories, and memes about the pressure to conform to traditional family expectations," Fish noted. "I believe these reflect a growing discontent among young people with outdated attitudes towards life." In this sense, he added, the choir's song serves as "a call to action to stand up and resist." "Behind the increasing visibility of the pressures they face is also the younger generation's growing desire for self-expression," Yue said. "It's not necessarily a rebellion. I think the younger generation wants to connect with the older generation and hope they can understand their perspectives and life choices." And for Jin, at least, one family has taken the message to heart: "My relatives all listened to 'What I Do Is For Your Own Good.' So I had a very comfortable Spring Festival.""

Note: I made some minor changes to the wording and sentence structure to improve clarity and flow, while trying to preserve the original meaning and tone of the text.

For law enforcement agencies investigating sex trafficking cases, online ads can hold crucial clues. However, the sheer volume of ads makes it impractical for them to manually scan each one for potential leads. That's where TraffickCam comes in - a simple phone app that leverages crowdsourced photos of hotel rooms to aid in locating victims and prosecuting traffickers. By turning on their phone's GPS and uploading photos of the room from four angles, travelers can contribute to TraffickCam's database, which law enforcement can then use to match suspected trafficking victims with their locations. TraffickCam's advanced image analysis tools convert the photos into valuable data points, including patterns on carpets, wall art, and landmarks outside the window. These data points play a critical role in identifying the location of the room. Developed by Exchange Initiative and Washington University researchers, TraffickCam was made possible by a $100,000 matching grant from the Congregation of the Sisters of St. Joseph and private donations through the St. Louis Community Foundation. "This is a straightforward way for citizens to take a stand against sex trafficking by simply taking photos," says Kimberly Ritter, director of development for Exchange Initiative. Since its launch in June 2016, TraffickCam has added over 150,000 hotels to its database, with over 100,000 users actively contributing. Ritter hopes that even more people will join the fight against sex trafficking by using the app. While tracking down traffickers, Ritter notes that even if a database identifies the location of a hotel room, it's a matter of luck whether the victim is still present. This is because traffickers often post photos from one location to advertise their services in another, she explains. Another common tactic is for traffickers to operate from a central location and post ads in multiple cities, then transport the victims to different cities based on the responses they receive. "In most cases, local girls working with local pimps will use local photos," says Sergeant Adam Kavanaugh, supervisor of the St. Louis County Multi-Jurisdictional Human Trafficking Task Force. He believes TraffickCam could aid investigators in identifying hotels and preparing effective sting operations in these situations. However, when it comes to tracking down "travelers" - trafficking victims who are moved across the country - the app may be more useful in tracing their movements across state lines. "We can then make a federal case based on interstate commerce," says Kavanaugh, which could result in a longer sentence for a convicted trafficker. Before rolling out TraffickCam to law enforcement agencies nationwide, it is being tested by Kavanaugh and the St. Louis County Police Department. "We're currently beta-testing the St. Louis area, and we're getting positive hits," he says, referring to ads that match hotel room photos in the database. After initial testing in this small area, Kavanaugh is optimistic about TraffickCam's potential to identify both hotel rooms and the routes traffickers use. "Technology plays a crucial role in modern law enforcement, and this app is just one more tool that can help make our job safer and more efficient," says Ritter. He hopes to make the app available to all law enforcement agencies in the US by Spring 2017 and eventually globally. "As this is cutting-edge technology, we need to refine it in the US first, and then we can explore making it accessible worldwide," Ritter explains. While global users can already download the app and upload photos to the database, Ritter notes that all uploaded photos from around the world will be stored for future use.

The app focuses on hotels because the US National Human Trafficking Hotline found that they are a common venue for sex trafficking, with nearly 10% of reported cases in 2016 taking place in a hotel or motel. Although the hotline believes the actual figure is higher, only around 10% of cases were linked to commercial-front brothels, while nearly 8% of cases involved unknown venues. Less than 5% of cases were street-based. While the app can only narrow down exact locations with a sufficient number of photos in the database, Ritter is confident that people will continue to contribute. "It's astonishing to see how many people are committed to fighting human trafficking," she says. "The more we work together to combat this crime, the better our chances of eradicating it."

NASA's quest to reach the moon got off to a dismal start 21 years ago, when the space shuttle Challenger disintegrated just 73 seconds into its flight, claiming the lives of all seven crew members on board. Last week, NASA paid tribute to the seven crew members who tragically lost their lives 14 years ago when the space shuttle Columbia broke apart during re-entry. Even on successful space missions, astronauts face numerous challenges. Those stationed at the International Space Station, for instance, are exposed to radiation levels 10 times higher than on Earth, increasing their risk of cancer. A staggering 79% of astronauts experience space motion sickness. In space, the heart deteriorates, the immune system weakens, and bones lose minerals and density at a rate of 1% per month. Fluids also redistribute themselves around the body, and for older astronauts, near vision can decline. It's no wonder that astronauts are considered heroes. Now retired, Captain Scott Kelly and Shuttle Commander Mark Kelly are part of a select group of individuals who have ventured into space, putting everything on the line for the greater good, not for personal gain. For this reason, CNN Chief Medical Correspondent Dr. Sanjay Gupta has chosen the identical twins for the CNN series "My Hero." "Looking back, it's easy to say that what they did was incredible," Gupta said. "But the reality is that they had to take significant risks. They had to say goodbye to their loved ones without knowing if they'd ever see them again. That's a difficult thing to do in pursuit of advancing human knowledge." Mark Kelly was chosen as an astronaut in 1996 and went on to fly four missions from 2001 to 2011 on the space shuttles Endeavour and Discovery. He made four trips to the International Space Station (ISS) and spent over 50 days in space. Kelly's final mission, which was also the last flight of the space shuttle Endeavour, took place in January 2011, around the same time his wife, then-Congresswoman Gabrielle Giffords, was recovering from an assassination attempt.

Scott Kelly was also selected for the space program in 1996 and flew four missions from 1999 to 2016. His missions included flights on NASA shuttles and Russian Soyuz spacecraft, and he spent a total of 520 days in space, the second-highest number of any astronaut. Scott's final mission was a unique one, as it allowed him to spend a year in space, a feat that his twin brother Mark did not achieve.

In 2012, Scott was chosen to participate in the One-Year Mission, a year-long stay on the ISS with cosmonaut Mikhail Korniyenko. The purpose of the mission was to study the effects of long-term space travel on the human body, and to do so, Scott underwent extensive testing on the ISS. However, to strengthen the results, a control subject was needed, which is where Mark came in.

The Twins Study, part of NASA's Human Research Program, brought together Mark and Scott with ten researchers to analyze samples taken from the twins before, during, and after Scott's mission. The initial findings, released in January 2016, have begun to shed light on the ways in which the human body changes when in space. At a biological level, the team found that Scott's body underwent changes, including a decline in bone formation during the second half of his mission, altered gene expression, and increased levels of a metabolite in his gut. The human body's response to the flu vaccine remained consistent in space, but the search for a hypothetical "space gene" that could have altered astronaut Scott Kelly's genome sequence continues. As part of the Twins Study, researchers conducted tests to measure the body's response, posture, and dexterity. The goal of the study is to understand how the human body will adapt to a six-month journey to Mars and how astronauts will fare when they arrive on the planet. The results of the Functional Task Test showed no significant differences between astronauts who spent six months and a year in space, but reaction time and accuracy did decrease in microgravity. According to John Charles, chief scientist at the Human Research Program, the study's findings have not identified any major obstacles to longer human spaceflight missions. The race to Mars is on, with NASA planning a mission to the planet in the near future. Scott Kelly, a retired astronaut, believes that the cost of the mission is the biggest impediment to its success, but if the cost can be overcome, the technology will follow. He has even volunteered to participate in the three-year mission. With a wealth of data on Scott's body in space, his insights are hard to ignore. The Twins Study not only aims to explore the effects of space travel on the human body but also lays the groundwork for a potential human settlement on Mars. NASA believes in redundant systems, and if it becomes feasible to make Mars similar to Earth, there would be significant value in doing so. However, as climate change affects our planet, it's essential to consider other places in the universe where humans may need to live one day. To achieve this, we must first understand the effects of space travel on the human body. The Twins Study is crucial in this regard, and when the full report is released this year, it will bring us one step closer to the Martian surface and potentially a new home for humanity.

Every woman has likely experienced some form of sexism in the workplace, such as being ignored in meetings, excluded from important discussions, interrupted, belittled, or even asked to perform menial tasks. Recently, a panel of female CFOs shared their own stories of daily sexism with a crowd of thousands of women. One executive, the CFO of a $400 million company, recalled a humiliating experience where she was asked to take notes during a meeting with her male colleagues. This kind of behavior is not a relic of the past, but rather a symptom of a culture that continues to marginalize women. The recent behavior of politicians like Senator Lindsey Graham and former Governor Mike Huckabee, who dismissed Senator Elizabeth Warren's opinions as "long overdue" and "scold-like," is a stark reminder that sexism is still prevalent. Moreover, research has shown that girls as young as five years old are more likely to assume that a "really, really smart person" is male, but by age six, they have already begun to doubt their own abilities. This shift in perception is alarming, and it highlights the need to teach confidence and self-acceptance to girls and women from a young age. By doing so, we can help break the cycle of self-doubt and hesitation that often holds women back from achieving their full potential. Confidence is a vital skill that can greatly impact one's life. I used to misunderstand confidence, viewing it as a personality trait or an emotion. However, it's actually a skill that can be developed through intentional actions. Confidence is the ability to listen to and trust your own ideas, and to take bold action despite uncertainty. It's about persisting in the face of challenges, knowing that you'll survive regardless of the outcome. As you take action, your competency grows, making it easier to step forward again in the future. Research shows that the most confident individuals are often the most respected, listened to, and admired. For women, developing confidence is particularly crucial, as a lack of confidence is often cited as a reason not to promote a woman, yet it's rarely explicitly stated. Elizabeth Warren is an exemplary model of confidence, fearlessly and unwaveringly pursuing her goals as a senator. Her courage is inspiring, as seen in her quote, "Speak your mind -- even if your voice shakes." Warren's confidence is evident in her willingness to challenge Donald Trump at every turn. It's no surprise that her interruption, beration, and silencing by McConnell on the Senate floor resonated so strongly. While she may have technically broken an arcane rule, it's striking that her male colleagues were able to read from Coretta Scott King's letter uninterrupted. Senator Tom Udall, for example, read the letter in its entirety without incident. Mitch McConnell's comment about Senator Elizabeth Warren's persistence has sparked a powerful movement, with the hashtag #ShePersisted trending on social media. But Warren's determination is a reminder that we all need to persist in the face of adversity. Despite what others may say or think, we must continue to push forward and speak up for ourselves. Here's how to do it: even when your voice shakes, speak out. No one can take away your confidence except for yourself. You don't have to feel ready or qualified, but you can still take action. Just look at Rosa Parks, who famously refused to give up her seat on a bus despite feeling shy and uncertain. In a radio interview after her historic act of civil disobedience, she said she didn't think she was capable of such a bold move. But she did it anyway. When we take action, our minds follow. That's what confidence is all about: believing in yourself and making a decision to bet on your own abilities.

Warren's bravery on the Senate floor is a perfect example of this. Despite being silenced by McConnell, she refused to be silenced and instead read the letter from Coretta Scott King outside the Senate chamber. The video of her defiance has been viewed millions of times, and her confidence has inspired countless women to speak up and take action. The message is clear: if it matters to you, persist. Confidence isn't about what others say or do, but about what you say and do. We women and our daughters need to say and do more, and we need to do it more often. It's time to take control of our own confidence and use our voices to make a difference.

In this young presidency, a new trend is emerging: shifting blame away from the White House. If the administration loses its immigration case in court, the judges are to blame. And if an attack occurs, the judges are to blame for that too. Trump has tweeted that if something happens, people should blame the Washington state judge and the court system. Similarly, if there was confusion at airports worldwide, Trump is deflecting responsibility by blaming a Delta computer outage, protesters, and the tears of Democratic leader Sen. Chuck Schumer. When asked about the decision to sign the executive order, Trump claimed that he wanted to take more time to implement it, but "the law enforcement people" told him otherwise. He said that he was hesitant to sign the order, but was convinced by the prospect of "a whole pile of people... with very evil intentions" entering the country before the restrictions took effect. In essence, Trump is saying that he's just a messenger, not responsible for the decision. It's worth noting that when was the last time a president went out of his way to stoke fear about a possible terror attack? Trump did just that on Wednesday, claiming that he knows more about the threat of terrorism than the public does, and that it's a greater threat than people understand. He said, "Believe me, I've learned a lot in the last two weeks, and terrorism is a far greater threat than the people of our country understand." While spreading fear may be a deliberate tactic to garner support for a ban, it's a campaign strategy that doesn't sit well in the Oval Office. It's clear that there's more to learn about the complexities of government and public service. As President, Trump's connection to government is relatively short, unlike his predecessors who have spent years serving in public office. During his campaign, he frequently boasted about buying the favor of public servants, a stark contrast to the norms of public service. Moreover, he has never held a CEO position in a publicly traded corporation. Instead, he's been the chairman of a private family business, surrounding himself with individuals indebted to him and family members. This starkly contrasts with the realities of the presidency, where he must navigate co-equal branches of government and foreign leaders who are responsive to public opinion in their own countries. The exception, of course, is his friend Vladimir Putin. In the business world, Trump is accustomed to being the supreme authority, but in the political sphere, he struggles to accept the notion of separation of powers. When 9th Circuit judges questioned lawyers, he deemed them "disgraceful." However, the idea that the branches of government don't simply obey the President's every command is anathema to him, rooted in his lifelong experience of being the ultimate authority. It's not a failure of democracy; it's the very essence of it. As Judge Gorsuch would attest, the system is designed to work this way.

The US ambassador to the United Nations has called for a strong condemnation of Russia's actions in eastern Ukraine, describing the situation as dire and demanding that Russia respect Ukraine's sovereignty and territorial integrity. The United States stands in solidarity with the people of Ukraine, who have endured nearly three years of Russian occupation and military intervention. The ambassador emphasized that the US will maintain its Crimea-related sanctions until Russia returns the Crimean Peninsula to Ukraine. This statement comes as violence in eastern Ukraine has surged, with dozens killed and over 11,000 explosions reported along the front line in a single day, according to the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe.

However, the Trump administration's stance on Russia sanctions is unclear, as Vice President Mike Pence has suggested that the US may lift sanctions in exchange for joint action against ISIS and international terrorism. This mixed signal has left Ukrainian diplomats seeking clarification from the White House, as they believe sanctions are a crucial tool in their diplomatic efforts. In Kiev, there is concern that if the US withdraws its support for sanctions, it could trigger a chain reaction, with European Union states such as Italy and Greece following suit. The Trump administration has hinted that it will lift sanctions on Russia, but in a gradual process. As violence surged in eastern Ukraine, the White House announced that it would relax sanctions imposed by the Obama administration on Russia's Federal Security Service. Could the next move be the reversal of the expulsion of Russian diplomats ordered by Obama in his final days in office? One thing is clear: tensions along the front line in eastern Ukraine have never been higher, and the risk of a full-scale escalation is real. Both sides have moved heavy weaponry out of storage and positioned it close to each other. Multiple Launch Rocket Systems, banned by the Minsk agreement, are back in use. The human toll is devastating: dozens of deaths in recent days have brought the total death toll since the conflict began in 2014 to nearly 10,000. The flashpoint industrial city of Avdiivka, home to 20,000 people, has seen most of the action. The city's coke and chemical plant, which provides heating to the surrounding community and raw materials for Ukraine's vital steel industry, is at risk of triggering a humanitarian and ecological disaster if shelling continues, according to Alexander Hug, Deputy Chief Monitor of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe. Moreover, fighting has resumed in previously quiet areas, including those near the strategic port city of Mariupol. Although Ukraine is better prepared for battle than it was at the start of the conflict, there are concerns that the rebel side is positioning itself to capture more territory. The aftermath of Debaltseve's crushing defeat makes it unlikely that Kiev will ignore the escalating aggression from the rebel side. If sanctions are lifted, they may have no choice but to escalate the situation, which could lead to anxious and unpredictable actions from Kiev. During my recent visit to Ukraine, I sensed a growing sense of abandonment among its people, who can no longer rely on traditional international security guarantees. As Ukrainian parliamentarian Nataliya Katser-Buchkovska emphasized, Ukraine needs reassurance from the "guarantors of the Western order" that it will not be left to face outside aggressors alone. While the Minsk agreements have had little effect in bringing peace to eastern Ukraine's battle-weary population, they remain the only framework signed by all parties, setting standards for behavior in a conflict that has displaced over 3 million people and could force many thousands more to flee. The White House's contradictory messages about Russia could be the spark that pushes this conflict beyond the point of no return.

Despite suggestions that it should take a more active role, the country showed little interest in intervening in North Korea's military affairs, citing the strained relationships between Pyongyang and Washington and Seoul as the main reason. North Korean state media hailed Sunday's missile test as a success, claiming that a previously undisclosed part of its arsenal, the Pukguksong-2 intermediate-range missile, was launched under the supervision of leader Kim Jong Un. The test is in violation of UN Security Council resolutions, which prohibit North Korea from conducting ballistic missile launches aimed at curbing its development of nuclear weapons. China's Foreign Ministry condemned the launch, stating that it is opposed to any activities that violate the resolutions. "Under current circumstances, it is crucial that all parties refrain from provoking each other or taking actions that escalate tensions on the Korean Peninsula," said ministry spokesman Geng Shuang at a press briefing. "As I have repeatedly emphasized, the root cause of the North Korea nuclear missile issue lies in the conflicts between North Korea and the United States, as well as between North and South Korea." Despite being North Korea's most important ally, China has taken a tougher stance on the country's nuclear program in recent years, voting in favor of UN sanctions and issuing condemnations after provocative military tests. Russia's Foreign Ministry also condemned the test, calling it a "defiant disregard" of UN resolutions, and the first since US President Donald Trump's inauguration. Russia and China were part of the Six Party Talks, a diplomatic effort launched in 2003 to curb North Korea's nuclear program, alongside the US, Japan, North Korea, and South Korea. The United Nations Security Council has scheduled an urgent meeting for Monday afternoon to discuss North Korea, following a request from the US, South Korea, and Japan. The meeting comes as Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe was visiting President Trump in the US when North Korea launched the missile, which landed in the Sea of Japan. Abe condemned the test as "absolutely intolerable," while President Trump pledged that the US "stands behind Japan, its great ally, 100%." Japan's chief Cabinet secretary, Yoshihide Suga, described the launch as a "clear provocation to Japan and the region," and Tokyo has already lodged protests with North Korea through its embassy in Beijing. The Pukguksong-2 missile, which was tested on Sunday, has raised concerns that North Korea may be closer than previously thought to developing a long-range intercontinental ballistic missile. The nuclear-capable missile is capable of traveling between 3,000 and 5,500 kilometers, according to state media. A US official reported that the missile tested flew 500 kilometers before landing in the Sea of Japan, and was launched from North Pyongan province. The Pukguksong-2 is believed to use a solid-fuel engine, which enables faster launch and greater mobility, according to a South Korean Joint Chiefs of Staff spokesman. The Joint Chiefs of Staff believe that North Korea used a cold-launching system, where the missile is initially lifted off the ground using pressure and then ignited during its flight, rather than igniting it on the ground. This approach is considered less stable, according to the spokesman. In a statement, Kim expressed satisfaction over the country's acquisition of another powerful nuclear attack capability, which he said adds to the nation's overall military might.

When Prime Minister Justin Trudeau visits the US, he will find a White House that is vastly different from the one he encountered during his previous visits, when he found a leader with a similar liberal worldview and youthful energy. During those visits, then-President Barack Obama often met with Trudeau, offering guidance on how to effectively advocate for progressive policies. Now, Trudeau faces a new challenge, as he must balance his desire to maintain a strong relationship with the US with the need to represent the concerns of anxious Canadians who are eager for him to address Trump's more controversial views. This meeting marks Trump's third official visit from a head of government, following earlier visits from the British and Japanese prime ministers, as well as Israeli leader Benjamin Netanyahu, who is scheduled to arrive on Wednesday. In his first three weeks in office, Trump has focused on shared priorities in his bilateral sessions, but Trudeau, who is 45 years old and a liberal, will present a very different leader from the ones he has met with previously. Despite their differences, aides in Washington and Ottawa say that Trump and Trudeau will aim to emphasize their neighborly relationship during their first face-to-face meeting, but their distinct styles will be on full display during a midday news conference. While disputes between the US and Canada are rare and usually not contentious, there have been disagreements in the past, such as over the import of softwood lumber and the construction of the Keystone XL pipeline, which Canada supports. However, under Trump's presidency, the differences between the two countries could become more pronounced. Trudeau has made a point of actively welcoming refugees fleeing war in Syria, even visiting the Toronto airport in 2015 to greet a planeload of migrants. When Trump issued his contentious executive order restricting Syrian refugees from entering the country, Trudeau took to Twitter to post a sharp message: "To those fleeing persecution, terror, and war, Canada welcomes you, regardless of your faith. Diversity is our strength. #WelcomeToCanada." The tweet was accompanied by a photo of the Prime Minister greeting a young girl during his 2015 visit to the airport. Although Trudeau didn't directly criticize the immigration order, which is currently facing legal challenges and remains on hold, he indicated that he would discuss a range of issues with Trump, including areas of agreement and disagreement. "We'll be discussing all sorts of things that we align on," he said, "and we'll also have respectful conversations about the areas where we don't see eye-to-eye." The refugee policy divide between Trudeau and Trump is just one of several areas of disagreement between the two leaders, who have also expressed vastly different views on climate change and economic policy. Trump has pledged to renegotiate the North American Free Trade Agreement, which includes Mexico, the US, and Canada, although detailed talks about the new accord's terms are unlikely to take place on Monday.

Adele swept the top awards for song and record of the year for "Hello" and album of the year for "25" at the night's ceremony, but then surprised everyone by saying that she thought Beyoncé deserved the album of the year award instead. "My artist of my life is Beyoncé," Adele said, praising the "Lemonade" album as "monumental," "well-thought-out," and "beautiful." She continued, "You are our light" and credited Beyoncé with empowering her friends and black friends, saying, "You make them stand up for themselves and I love you, and I always have and I always will." While some on Twitter were uncomfortable with Adele's comment about her "black friends," many others praised her for acknowledging the album's impact on women of color. Adele's heartfelt words left Beyoncé visibly emotional, with the singer appearing to respond with "I love you" from the audience. Beyoncé's "Lemonade" album had already sparked controversy since its release, including criticism from police organizations over the imagery and themes in the video for her "Formation" single and her Super Bowl 50 halftime performance, which featured dancers in Black Panther-inspired costumes. The Beyoncé controversy is more significant than you might think. Throughout her career, Beyoncé has been unapologetic about using imagery to spark conversations about culture, race, and empowerment. During her acceptance speech for Best Urban Contemporary Album for "Lemonade," she reiterated her commitment to this approach. She emphasized the importance of showcasing diverse images to her children, so they can grow up in a world where they see themselves reflected in their families, media, and society at large - from the news to the Olympics, the White House, and the Grammys. Beyoncé's goal is for every child, regardless of race, to feel confident in their beauty, intelligence, and capabilities. She believes it's crucial to learn from the past and recognize the patterns that lead to repeated mistakes, in order to create a more inclusive and equitable future.

The winners of the Grammy Awards are indicated with an asterisk (*):

* Album of the year: "25" by Adele *
* Record of the year: "Hello" by Adele * and "Formation" by Beyoncé *
* Song of the year: "Formation" by Khalif Brown, Asheton Hogan, Beyoncé Knowles, and Michael L. Williams II * and "Hello" by Adele Adkins and Greg Kurstin *
* Best new artist: Kelsea Ballerini, The Chainsmokers, Chance the Rapper *, Maren Morris, and Anderson.Paak *
* Best urban contemporary album: "Lemonade" by Beyoncé * and "Ology" by Gallant
* Best pop duo/group performance: "Closer" by The Chainsmokers featuring Halsey, "7 Years" by Lukas Graham, "Work" by Rihanna featuring Drake, "Cheap Thrills" by Sia featuring Sean Paul, and "Stressed Out" by Twenty One Pilots *
* Best rock song: "Blackstar" by David Bowie *, "Burn the Witch" by Radiohead, "Hardwired" by Metallica, "Heathens" by Twenty One Pilots, and "My Name Is Human" by Highly Suspect
* Best rap album: "Coloring Book" by Chance the Rapper *, "And the Anonymous Nobody" by De La Soul, "Major Key" by DJ Khaled, "Views" by Drake, "Blank Face LP" by ScHoolboy Q, and "The Life of Pablo" by Kanye West
* Best country solo performance: "Love Can Go To Hell" by Brandy Clark, "Vice" by Miranda Lambert, "My Church" by Maren Morris *, "Church Bells" by Carrie Underwood, and "Blue Ain't Your Color" by Keith Urban

For the full list of Grammy winners, visit Grammy.com.

The city has suffered irreparable losses since the terrorist group occupied it in May 2015, with many of its priceless antiquities, monuments, and historic sites destroyed. Russia's Defense Ministry reported on Monday that it has detected an increase in truck activity near the ancient site, indicating that ISIS is planning to cause further damage to the complex. According to the statement, "We have detected an increase in truck movement near the ancient city as Syrian troops make progress in their advance on Palmyra. This suggests that Daesh (ISIS) intends to bring in explosives to inflict maximum damage on the remaining architectural relics before they withdraw." As rival forces close in on Raqqa, the question remains: when and how will they take control? Footage captured by a Russian unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) shows the uptick in ISIS truck activity, revealing the group's intention to deliver explosives and cause maximum damage to the ancient monuments before their retreat. The same footage also shows the destruction already wrought by ISIS, including the Roman theater, Tetrapylon column, Triumphal Arch, Lion of Al-lÄt, Temple of Baalshamin, Temple of Bel, and other sites. Russian topographers and archaeologists from the Institute of Material Culture History at the Russian Academy of Sciences collaborated with the Defense Ministry to conduct a photo survey of the site, producing high-definition 3D metric models of the terrain and architectural objects that offer greater detail than current satellite photos. "This allows us to gain a comprehensive and complex understanding of what the ancient city was like before the destruction wrought by barbarians," the statement said. Meanwhile, rumors circulate that ISIS is facing financial difficulties. ISIS fighters ravaged a significant portion of the ancient Roman amphitheater in Palmyra, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, in January, nearly two years after recapturing the city in December of the previous year. The amphitheater, a historic landmark, has also been used as a site for the brutal executions carried out by the extremist group. In August 2015, ISIS beheaded Khaled al-As'ad, a university professor and former director of antiquities and museums in Palmyra, after he refused to reveal the location of valuable artifacts to the militants. The group initially seized control of Palmyra in May 2015, and despite a brief push by Syrian regime forces to drive them out, the city fell to ISIS once again in December when government troops withdrew and over 4,000 militants returned. Analysis: While the Syrian regime has made gains in this battle, the war in Syria remains far from over.

The Oroville Dam, the nation's tallest, remains structurally sound. However, the emergency spillway, which plays a crucial role in preventing water from overflowing the dam during periods of high water levels, was experiencing erosion on Sunday. The damage prompted a mandatory evacuation order for cities and counties near Lake Oroville, citing concerns that the situation could pose a risk to downstream communities. The evacuation order remains in effect, with Butte County Sheriff Kory Honea indicating that it will not be lifted until the risk is better understood. "I won't lift the evacuation order until I have a clearer understanding of the potential risks involved," he said during a press conference on Sunday night. In response to the crisis, California Governor Jerry Brown issued a state emergency declaration to support local authorities with the situation and evacuations.

The situation unfolded due to heavy rainfall in Northern California this winter, which has filled Lake Oroville to the point of near overflow. The lake also receives water from the northern Sierra Nevada mountain range, which is experiencing one of its wettest seasons on record. This has raised concerns about the potential for the water to overflow the dam and flood nearby communities. Located approximately 75 miles north of Sacramento, the Oroville Dam is a critical component of the region's flood control system. The dam features two spillways - the primary and emergency spillways - designed to prevent overflow. Unfortunately, both spillways are currently experiencing significant problems. Last week, the primary spillway suffered damage due to erosion, according to the California Department of Water Resources, with photos showing a massive hole on the lower part of the structure. The emergency spillway, which is typically used as a last resort, is only activated when water levels reach 901 feet in elevation. For the first time in its 48-year history, the dam's emergency spillway was put to use over the weekend. On Saturday, a small amount of water began flowing into the emergency spillway, and the volume of water increased. By 3 p.m. on Sunday, authorities realized that the dam's emergency spillway was eroding, according to Honea. The erosion of the spillway is hazardous because it can cause the surrounding soil and debris to slide down the hill, potentially leading to a 30-foot wall of water, warned Kevin Lawson, California Fire incident commander. If left unchecked, the erosion could result in large, uncontrolled releases of water from Lake Oroville, authorities warned. Residents were urged to evacuate immediately, with Honea's office using the most urgent language possible: "This is NOT a drill." The evacuation order included all of Yuba County on the valley floor, as well as the city of Marysville. Approximately 35,000 people from Butte County, 65,000 from Yuba County, 76,000 from Yuba City, and 12,000 from Marysville City evacuated, according to California Fire. Local businesses closed, shelters opened, and gas stations were flooded with cars as residents tried to leave the area. Evacuees were stuck in traffic for hours, including Sean Dennis, who was stuck in his car for 4.5 hours, 30 miles south of Oroville. "It was pretty scary, just because of how quickly everything was developing," he said. "My wife and I managed to fill as many garbage bags as we could with whatever items we could find. We loaded both of our cars to capacity. We're not taking any risks," a resident said. According to police, rumors of looting were unfounded, as there were no reports of such activity.

Following evacuation orders, authorities observed a significant reduction in the water flowing over the emergency spillway. The flow of water on the emergency spillway eventually ceased Sunday night, after the Department of Water Resources withdrew more water from the other spillway. The primary spillway is releasing water at a rate of 100,000 cubic feet per second, aimed at reducing the amount of water flowing down the emergency spillway. Typically, the main spillway flows at a rate of 55,000 cubic feet per second.

"Our goal is to lower the lake level by 50 feet," said Cal Fire's Lawson. "If we can achieve that, it will bring a sense of calm to our efforts." So far, repairs to the emergency spillway have been delayed due to teams' inability to access the damaged area. A team will assess the situation on Monday morning, according to Bill Croyle, the acting Director of the Department of Water Resources. Authorities must act quickly, as more rain is forecasted for Wednesday.

The modern musical "La La Land" swept the British Academy of Film and Television Arts awards, taking home five awards, the most of any movie, including best film and individual honors for Emma Stone and director Damien Chazelle. The film had been nominated for seven awards and its BAFTA success comes just one day before the final Oscar ballot opens, further solidifying its position as the frontrunner for top honors at the 89th Academy Awards, which will take place on February 26. In the past decade, the BAFTA winner for Best Film has gone on to win the Oscar for Best Picture six times. Another big winner was "Lion", which received awards for Best Adapted Screenplay and Best Supporting Actor for Dev Patel. Viola Davis once again took home the award for Best Supporting Actress for her role as Rose in "Fences", extending her impressive awards streak heading into the Oscars. In a post-ceremony press conference, Davis expressed skepticism about the notion that black filmmakers and actors have had more success since the #OscarsSoWhite controversy, suggesting that the recent surge in success could be an anomaly. She noted that while African-American actors have had a lot of success in the past year, it's possible that this could be followed by a period with little representation. "I believe that what still is a deficiency is that we can have a year with a plethora of African-American movies and then the next year, nothing," Davis said. **Winners of the Night:**

* Best Film: **"Arrival"**, **"I, Daniel Blake"**, **"La La Land"**, **"Manchester by the Sea"**, and **"Moonlight"**
* Director: **Denis Villeneuve** for **"Arrival"**, **Ken Loach** for **"I, Daniel Blake"**, **Damien Chazelle** for **"La La Land"**, **Kenneth Lonergan** for **"Manchester by the Sea"**, and **Tom Ford** for **"Nocturnal Animals"**
* Original Screenplay: **"Hell or High Water"**, **"I, Daniel Blake"**, **"La La Land"**, **"Manchester by the Sea"**, and **"Moonlight"**
* Adapted Screenplay: **"Arrival"**, **"Hacksaw Ridge"**, **"Hidden Figures"**, **"Lion"**, and **"Nocturnal Animals"**

**Individual Awards:**

* Leading Actor: **Andrew Garfield** for **"Hacksaw Ridge"**, **Casey Affleck** for **"Manchester by the Sea"**, **Jake Gyllenhaal** for **"Nocturnal Animals"**, **Ryan Gosling** for **"La La Land"**, and **Viggo Mortensen** for **"Captain Fantastic"**
* Leading Actress: **Amy Adams** for **"Arrival"**, **Emily Blunt** for **"The Girl on the Train"**, **Emma Stone** for **"La La Land"**, **Meryl Streep** for **"Florence Foster Jenkins"**, and **Natalie Portman** for **"Jackie"**
* Supporting Actor: **Aaron Taylor-Johnson** for **"Nocturnal Animals"**, **Dev Patel** for **"Lion"**, **Hugh Grant** for **"Florence Foster Jenkins"**, **Jeff Bridges** for **"Hell or High Water"**, and **Mahershala Ali** for **"Moonlight"**
* Supporting Actress: **Hayley Squires** for **"I, Daniel Blake"**, **Michelle Williams** for **"Manchester by the Sea"**, **Naomie Harris** for **"Moonlight"**, **Nicole Kidman** for **"Lion"**, and **Viola Davis** for **"Fences"**

**Other Awards:**

* Outstanding British Film: **"American Honey"**, **"Denial"**, **"Fantastic Beasts and Where To Find Them"**, **"I, Daniel Blake"**, **"Notes on Blindness"**, and **"Under the Shadow"**
* Outstanding Debut by a British Writer, Director, or Producer: **"The Girl With All the Gifts"**, **"The Hard Stop"**, **"Notes on Blindness"**, **"The Pass"**, and **"Under the Shadow"**
* Film Not in the English Language: **"Dheepan"**, **"Juileta"**, **"Mustang"**, **"Son of Saul"**, and **"Toni Erdmann"**
* Documentary: **"13th"**, **"The Beatles: Eight Days a Week -- The Touring Years"**, **"The Eagle Huntress"**, **"Notes on Blindness"**, and **"Weiner"**
* Animated Film: **"Finding Dory"**, **"Kubo and the Two Strings"**, **"Moana"**, and **"Zootropolis"**
* Original Music: **"Arrival"**, **"Jackie"**, **"La La Land"**, **"Lion"**, and **"Nocturnal Animals"**
* Cinematography: **"Arrival"**, **"Hell or High Water"**, **"La La Land"**, **"Lion"**, and **"Nocturnal Animals"**
* Editing: **"Arrival"**, **"Hacksaw Ridge"**, **"La La Land"**, **"Manchester by the Sea"**, and **"Nocturnal Animals"**
* Production Design: **"Doctor Strange"**, **"Fantastic Beasts and Where To Find Them"**, and **"Hail, Caesar!"** The 89th Academy Awards honored several films, including "La La Land", "Nocturnal Animals", "Allied", "Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them", "Florence Foster Jenkins", "Jackie", and "Doctor Strange".

The winners in various categories included costume design for "La La Land" and "Florence Foster Jenkins", and make-up and hair for "Doctor Strange".

The awards also recognized excellence in sound, with winners including "Arrival", "Deepwater Horizon", "Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them", "Hacksaw Ridge", and "La La Land".

In the special visual effects category, the winners were "Arrival", "Doctor Strange", "Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them", "The Jungle Book", and "Rogue One: A Star Wars Story".

The British short animation category featured winners "The Alan Dimension", "A Love Story", and "Tough", while the British short film category included "Consumed", "Home", "Mouth of Hell", "The Party", and "Standby".

The public-voted Rising Star award went to Anya Taylor-Joy, Laia Costa, Lucas Hedges, Ruth Negga, and Tom Holland.

"In the heat, the whales' bodies can become pressurized and potentially explode, but we've taken precautions to prevent that," said Trish Grant, a spokesperson for New Zealand's Department of Conservation. "Our staff has been using a specialized tool to puncture the dead whales and release the built-up gas inside their carcasses, which was designed by a local individual for us."

Excavators will be used to relocate the dead whales further up Farewell Spit in Golden Bay, on the tip of New Zealand's South Island, to a secluded area within the nature reserve that is not open to the public. According to the Department of Conservation, approximately 400 whales died on Farewell Spit between Friday and Sunday, making it the third largest mass stranding of whales in the country's history.

The Department of Conservation spent Monday monitoring a pod of whales still in the Golden Bay area from the coastline, as concerns grew that they too might beach themselves. "We've completed our monitoring for tonight, but we'll resume our searches tomorrow," Grant said. "The whales are still in the Golden Bay area, relatively close to shore, and there's a risk they could strand overnight."

The whales were first spotted in the water late on Thursday night by a department staffer, before being found on the beaches of Farewell Spit the following morning. Hundreds of volunteers joined the rescue effort. According to Grant, Farewell Spit is considered a whale trap due to its shallow waters.

The largest whale stranding event in New Zealand occurred in 1918, when 1,000 whales stranded themselves on the Chatham Islands. The second largest was in Auckland in 1985, when 450 whales ended up on a beach. Grant noted that a variety of factors can contribute to whale beachings. "According to Grant, sometimes a diseased member within the group can be the cause - because of their strong social connections, if one individual gets into trouble, it can have a ripple effect and affect the others as well."

A White House statement described the conversation between Trump and Xi as "extremely cordial." Trump's reaffirmation of the US commitment to the "One China" policy was particularly significant for Xi. The phone call, combined with a personal letter from Trump to Xi sent two days earlier, which expressed the US interest in establishing "constructive relations" with China, helped to alleviate many of the uncertainties generated by Trump's earlier comments that the "One China" principle was negotiable. Trump's initial challenge to the "One China" principle and his threat to impose a 45% import duty on Chinese goods during the election campaign had raised concerns that the two countries were headed for a collision course. Domestic setbacks may have contributed to Trump's apparent return to the "One China" principle. Following the election, Trump felt invincible, with foreign leaders eager to court him and his popularity soaring at home and abroad. However, since taking office, Trump has faced significant domestic frustrations, with his policy initiatives facing fierce criticism and opposition from the public, media, and other branches of government. According to a CNN/ORC poll, a majority (53%) disapprove of Trump's job performance, the highest disapproval rate for a newly elected president since polls began tracking this data. As a result, Trump has become increasingly frustrated and vexed by domestic challenges, and a major confrontation with China would only add to his woes, promising to be a nasty and uncertain outcome. President Trump likely returned to the "One China" principle after reassessing the priorities of his administration's domestic and foreign policy agendas. China's successful diplomatic efforts, employing both conventional and unconventional tactics, may have contributed to Trump's reversal. In public, China has consistently emphasized that the "One China" principle is a core interest and will fight to maintain it. Meanwhile, China has pursued unconventional approaches to shape Trump's China policy, recognizing that he relies heavily on a small group of advisors, including his son-in-law Jared Kushner and daughter Ivanka Trump. To smooth relations with Trump, China has attempted to directly influence the first family. For instance, Kushner attended a dinner hosted by Chinese business tycoon Wu Xiaohui soon after Trump's election, and Ivanka Trump paid a surprise visit to China's embassy in Washington to attend a Chinese New Year reception. Behind closed doors, China may have successfully shaped Trump's position on the "One China" policy through a combination of deterrence and accommodation. While Trump's commitment to the "One China" principle has temporarily alleviated a hurdle to Sino-US relations, the future of the bilateral relationship remains uncertain. Multiple issues, including trade, the South China Sea, and North Korea's nuclear challenge, may still lead to conflict between the two countries. The US and China can take several steps to reduce tensions and foster cooperation. While the US should avoid using the "One China" principle to pressure Beijing on trade issues, China must be willing to make significant concessions. The Trump administration has a legitimate grievance due to the massive trade deficit, and China needs to address the issue of fair trade. This could involve granting US companies greater access to the Chinese market. On the South China Sea issue, the Trump administration's recent statements have been encouraging, with Secretary of Defense James Mattis emphasizing the importance of diplomacy in resolving disputes. China should not misinterpret this as a sign of weakness, but rather refrain from taking actions that could escalate the conflict. Furthermore, China should make genuine efforts to curb North Korea's nuclear ambitions, as greater efforts would not only contribute to regional stability but also strengthen Sino-US cooperation on this critical security issue. By doing so, China can demonstrate its commitment to helping the US address this complex challenge.

President Trump held a news conference that lasted an hour and fifteen minutes, creating a memorable moment in modern American political history. He displayed a rare level of anger and grievance, which is unusual for a president, especially one who has only been in office for four weeks. Trump criticized the media, saying, "I have never seen more dishonest media, frankly, than the political media." He later slammed leaks from the intelligence community, which had led to the resignation of national security adviser Michael Flynn. Trump emphasized that the leaks are real, but the news is often fake due to the prevalence of false information. This news conference was a departure from the usual dynamics of a presidential press conference, with Trump focusing on his own poll numbers, his victory over Hillary Clinton, and his views on cable TV ratings and panel discussions. Trump stated that he is taking his message directly to the people, citing the many problems his administration inherited from the previous government and economy. He described the situation as a "mess" at home and abroad. This kind of message, delivered in a straightforward and unvarnished manner, was a key factor in Trump's presidential victory. However, his approach may also offend or alarm some voters and may not alleviate concerns about Trump among political elites in Washington. Trump predicted how his news conference would be perceived by the press, saying, "Tomorrow, they will say: 'Donald Trump rants and raves at the press.'" He insisted that he was not ranting and raving, but simply stating the truth. President Trump, visibly frustrated with the media's portrayal of his administration, decided to take matters into his own hands and hold an impromptu press conference. The event was not scheduled until Thursday morning, but Trump's aides said he was eager to address the public and defend himself against negative reports.

According to a senior administration official, Trump walked into the Oval Office that morning and told his top aides, "Let's do a press conference today." The official confirmed that the idea was entirely the President's, stating, "I'm here today to update the American people on the incredible progress that has been made in the last four weeks since my inauguration."

Trump began the press conference by announcing his new pick for labor secretary, Alexander Acosta, before launching into a defense of his administration's accomplishments. "We have made incredible progress," he said. "I don't think there's ever been a president elected who in this short period of time has done what we've done."

Trump expressed his resentment towards the media, saying he was tired of picking up newspapers and turning on the TV only to hear reports that his White House was in chaos. "This administration is running like a fine-tuned machine," he insisted, despite apparent frustration with the coverage and possibly even his own aides.

In a statement that hinted at his frustration, Trump said, "I don't mind a bad story if it's true," but complained that much of what was reported about his administration was unfair. President Trump criticized the media's coverage of his initial travel ban, which restricted nationals from seven predominantly Muslim countries and caused chaos at US airports before being blocked by a federal court. "We had a seamless rollout of the travel ban," Trump said. "But we had a bad court decision, and that's the only issue with the travel ban." However, Trump also announced plans to issue a new executive order that would be tailored to the court's ruling to ensure its legality. In addition, Trump accused former Obama administration officials of leaking information about his alleged contacts with Moscow to discredit his administration. Trump faced repeated questions about whether his campaign staff had been in contact with Russia, which has dominated the news cycle. "No one I know has had contact with Russia," Trump said. "How many times do I need to answer this question? Russia is just a distraction. I haven't made a phone call to Russia in years, and I have no business dealings or financial ties to Russia."
