Trump also claimed, "I own nothing in Russia, I have no loans in Russia, and I'm not involved in any deals there." He dismissed the Russia allegations as "fake news."

The current administration is functioning efficiently and effectively."
* "The leaks are genuine, but the news reports are inaccurate."
* "I prefer to select a reporter who is approachable and cooperative."
* "I was provided with that information, but I'm not sure about its accuracy."
* "I'm simply conveying the truth, not ranting or raving, about the dishonest nature of some individuals."
* "Obamacare has led to overcrowding in public areas, and it's unclear how some individuals ended up there."
* "Reports about Russia's contacts are fabricated and based on false information."
* "It's important to note that Flynn's actions were not illegal, and he may have even done something beneficial."
* "Flynn was fired because he failed to properly inform our Vice President, and then claimed not to remember the details, which was unacceptable to me."
* "I believe I would make a decent journalist if I had chosen that career path."
* "Dealing with Russia requires a delicate approach, as demonstrated by my willingness to engage with them constructively."
* "The idea of using military force against a Russian ship is a complex issue, and it's essential to consider the potential consequences."
* "A nuclear conflict would be catastrophic and unprecedented. Both Russia and the US possess significant nuclear capabilities, and it's crucial that we maintain a positive relationship with Russia to avoid such a scenario."
* "The rollout of the travel ban was smooth, but it was hindered by unfavorable court decisions."
* "There are two distinct realities in Chicago: one is a thriving, luxurious, and safe city, while the other faces significant challenges." "Beyond the headlines, there's another Chicago that's often overlooked, but it's arguably more troubled than many of the places in the Middle East that dominate the news."

President Trump announced his new nominee for Secretary of Labor, Alexander Acosta, just one day after his first pick, Andy Puzder, withdrew his nomination. Trump highlighted Acosta's experience, stating that he has been confirmed by the Senate three times. Trump praised Acosta, saying, "I have wished him the best, we just spoke and he is going to be a tremendous secretary of labor." Acosta was not present at the event with the President. If confirmed, Acosta would be the first Hispanic member of Trump's Cabinet. Acosta, currently the dean of the Florida International University School of Law, has a background in labor law, having served on the National Labor Relations Board and clerked for Supreme Court Justice Samuel Alito. NBC News was the first to report Acosta as Trump's pick. Prior to his nomination, Acosta practiced law at Kirkland & Ellis in Washington. Trump's first pick for Labor Secretary, Andy Puzder, withdrew his nomination on Wednesday after Republican senators indicated they would not support him. Puzder, the CEO of the Hardee's and Carl's Jr. fast food chains, faced opposition from both Democrats and Republicans due to his stance on labor issues and his employment of an undocumented immigrant housekeeper. Senior GOP officials informed the White House that Puzder lacked a viable path for confirmation. "The tumultuous nomination process took a toll on Puzder, as those close to the nominee revealed to CNN that he was shocked by the intensity of the political fray."

President Trump expressed his dissatisfaction with the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals' decision to block his travel ban, stating that the new order would be tailored to address what he considers a "very bad decision". Meanwhile, the Justice Department filed a 47-page brief with the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals, arguing that it doesn't need a larger panel of judges to rehear its appeal, as a new order is forthcoming. The brief criticized the Ninth Circuit's "seriously flawed" ruling, but indicated that the President plans to rescind the order and replace it with a revised one to address constitutional concerns. The revised order would allow the country to be protected immediately, rather than continuing with potentially time-consuming litigation. The Trump administration's next move has been a topic of speculation since the Ninth Circuit refused to lift a federal judge's temporary restraining order on the executive order, which banned foreign nationals from several countries and all refugees from entering the US for a certain period. Last Friday, an unidentified judge on the Ninth Circuit requested a full court vote on rehearing the decision, a move that came at a time of uncertainty regarding the Justice Department's plans to pursue the appeal. The states of Washington and Minnesota, which brought the lawsuit, argued in their court filing on Thursday that there is no basis for rehearing the case, as the three-judge panel's opinion is "firmly grounded in precedent." Meanwhile, the nation awaits a new or modified executive order on immigration from the Trump administration, while at least one federal court is pushing forward with litigation over the original order. In Seattle, US District Court Judge James Robart, who previously halted key provisions of the travel ban, denied the Trump administration's request to delay further proceedings in his court, allowing the parties to move forward to the discovery phase of the case.

Following Flynn's resignation, Trump appointed Ret. Lt. Gen. Joseph Keith Kellogg, who worked under Flynn, as the acting national security adviser. When asked if a new candidate for national security adviser was being considered, a White House official replied, "Not to my knowledge." Harward stated in a release that he decided not to take the position because he wanted to focus on personal and family matters that would have been difficult to balance with the demands of the job. "As military personnel understand, this role requires constant, 24/7 dedication and commitment. I'm currently unable to make that commitment," Harward said. He expressed his sympathies to those who carry the weight of national security responsibilities and added, "God bless our great nation." A friend of Harward's revealed that he was hesitant to accept the position due to the perceived chaos in the White House, describing the offer as a "s*** sandwich." According to a Republican official, Harward made it a condition of taking the job that he could assemble his own team, but ultimately felt this was not possible. A senior Republican familiar with the process said that Harward's decision was largely driven by questions about the lines of authority, which could not be resolved to his satisfaction. The official described the situation as more of a matter of uncertainty rather than a disagreement. Prior to his decision, Harward served as the deputy to General Mattis when he was commander of US Central Command, which oversees military operations in Iraq and Afghanistan. Michael Flynn was forced to resign from his position in the Trump administration after reports surfaced that he had discussed sanctions with the Russian ambassador before Trump's inauguration and misled Vice President Mike Pence about the conversation. The White House claimed that Flynn's failure to disclose the details of his conversation led to a breakdown in trust between Flynn and the President, ultimately prompting his resignation. After a 30-year military career, Robert Harward became the CEO of Lockheed Martin's United Arab Emirates division. As a former employee of the National Security Council's counterterrorism office from 2003 to 2005, Harward was well-versed in the role of national security adviser and the workings of the National Security Council. Following Flynn's resignation, Harward's name was floated as a potential replacement, alongside acting adviser Kellogg and retired Army General David Petraeus, who had pleaded guilty to mishandling classified information in 2015. Retired Army Major General James "Spider" Marks, a CNN military analyst, described Harward as an "incredibly talented guy" in an interview with CNN's Erin Burnett on "OutFront." Marks declined to speculate on why Harward turned down the job, but suggested that the turmoil in the White House may have been a contributing factor. "I'm sure Bob looked at this, Admiral Harward looked at this, and said, 'Look, there's a lot of forming and storming going on right now,'" Marks said. However, Senator James Lankford, a Republican from Oklahoma, dismissed the idea that White House chaos led to Harward's decision not to accept the role, calling it "hearsay." "Am I surprised that we're still in the process of filling this position 72 hours after Flynn resigned? No, I'm not," Lankford said in an interview with Burnett.

Despite his efforts to reassure key allies, such as Germany, about the US's resolve on Russia and other issues, Vice President Mike Pence faces questions about his level of involvement in President Donald Trump's thinking on the Kremlin. On Monday, Trump fired his national security adviser, Michael Flynn, for misleading Pence about his conversations with the Russian ambassador. Pence, who had previously repeated Flynn's statements on television, only discovered he was misinformed last Friday - two weeks after Trump learned that the Justice Department was investigating the matter. As Pence seeks answers about why he was misled, Trump has shown little concern for his vice president's compromised position. Instead, Trump has portrayed Flynn as unfairly targeted by illegal leakers of classified information. At a news conference, Trump expressed frustration about how the press obtained classified information, saying, "How do they do it? Because it's an illegal process and the press should be ashamed of themselves." The incident has left Pence frustrated and dismayed, and has raised questions about how much he can be trusted as a credible representative of Trump's views in Europe, where the top concern is the US's stance on sanctions against Moscow. As Pence travels abroad for the first time since taking office, he will attend the Munich Security Conference, meet with German Chancellor Angela Merkel, and hold talks with key European leaders in Brussels. According to Derek Chollet, executive vice president at the German Marshall Fund of the United States, he expects Pence to maintain a consistent stance on Russia and commitment to Europe, similar to his views presented during the vice presidential debate last year. However, this may still leave allies wondering if Pence is truly speaking for Trump. White House aides revealed that Pence and Trump had discussed the upcoming trip, which will also involve meetings with the leaders of Iraq and Afghanistan. The aides emphasized that Pence will work to reassure US allies during his trip and dismissed concerns that he may be perceived as an unreliable voice for Trump. "I don't think any of our allies will question for a second whether the vice president is speaking on behalf of the administration, in conjunction with the President, on any matter," said a senior White House official, speaking anonymously to preview Pence's trip.

As Pence arrives in Europe, leaders are expressing deep unease, with many viewing Trump with skepticism. Few believed Trump could win the election and did little to hide their disdain for the billionaire real estate developer as he campaigned. The frenetic first month of Trump's presidency has only deepened European leaders' concerns. The resignation of Flynn this week has brought some optimism among Western diplomats who were troubled by his desire to strengthen ties with Moscow. However, widespread uncertainty remains about what steps Trump may take to begin cooperating with Russian President Vladimir Putin. Western diplomats and US officials who have met with Trump administration envoys describe mixed messages about the future of US policy toward Russia. While some US officials, including Secretary of State Rex Tillerson and UN Ambassador Nikki Haley, have reiterated that US sanctions against Russia will remain in place due to its incursion into Ukraine, others have been less definitive. The future of a separate set of sanctions imposed on Russia for its election cyber-meddling is also uncertain. The timing of Flynn's phone call to the Russian ambassador coincided with the Obama administration's imposition of those sanctions, and President Trump has left the door open to lifting them. This has raised concerns among some European leaders, who fear that the same Russian cyber intrusions could impact upcoming elections in France and Germany. The uncertainty surrounding the sanctions has also contributed to unease in European capitals, which were already on edge due to Trump's campaign trail criticisms of NATO. During his presidential campaign, Trump had described the defense alliance as "obsolete" and chastised member countries for not meeting defense spending requirements. However, since taking office, he has largely tempered these remarks. Last month, he reaffirmed the administration's support for NATO during a speech at US Central Command in Florida. Vice President Pence will aim to deliver a more consistent message during his upcoming trip to Munich and Brussels, where he will meet with NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg and other European leaders. Pence's message will focus on the importance of Russia adhering to the Minsk ceasefire agreement in Ukraine and the need for NATO to remain a cornerstone of Western security. According to a senior White House adviser on foreign policy, Pence wants to "reaffirm that we're stronger together" and reassure European leaders that the US is committed to its traditional foreign policy stance.

According to officials, the appointment is expected to be announced as early as Friday. However, some inside the White House are unhappy with the choice, with longtime Trump loyalists expressing a preference for a veteran from the campaign. "Dubke and his Crossroads associates did everything they could to undermine the Trump movement and failed," said one loyalist. The position of communications director was initially offered to Jason Miller, Trump's transition spokesman, but he declined to take the role to focus on his family. Dubke did not respond to CNN's request for comment. Dubke founded Crossroads Media in 2001 and grew the company into a prominent national firm during the 2008 presidential campaign. According to the company's website, Crossroads is "the premier Republican media services firm," and Dubke has a "unique understanding of the relationship between political strategy and public policy development." The appointment is expected to alleviate some of the pressure on embattled Press Secretary Sean Spicer, who has faced a rocky start to his tenure as the administration's official spokesman. Until now, Spicer has served in both roles, which are typically filled by separate staff members.

A meeting between US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson and Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov, held on the sidelines of a G20 summit in Bonn, Germany, takes place at a time of strained US-Russian relations and turmoil in Washington as the new Trump administration settles into its role. Tillerson's comments, made during a brief on-camera statement following the meeting, may help to alleviate concerns among US allies. "As I emphasized during my Senate confirmation hearing, the United States will consider collaborating with Russia when we can identify areas of practical cooperation that benefit the American people," Tillerson said. "Where our interests diverge, the United States will stand up for its values and those of its allies. As we seek new common ground, we expect Russia to uphold its commitment to the Minsk Agreements and work to reduce tensions in Ukraine." The White House and the Kremlin have engaged in a war of words in recent days over Crimea, the Ukrainian territory annexed by Russia in 2014. Speaking shortly before, Lavrov said that the two had a range of issues to discuss, mirroring the topics that were addressed during the January 28 phone call between Russian President Vladimir Putin and US President Donald Trump. When asked whether the turmoil in Washington could impact US-Russian relations, Lavrov replied, "We do not interfere in the domestic affairs of other countries." His comments came at the same time as US Defense Secretary James Mattis stated that there was "very little doubt" that Russia had interfered in or attempted to interfere in several democratic elections. Speaking after a NATO conference in Brussels, Belgium, Mattis described Russia's actions around the world as "aggressive" and "destabilizing." Mattis dismissed the notion of strengthening military ties with Russia, stating, "We are not currently equipped to collaborate on a military level, but our political leaders will engage and strive to find common ground." The trip to Germany by Secretary of State Tillerson comes as the Trump administration is working to alleviate concerns among European allies, while also exploring new avenues for cooperation with Russia, as advocated by President Trump despite opposition from some members of his own party. The White House is in disarray following the resignation of National Security Adviser Michael Flynn, who stepped down amidst questions about the nature of his conversations with Russia regarding sanctions before taking office. Meanwhile, Congress is investigating various aspects of Russia's alleged interference in the US election, and lawmakers are scrutinizing President Trump's ties to the country.

Selangor Police Chief Abdul Samah Mat has stated that the body of Kim Jong Nam will not be released and the autopsy report will not be made public unless DNA samples are provided by a next of kin. Kim Jong Nam died after being attacked at Kuala Lumpur International Airport on Monday. South Korean officials have alleged that he was poisoned. Three individuals have been arrested in connection with Kim's murder: an Indonesian woman, a Malaysian man, and another woman carrying Vietnamese identification. Four days after the killing, many questions remain unanswered. Here's what is currently known:

Kim Jong Nam was on his way to catch a flight to Macau on Monday morning to visit his family, where he had been living since leaving North Korea years ago. Macau, a short ferry or helicopter ride from Hong Kong, is a popular destination for gamblers from mainland China. The details of Kim's murder are still unclear, but Selangor State Criminal Investigations Department Chief Fadzil Ahmat told Reuters that Kim "felt like someone grabbed or held his face from behind." Kim felt dizzy and immediately sought medical help at an airport customer assistance counter, which led to him being taken to the on-premises clinic. Unfortunately, an ambulance was called too late, and Kim died on the way to the hospital.

The exact cause of Kim's death is still unknown. Initially, local media reported on poison needles and deadly sprays, but it was unclear whether Kim had been killed or suffered a heart attack. Later, on Wednesday, South Korea's National Assembly Intelligence Committee Chairman Lee Cheol Woo publicly stated that Kim had been murdered by "two Asian women" using poison. South Korea has not disclosed how it discovered the poisoning or what toxin was used to kill Kim Jong Nam. The autopsy results, which were completed on Wednesday, have not been released. Deputy Prime Minister Hamidi of Malaysia stated that no next of kin have come forward to claim Kim's body. There is no known motive for the killing, and no explanation has been provided for how Kim was poisoned. South Korea's Lee told lawmakers on Wednesday that North Korea was responsible for Kim's death, but he did not offer any evidence to support his claim. A South Korean legislator, Lee Chul Woo, suggested that North Korea had been trying to assassinate Kim Jong Nam for the past five years, but he did not provide any concrete evidence. When asked about rumors of North Korean involvement, Malaysia's Deputy Prime Minister Ahmad Zahid Hamidi characterized the speculation as unfounded. North Korea has requested Kim's body, but Malaysian authorities have declined to release it until their investigation is complete. The police have released grainy security footage from the airport showing two young female suspects, one of whom was wearing a blue skirt and white t-shirt with "LOL" written on it. The first suspect, a 30-year-old Vietnamese woman named Doan Thi Huong, was arrested on Wednesday morning at Kuala Lumpur International Airport, two days after the attack. She was carrying Vietnamese identification documents. Later that evening, a 26-year-old Malaysian man named Muhammad Farid Bin Jalaluddin was taken into custody to assist in the investigation. At 2 a.m. on Thursday, Jalaluddin led investigators to his 25-year-old Indonesian girlfriend, Siti Aishah, who was then arrested on suspicion of being involved in Kim's death. "No charges have been filed. Who was Kim Jong Nam? If circumstances had unfolded differently, Kim Jong Nam could have become the leader of North Korea. Born in 1971, he was the eldest son of then-North Korean leader Kim Jong Il. His mother, actress Song Hye-rim, was one of Kim Jong Il's favored mistresses, and for a time, Kim Jong Nam was the most visible of his father's sons. However, in 2001, he reportedly lost his father's favor after attempting to use forged documents to visit Tokyo Disneyland. In contrast, his half-brother, Kim Jong Un, was born to a different mistress, Ko Yong Hui, who was politically ambitious and eager to see her son succeed Kim Jong Il as leader. According to author Yoji Gomi, who wrote a book in 2012 titled "My Father, Kim Jong Il, and Me," Kim Jong Nam believed his younger brother was unfit to lead the country."

The Sehwan Hospital, a 100-bed facility, was overwhelmed with patients after the attack, said Dr. Zahid Hussain in an interview with CNN. In addition to the 200 injured, many more were transferred to larger hospitals in other cities of Sindh province, he added. Thousands of people, including families with children, had gathered at the ancient Lal Shahbaz Qalandar shrine for a Sufi ritual known as Dhamal, which involves music, chanting, and prayer. The Islamic State Khorasan, ISIS' affiliate in Afghanistan and Pakistan, claimed responsibility for the attack in a phone call to CNN. According to the Amaq news agency, which is affiliated with ISIS, the attack was carried out by a suicide bomber wearing an explosives vest. Pakistani Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif condemned the attack as "brutal" and ordered all state institutions to mobilize resources for rescue and relief efforts. In a statement, the Prime Minister said, "I have directed all the state institutions to mobilize all resources for rescue and relief after this brutal terror attack on Lal Shahbaz Qalandar's shrine." The Pakistani military blamed operatives from Afghanistan for a recent surge in attacks on the country, with Maj. Gen. Asif Ghafoor, the military's spokesman, tweeting, "Recent terrorist acts are being executed on directions from hostile powers and from sanctuaries in Afghanistan. We shall defend and respond." In another tweet, he urged the public to remain calm, saying, "Your security forces shall not allow hostile powers to succeed. We stand for our nation." Later, the military spokesman announced that the Pakistan-Afghanistan border had been closed due to security concerns. The attack comes just days after a bomb exploded during a protest in Lahore, Pakistan, on Monday, killing at least 14 people and injuring 59 others, according to government spokesman Malik Ahmad Khan. A splinter group of Pakistan's Tehreek-i Taliban, also known as the Pakistani Taliban, Jamat-ul-Ahrar, issued a statement claiming responsibility for the attack, which was emailed to CNN.

New Zealand and Australia may finally be able to enjoy some extra space, as they are situated on separate continents. New Zealand resides on a massive landmass of approximately 1.8 million square miles, known as Zealandia. This new continent also encompasses New Caledonia and several other territories and island groups. The concept of a potential continent in this region has been debated for some time, with geophysicist Bruce Luyendyk introducing the term Zealandia in 1995. Over the past decade, dedicated research has revealed that Zealandia is not just a collection of continental islands and fragments, but rather a large and distinct continental crust that warrants official recognition as a separate continent. Previously, New Zealand and New Caledonia were grouped with Australia under the umbrella term Australasia. While many would refer to Zealandia as the eighth continent, geologists often consider Europe and Asia as a single continent, Eurasia. The Geological Society of America's recent publication comes on the heels of a breakthrough discovery just last week, where scientists uncovered a "lost continent" beneath the Indian Ocean.

President Trump lashed out at reporters, resumed disputing the election results, and refused to acknowledge established facts. While some of his supporters appreciate his blunt honesty and willingness to counter critics, this approach is not suitable for the presidency. The recent news conference highlighted several concerns, not only among Democrats but also some Republicans, about Trump's behavior. By spreading false information about widespread voter fraud, he perpetuates the dissemination of misinformation from a position of power. When he insists he would have won the popular vote if not for fraud, and claims he had the largest Electoral College victory since Ronald Reagan, it's alarming for the political system and encourages legislation that could restrict voting rights. Trump remains fixated on the Hillary Clinton email scandal, despite increasing reports about his own security lapses being front-page news. Despite numerous reports linking Russia to his campaign team, Trump showed no indication of taking these revelations seriously or being troubled by them. His thin skin was evident in his insulting remarks about reporters and news organizations, leading him to prioritize attacking them over answering questions. Instead of addressing the "mess" he inherited, the President chose to deflect by criticizing the "dishonest media" for not giving him the recognition he feels he deserves. It's evident that he is not surrounded by advisors who are willing to challenge his most egregious behavior. He creates his own worldview, defends it zealously, and struggles to incorporate factual information that contradicts his beliefs. This approach can have devastating consequences for his foreign and domestic policies. It's also clear that the President remains embroiled in a bitter feud with the media, and journalists must be vigilant in monitoring and pushing back against a White House that appears reluctant to share meaningful information. History has shown that this kind of worldview can ultimately consume a President, as their paranoia, pettiness, and anger can drive them to unethical or illegal behavior in an effort to protect their reputation. During Wednesday's news conference with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, the President's impromptu statement that he was open to a one-state solution sent decades of diplomatic efforts into disarray and had the potential to spark violence rather than constructive dialogue. While Americans may have differing opinions about the President's actions, there are limits to what is acceptable. As President, the consequences of poorly thought-out statements and off-the-cuff attacks can be dangerous and far-reaching. The chaos that has engulfed the White House has created an environment in which powerful individuals, such as Michael Flynn, can act with impunity. This was a lesson learned by President Ronald Reagan, who witnessed illegal activities by members of his National Security Council in Nicaragua. As a role model for the nation, the President's behavior sets a tone that fuels rather than dampens partisan anger, which has plagued the country. The question is whether anyone in the Oval Office or the Republican Party will step in to restrain the President and whether Republicans will start to question his conduct. The withdrawal of Andrew Puzder as secretary of labor and Republicans calling for an investigation into the Trump-Russia connection are early signs that the Republican Party may be fragmenting. As Republicans on Capitol Hill watch Trump squander time on petty squabbles rather than sending them legislation, they will grow increasingly anxious about the impact on their future majority. If Trump pushes them to the brink, it would be a perilous moment for the administration. Despite boasting about his ability to make deals and get things done, President Trump's legislative record is sparse compared to other presidents at this point in their term. Most of his presidency has been marked by public spectacle rather than genuine governance. Even Trump supporters must be disappointed by the White House's handling of the immigration executive order, which was left dead in the courts due to sloppy execution. While there is still time for Trump to recover, Democrats should not be overconfident about this challenging moment. However, CNN's Jake Tapper was correct in highlighting the President's impression on voters and lawmakers, which will only deepen as these events unfold and raise questions about the kind of President we have.

President Trump has issued a series of executive orders aimed at dismantling barriers to deportations and hiring new law enforcement officials to spearhead the effort, utilizing the Department of Homeland Security to fulfill his campaign promise of tackling undocumented immigration. In a statement, Trump boasted, "We're removing really bad individuals from this country at a rate that's unprecedented. And they're the bad ones. It's a highly organized and efficient process." He also claimed, "You're seeing what's happening at the border. For the first time, we're getting gang members out, drug lords out." A White House spokesperson defended Trump's characterization of deportations as a "military operation," saying the President meant it as an adjective describing the orderly and professional manner in which his executive orders are being implemented. However, Trump's administration has clarified that it is not using the military to deport undocumented immigrants. Department of Homeland Security Secretary John Kelly explicitly stated that there would be "no use of military force in immigration operations, none." Despite earlier denials, the Trump administration has expanded the number of undocumented immigrants who are subject to deportation. According to White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer, "Everybody who is here illegally is subject to removal at any time," a policy consistent with international standards. "If you are in this country illegally, there must be a provision that allows for your removal."

Mexican official Osorio Chong expressed disagreement with the US government's recent measures, stating, "We do not agree on the different measures that have been stated by the government of the United States, which affect Mexico." US Department of Homeland Security Secretary John Kelly and Secretary of State Rex Tillerson visited Mexico to mend the strained relationship and address the growing differences between the two nations. The visit comes after months of heated rhetoric from US President Donald Trump and the implementation of new immigration measures that have significant implications for Mexico, including the potential for a significant increase in deportations back to the southern border. Osorio Chong expressed Mexico's concern about the rise in deportations during meetings with Kelly and Tillerson on Thursday. Mexican Foreign Minister Luis Videgaray also addressed the tensions, saying that Mexico perceives the Trump administration's policies as potentially harmful to Mexicans. He emphasized the importance of respecting the human rights of Mexicans living in the US, particularly in regards to illegal migration. Videgaray noted that it would take significant progress to overcome the current negative feelings between the two nations, adding that facts were needed to achieve this goal. Tillerson acknowledged that differences between sovereign countries are inevitable, but focused on shared concerns during his public comments, stating that the US and Mexico had listened carefully to each other's concerns and raised them respectfully and patiently. US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson emphasized the importance of the rule of law on both sides of the US-Mexico border, vowing to work with Mexico to curb the flow of cash and weapons from the US. However, according to a senior administration official, Tillerson's message in meetings was more forceful, stating that a successful relationship and border requires reciprocity. Ahead of their remarks, President Donald Trump predicted that Tillerson's visit to Mexico would be a challenging one, citing the need for Mexico to be treated fairly. Trump told manufacturers at the White House that the trip would be difficult because "we have to be treated fairly by Mexico." Upon his arrival, Mexican Foreign Secretary Luis Videgaray publicly reiterated that Mexico would not accept measures imposed unilaterally by another government. The trip by US Homeland Security Secretary John Kelly and Tillerson aimed to establish relationships and coordinate on bilateral issues, including counterterrorism, border security, and trade, which totals $1.5 billion daily. The officials also met with President Enrique Peña Nieto and Mexican military officials. However, their Mexican debut was marred by controversy, as the Trump administration has introduced policies that target Mexico and Mexicans as a security threat and economic burden on the US. On Tuesday, the administration issued guidance expanding the scope of deportations from a focus on criminals to include all undocumented immigrants in the US. The proposal also grants state and local law enforcement agencies the authority to act as immigration officers. Another aspect of the asylum procedure change would allow immigration officers to more easily send non-Mexican migrants back to Mexico if they entered the country on their way to the US. This could potentially result in tens of thousands of Central Americans fleeing violence, gangs, and drug cartels being sent back to Mexico. According to a Mexican official, who spoke on condition of anonymity to discuss sensitive diplomatic matters ahead of a meeting with Kelly and Tillerson, Mexico would not accept deportees who are not Mexican nationals. A second official pointed out that there is no bilateral agreement requiring Mexico to take these immigrants and that Mexico is not bound by any US presidential order. While the US may try to apply pressure, Mexico has some leverage, the official said. For over two years, Mexico has been stopping Central American migrants before they reach the US, and if Trump does not drop his "orders," it will make it more difficult for Mexico to continue this cooperation. Trump has also suggested alternative ways to apply pressure, including imposing a 20% tariff on Mexican goods entering the US and seizing remittances from Mexicans in the US. Additionally, the President has ordered Cabinet agencies to inform him of the total direct and indirect aid the US provides to Mexico, a move that some see as an attempt to gain leverage in the debate over the border wall that Trump insists will be built and that Mexico will pay for. Mexican officials have repeatedly denied that they will pay for the wall. Under the Merida Initiative, the State Department has provided Mexico with $2.6 billion since 2008 to strengthen rule of law, counter narco-trafficking, support judicial reform, and police professionalization. This does not include aid from other State Department programs. Mexico also receives funding from various other US government agencies, including Defense, Energy, Labor, Health and Human Services, Interior, the Peace Corps, the US Agency for International Development, and DHS. Kelly recently distributed an implementation memo asking his staff to calculate the amount of direct and indirect aid DHS provides to Mexico, a process that is still underway.

A correction has been made to a previous version of this story, which incorrectly reported the status of the case against Senator Leila de Lima. Although a court has ordered her arrest, she has not yet been taken into police custody. Senator Leila de Lima is accused of abetting the illegal drug trade at the New Bilibid Prison during her tenure as Justice Secretary from 2010 to 2015. On Thursday, a judge in the Muntinlupa Regional Trial Court found sufficient probable cause to issue arrest warrants against de Lima and two others. A team from the Philippine National Police arrived at de Lima's residence south of Manila and then at the Senate, where she sought refuge after learning the warrant would be served that evening. At the Senate, the sergeant-at-arms agreed to serve the warrant the following morning, as requested by de Lima earlier in a televised statement. De Lima's fellow party members in the Senate have expressed outrage over the "haste" of the arrest warrant, with a graphic reading "One for Leila" circulating on social media. Senator Kiko Pangilinan, a close ally of de Lima, urged social media users to share the graphic as a sign of their opposition to political persecution. At a press conference shortly after the arrest warrant was issued, de Lima reaffirmed that she would not flee from the cases against her. She has consistently denied any involvement in the illegal drug trade. The allegations against de Lima were first raised by President Duterte in a speech in August, which accused her of receiving payoffs from convicted drug lords who were able to continue their illegal operations from behind bars while she was Justice Secretary. The New Bilibid Prison is managed by the Bureau of Corrections, an arm of the Department of Justice. Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte won the presidency on a campaign promise to crack down on crime, particularly illegal drugs. Since taking office in June, his police force has engaged in a brutal crackdown on drug dealers and users, resulting in the deaths of thousands of suspects at the hands of law enforcement and vigilantes. Senator Leila de Lima became the target of investigations launched by Duterte's political allies after she initiated a Senate inquiry into alleged extrajudicial killings during Duterte's war on drugs. A Senate committee, led by a close ally of Duterte's, decided in October to drop its inquiry into the deaths of drug dealers and users during the early months of Duterte's presidency. In December, Duterte publicly admitted to having killed drug suspects during his time as mayor of Davao City. A former leader of the notorious Davao Death Squad has accused Duterte of ordering bombings. Duterte has responded by telling de Lima to "face the music" and claiming that the charges against her are airtight. De Lima, however, has been linked to the drug trade at the New Bilibid Prison by convicted felons who have testified against her. De Lima has countered that the government pressured these convicts to testify and that they have a personal vendetta against her. As justice secretary, de Lima had previously conducted a raid at the maximum security area of the New Bilibid Prison, which revealed a luxurious lifestyle among high-profile inmates who are now among the witnesses against her. Duterte has denied allegations that he personally threw a person from a helicopter. De Lima has vowed to take legal action to protect herself from what she perceives as political persecution. Last week, Duterte expressed confidence in the Justice Department's case against de Lima, stating that she "will have to face the music" and the charges against her.

Malaysian Inspector-General of Police Khalid Abu Bakar told reporters that the police have formally requested an interview with the North Korean embassy's second secretary, Hyong Kwang Song, who is wanted for questioning in connection with the death of Kim Jong Nam, the half brother of North Korean leader Kim Jong Un. Kim Jong Nam died last Monday after allegedly being poisoned while on his way to catch a flight to Macau from Kuala Lumpur. North Korea has strongly denied any involvement in his death, publishing an article in its state media, KCNA, which criticized the Malaysian investigation and claimed that Malaysia was responsible for his death. The article quoted a spokesman for the Korean Jurists Committee, saying that the investigation was full of weak points and contradictions.

The Malaysian police have issued Interpol notices for four suspects, believed to be back in Pyongyang, and are also seeking three North Koreans for questioning, including Hyong Kwang Song and Kim Uk Il, an Air Koryo staff member. Both are believed to still be in Malaysia. However, the North Korean embassy will not be searched, as it has diplomatic immunity.

Two women, Indonesian Siti Aishah and Vietnamese Doan Thi Huong, have already been taken into custody in connection with the alleged murder. At a press conference, Inspector-General Bakar revealed that the two women were trained to apply a liquid substance to Kim's face and then wash their hands immediately. "He dismissed their earlier claims that they thought they were on a prank show. 'They knew it was toxic, of course they did,' Bakar said. Aishah's boyfriend, Muhammad Farid Bin Jalaluddin, who was taken in for questioning, was released on bond on Wednesday. North Korea denies poison reports: Tensions between North Korea and Malaysia are escalating as the rogue state continues to criticize Malaysia's handling of the investigation. In response, Malaysian Prime Minister recalled his ambassador from Pyongyang after the North Korean ambassador accused their country of conspiring with hostile forces. A recent article published on KCNA accused South Korean conservative media of spreading a false report that Kim had been poisoned. The article also strongly rebuked Malaysia for its refusal to hand over Kim's body without DNA from a next of kin, claiming that this was a politicized move that disregarded international law and morality, and was instead motivated by sinister purposes."

Pope Francis criticized Christians who scandalize others, saying that their hypocrisy can be a grave offense. He noted that many people have been led to question the faith due to the actions of these individuals, saying that it is better to be an atheist than to be a Catholic like that. According to Francis, scandal is when one's words and actions do not align, and this is a serious issue in the Catholic Church. He gave examples of such scandals, including money launderers and business owners who take lavish vacations while neglecting their employees. In his sermon, Francis drew on the Gospel of Mark, where Jesus says it is better to be drowned than to cause others to sin. The Catholic Catechism defines scandals as including business leaders who encourage fraud, teachers who agitate students, and manipulators who turn people away from moral values. Francis' comments were aimed at protecting his flock from the negative influence of hypocritical Christians. In the United States, some Catholics have cited the church's teachings on scandal to argue that priests should not distribute Holy Communion to politicians who support abortion rights. However, Francis instead focused his criticism on greedy businesspeople, highlighting the need for authentic Christian behavior. The Pope's comments also touched on an ancient debate in Christianity: whether salvation is open to all believers or only those who live a good life on earth. The Pope made a provocative suggestion, characteristic of his straightforward manner. He envisioned a wealthy Christian arriving at the gates of heaven and boasting, "Here I am, Lord! I attended Church, I was close to you, I'm a member of this group, and I did this... Don't you remember all the sacrifices I made?" In response, Jesus might say, according to the Pope: "Yes, I remember. The sacrifices, I recall them: All tainted. All taken from the poor. I don't know you." The Pope was criticizing those who lead a double life, pretending to be devout while engaging in scandalous behavior.

This is not the first time Pope Francis has targeted Christian hypocrites. In a previous sermon, he condemned the "hypocrisy" of Christians who speak piously but fail to help others. "To be a Christian means to act: to do the will of God, and on the day of judgment, we will be asked about our actions, not just our words. The Lord will ask us, 'What did you do?'"

Pope Francis has also addressed atheists in the past. In 2013, he suggested that heaven might be open to all people, regardless of their beliefs. "The Lord has redeemed all of us, all of us, with the Blood of Christ: all of us, not just Catholics. Everyone." When asked about atheists, the Pope replied, "Even the atheists. Everyone!" He emphasized the importance of working together, saying, "We must meet one another through good deeds. 'But I don't believe, Father, I'm an atheist!' But do good, and we will meet one another in heaven." The Vatican later issued a clarification, stating that the Pope was simply emphasizing God's universal love and urging Christians and non-believers to collaborate.

"I believe one of the most significant moments in modern American history was President Trump's immediate withdrawal from the Trans-Pacific Partnership. This move allowed us to exit a trade deal and reclaim our sovereignty," Bannon said, referring to the massive trade agreement. According to Bannon, this decision was just the first step in rethinking US trade policies, and he pointed to it as one of three crucial steps Trump has taken since taking office. On the national security front, Bannon highlighted Trump's executive orders on building a border wall and strengthening immigration enforcement policies. He also emphasized the importance of Trump's efforts to dismantle the administrative state by appointing private sector individuals to key economic Cabinet positions, which will help reduce federal regulations. At CPAC, Bannon joined White House Chief of Staff Reince Priebus onstage, crediting Priebus with helping launch Trump's political career. The two men discussed Trump's electoral victory, the administration's agenda, and criticized the media together, aiming to dispel the notion that they are rivals vying for power and influence within the West Wing. "In terms of our relationship, I think the biggest misconception is everything you're reading," Priebus said. "The opposition party, or mainstream media outlets, have consistently gotten it wrong in their portrayal of the campaign, the transition, and now the administration," Bannon added. The two praised each other, insisting that their working relationship is extremely close. ("We share an office suite and are together from 6:30 am until about 11 pm each day," Priebus said.) While praising Bannon as "incredibly loyal" and "extremely consistent," Priebus described Bannon as someone who admires his "determination" and noted that he is "always kind of steady." The forum provided a rare glimpse into Bannon's thinking, which was marked by dark views of the news media, visions of a "new political order," and grand plans to reshape the US's global posture. Bannon credited Trump with staying committed to his campaign promises, saying, "Every day in the Oval Office, he tells Reince and I: 'I committed to this with the American people, I promised this when I ran and I am going to deliver on this.'" Despite their efforts to present a united front, Bannon acknowledged that he and Priebus don't always see eye-to-eye, which he believes makes them "good partners." The joint appearance was the latest attempt by the two men to dispel reports of division, instead portraying their relationship as chummy and symbiotic. In recent interviews, Bannon has praised Priebus, saying, "He's doing an amazing job." Priebus echoed this sentiment, stating, "We are executing on President Trump's agenda in record time. That's because Reince is getting the job done." The two men also joked about giving each other massages and said they talk all day long "until somebody falls asleep." According to White House sources, their account has been supported in recent weeks. A source who spoke with both Bannon and Priebus separately last week revealed that while Bannon had no negative comments about Priebus, the White House chief of staff was critical of Bannon over the phone. The two men's professional backgrounds couldn't be more contrasting. While Priebus has a long history in establishment Republican politics, having risen to Republican National Committee chairman before becoming chief of staff, Bannon built his career in the private sector, amassing wealth before leading the provocative and anti-establishment Breitbart News. Following Trump's election, their appointments to the West Wing were jointly announced, with Trump describing them as "equal partners" who would work together.

A White House official revealed on Thursday evening that the request for FBI assistance was made only after the agency expressed skepticism about the accuracy of the reports. White House officials had sought the help of the FBI and other agencies investigating the Russia matter to verify that the reports were false and that no contacts had taken place, officials said. The reports of contacts were first published by The New York Times and CNN on February 14. The direct communication between the White House and the FBI was unusual due to decade-old restrictions on such contacts. A request from the White House to influence an ongoing FBI investigation is a violation of established procedures limiting communications with the agency. Late on Thursday night, White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer disputed CNN's characterization of the White House's request to the FBI, saying, "We didn't try to discredit the story. We asked them to tell the truth." The FBI declined to comment on the matter. The discussions between the White House and the FBI began with FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe and White House Chief of Staff Reince Priebus at a separate White House meeting the day after the stories were published, according to a US law enforcement official. Initially, the White House disputed this account, claiming that McCabe had called Priebus early that morning to say that The New York Times story greatly exaggerated what the FBI knew about the contacts. However, a White House official later corrected their version of events to confirm the account described by the law enforcement official. A White House official revealed that Priebus later reached out to FBI Director James Comey and former Deputy FBI Director Andrew McCabe, asking them to discuss the New York Times story on background with reporters to dispute the allegations. According to a law enforcement official, McCabe did not share details about the case, but would not specify what he told Priebus. Comey declined the request for the FBI to comment on the story, citing the ongoing investigation into alleged communications between Trump associates and Russian nationals known to US intelligence. The White House issued a denial, with Priebus labeling the New York Times story "complete garbage." In an interview on Fox News Sunday, Priebus criticized the story, saying it was based on "no direct sources" and contained "treasonous type of accusations." He claimed that the top levels of the intelligence community have assured him that the story is inaccurate and grossly overstated, but refused to provide evidence to support this claim. CNN has previously reported that there was frequent communication between high-level Trump campaign advisers and Russian officials during the summer of 2016. Members of the House and Senate Intelligence Committees, however, confirm that their investigations into these alleged Russian contacts with the Trump campaign are ongoing, despite Priebus' assertion that there is nothing to the reports. It remains unclear what the committees will ultimately find and whether any of the information will be declassified and made public. Despite the Trump administration's efforts to push back, the investigation into Capitol Hill is delving deeper into areas that may not be comfortable for the White House. The Justice Department's procedures, outlined in memos from 2007 and 2009, prohibit direct communications between the White House and FBI on pending investigations, except in limited circumstances. According to the memos, only the Attorney General, Deputy Attorney General, Counsel to the President, Principal Deputy Counsel to the President, President, or Vice President can initiate communication on pending or contemplated criminal investigations. The memos emphasize that such communication should only occur when it is essential for the President's duties and appropriate from a law enforcement perspective. A Department of Justice spokesperson stated that Attorney General Jeff Sessions is reviewing the memos and that the Department is following the guidelines in its communications with the White House.

Meanwhile, concerns about Russia's efforts to influence individuals with ties to Trump are growing, with increasing numbers of congressional members voicing their concerns. On February 17, the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence held a briefing with Comey, during which new information about Russia was reportedly discussed. Senators James Lankford and Angus King, both members of the committee, declined to provide details about the briefing, but Senator Lankford noted that every briefing yields new information. In response to a question about Priebus' denial of the claims, Senator King expressed surprise at Priebus' categorical denial.

Representative Eric Swalwell, a Democratic member of the House Intelligence Committee, emphasized that his panel's inquiry will follow leads wherever they may lead, even if they are uncomfortable for Republicans. "The American public will want to know if the President had personal or financial ties to the Russian government," Swalwell said. This story has been updated to reflect new information and comment from the White House.

Malaysian police announced on Friday that tests on Kim's eyes and face had revealed the presence of a toxic substance. Nerve agents, such as VX, are considered the most toxic and fast-acting substances in chemical warfare, according to the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Kim, the estranged half-brother of North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, died on February 13, just before he was set to board a flight from Kuala Lumpur to Macau. Malaysian police claim that two women were instructed by four North Koreans to apply a liquid to Kim's face, which caused him to feel dizzy minutes later and ultimately led to his death. However, North Korea has rejected this version of events, stating that the women would have died if they had indeed applied a lethal chemical to their own hands. The country vehemently denies any involvement in Kim's death.

It's worth noting that VX is a binary chemical weapon, which requires two compounds to be mixed together before it becomes lethal, according to the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW). This design is typically used for the safe storage of chemical weapons.

VX works by inhibiting the function of an enzyme that helps the body's nervous system operate, leading to paralysis and suffocation. "VX is probably the state-of-the-art nerve agent," said CNN military analyst Rick Francona. "It is probably the most lethal of all the nerve agents ever designed." Symptoms can appear within seconds, and even small doses of as little as 10 milligrams on the skin can affect individuals. Larger exposure can lead to convulsions, paralysis, and deadly respiratory failure. VX is particularly dangerous when inhaled, rather than absorbed through the skin, according to Nial Wheate, a chemical weapons health expert at the University of Sydney. The official emphasized that the substance is not a skin agent, but rather a chemical that can be dispersed through the air. The nerve agent is classified as one of the most deadly substances under the Chemical Weapons Convention, which North Korea has not ratified. While it's highly lethal, experts say it's not particularly difficult to manufacture. North Korea has had the capability to produce and use nerve agents for some time. According to a 2009 report by the International Crisis Group, the country possessed a significant stockpile of chemical weapons, estimated to be between 2,500 to 5,000 tons, which could be delivered via artillery, rocket launchers, and ballistic missiles. However, an expert noted that the blast from a delivery system like a missile would likely destroy much of the VX, making it more suitable for use in close quarters through aerosol dispersal. The investigation has identified 11 individuals, although not all are considered suspects. Three individuals are currently in custody, including a North Korean man and two women, Siti Aishah of Indonesia and Doan Thi Huong of Vietnam, who are believed to have wiped Kim's face. Indonesian police previously stated that Aishah believed she was participating in a prank for a TV show, but this was vehemently denied by Malaysian authorities. "These two ladies were trained to apply the substance to the deceased's face," said a Malaysian official. "They knew it was toxic."

Diplomatic tensions between North Korea and Malaysia are escalating over the investigation. North Korea has accused Malaysia of being influenced by South Korea's initial claim that Kim was poisoned by the North, and has denied any involvement in the incident. North Korea's ambassador to Malaysia, Kang Chol, accused the host country of conspiring with hostile forces, prompting Malaysia's Prime Minister to recall his ambassador to North Korea and summon Kang. A state media article in North Korea on Thursday strongly rebuked Malaysia for its refusal to hand over Kim's body without DNA from a next of kin, claiming that Malaysia was politicizing the transfer and seeking a sinister purpose. Malaysia's police inspector-general, Bakar, accused North Korea of obstructing the investigation, stating that the North Koreans had failed to respond to requests to hand over four suspects in Pyongyang and had not assisted in locating three North Koreans believed to be in Malaysia, including an embassy employee, who are wanted for questioning. Bakar warned that if the three individuals do not come forward, Malaysia will seek arrest warrants. Malaysia has also requested assistance from Interpol, asking the international police organization to issue an alert for the four suspects believed to have trained Aishah and Huong and then returned to Pyongyang.

VX nerve gas was first developed in the United Kingdom in the 1950s as a highly toxic and deadly chemical warfare agent. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), the formula has been replicated by various countries, including the United States, Russia, Syria, and Iraq. Here's what we know about VX nerve agent:

VX is an oily liquid with an amber color, but it is odorless and tasteless. As a nerve agent, VX is chemically similar to pesticides but much more potent. In fact, it is the most toxic and deadly of all nerve agents, including Sarin, which was developed in Germany in 1938 as a pesticide. Due to its extreme lethality, VX is considered a weapon of mass destruction.

When inhaled as a vapor, VX is the quickest and deadliest form of the agent. As a liquid, it can be released into a water supply or used to contaminate food, posing a significant threat to human life. Like all nerve agents, VX works by disrupting a vital enzyme, ultimately leading to respiratory failure and death.

VX is not only the deadliest nerve agent but also the most persistent in the environment. It evaporates slowly, especially in cold conditions, making it a long-term threat. The symptoms of VX exposure vary depending on the amount of the agent ingested, with immediate effects ranging from convulsions and loss of consciousness to paralysis and death due to respiratory failure. Smaller, non-fatal doses can cause a range of symptoms, including increased heart rate, blurred vision, nausea, diarrhea, drooling, pain, and weakness. Small doses of the toxic gas VX can cause confusion and drowsiness, even in small quantities. Fortunately, antidotes are available for exposure to VX, and they are most effective when administered immediately. Is VX banned? Yes, it is prohibited as a chemical weapon under several international agreements, including the 1925 Geneva Protocol and the 1993 Chemical Weapons Convention. The 1925 Geneva Protocol was established in response to the use of poisonous gas in World War I, and it was later expanded by the 1993 Convention to include a ban on the development, production, stockpiling, retention, and transfer of chemical weapons. According to the Chemical Weapons Convention, VX is classified as a Schedule 1 chemical, which means it poses a high risk to the convention and is rarely used for peaceful purposes. Signatories to the Convention are only permitted to possess small quantities of Schedule 1 chemicals for research, medical, pharmaceutical, or defensive purposes. Both the US and Russia have previously admitted to possessing stockpiles of VX and are obligated to destroy them under the Convention. When was VX first used? It was deployed during the Iran-Iraq war in the 1980s. VX is part of the same family of toxic substances as Sarin, which was used in the 1995 nerve gas attack on the Tokyo subway that killed 12 people and sickened over 5,500 commuters. Due to its relatively simple production process, VX can be made in a reasonably sophisticated laboratory. According to CNN military analyst Rick Francona, "Any country with a sophisticated chemical weapons program can produce VX. The formula has been around since the 1950s, so it's not a new discovery – it just requires the political will and determination to build the weapon."

Caitlyn Jenner, a reality TV star and former Olympian, initially remained silent after the Trump administration revoked Obama-era guidelines on transgender bathroom use in public schools. However, she broke her silence 24 hours later with a tweet and video message. Dressed in a pink blouse with a "pussy bow" design, Jenner addressed the camera directly. "I have a message for President Trump from one Republican to another," she said, holding up her hand as if on a phone. "This is a disaster, and you can still fix it. You made a promise to protect the LGBTQ community. Call me." In June, when Trump became the presumptive GOP nominee, Jenner told STAT that she believed he would be better for women than Hillary Clinton. "Many people view the Democrats as more supportive of LGBTQ issues," she said. "However, Trump seems to be very supportive of women and the LGBTQ community, particularly in the wake of the North Carolina bathroom issue, where he backed the community. Although there are many unknowns about Trump's stance, with Hillary, you know what you're getting in terms of LGBTQ support." Jenner was spotted attending an inauguration eve dinner at Washington's Union Station alongside House Speaker Paul Ryan. "Republicans need help understanding LGBTQ issues, and I'm here to help," she tweeted. As a transgender woman who publicly came out in 2015, Jenner documented her life after transition in the E! docuseries "I am Cait." The show often tackled political issues, with Jenner frequently discussing transgender rights and featuring LGBT activists in nearly every episode. Her video message also included a message for transgender kids and bullies, with a dig at Attorney General Jeff Sessions. "I want to send a message to the transgender youth of America: you are making progress. Although it may not feel like it every day, you are on the path to achieving full freedom and acceptance nationwide, and it will be a bipartisan effort. To support this cause, I encourage you to visit the National Center for Transgender Equality and make your voices heard in Washington.

"To the bullies who target vulnerable individuals, including transgender youth and women, I say: your actions are misguided and weak. Instead of picking on others, you should focus on addressing your own insecurities.

"I'm not the only one speaking out against this policy. Celebrities like Jackie Evancho, who has a transgender sister, and Ellen DeGeneres have also expressed their support for the transgender community. Jackie Evancho has even asked for a meeting with the President, while Ellen DeGeneres has encouraged everyone to know that we will continue to fight for the rights of transgender individuals."

Florida Representative Matt Gaetz, a staunch Trump supporter, stopped short of calling for Congress to subpoena President Trump's tax returns. Gaetz, who campaigned with Trump over the weekend and held a town hall meeting at the Oops Bowling Alley in Pensacola, surprised the audience by saying, "Donald Trump should release his tax returns." During the meeting, Donna Waters, a 56-year-old lawyer from Pensacola, became emotional as she pressed Gaetz for an answer. Waters, who claimed to be a descendant of an immigrant who arrived in Jamestown in 1607, stated that her family has a long history of military service, including fighting in every major US war. She said, "Whenever there's a threat to this country, my family has stepped forward," and then referred to the allegations of Russian interference in the government. Waters asked Gaetz, "You're on the Judiciary Committee, you've said you'll investigate the Russian allegations. Will you call for the release of President Trump's income tax returns?" The crowd erupted in shouts of "Yes or no!" before Gaetz took the microphone again and said, "If you hear me out, you'll like my answer." He then called for Trump's tax returns, receiving some rare applause from the crowd, which was otherwise upset over Gaetz's stance on issues like abolishing the Environmental Protection Agency. During his presidential campaign, Trump made history by becoming the first major-party nominee since 1972 to refuse to release his tax returns, citing ongoing IRS audits and promising to do so once the audits were complete. However, last month, Trump's top adviser Kellyanne Conway revealed that the President has no intention of releasing his tax returns, citing ongoing business advice urging him not to disclose the documents. Meanwhile, at a town hall meeting in Florida, protesters booed, chanted, and jeered Congressman Matt Gaetz, with some shouting "Impeach Trump!" when a questioner asked if he would vote to impeach the President. Gaetz responded by saying he doesn't agree with Trump on every issue, but he supports the President and will stand by him. Throughout the event, Gaetz engaged directly with the protesters, who occasionally interrupted him with shouts and chants. At one point, a constituent confronted him about his bill to abolish the Environmental Protection Agency, prompting protesters to shout "Your last term!" as Gaetz walked away. Gaetz also took steps to control access to his earlier events, holding a meeting with constituents in a back room of a restaurant with limited access. Later, he was escorted past a crowd of over 100 protesters by sheriff's deputies and members of Bikers for Trump, who claimed to be providing security.

Leicester City's manager, Claudio Ranieri, who took the helm in July 2015, guided the team to an astonishingly successful season, defying 5,000-to-1 odds to win the league title. However, the club's recent domestic results have put their Premier League status in jeopardy, prompting the Board to reluctantly decide that a change in leadership is necessary for the team's long-term interests. Ranieri was honored with The Best FIFA Men's Coach award just last month for his remarkable achievement. "This has been the most difficult decision we've made in nearly seven years since King Power acquired the club," said Aiyawatt Srivaddhanaprabha, the club's vice chairman. "But we must prioritize the club's future over personal sentiment, no matter how strong it may be." Leicester City's fairy tale story has not continued into this season, with the team now just a point away from the relegation zone, which would see them drop to a lower league next season - a feat not achieved by a defending champion since Manchester City 79 years ago. Ranieri's dismissal sent shockwaves through the football world, with widespread condemnation from fans, rival managers, and pundits alike. Manchester United manager Jose Mourinho paid tribute to Ranieri on Instagram, garnering over 100,000 likes in just three hours. "CHAMPION OF ENGLAND and FIFA MANAGER OF THE YEAR sacked... keep smiling AMICO. Nobody can delete the history you wrote," the post read. Former Manchester United and England defender Rio Ferdinand expressed his shock, while ex-Liverpool and Real Madrid striker Michael Owen called the decision a "total and utter disgrace." Owen tweeted, "I've lost a lot of love for the beautiful game today. The players and fans of Leicester have been massively let down." Gary Lineker, a former England national team captain and Leicester's most prominent ex-player, described the move as "inexplicable, unforgivable, and gut-wrenchingly sad." Leicester City has announced that its board will begin searching for a new manager and will refrain from making any further comments until the process is complete.

North Korea has lashed out at its only significant ally, China, accusing it of "following the US's lead" after China announced it would no longer import coal from the country. Without directly naming China, North Korea's official state news agency, KCNA, stated that a "neighboring country" had taken "inhumane steps" to block trade. In response, the Global Times, a state-sanctioned tabloid, fired back, saying that the ban had "left Pyongyang in a state of pain and fury." The Global Times added that China is accustomed to handling sensitive issues with North Korea, just as it does with the US administration, and will always approach such issues with confidence. China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs responded more calmly, stating that it is willing to work with North Korea to promote the "healthy and sound development" of their bilateral relations. China announced on Saturday that it would halt all coal imports from North Korea by the end of 2017, following Pyongyang's recent missile test. Analysts believe this move indicates that Beijing has had enough of the Pyongyang regime. Coal is North Korea's primary export and a vital source of foreign currency for its fragile economy, with most of its exported coal being shipped to China, its main ally and economic benefactor. According to KCNA, China is "dancing to the tune of the US" while trying to justify its actions, claiming that they are meant to curb North Korea's nuclear program rather than harm the livelihoods of its people. China's Ministry of Commerce described the decision to ban coal imports from North Korea as "utterly childish," stating that it was made to comply with a UN Security Council resolution that China helped draft and pass last November. The resolution, which imposed some of the toughest sanctions yet on North Korea, aimed to reduce coal imports by 62%, according to Kevin Gray, a reader in international studies at the University of Sussex in the UK. Gray notes that the ban could also be seen as a form of "payoff" for US President Donald Trump's recent acceptance of the One China policy, as Trump has repeatedly urged China to take a tougher stance on North Korea. In an interview with Reuters, Trump acknowledged China's significant influence over North Korea, stating, "China has tremendous control over North Korea and could solve the problem." However, analysts suggest that Trump may overestimate China's ability to control its neighbor, given the strained relations between Pyongyang and Beijing since Kim Jong Un took power. Kim's purge of government officials with ties to China and the murder of his older brother in Malaysia, who was living in China and advocated for Chinese-style economic reforms, have likely further deteriorated ties between the two countries. "Despite China's latest sanctions, North Korea remained calm, insisting that the ban would have little impact on its nuclear weapons program. According to the KCNA report, it is 'childish' to believe that a few dollars would deter the DPRK from producing nuclear weapons and intercontinental ballistic missiles."

In an interview on Fox News' "Fox and Friends", Trump was asked if he believed Obama was responsible for the recent town hall protests against Republicans. The interviewer asked, "It seems that Obama's organization is involved in organizing some of these protests against you. Do you think President Obama is behind it, and if so, is that a violation of the unwritten code of conduct for presidents?" Trump replied, "I think he is behind it. I also think it's politics, that's just the way it is." He then discussed the leaks that have disrupted his first month in office, saying, "You never know what's really going on behind the scenes. You might be right, or possibly right, but you never really know." Trump suggested that Obama's people are involved in the protests and that some of the leaks may be coming from the same group, which he described as a serious threat to national security. However, he also acknowledged that this is just politics, and it's likely to continue. Trump did not provide any evidence to support his claim in the clip released by Fox News on Monday night. CNN has reached out to Obama's office for comment. A coalition of groups, including Organizing For Action, the SEIU, MoveOn.org, and the Center for American Progress, have been working to help with grassroots organizing around GOP town halls. Organizing for Action, a group formed from Obama's campaign organization, has 14 professional organizers who are teaching local activists how to effectively voice their opposition to the GOP's top agenda items. "In an interview with Fox News earlier this month, Trump attributed reports of his conversations with the leaders of Mexico and Australia to leaks from individuals who served under his predecessor, President Obama. Trump's administration has struggled with a persistent problem of internal leaks to the media, a issue he has repeatedly criticized since taking office. He has claimed that these leaks pose a threat to national security."

The decision to block reporters from a White House press briefing sent a clear signal that President Trump is enraged about leaks coming from within the administration. According to sources, Trump had given his blessing for the move before it was carried out by Press Secretary Sean Spicer last Friday. When CNN reached out to Spicer, he denied that Trump was involved in the decision, claiming that he had not been informed about the gaggle and had not discussed it with anyone. Trump met with regional media outlets on Friday, but CNN and other news outlets were excluded from attending an off-camera press briefing that was attended by hand-picked reporters. Meanwhile, Politico reported that Spicer was cracking down on leaks from the White House, where staffers were even asked to surrender their phones for a "phone check" at one point. Sources also revealed that Trump and his top advisors were aware of Spicer's efforts to contact intelligence chairmen and government officials in an attempt to counter news stories about Russian links. The sources noted that Spicer has gained higher standing within the West Wing in recent weeks, having proven his loyalty to Trump by carrying out orders without question. One person close to the situation described Spicer as the "enforcer" of the administration's policies.

A statement released by the firm on Monday evening confirmed that PwC managing partner Brian Cullinan mistakenly handed the backup envelope for Actress in a Leading Role to presenters Warren Beatty and Faye Dunaway instead of the envelope for Best Picture. According to the statement, once the error occurred, the protocols for correcting it were not followed quickly enough by Cullinan or his partner, Martha Ruiz. As a result, "Moonlight" was eventually crowned the best picture winner. Ruiz and Cullinan, the two employees responsible for managing the envelopes containing the names of Oscar winners, had alternated handing envelopes to presenters from opposite sides of the stage during the ceremony. In a statement, PwC acknowledged that it had failed to uphold the integrity of the awards process, saying, "For the past 83 years, the Academy has entrusted PwC with the integrity of the awards process during the ceremony, and last night we failed the Academy."

The Academy also released a statement on Monday evening, apologizing to the cast and crew of "La La Land" and "Moonlight" whose experience was affected by the error. The statement praised the "tremendous grace" displayed by those involved and apologized to presenters Warren Beatty and Faye Dunaway, filmmakers, and fans worldwide. The Academy added that it had spent the night and day investigating the circumstances and would determine what actions to take going forward, stating that it is "unwaveringly committed to upholding the integrity of the Oscars and the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences."

The controversy surrounding the mistake comes after it was revealed that Cullinan had tweeted a photo of Emma Stone with her new Oscar shortly before the mistake was made. The tweet, which has since been deleted, showed Stone smiling with her award backstage at 9:05 p.m. on Sunday. PWC, a company responsible for tabulating Oscar results, issued a statement apologizing for the mistake and said they were investigating how it occurred. The company's tweet, which is still available on Google's cached page, was posted just minutes before presenters Dunaway and Beatty were given the envelope containing the already announced best actress results. As of Monday evening, PWC had not responded to CNN's request for comment. In a related article, it was noted that this was not the first time an envelope mix-up had occurred at the Oscars. In 1964, Sammy Davis Jr. was given the wrong envelope and accidentally announced the winner of a different category. PWC has implemented various measures to prevent such mistakes, including printing the category names on the outside of the envelopes in large text to prevent confusion. However, it's worth noting that this year's envelope design was changed to red paper with gold lettering, which may have been harder to read in dim backstage lighting. Photos taken during the ceremony confirmed that Dunaway and Beatty had the wrong envelope on stage. Dunaway, who announced "La La Land" as the winner of best picture, has declined to comment on the incident. After the envelopes containing the winners' names are filled, they are sealed by the only two people who know the results beforehand - Ruiz and Cullinan.
