Two sets of envelopes are prepared, and Ruiz and Cullinan are responsible for transporting them to the ceremony, accompanied by security personnel. As an added precaution, Ruiz and Cullinan commit the winners' names to memory, enabling them to respond swiftly if a wrong name is announced or to share the winner with presenters if something goes awry with the envelopes. This protocol was put to the test in 2017, when Sharon Stone and Quincy Jones accidentally handed the wrong envelope to the first winner during a presentation. Fortunately, the PwC representative on site was able to discreetly inform Jones of the correct winner offstage. The mistake was acknowledged on stage by three "La La Land" producers before the correct winner, "Moonlight", was announced, ultimately taking home three Oscars. Despite the error, "La La Land" still earned five Academy Awards.

Two women, Siti Aisyah from Indonesia and Doan Thi Huong from Vietnam, were arrested after surveillance footage showed them approaching Kim Jong Nam at Kuala Lumpur International Airport on February 13. According to police, the women applied a highly toxic VX nerve agent to Kim's face before fleeing the scene. Kim died en route to the hospital just 20 minutes later. Malaysia's Attorney General, Mohamed Apandi Ali, announced that the women will be formally charged on Wednesday. In Malaysia, murder can carry the death penalty. Aisyah has claimed that she did not intend to kill Kim, telling Indonesian officials that she believed she was participating in a prank show and was using baby oil on his face. However, Malaysian police chief Khalid Abu Bakar asserts that both women were aware they were applying a deadly nerve toxin to Kim's face. A third suspect, Ri Jong Chol, a North Korean citizen, remains in custody. Amidst diplomatic tensions between Malaysia and North Korea, a high-level North Korean delegation arrived in Kuala Lumpur on Tuesday to negotiate the return of Kim's body. The delegation, led by former North Korean Deputy UN Ambassador Ri Tong Il, aims to discuss the release of the detained North Korean citizen and the development of friendly relations between North Korea and the Malaysian government. Malaysian authorities have consistently refused to release Kim's body until they receive DNA evidence from his next of kin. "North Korea has categorically denied any involvement in Kim's murder, instead accusing South Korea of attempting to falsely implicate Pyongyang in the killing."

According to two South Korean parliamentarians who were briefed by the National Intelligence Service, the recently fired state security chief Kim Won Hong and over five deputy minister-level officials who worked under him have been executed by anti-aircraft guns. The officials are believed to have been executed for making false reports to North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, said South Korean lawmaker Kim Byung-kee.

The State Security Ministry, which is responsible for North Korea's intelligence service, prison camps, and domestic surveillance, is at the center of the controversy. The ministry is accused of making false reports to Kim Jong Un, which led to the executions of the officials.

Lawmaker Lee Cheol-woo, who was present during the briefing, added that the ministry controls and monitors the public and party officials, and that false reports were made to Kim Jong Un. The dictator was reportedly furious by this finding and ordered the execution of the five officials and the removal of a statue of his father, Kim Jong Il, from the Ministry's grounds as punishment.

The US Treasury has accused Kim Won Hong of directing and managing activities in the prison camps, including beatings, forced starvation, sexual assault, forced abortions, and infanticide. The Ministry for State Security reports directly to Kim Jong Un. In January, Kim Jong Un fired Kim Won Hong, one of his top officials, according to South Korea's Unification Ministry. As Minister of State Security, Kim Won Hong was responsible for overseeing North Korea's notorious prison camps, rooting out spies, and conducting counterespionage operations abroad. According to Unification Ministry spokesman Jeong Joon-hee, Kim Won Hong was punished for human rights abuses committed during interrogations at the State Security Department and other offenses.

A report released in 2016 claims that Kim Jong Un has ordered the execution of 340 people since taking power in 2011. The report, "The misgoverning of Kim Jong Un's five years in power," by the Institute for National Security Strategy, a South Korean think tank, details how the North Korean leader uses executions to maintain his grip on power. Of those killed, approximately 140 were senior officials in the government, military, and ruling Korean Worker's Party.

The regime has also used gruesome methods of execution in the past. In May 2015, Kim Jong Un had his Defense Minister, Hyon Yong Chol, killed with an anti-aircraft gun at a military school in Pyongyang, in front of an audience. According to Bruce Bennett, a senior defense analyst at the RAND Corporation, the execution would have torn the victim's body apart. Kim Jong Un ensured that the Defense Minister's family was present to witness the execution.

The article concludes by questioning whether Kim Jong Un is a madman or a mastermind, highlighting his brutal methods of maintaining power.

According to two US officials, al-Masri was killed in an attack orchestrated by the US intelligence community. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights, a UK-based activist group, reported that al-Masri was killed on Sunday in a missile strike that targeted his vehicle near al-Mastoumeh village in Idlib. Several Syrian opposition activists also confirmed that al-Masri was killed in a missile strike. Abdallah al-Muhaysini, a senior member of Jabhat Fatah al-Sham, paid tribute to al-Masri in a eulogy posted on his official Telegram channel, saying, "May Allah accept Abu al-Khayr in His heaven. May Allah gather us together with him." Al-Muhaysini is a prominent leader within Jabhat Fath al-Sham, which was previously known as Al-Nusra Front, an al Qaeda affiliate. Al-Nusra Front in Syria split from al Qaeda last summer, with the blessing of al Qaeda leader al-Zawahiri. According to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights, al-Masri, whose real name was Abdullah Muhammad Rajab Abd al-Rahman and who was an Egyptian national, was killed in a car near al-Mastoumeh camp during the strike. The White Helmets, also known as Syria Civil Defence in Idlib, reported the incident and posted pictures on their Facebook account, stating that two people were killed in the strike without revealing their identities. In 2005, Abdullah Muhammad Abd Al-Rahman was designated as a terror supporter by the US Treasury Department, which held him responsible for coordinating al Qaeda's activities with other terrorist organizations. In 2016, the UN Security Council added him, along with 81 others, to a sanctions list.

A 42-year-old man was taken into custody by the Australian Federal Police in the rural town of Young, New South Wales. According to a statement from the police, the individual had been designing and researching a laser warning system to detect incoming munitions and long-range guided missiles on behalf of the terrorist group. He faces three charges, which, if he is found guilty, could result in a maximum penalty of life imprisonment. Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull emphasized that support for ISIS is not limited to major cities, citing previous cases of Australians being arrested for planning terrorist acts or providing financial support to terrorist groups, as well as those who have traveled to conflict zones to fight for ISIS. Turnbull assured the public that no attack was planned for inside Australia. Assistant Commissioner Ian McCartney of the Australian Federal Police stated that the arrest was the culmination of over 18 months of investigations. This development comes less than two months after a planned terrorist attack on Christmas Day was thwarted in Melbourne, where six individuals were arrested for planning to detonate improvised explosive devices in the city center.

China has made a significant shift away from its decades-long one-child policy, which previously imposed harsh penalties, including fines and forced abortions, on families having more than one child. According to Wang Peian, vice-minister of the National Health and Family Planning Commission, the commission is exploring "birth rewards and subsidies" for second children, as reported by China Daily on Tuesday. Wang made this announcement during a meeting of the China Social Welfare Academy, a Chinese non-governmental organization that closely collaborates with the government. However, a spokesperson for the organization declined to comment on Wang's speech to CNN. The decision to offer incentives for second children was partly prompted by a 2015 survey conducted by the NHFPC, which found that 60% of families were hesitant to have a second child due to financial constraints. China abolished its one-child policy in October 2015, allowing couples nationwide to have two children. Since then, birth rates have increased, but the government aims to meet higher birth rate targets as the population ages. Lu Jiehua, a sociology professor at Peking University, views financial incentives for a second child as a "positive signal." However, the success of such incentives will depend on the government's ability to cover the increasing costs of living and education in China. "The financial incentives would require more effort from other government agencies to cover the cost of raising a child, which is more important than giving birth," Lu emphasized. The one-child policy was introduced in 1979 in response to concerns about a rapid population growth following the baby boom of the 1950s and 1960s. China's fertility rate plummeted sharply, dropping from nearly six births per woman between 1960 and 1965 to 1.5 per woman between 1995 and 2014. In response, the government launched a two-child policy in 2016 as part of a program to boost the declining birth rate, particularly due to China's rapidly aging population and looming shortage of working-age residents. With over 114 million people aged 65 or older, and an expected 90 million retirees in the next three decades, China is facing a significant labor shortage. By 2030, the government warns that China will have the world's oldest population, with over 400 million people aged 60 or older.

While the two-child policy has shown some success, with or without subsidies, in increasing the birth rate, there are still challenges to building a robust workforce. According to experts, many women of childbearing age in China were raised under the one-child policy and may be less inclined to have children, let alone a second pregnancy. "It's difficult to change their mindset," said Lu, citing the long-term impact of strict family planning policies. Experts predict that the effects of the two-child policy won't be fully felt until the new babies are old enough to join the workforce.

President Trump's inaugural address on January 20 seemed to echo the divisive tone of his campaign, but his remarks on Capitol Hill surprisingly resembled those of his predecessors. Critics may argue that, despite the rhetoric, Trump's words didn't stray far from his most controversial plans. However, his nods to traditional presidential tropes created an intriguing contrast. Let's compare his inaugural addresses from then and now.

On prosperity, Trump's words were starkly different. Then, he said, "For too long, a small group in our nation's Capital has reaped the rewards of government while the people have borne the cost... while they celebrated in our nation's capital, there was little to celebrate for struggling families all across our land." In contrast, his current message is one of unity, stating, "While we may be a nation divided on policies, we are a country that stands united in condemning hate and evil in all its forms."

On unity, Trump's tone shifted dramatically. Then, he famously declared, "This American carnage stops right here and stops right now." Now, he's emphasizing unity, saying, "That torch is now in our hands. And we will use it to light up the world. I am here tonight to deliver a message of unity and strength, and it is a message deeply delivered from my heart."

Regarding globalization, Trump's views have also evolved. Then, he criticized the US for making other countries rich while its own wealth disappeared, saying, "We've made other countries rich while the wealth, strength, and confidence of our country has disappeared over the horizon." Now, he's touting the benefits of international cooperation, stating, "America is friends today with former enemies. Some of our closest allies, decades ago, fought on the opposite side of these World Wars. This history should give us all faith in the possibilities for a better world."

Finally, on the American dream, Trump's message has changed significantly. Then, he lamented the decline of the middle class, saying, "The wealth of our middle class has been ripped from their homes and then redistributed across the entire world." Now, he's promoting a sense of optimism, declaring, "A new surge of optimism is placing impossible dreams firmly within our grasp." Original: "We will no longer accept politicians who are all talk and no action -- constantly complaining but never doing anything about it."

Rewritten: "We demand accountability from our leaders, rejecting empty rhetoric and instead seeking results-driven individuals who can effectively address the pressing issues facing our nation."

Original: "Solving these, and so many other pressing problems, will require us to work past the differences of party. It will require us to tap into the American spirit that has overcome every challenge throughout our long and storied history."

Rewritten: "To overcome the complex problems we face, we must transcend partisan divisions and tap into the resilient American spirit that has consistently guided us through times of adversity and propelled us towards a brighter future."

Sixty-six Democratic women representatives and delegates who make up the House Democratic Women's Working Group wore white clothing, paying homage to the suffragette movement of the early 1900s, where supporters wore white to represent purity. According to Florida Democratic Rep. Lois Frankel, the group's chair, they wore white to unite against the Trump administration's attempts to roll back women's progress in the last century and to continue advocating for women's advancement. The members' white attire represents their support for Planned Parenthood, affordable healthcare, reproductive rights, equal pay, paid leave, affordable childcare, and lives free from fear and violence.

In a tweet, Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi expressed her support for the movement, saying, "Tonight, our Democratic #WomenWearWhite in support of women's rights -- in spite of a @POTUS who doesn't!" Republican Rep. Cathy McMorris Rodgers, chair of the House Republican Conference, responded by calling for unity, stating, "I think this is an important time for us to be coming together. Typically, when a president is elected, you have that coming together as a country, which we haven't had, and I'm hopeful that people will listen to his message tonight and that they'll be willing to come together, find the common ground, so that we can do the important work that the people expect us to do."

The color white has become a symbol of celebrating women in politics throughout history, with many notable instances of women wearing white to represent their unity and solidarity. In 2016, a social media movement called #WearWhiteToVote emerged on Election Day as a nod to the suffragettes, who bravely fought for women's right to vote. On the night of the Democratic National Convention, Hillary Clinton made a powerful statement by donning a white suit as she accepted the presidential nomination. Since President Trump's inauguration, many women who disagree with his policies have been organizing against him, spearheading global women's marches in January and planning further protests in the months ahead.

The White House delayed the announcement of the revised travel ban until late Tuesday night, after Trump's speech received widespread positive reviews for its optimistic and unifying tone. This decision was likely influenced by the desire to avoid undercutting the favorable coverage, as the administration had originally planned to sign the executive order the following day. According to an official, the administration wanted the executive order to have its own "moment" and not be overshadowed by the president's speech. The sudden change in plans occurred as Trump and his top advisors returned to the White House after his address to a joint session of Congress on Tuesday night.

Trump's initial executive order, signed a week after his inauguration, had banned citizens of seven Muslim-majority countries from entering the US and temporarily suspended the entry of all refugees. However, a federal court issued a temporary stay, which was later upheld by a federal appeals court, halting the implementation of the travel ban. The new travel ban, expected to be signed soon, will exclude legal permanent residents and existing visa holders from the ban entirely, sources familiar with the plans told CNN. The document is still subject to change, but it is expected to make significant revisions, including excluding legal permanent residents and those with validly issued visas from the ban. Additionally, the new order is likely to revise or exclude language prioritizing the refugee claims of certain religious minorities.

In Munich, Germany, earlier this month, Department of Homeland Security Secretary John Kelly promised a "phased-in" approach to minimize disruption when implementing the revised travel ban. The remaining aspects of the new executive order are yet to be revealed, particularly with regards to refugees. Specifically, it is unclear what will happen to the 120-day suspension of the refugee program, whether Syrian nationals will still be indefinitely barred, and whether the cap on the number of refugees will be changed. The initial executive order capped the number of refugees at 50,000 for fiscal year 2017. Two sources expect the President to formally revoke the earlier executive order, despite earlier statements from White House press secretary Sean Spicer suggesting the two orders would coexist on a "dual track." The administration may argue that the legal challenges to the original executive order are moot, but those challenging the order tell CNN that the legal battles are likely to continue even after the new order is signed. According to ACLU attorney Lee Gelernt, exempting lawful permanent residents and current visa holders will not address the core legal issue - that the ban was motivated by religious discrimination, as evidenced by the President's repeated calls for a Muslim ban. Gelernt notes that the discriminatory intent cannot be removed simply by modifying a few words or making legal adjustments.

Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi's expression turned grim when President Trump mentioned repealing and replacing the Affordable Care Act. Dressed in white to honor women's suffrage, Pelosi shook her head and pursed her lips in disapproval. Other Democrats, such as Rep. Jackie Speier, unequivocally rejected the idea of repealing Obamacare, giving it a thumbs-down. Republican House Speaker Paul Ryan appreciated President Trump's reference to negotiators needing to secure better deals to repair the nation's infrastructure, a topic dear to the President's heart. Rep. Debbie Wasserman Schultz and Rep. Keith Ellison maintained somber faces when the President mentioned crime in inner cities, while the President enjoyed the full support of Republican leaders Rep. Kevin McCarthy and Rep. Steve Scalise on his "America first" agenda. The half-and-half crowd, a standard feature of Joint Sessions of Congress, was on full display, with Republicans largely backing President Trump's views on immigration and Democrats displaying less enthusiasm. However, there were moments that brought the crowd to their feet, including support for the troops and their families. Carryn Owens, the wife of Ryan Owens, a Navy Seal killed in a raid in Yemen, received a prolonged standing ovation of over two minutes.

During his confirmation hearings, Attorney General Jeff Sessions did not mention his meetings with Russian Ambassador Sergey Kislyak, despite stating that he knew of no contacts between Trump surrogates and Russians. A Justice Department official maintains that Sessions did not intentionally mislead senators during his confirmation. The Washington Post was the first to report on Sessions' meetings with Kislyak.

Kislyak, the Russian ambassador, is considered by US intelligence to be one of Russia's top spies and recruiters in Washington, according to current and former senior US government officials. However, Russian officials dispute this characterization.

Sessions met with Kislyak twice: once in July on the sidelines of the Republican convention and again in September in his office, when he was a member of the Senate Armed Services committee.

As an early Trump supporter and regular campaign surrogate, Sessions was well-positioned to discuss campaign-related issues with Kislyak. However, Sessions swiftly denied any such discussions, stating in a statement, "I never met with any Russian officials to discuss issues of the campaign. I have no idea what this allegation is about. It is false."

In response to the news, key Democratic lawmakers immediately called for Sessions' resignation. House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi characterized Sessions' earlier comments as "apparent perjury" and demanded his resignation.

The potential connection between Kislyak and Russian spying is one reason why former National Security Adviser Michael Flynn's interactions with Kislyak and his failure to disclose their discussions raised concerns among intelligence officials. During his confirmation hearing to become attorney general, Sessions was asked about Russia and responded that he "did not have communications with the Russians." A spokesperson for Senator Sessions, Sarah Isgur Flores, defended his testimony, stating that there was no misinformation provided to Congress. According to Flores, Sessions was asked about communications between Russia and the Trump campaign, not about meetings he took as a senator and member of the Armed Services Committee. In fact, Sessions had over 25 conversations with foreign ambassadors last year, including those from the UK, South Korea, Japan, Poland, India, China, Canada, Australia, Germany, and Russia, as a senior member of the Armed Services Committee.

A Justice Department official confirmed the meetings, noting that Sessions met with the ambassadors in his capacity as a senator on the Armed Services Committee. The White House also issued a statement, saying that this was just another attempt by partisan Democrats to attack the Trump Administration. The statement emphasized that Sessions met with the ambassador in an official capacity as a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, which is consistent with his testimony.

In response to the report, Rep. Elijah Cummings, the ranking member of the House Oversight Committee, called for Sessions' resignation. Cummings stated that there is no longer any doubt that a truly independent commission is needed to investigate potential ties between Russia and the Trump campaign. It is unacceptable that even after Michael Flynn was fired for concealing his conversations with Russia, Sessions would keep his own conversations with Russian officials for several weeks.

Cummings also criticized Sessions' claim during his confirmation hearing that he had no communications with Russia, calling it "demonstrably false." Senator Al Franken, a Democrat from Minnesota, who asked Sessions about Russia during his confirmation hearing, stated that if the reports of Sessions' contacts with Kislyak were true, then Sessions' response was "at best misleading." Senator Franken stated, "It's now clearer than ever that the Attorney General cannot, in good faith, oversee an investigation into the Trump-Russia connection at the Department of Justice and the FBI, and he must recuse himself immediately."

The news about Sessions' contacts with Kislyak came as a report from the New York Times revealed that officials in the Obama administration had shared information throughout government about potential Russian contacts with Trump's associates and interference in the 2016 election. According to the report, these officials took this step to preserve the information after Obama left office.

Regarding the Obama administration's efforts, Eric Schultz, Obama's spokesman, told CNN that the situation was serious, as evidenced by President Obama's call for a review and the US response. Schultz explained that when the intelligence community conducts a comprehensive review, it is standard practice for a significant amount of information to be compiled and documented.

Two days before Trump's inauguration, the State Department sent a batch of classified documents related to Russian attempts to meddle in elections worldwide to Senator Ben Cardin, a Maryland Democrat and the ranking member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. Cardin's spokesman, Sean Bartlett, told CNN that the senator had received the documents on request and that they were shared with both Republican and Democratic committee staffers.

"Lindsey Graham, a senator who was a strong supporter of Jeff Sessions' appointment as Attorney General, said that Sessions 'cannot make this decision' regarding the Russian ambassador meetings. However, Graham sidestepped a question about a Washington Post report that Sessions had two meetings with Russian Ambassador Sergey Kislyak during the 2016 presidential campaign, saying he needed more information. Graham told CNN's Dana Bash at a town hall event with Senator John McCain that he wants to know the facts about any contacts between the Trump campaign, the Clinton campaign, and Russian officials. 'If there were contacts, they may be legitimate; they may be okay. I want to know what happened,' Graham said. The meetings between Sessions and Kislyak took place in July and September, when Sessions was a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee. The Justice Department had previously disclosed the meetings, stating that Sessions did not mislead senators during his confirmation hearing when he said he knew of no contacts between Trump surrogates and Russians. As a senator, Sessions was an early supporter of Trump's presidential campaign and regularly appeared on behalf of the candidate. Sessions' spokeswoman, Sarah Isgur Flores, defended the Attorney General's answers to Congress, saying that he was only asked about communications between Russia and the Trump campaign, not about his meetings as a senator. 'Last year, the Senator had over 25 conversations with foreign ambassadors as a senior member of the Armed Services Committee, including ambassadors from Britain, Korea, Japan, Poland, India, China, Canada, Australia, Germany, and Russia,' Isgur Flores stated. Both McCain and Graham criticized Trump's approach to Russia and its President, Vladimir Putin, with Graham saying that Trump has a 'blind spot' when it comes to Russia. 'The bottom line is that Putin is disrupting democracy everywhere,' Graham said." Senator McCain, who has advocated for a special committee to investigate Russia's interference in the US election, emphasized that the country's efforts demand greater attention. "Make no mistake, the Russians' attempts to manipulate our election could have had devastating consequences for democracy," he stated. "That's why it's crucial we devote a significant amount of attention to the Russians and their activities in Europe, particularly their efforts to influence the outcome of the French election, which they are attempting to do using cyber means." Additionally, Sergey Kislyak, who is viewed by US intelligence as one of Russia's most senior spies and spy-recruiters in Washington, according to current and former senior US government officials.

Attorney General Jeff Sessions had two meetings with the Russian ambassador to the US, the Justice Department revealed on Thursday, further fueling concerns about Russia's ties to the current administration. During his confirmation hearings in January, Sessions failed to disclose these conversations with Sergey Kislyak, despite the fact that some Americans viewed Russia as an adversary due to numerous reports of its interference in the US election. Here's how Sessions responded to questions about interacting with Russian officials during his confirmation hearings:

Senator Al Franken asked, "If there was any evidence that anyone affiliated with the Trump campaign communicated with the Russian government during the 2016 campaign, what would you do?" Sessions replied, "I'm not aware of any of those activities. I have been called a surrogate at times, and I did not have communications with the Russians." (January 10)

Senator Patrick J. Leahy asked in a questionnaire, "Have you been in contact with anyone connected to any part of the Russian government about the 2016 election, either before or after election day?" Sessions responded, "No." (January 10)

It was later revealed that Sessions, as a senator and top Trump surrogate, met with the Russian ambassador twice: in July at the Republican National Convention and in September during his membership on the Senate Armed Services Committee. In a statement on Thursday, Sessions denied meeting with Russian officials to discuss campaign issues, saying, "I never met with any Russian officials to discuss issues of the campaign. I have no idea what this allegation is about." US intelligence officials regard Sergey Kislyak as a top-tier spy and talent scout, according to current and former senior US government officials. However, Russia's foreign affairs ministry has denied these allegations. Interestingly, Kislyak is the same individual who had a meeting with Mike Flynn, Trump's former national security adviser, before the President took office. Flynn ultimately resigned from his position after just 23 days, citing his contacts with Russia as the reason.

The French parliament has formally confirmed a move that will allow prosecutors to investigate Marine Le Pen over tweets she posted in December 2015, which featured images of ISIS killings. The tweets violate French law, which prohibits the distribution of violent images and inciting terrorism. Parliamentary President Antonio Tajani announced that a "clear majority" of members voted in favor of lifting Le Pen's immunity. As a member of the European Parliament, Le Pen enjoys immunity for freedom of speech, but this can be lifted if requested by a member state's authorities. Under French law, distributing violent images can result in a maximum penalty of three years in prison and a fine of up to 15,000 ($79,000). The lifting of Le Pen's immunity only relates to this specific case, and any further action is unlikely to occur before the first round of voting on April 23. Le Pen is already under scrutiny over allegations that her European Parliament staff were paid for non-existent jobs. Initially, Le Pen admitted that her staff had been paid while not working, according to the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF). However, she later denied making this statement.

The outings of the two men, both 32, were often so brief that they were back home with their families before anyone had a chance to ask where they had been. Despite the brevity, the bar remained a sanctuary where they could laugh and unwind after a long day's work, surrounded by familiar faces and a sense of comfort. However, for Madasani, the memory of that night is now tainted with a sense of regret and longing. "I just wish we hadn't gone there that night," he said, his words heavy with sorrow.

On the evening of the University of Kansas basketball game, which was playing on the big screen TV, Madasani and Kuchibhotla were sitting on the patio, engaged in their own conversation and laughter. "We were having a good time," Madasani recalled. But their tranquility was disrupted just minutes into their first beers, around 6:15pm, when a stranger approached them. The man, who was unknown to them, pointed a finger at them and Madasani sensed immediately that something was amiss. "He had this angry look on his face, and you could tell something was wrong," Madasani said.

Madasani didn't respond to the stranger, but Kuchibhotla did, politely trying to diffuse the situation. "He said, 'No sir, we are here legally, we are on H1B, we are from India,'" Madasani recalled. After the exchange, Madasani got up and went back into the bar, feeling surprised and uneasy about the random encounter. "Typically, those things happen after a few hours when people have gotten to know you," he said. "You've been hanging around for a while, and then they come up and start a conversation." But this encounter was different, and it would have far-reaching consequences. It was just before half past six when this incident occurred. The attack came out of nowhere; we hadn't spoken to the stranger or said anything that could have provoked him. Madasani and his friend were speaking English, their second language, rather than their native Telugu. Kuchibhotla made a point to speak English in public, Madasani noted. The stranger left the patio at 6:45 p.m., and the group began to relax, enjoying the fading sunlight. "It was a peaceful atmosphere," Madasani recalled. "You're in that relaxed zone, and we see him leaving. Everyone on the patio was watching because he was disturbing not just us, but everyone around us." The tranquility was short-lived. Within 30 minutes, the friends learned that the man had returned with a gun. Madasani remembered how events unfolded quickly, leaving little time to react. "I heard a loud pop right next to my ear," he said, describing the sound of the gunshot. He then dropped to the ground and started crawling. "I just wanted to survive," Madasani said, thinking about his unborn child with his wife. As he crawled towards the door, he tried to stand, but it was then that he realized he had been injured in his leg. He fell to the ground once, managed to make his way to the patio, and fell again. "It was just too much pain, and a lot of blood," he said. On the patio, patrons tended to Madasani's injury, tying a shirt over his leg as he lay there. As he looked on, he saw his friend, Kuchibhotla, motionless on the ground. The alleged shooter, Adam Purinton, 51, remains in jail after being arrested hours after the incident at an Applebee's restaurant in Clinton, Missouri, approximately 70 miles from Olathe. He is facing one charge of first-degree murder and two charges of attempted first-degree murder, with a bond set at $2 million. Despite the FBI's investigation, a motive for the shooting has not yet been established, and it is unclear whether the incident will be considered a federal hate crime. In the days following the shooting, Srinivas Madasani has struggled to understand why he and his friend ended up at the bar that night. "I could have said no, but when Kuchibhotla asks you to go, you go," Madasani said, recalling his friend's persuasive nature. "He was the kind of guy who didn't drink during the week because he wanted to work, and when he asks, you go."

Madasani reflected on the events leading up to the shooting, revealing that he was the one still working that night. "I was emailing with a coworker in California, and I could have told Srinivas that I had work to do and suggested we postpone our plans," he said. "I should have done that." Madasani described his friend as a kind and gentle person who rarely got angry, didn't gossip, and was loved by everyone around him. "He was the kind of guy I wanted to be, and he made me a better person," Madasani said.

As he grapples with the loss of his best friend, Madasani acknowledges that the violence is not an isolated incident. "Other things happen in this country, in the world, and here in Kansas, and I can confidently say that what happened is not what this country or community believes in," he said. Despite receiving support from friends of different racial backgrounds, Madasani admits that the events of the past week have left him feeling unsettled. "I still feel like this isn't reality," he said. "It's still not sunk in. I still don't want to believe what's happening."

Malaysian Attorney General Mohamed Apandi Ali told CNN that police lack sufficient evidence to charge Ri Jong Chol, a North Korean national. After his release, Chol will be deported back to North Korea, Ali said. The murder of Kim Jong Nam, the half-brother of North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, occurred on February 13, before he was set to depart for Macau. Two women have been charged with his murder, which investigators believe was carried out by smearing the deadly nerve agent VX on his face at Kuala Lumpur International Airport. Ri was the only North Korean to be detained in the case, although police have identified four other North Korean suspects who are believed to be back in Pyongyang. Three additional North Koreans are wanted for questioning, but Malaysian authorities say the North Korean government is not cooperating and is hindering the investigation. The suspects are thought to be hiding in Malaysia. South Korea has accused North Korea of orchestrating the murder, while North Korea has denied any involvement and blamed Seoul and Washington for attempting to destabilize its government. The brazen public killing has also strained diplomatic relations between North Korea and Malaysia. In response, Malaysia's Deputy Prime Minister Ahmad Zahid Hamidi announced that North Koreans will need to obtain a visa to enter the country starting March 6, according to Malaysia's state news agency Bernama. Currently, Malaysian nationals are the only individuals who can travel to North Korea without a visa. A diplomatic crisis unfolded when North Korea's ambassador to Malaysia, Kang Chol, declared on February 17 that his country would reject the results of an "imposed" autopsy on one of its citizens and demanded the immediate release of the body. Kang subsequently accused Malaysian officials of colluding with "hostile forces" during the investigation, prompting a stern rebuke from Malaysia. Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak responded by calling Kang's statement "completely unwarranted" and "demonstrating a lack of diplomatic courtesy." "Malaysia will not be influenced or controlled by any other country," Razak emphasized. VX is a highly potent nerve agent and one of the most dangerous chemical weapons ever developed. It is banned under the Chemical Weapons Convention and works by inhibiting an enzyme that regulates muscle function, leading to paralysis and suffocation. VX is lethal in doses as small as 10 milligrams. "VX is likely the most advanced nerve agent," said CNN military analyst Rick Francona. "It is likely the most lethal of all the nerve agents ever designed."

Threatening phone calls have been made to Jewish community centers and schools in nearly 33 US states and two provinces in Canada, with callers claiming that a bomb is hidden in one of the children's backpacks and will detonate shortly. Some of the callers made anti-Semitic statements, with one voice warning, "The Jews will be decimated." The FBI and the Justice Department's Civil Rights Division are investigating possible civil rights violations. So far, there have been no reports of actual devices being found at any of the targeted locations.

Jewish community centers and leaders across more than a dozen states and in Canada have shared their experiences with the threatening calls. The sex of the callers varied, and the details provided were often vague, suggesting that some callers may not have known the specific locations they were targeting. At several community centers, staff members were trained to handle the calls and followed established procedures. For example, a receptionist at the Merage Jewish Community Center of Orange County in California attempted to keep a caller talking, despite the caller becoming agitated and telling the receptionist, "You're asking too many questions." The receptionist continued to ask questions, trying to get more information about the bomb, but the caller provided no specific answers. In Los Angeles, Brian Greene, executive director of the Westside Jewish Community Center, described the caller's voice as "mechanical" and distorted, sounding like a woman but possibly not. The caller claimed there was a bomb in the building and instructed everyone to evacuate within an hour. When asked about the bomb's location, the caller replied, "That's not important, just get everyone out of the building."

At the Charles E. Smith Jewish Day School in Rockville, Maryland, an automated bomb threat was received, warning that "Jewish souls would be destroyed," according to Laurie Ehrlich, the school's director of marketing and communications. The front-desk receptionist managed to obtain a callback number from the caller, which was then given to the police.

In Maryland, the caller on January 9 to another Jewish community center sounded like an older woman, but it's possible that it was an automated message. The person who answered the call tried to engage the caller but received no response and was hung up on.

The bomb threat received on Monday at the Hebrew Day School of Ann Arbor in Michigan was made by a person who had disguised his voice, according to David Shtulman, executive director of the Jewish Federation of Greater Ann Arbor. The caller claimed, "There is a bomb in one of the children's backpacks and it's going to detonate shortly." There were no demands made and no conversation with the caller, who quickly hung up. The school received a threatening call in May 2016, which was particularly unsettling because it was the first of its kind, according to Shtulman. The caller claimed that his brother had placed a bomb in a backpack and hung up, but remained on the line when the school called him back. "Why are you arguing with me when you should be getting out?" the caller said, according to Shtulman.

In New York, the Jewish Community Center of Greater Buffalo in Buffalo received a bomb threat, with the caller claiming there was a bomb in the lobby. "They evaded any questions we had for them and it was clear to us they didn't know our building specifically," said Rick Zakalik, the center's executive director. Zakalik addressed parents at a meeting, likening the experience to "duck and cover" drills from elementary school days. He noted that bomb threats are relatively rare and that Jewish institutions are often targeted.

In Connecticut, the Mandell Jewish Community Center of Greater Hartford refreshed its training to deal with bomb threats after receiving its first and only threat the day after training, said David Jacobs, the center's executive director.

In Arizona, the Tucson Jewish Community Center was able to keep the caller on the phone by asking questions, said Todd Rockoff, the center's CEO. The caller's voice was hard to make out, Rockoff said.

In Delaware, the Siegel Jewish Community Center in Wilmington received a bomb threat, but Executive Director Ivy Harlev declined to provide further details. Harlev praised the community's resilience in the face of adversity, saying, "I can tell you that my community has been incredibly strong in the face of this adversity. This affects more than just the Jewish community."

According to a CNN report on Tuesday, the US military is seeking to increase intelligence-gathering raids in Yemen, similar to those conducted during the first week of Donald Trump's presidency. It remains unclear whether this adjustment to the approval process will apply to these operations. White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer described the discussions about the authorization process as a philosophical shift rather than a policy change. Spicer emphasized that President Trump trusts the experts in the field, saying, "He believes these are the experts in this field." However, Spicer also clarified that the protocol for signing off on decisions is not changing, and that certain decisions still require the President's approval. A senior defense official noted that while the President may not be directly involved in the approval process, Defense Secretary James Mattis and senior military commanders can brief him at any time and seek his specific approval for high-risk missions. The official emphasized that the goal is to streamline the approval process for time-sensitive missions, which are fundamentally judgement calls. However, military analysts have warned that pushing decision-making authority below the President for high-risk missions could create problems. According to retired Col. Cedric Leighton, greenlighting missions without the President's direct approval poses a significant risk. "If something goes wrong, the President would be left holding the bag, and it would be difficult for him to do that if he wasn't part of the approval process," Leighton said.

Leighton also emphasized the importance of centralized control, stating that while it may seem appealing to some, it can lead to unintended consequences. "If something goes terribly wrong, there will be significant political fallout, even if the President didn't directly approve or understand the details of the mission," he explained.

From a military perspective, Leighton believes that the President's authority is essential, particularly for high-stakes operations. "What you really need is a commander in chief who is involved in the approval process, especially for sensitive missions like those in Yemen," he said.

Under the Obama administration, the White House maintained significant control over high-risk missions, such as those involving significant opposition forces, new military techniques, or specialized units like SEAL Team Six or Delta Force. According to several defense officials, President Barack Obama was cautious about these types of missions and often sought to review and approve them personally.

Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov stated at a Moscow press conference that the ambassadors are appointed to maintain relationships. He explained that these relationships are maintained through meetings, talks, and establishing contacts with officials from both the executive and legislative branches of power. Lavrov dismissed the controversy surrounding Kislyak, saying, "I can only quote what the media said today - this all looks like a witch hunt."

According to CNN, US intelligence considers Kislyak to be one of Russia's top spies and recruiters in Washington. However, Russia's Foreign Ministry has strongly denied allegations that Kislyak, the top diplomat in Washington, is a spy. Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Maria Zakharova described Kislyak as a "well-known, world-class diplomat" who has worked with American colleagues for decades in various fields. She expressed shock at CNN's accusation that Kislyak is a Russian spy, saying, "He was deputy minister of foreign affairs in Russia, who has communicated with American colleagues for decades in different fields, and CNN accused him of being a Russian spy... of recruiting? Oh my God!"

US Attorney General Jeff Sessions recused himself from any investigation related to Trump's 2016 presidential campaign after it was revealed that he had failed to disclose two pre-election meetings with Kislyak in Washington. The meetings occurred at a time when Russia was accused of interfering in the presidential race. The pressure on Sessions to recuse himself grew as prominent Republicans broke ranks with the administration, calling for him to step down. Despite this, Trump expressed his support for Sessions shortly before the recusal announcement. Trump defended Jeff Sessions, saying that while Sessions could have been more accurate in his responses during the confirmation hearings, he did not intentionally make any misleading statements. "Jeff Sessions is an honest man. He didn't say anything wrong. He could have been more precise, but it wasn't intentional," Trump stated. Trump then shifted the focus to the Democratic Party, accusing them of "overplaying their hand" and losing their grip on reality after losing the election. He also criticized the media for spreading "total misinformation" and described the leaks of classified information as a "total witch hunt."

Meanwhile, Maria Zakharova, the Russian Foreign Ministry's spokesperson, described media reports about Sessions' meetings with Kislyak as "shameful" and an "attempt at total misinformation." She defended the role of Russian diplomats, saying that it is normal for them to make contacts with foreign officials. When asked about the characterization of Kislyak as a spy, Zakharova's colleague, Dmitry Peskov, said that there has been no official statement from US intelligence agencies confirming such allegations. Peskov also reiterated that Russia has never interfered in the domestic affairs of another country and has no plans to do so.

Peskov expressed concern about the "overly emotional environment" surrounding the relationship between Russia and the US, saying that it was affecting the prospects of a meeting between Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin. He noted that the negative atmosphere was building resistance to developing a relationship with Russia, which was having an obvious negative impact. Kislyak's interactions with Michael Flynn, Trump's former national security adviser, ultimately led to Flynn's dismissal last month. According to the Justice Department, Sessions met with Kislyak on two occasions in 2016: once in July on the sidelines of the Republican convention, and again in September in his Senate office, where he was a member of the Senate Armed Services committee. As a Republican senator from Alabama, Sessions campaigned on behalf of Trump throughout the 2016 presidential election. During his confirmation hearings, Sessions stated that he was unaware of any contacts between Trump surrogates and Russians, failing to mention his two meetings with Kislyak. In response to reports of these meetings, Sessions' spokeswoman, Sarah Isgur Flores, claimed that there was nothing misleading about his previous answer, as he was only asked about communications between Russia and the Trump campaign, not about his meetings as a senator. Sessions also strongly denied ever discussing campaign-related issues with anyone from Russia, stating, "I never met with any Russian officials to discuss issues of the campaign. I have no idea what this allegation is about. It is false." The House Intelligence Committee has recently approved a plan to investigate Russia's alleged interference in the US elections, which will involve examining contacts between Trump's campaign and Russia, as well as looking into who leaked the details. Democrats have called for an independent investigation into the matter. Russia has consistently denied allegations that it meddled in the US election campaign.

Kushner and Flynn met with Sergey Kislyak, the Russian ambassador to the United States, at Trump Tower in December, according to a senior administration official. The official described the meeting as an "introductory meeting" and "a brief, inconsequential hello" that lasted around 10 minutes. Kislyak is a key figure in the ongoing investigation into Russia's alleged interference in the US election. Flynn was fired from his role as national security adviser after he was accused of misleading the administration about his conversations with Kislyak. Attorney General Jeff Sessions has also been linked to Kislyak, and announced on Thursday that he would recuse himself from investigations into the Trump campaign's ties to Russia. The initial reports of Kushner's meeting with Kislyak came from The New Yorker, while Flynn's meeting was first reported by The New York Times. An administration official downplayed the significance of the meeting, saying it was simply an attempt to meet with key international players during the transition period. The official noted that Kushner met with dozens of other ambassadors during this time. Another national security adviser, J.D. Gordon, also revealed on Thursday that he had met with Kislyak during the Republican National Convention in July. Gordon told CNN that he, along with other national security advisers, had expressed a desire to improve relations with Russia, but emphasized that there was no inappropriate discussion about colluding with Russia to aid the Trump campaign. Gordon's statement was consistent with his previous public comments on the matter. Gordon had previously pushed for language in the GOP platform that would prevent Ukraine from being armed in its conflict with pro-Russian separatists, an effort that ultimately succeeded. However, Gordon claims he was simply advocating for a position that Trump himself had expressed, which was a desire to avoid a major war breaking out in Ukraine. In a statement to CNN, Page declined to comment on any meetings and maintained that he had never engaged in any improper activities with regards to Russia. Page did confirm that he had met with Kislyak in Cleveland, acknowledging as much in an interview with MSNBC's Chris Hayes on Thursday night, stating, "I do not deny that."

Inspector General of Police Khalid Abu Bakar announced that a warrant had been issued for Kim Uk Il, a 37-year-old individual, in connection with the death of Kim Jong Nam, the estranged half-brother of North Korean leader Kim Jong Un. Kim Jong Nam was killed with a VX nerve agent at Kuala Lumpur International Airport on February 13. In addition, a request has been made through the Foreign Ministry to cooperate with Hyon Kwang Song, the second secretary at the North Korean embassy, as part of the ongoing investigation. Earlier, Ri Jong Chol, the only North Korean man detained in connection with the case, was released from custody and deported under heavy police escort. Malaysian authorities have not yet gathered sufficient evidence to charge Ri, according to the country's attorney general. Deputy Prime Minister Ahmad Zahid Hamidi stated that Ri will be flown from Malaysia to Pyongyang, via Beijing, accompanied by two officials from the North Korean embassy. Malaysia's Director General of Immigration, Seri Mustafar Ali, revealed that Ri has been blacklisted from re-entering the country. North Korea has consistently denied any involvement in the murder.

In a separate development, two women, Siti Aisyah and Doan Thi Huong, have been charged with Kim's murder. Both women have pleaded not guilty and claimed they believed they were participating in a TV prank show. According to their home countries, the women maintained that they thought the substance they applied to Kim's face was a harmless substance, such as baby oil. However, Malaysian authorities have identified the substance as VX nerve agent, a deadly chemical weapon banned under international law. "Following the application of the liquid to Kim's face by the women, he began to feel disoriented and ultimately succumbed to his injuries shortly after being transported to the hospital, according to Malaysian authorities. VX is the most toxic nerve agent in the world, and one of the most hazardous chemical weapons ever produced. It is prohibited under the Chemical Weapons Convention."

At the Scottish Conservative Party conference in Glasgow, Theresa May emphasized that there would be no benefits to Scotland becoming independent when the UK leaves the EU. The uncertainty surrounding Brexit has sparked speculation that the Scottish National Party might demand a second independence referendum, following last year's referendum in which 62% of Scottish voters opted to remain in the EU. May accused the SNP of having an "obsession" with independence and neglecting other domestic issues, describing their focus as a "tunnel-vision nationalism" that prioritizes independence above all else. She vowed that the UK government would negotiate a deal with the EU that would safeguard Scottish interests after Brexit. "I am committed to ensuring that as we leave the EU, we do so as one United Kingdom, thriving outside the EU as a single nation," May said. "This means securing a deal with the EU that benefits all parts of the UK - England, Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland - as well as the UK as a whole." 

Scotland's First Minister, Nicola Sturgeon, has repeatedly argued that Scotland should remain in the European Single Market even after the rest of the UK has left. In a recent speech, she criticized the UK government for disregarding Scotland's views and refusing to compromise as it prepares to trigger Article 50, initiating the formal process of leaving the EU. If Scotland fails to secure a special deal in the UK's negotiations with the EU, Sturgeon suggested that a second independence referendum would be a legitimate and necessary way to give the Scottish people a say in their future direction. "The proposed deal would give Scotland a genuine choice about whether to remain part of the UK after Brexit, a UK that is now taking a fundamentally different path than the one envisioned in 2014. In the 2014 Scottish independence referendum, 55% of voters chose to remain part of the United Kingdom. The Scottish government has recently published a report outlining ways for Scotland to maintain its current position within the single market, which ensures the free movement of goods, services, and people, even if the rest of the UK leaves the EU. However, Prime Minister May has indicated that the UK government will pursue a 'hard Brexit', which would result in the UK's withdrawal from the single market and European customs union."

The US Attorney's Office for the Eastern District of New York has indicted 13 members of the MS-13 gang, also known as La Mara Salvatrucha, on charges including seven counts of murder, racketeering, attempted murder, assault, obstruction of justice, and arson. The 41-count indictment was unsealed in federal court in Central Islip, New York, on Thursday. According to US Attorney Robert L. Capers, law enforcement was determined to prevent the brutal murders from becoming cold cases. Two students, 15-year-old Nisa Mickens and 16-year-old Kayla Cuevas, were brutally beaten with baseball bats and a machete, Capers said. The girls attended Brentwood High School in Brentwood, a working-class community in Suffolk County, about 45 miles east of New York City. Initially, police believed gang involvement in the girls' deaths and the deaths of two others, whose skeletal remains were found after months of being missing. However, no arrests have been announced in the latter two cases. Suffolk County Police Commissioner Timothy Sini said, "The Brentwood family has spent the last six months in mourning, but today marks the beginning of the healing process for this beautiful and resilient community." Authorities revealed that Kayla had been involved in a series of disputes with MS-13 gang members and associates months prior to her death. The altercation at Brentwood High School a week before the girls' deaths, in which Kayla and her friends were involved, was seen as a catalyst for the gang's vow to seek revenge. On September 13, gang members went on a rampage, seeking to kill rival gang members in Brentwood. According to prosecutors, the girls, who had gone for a walk that night, were spotted by gang members, including one of the indicted individuals, News 12 Long Island reported. According to authorities, the gang leaders responsible for the murders of Nisa and Kayla were also under indictment, and they gave permission for the killings. A passerby found Nisa's body on a Brentwood street on September 13, just one day before her 16th birthday. The next day, Kayla's body was discovered in the backyard of a nearby home. Suffolk County Executive Steve Sini delivered a message to the community, stating that while the loss of Nisa and Kayla can never be undone, the fact that their killers will be held accountable can bring some solace. A third Brentwood High School student, 18-year-old Jose Pena, was killed on June 3, 2016. His skeletal remains were discovered on October 17, 2016, in a wooded area used as a burial ground for MS-13 victims. Authorities believe Pena was killed because he was suspected of violating gang rules. A forensic examination revealed that Pena's bones showed signs of repeated stab wounds and beatings with a blunt force instrument. Suffolk police have taken steps to combat gang activity, including collecting intelligence on MS-13 members and creating a list of gang members to be placed under surveillance. The police have also arrested numerous gang members for various crimes. Since September 2016, 125 MS-13 members have been arrested, according to Sini. Sini vowed to eradicate MS-13 from the community, stating, "We are going to eradicate MS-13 from these communities." MS-13 is one of the largest criminal organizations in the United States, with over 6,000 members operating in at least 46 states and the District of Columbia, according to federal authorities. The organization has a significant presence in El Salvador, Mexico, Honduras, and Guatemala, with over 30,000 members operating in these countries, federal authorities said. According to the US Attorney's Office, MS-13 is the largest and most violent street gang on Long Island. Two of the suspects are US citizens, while a third is a legal permanent resident, and the remaining individuals are undocumented immigrants, said Capers. If found guilty, the defendants could face sentences ranging from life in prison to the death penalty.

The Swedish government announced on Thursday that it will reintroduce compulsory military service, a move that has not been seen in the country since 2010. This time, however, the service will be gender-equal, marking a significant change in the country's military policy. Defense Minister Peter Hultqvist cited Russia's annexation of Crimea in 2014 as a key factor in the decision, stating that the move is a response to the new security situation created by Russia's actions. "After Russia's annexation of Crimea against international law, and their increased military exercises near the border, we have a new security situation," Hultqvist said. The minister also emphasized that Sweden is strengthening its military cooperation with Finland and NATO partners, despite not being a member of the alliance. Sweden had previously suspended conscription in 2010 and instead relied on a volunteer recruitment system. However, the country's defense forces have been struggling with low numbers, with a shortage of 1,000 full-time personnel. To address this issue, the government has announced a plan to increase defense spending by $720 million over five years and aims to have 6,000 full-time members and 10,000 part-time personnel serving. Under the new plan, those born between 1999 and 2000, as well as older volunteers, will undergo testing in July to determine their eligibility for military service. Of the approximately 100,000 individuals in the correct age category, 13,000 men and women will be selected to undergo physical and psychological assessments. This marks the first time that Sweden has conscripted women. Not all individuals will be required to enlist, with only 4,000 people per year expected to be conscripted until 2019. According to Radebo, while there will be no quota system in place to ensure a specific ratio of male to female recruits, the "gender equal" policy for the 1999 generation is expected to lead to an increase in the number of women serving in the armed forces. The new recruits will participate in their first military exercises on January 1, 2018. Conscripts will undergo training for nine to 11 months before deciding whether to pursue a career in the military or join as a reserve soldier.

Regarding the country's military activities, Radebo stated, "We see that we have more military activities in our neighborhood, and also that the illegal annexation of Crimea and the ongoing conflict in Ukraine are certainly factors in this." She added, "We react to these activities and do not speak of threats, which is why we have a parliamentary decision with 70% support behind our decision to strengthen our military capacity and increase cooperation with neighboring countries." Sweden, a neutral country, has recently stepped up its defensive efforts. In September, it deployed 150 troops to the island of Gotland, which is located between the mainland and several former Soviet Baltic states amid rising tensions with Russia. According to a Swedish government report, a full battalion will be established on the island by 2018.

According to a report, army units working alongside allied and supporting forces inflicted significant losses on ISIS forces in operations supported by Syrian and Russian air power. Palmyra was captured by ISIS from regime forces in December after a coordinated attack by hundreds of ISIS militants in and around the city. Strategically important to both sides in Syria's more than five-year civil war, Palmyra is located in Homs province, approximately 225 kilometers (140 miles) from Raqqa, considered ISIS' headquarters in Syria. Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov stated that Syrian government forces completed their operation with the assistance of Russian air power, as reported by Russia's state news agency TASS. Control over the city has repeatedly changed hands, with the regime and ISIS alternating control. Syrian forces recaptured Palmyra from ISIS in March, after it was seized by ISIS the previous May, during which ISIS began demolishing ancient ruins in the city. At a peace talk gathering in Geneva, Syrian rebel leaders refused to congratulate the regime. Nasser al-Hariri, a member of the Syrian Coalition, likened the struggle for Palmyra to watching a cartoon, stating, "This is the second time we've seen the handover [of Palmyra] and this is obviously being used for political reasons." Al-Hariri added, "If we want to follow the game of (Syrian President) Assad and Palmyra, it will be like watching Tom and Jerry." The Syrian army has previously claimed that capturing Palmyra would be a launchpad for expanding military operations into Raqqa and Deir Ezzor provinces. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights, a monitoring group, also confirmed Palmyra's recapture. "According to Rami Abdulrahman, the founder of the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights (SOHR), the city was seized following intense battles between ISIS and government forces that began on Wednesday."

After expressing concern about WikiLeaks' release of documents allegedly revealing CIA surveillance techniques, Spicer's message became muddled. He linked the latest WikiLeaks document dump to surveillance efforts during the Obama administration, days after President Trump claimed, without evidence, that President Obama had tapped his phones during the 2016 campaign. Spicer then argued that there is a "double standard" when it comes to the level of outrage elicited by different leaks. In a statement, he said, "I love WikiLeaks!" The White House has repeatedly argued that too much attention has been devoted to the investigation into contacts between Trump campaign officials and suspected Russian operatives, and not enough to the leaks of confidential information. "It's interesting how there's a double standard when leaks occur, and how much outrage there is," Spicer said. Spicer's comments came as he relayed Trump's "concern" about the leaks and said Americans should be "outraged" by the release of classified information. "This kind of disclosure undermines our country, our security, and our well-being," Spicer said. Spicer's claims on Wednesday came as he faced questions about a double standard on the President's part in condemning this leak while he praised WikiLeaks' publication of emails related to his rival Hillary Clinton during the 2016 campaign. Trump had proclaimed, "I love WikiLeaks!" as he read hacked emails before crowds of cheering supporters. Spicer said there is a "massive, massive difference" between the two disclosures. "There's a big difference between disclosing John Podesta's personal emails and leaking classified information," Spicer said. During the 2016 presidential campaign, Donald Trump frequently praised WikiLeaks for releasing hacked emails from Clinton campaign chairman John Podesta's account, many of which portrayed Hillary Clinton in a negative light. However, the US intelligence community concluded that these emails were hacked and released by Russian sources as part of a campaign to harm Clinton. Trump's comments on hacking during the campaign went beyond praising WikiLeaks, as he also applauded the hacking of the Democratic National Committee and downplayed the severity of various election-related hacks. At one point, he even urged Russia to find and release the 33,000 emails allegedly deleted from Clinton's private email server, which she used while serving as Secretary of State.

Representative Adam Schiff, the top Democrat on the House Intelligence Committee, criticized White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer's claim that there was no comparison between Trump's praise of WikiLeaks' campaign-related document dumps and the recent leak of CIA documents. "The reality is that both were wrong and both were serious threats to our national security," Schiff told CNN's Wolf Blitzer, arguing that the Democratic document release was part of the Russian campaign to undermine US democracy. "Both should be condemned."

Spicer's decision to mix politics with his condemnation of WikiLeaks' latest dump departed from the approach taken by his predecessors, who focused solely on expressing the government's concerns about leaks without drawing in tangential issues. This simpler approach was exemplified by Robert Gibbs, the White House press secretary in 2010, who only commented on the government's concerns about WikiLeaks' publication of classified diplomatic cables without getting involved in political debates. "Gibbs stated that by releasing stolen and classified documents, WikiLeaks has not only compromised the cause of human rights, but also jeopardized the safety and efforts of these individuals. He also unequivocally condemned the unauthorized disclosure of classified documents and sensitive national security information, expressing strong disapproval."

I made some minor changes to improve the clarity and flow of the sentences, while trying to maintain the original meaning and tone. Let me know if you have any specific requests or preferences!

Former FBI Director James Comey emphasized that absolute privacy is non-existent in the United States, stating that there is no place outside of judicial reach. He made this remark during a discussion on cybersecurity at a Boston College conference, referencing the 2013 revelations by Edward Snowden about US spy practices. Comey noted that even private communications with spouses, clergy members, or attorneys are not entirely private in America, as a judge can compel individuals to testify in court about these communications in appropriate circumstances. However, he also emphasized that Americans have a reasonable expectation of privacy in their homes, cars, and devices, which is a vital part of being an American. The government cannot invade this privacy without a valid reason, which is reviewable in court, Comey added.

In the last four months of 2016, the FBI lawfully accessed 2,800 devices recovered in criminal, terrorism, and counterintelligence investigations, but was unable to open 43% of those devices. Comey emphasized that Americans' desire for privacy and security should never be seen as mutually exclusive. "We all value privacy. We all value security. We should never have to sacrifice one for the other," he said.

Comey's comments come amidst controversy surrounding his leadership of the FBI, including the handling of the Hillary Clinton email investigation and President Donald Trump's baseless accusations that President Barack Obama ordered wiretapping at Trump Tower. Comey did not address the wiretapping claim or WikiLeaks' recent claim that it obtained internal CIA documents. James Comey stated that he intends to complete his 10-year term. "You'll have to endure my presence for approximately another 6.5 years," he said, "and I would be delighted to be invited back for another term."

Following their 4-0 defeat in the first leg in Paris, few thought Barcelona had a chance to reach the quarterfinals, as no team had ever come back from such a deficit in the Champions League. However, Barcelona made a thrilling start to the match and, early in the second half, a Lionel Messi penalty gave them a 3-0 lead at the Camp Nou. The home team seemed to be cruising, but just past the hour mark, Edison Cavani's volley brought PSG back into the game, leaving Barcelona needing to score three more goals, given PSG's crucial away goal. Nevertheless, with just two minutes of normal time remaining, Neymar's exquisite free-kick gave Barcelona new hope, and two goals in stoppage time completed the most incredible comeback. The final five minutes of stoppage time were almost impossible to describe. In the 91st minute, Luis Suarez, who had given Barcelona an early lead, won a penalty, which Neymar converted. With time running out, Barcelona threw everyone forward, including their goalkeeper Marc-André ter Stegen. And just as the game was about to end, Barcelona's sixth goal came from an unlikely source - not their star strikers Messi, Neymar, or Suarez, but defender Sergio Roberto, a product of Barcelona's youth academy born in Catalonia. Bayern Munich's Franck Ribery, who had played for the German club in their 5-1 thrashing of Arsenal on Tuesday, described the game as "unbelievable." Former Bayern and Chelsea star Michael Ballack tweeted, "That's Champions League," followed by a series of fire emojis. In the 2005 Champions League final, Liverpool staged an incredible comeback from 3-0 down to defeat AC Milan on penalties, but Barcelona's remarkable turnaround against Paris Saint-Germain is arguably the greatest comeback in Champions League history. Barcelona's president, Josep Maria Bartomeu, hailed the achievement as "historic" and said it would be remembered forever.

Ahead of the second leg, Barcelona coach Luis Enrique exuded quiet confidence, citing his team's recent league victories over Sporting Gijon and Celta Vigo. "We're in good form, and we have to be confident," he said. "We're in the middle of the tie, and we have nothing to lose and everything to gain. If they score four, we can score six."

The aftermath of the match was marked by shock and disappointment from Paris Saint-Germain, with their English Twitter feed summarizing their defeat with a single word: "gutted". Their website's headline for a report on the game was equally stunned, using the word "speechless". The Qatari owners of PSG had appointed Spanish coach Unai Emery in June 2016, hoping his tactical expertise would help the club win the Champions League. Emery had previously led Sevilla to three consecutive Europa League titles, and PSG's billion-dollar budget was expected to fuel their quest for the top prize. However, in the first leg, PSG's high-intensity press had initially left Barcelona looking subdued. PSG's fortunes didn't seem to be on their side on Wednesday, as Barcelona's second goal came courtesy of an own goal from Layvin Kurzawa, while Edinson Cavani's shot hit the post and the home side's first penalty resulted from Thomas Meunier's slip, which allowed Neymar to fall and win a foul. Despite their commanding performance and first-leg lead, the French side will be left wondering how they exited the Champions League. For more news and videos on the match, visit cnn.com/football.

PSG's CEO and chairman, Nasser Al-Khelaifi, said he hadn't spoken to the players yet, but it wasn't the right time. "Everyone is annoyed, it's normal. We're going to calm ourselves down," he added. Unai Emery, the PSG coach, reflected on the game, saying, "In five minutes, we lost everything. We weren't able to defend. It's an experience. A negative experience, but an experience all the same. I'm learning for the future."

The scene in the Nou Camp press area was chaotic, with journalists struggling to process the events on the field. "This is a crazy, unique sport," said Barcelona coach Ernesto Valverde. "I dedicate this win to all Barça fans who kept faith in us. No one stopped believing," he added. "The team were spectacular. We were rewarded in the end." Meanwhile, Borussia Dortmund beat Benfica 4-0 in the other quarterfinal match, winning their tie 4-1 on aggregate.

During a 60-minute meeting, sources revealed that President Trump scolded the conservative groups, including Club for Growth, the Heritage Foundation, Americans for Prosperity, FreedomWorks, and the Tea Party Patriots, for labeling the House GOP proposal "Obamacare lite." Trump reportedly warned the tea party activists, "You're helping the other side." In characteristic Trump fashion, he shifted into salesman mode, telling the group, "This is going to be fantastic. You're going to make it even better." He also assured them, "I'll work hard to get it done."

The meeting, which took place in the White House, involved senior advisers Steve Bannon, Reince Priebus, Kellyanne Conway, and Marc Short, as well as other top West Wing staff. According to sources, White House aides expressed a willingness to discuss one aspect of the House GOP plan that has been a point of contention for tea party-aligned groups: the provision that delays the overhaul of expanded Medicaid funding until 2020. The conservative groups present at the meeting requested that the date be moved up to January 1, 2018. White House aides reportedly indicated that they were open to discussing the issue.

Concerns were also raised about the tax credits in the House GOP plan, which provide financial assistance to lower-income Americans to purchase health insurance. Tea party groups view these credits as subsidies. According to a source at the meeting, the White House responded forcefully to these concerns. Office of Management and Budget Director Mick Mulvaney, a former member of the conservative House Freedom Caucus, delivered a passionate defense of the tax credits, surprising attendees from the conservative groups. One attendee described Mulvaney's defense as "very defensive." President Trump expressed confidence that the healthcare plan would pass the House and outlined his strategy for securing Senate passage. He plans to campaign extensively in red states where vulnerable Democrats are up for re-election, telling a meeting that he will hold large-scale events at football stadiums in states where he won by a significant margin. "I'm going to dare people to vote against me," Trump said, according to a source at the meeting. The President also expressed optimism about winning over prominent Republican opponents of the plan, including Kentucky Senator Rand Paul, a former primary rival. "I love him. He's a friend.
