He's going to end up voting for it," Trump said. A source at the meeting was surprised by the White House staff's lack of preparation for the initial conservative backlash against the GOP plan, given that they had "telegraphed" their intentions for weeks. A White House official countered that the meeting was a genuine policy discussion focused on specific details. Trump made it clear that he was open to suggestions for improving the bill, but emphasized that this was the opportunity to repeal and replace the existing healthcare system.

President Trump made a claim on Saturday without providing evidence that former President Barack Obama wiretapped his phones at Trump Tower before the 2016 election. On Wednesday, CNN affiliate WEWS reporter John Kosich asked Vice President Mike Pence a straightforward yes or no question: Did he believe Trump's allegation? Pence dodged the question and attempted to shift the conversation to healthcare, a topic the Trump administration has been pushing to reform. Kosich followed up, "The President has accused former President Obama of committing a felony by wiretapping Trump Tower. Can you simply answer 'yes' or 'no' as to whether you believe that?" Pence sidestepped the question, saying, "What I can say is that our administration is confident that the congressional committees investigating issues surrounding the 2016 election will conduct a thorough and fair inquiry. They will examine the allegations and other concerns. However, we remain focused on the issues that matter most to the American people, including creating jobs in Ohio and building a healthcare system that prioritizes consumer choice."

A team of two individuals from the World Food Programme, comprising a man and a woman, arrived in Beijing on Thursday, according to a United Nations spokesperson. They were among 11 Malaysian citizens who became stranded in the country after North Korea imposed a ban on Malaysian departures. The group included four embassy staff members and their family members. In response, Malaysia also banned North Koreans from leaving the country, with officials declining to disclose the number of North Koreans currently in Malaysia. The strained relations between Malaysia and North Korea date back to the murder of Kim Jong Nam, the half-brother of North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, on February 13. Kim was poisoned with the deadly VX nerve agent while checking in for a flight from Kuala Lumpur to Macau, according to Malaysian police. Two women, one from Indonesia and the other from Vietnam, have been charged with murder and face the death penalty if convicted. Malaysian police are currently searching for seven North Koreans in connection with the murder, including four suspects believed to be back in their home country and three others thought to be hiding at the North Korean embassy in Malaysia. Kim's family is reportedly in hiding, with his son, Kim Han Sol, making his first public appearance since the murder in a video on Wednesday.

The state's attorneys filed a 40-page request with a federal judge just before midnight on Tuesday, seeking a temporary restraining order to block the implementation of a new executive order. The order, signed by President Trump on Monday, prohibits foreign nationals from six Muslim-majority countries from entering the US for 90 days and bans all refugees for 120 days. Hawaii Attorney General Douglas Chin stated that the filings ask the court to declare sections 2 and 6 of Trump's executive order unconstitutional and contrary to US laws. "Sections 2 and 6 of the March 6, 2017 Executive Order violate the Immigration and Nationality Act by discriminating on the basis of nationality, ignoring and modifying the statutory criteria for determining terrorism-related inadmissibility, and exceeding the President's authority under the Immigration and Nationality Act," Chin said. The executive order is having a significant impact on the economy, according to the state's attorney. "The new executive order is establishing religion in the state of Hawaii contrary to its constitution, inflicting immediate damage to our economy, educational institutions, and tourism industry, and subjecting a portion of our citizens to second-class treatment and discrimination, while denying all Hawaii residents the benefits of an inclusive and pluralistic society," the state's attorneys argued in court filings. "The executive order means that thousands of individuals across the United States and in Hawaii who have immediate family members living in the affected countries will now be unable to receive visits from those persons or to be reunited with them in the United States." The Justice Department declined to comment on the filing, but will have an opportunity to respond to the state's amended complaint against the travel ban on March 13. Hawaii's entire history and culture are built on the principles of nondiscrimination, not only in its constitution but also in its laws, according to Chin, a spokesperson for the state. Hawaii has a significant number of foreign-born residents, with approximately 20% of its population consisting of non-citizens, and 20% of its workforce comprising individuals who are not foreign-born.

US District Court Judge Derrick Watson has approved an expedited briefing schedule for the case, allowing it to be heard before the new executive order takes effect on March 16. Attorney General Jeff Sessions argued that the ban is necessary to ensure national security, as some governments are unable or unwilling to provide necessary information to vet visitors responsibly or actively support terrorism.

Hawaii had previously sued over Trump's original travel ban, but the case was put on hold temporarily while a nationwide temporary restraining order was in place. However, Judge Watson lifted the hold on Wednesday, allowing the state to proceed with its lawsuit against the new executive order.

According to Neal Katyal, one of the lead attorneys for Hawaii and former acting US solicitor general, the new travel ban "covers fewer people than the old one" but still suffers from the same constitutional and statutory defects. The state's amended complaint primarily emphasizes the new executive order's alleged discriminatory intent and effect, as well as the harm it poses to Hawaii's economy. Hawaii is also a party to the lawsuit, represented by an American imam who has lived in the state with his wife and children for over a decade. However, his Syrian mother-in-law is now unable to visit them because she lacks a valid visa to enter the US. While many immigrant rights organizations and state attorneys general had expressed strong reservations about the new travel ban when it was announced on Monday, no new lawsuits or amended filings had been filed until now. The Justice Department filed a flurry of notices in federal courts on Monday, including in this Hawaii case, alerting judges to the new order and arguing that it falls outside of the injunctions that blocked the original ban. The government cited the significant changes to the new order, including its exemption of green card holders and those with valid visas.

US-backed fighters are gearing up to launch an assault on Raqqa, the self-proclaimed capital of ISIS, within the next few weeks, according to officials. However, the Pentagon and Marine Corps have declined to confirm the deployment due to security concerns in the region. They have also refused to disclose the exact location or number of troops involved. The Washington Post was the first to report the deployment of Marines. The news is not surprising, as military commanders have been discussing the possibility of deploying artillery forces to the area for weeks, with the aim of boosting the capabilities of US-backed Arab and Kurdish forces. A similar deployment was made last year near Mosul, Iraq, where several hundred Marines equipped with artillery guns provided covering fire for advancing forces. Since Marines were already stationed in the region, the deployment to Syria did not require specific approval from President Donald Trump or Defense Secretary James Mattis, although both the White House and Pentagon were aware of the plan. The Marines were deployed from ships in the Persian Gulf region. This marks the second significant expansion of US ground forces in northern Syria in recent days, following the deployment of approximately 100 Army Rangers in and around Manbij, Syria. US officials have taken the unusual step of publicly discussing the Ranger deployment and its location to prevent them from inadvertently coming under fire from forces in the region or Turkish, Russian, or Syrian forces. The US troops in Manbij are present to deter hostilities, rather than their typical mission of training, advising, and assisting local forces. The deployment of Marines and Rangers in Syria raises questions about whether it violates the current cap on US forces in the country. The cap restricts the US to having more than 500 forces in Syria at any given time, and until now, troops in the area have primarily consisted of Special Operations Forces. Despite this, the US believes the pressure on ISIS in Raqqa is yielding results. According to a US official, intelligence suggests that some ISIS leaders and operatives are still attempting to flee the city. The official also revealed that US intelligence has detected extensive booby traps in Raqqa, including trenches, tunnels, roadside bombs, and buildings and houses rigged to explode. This suggests that the US has likely gathered intelligence from both aerial surveillance and ground sources. However, the official noted that Raqqa is unlikely to be the final battle against ISIS, as the group still has personnel scattered in areas south and east of the city. Estimates suggest that ISIS may have as many as 4,000 fighters in Raqqa, according to rough US calculations.

White House press secretary Sean Spicer clarified that President Trump's tweet about wiretapping was not referring to the specific surveillance activity, but rather "broadly, surveillance and other activities" that took place during the 2016 election. Spicer explained that Trump used the term "wiretaps" in quotes to encompass a range of surveillance methods, not just the narrow definition of wiretapping, which involves tapping into a telephone or telegram wire to obtain information. Spicer also emphasized that Trump's tweet was not accusing former President Obama of personal involvement, but rather referring to the Obama administration's actions in general.

The White House has yet to provide any evidence to support Trump's claim, despite the deadline for the Justice Department to do so. Numerous former officials have denied the existence of any warrant to wiretap Trump Tower. Spicer's comments came on the same day that the deadline passed, and a week after he initially declined to provide further explanation for Trump's tweet.

In his initial tweets, Trump specifically referred to phone tapping, using quotation marks only in two of the four tweets. However, Spicer claimed that Trump was referring to means of surveillance beyond wiretapping when he made the accusation. Despite this, Spicer did not reject the concept of a "Deep State" or other shadowy forces operating within the government. Trump's question about the legality of wiretapping a presidential candidate sparked controversy. In response, Trump tweeted that Obama had tapped his phones in October, claiming that he had stooped low to do so during the election process. However, not only Spicer, but also other White House officials, including Counselor Kellyanne Conway, attempted to redefine the term "wiretap" despite Trump's clear language. In an interview with the Bergen County Record, Conway discussed the wiretapping claims, suggesting that the Obama administration may have used other covert surveillance methods, such as those revealed by Wikileaks, to monitor Trump Tower. During the interview, columnist Mike Kelly asked Conway if Trump Tower had been wiretapped. Conway replied that there are many ways to surveil each other, and went on to suggest that surveillance could take place through phones, TVs, or even microwaves that can turn into cameras.

The House Intelligence Committee has given the Department of Justice until Monday to provide evidence supporting President Trump's claims of wiretapping, a source familiar with the matter told CNN. The committee has also sent letters to various intelligence agencies this week to obtain records related to Russia. Former President Barack Obama has denied the allegations through a spokesperson, and his former director of national intelligence, James Clapper, has publicly refuted them. Sources close to the FBI have told CNN that Director James Comey has also disputed Trump's claims. Despite making the allegations over a week ago, Trump has yet to provide any evidence to back them up. In a Sunday night interview, Kellyanne Conway, a senior adviser to the President, appeared to expand on the allegations, suggesting that the Trump campaign may have been spied on using unconventional methods such as microwaves and television sets. However, she did not provide any concrete evidence to support her claims, and later clarified that she was speaking generally about surveillance. As the deadline set by the House Intelligence Committee approaches, calls for Trump to produce evidence are growing louder, including from some within his own party. Senator John McCain told CNN's Jake Tapper on "State of the Union" that Trump has two options: retract his claims or provide the information the American people deserve. McCain expressed skepticism about the allegations, but urged Trump to clear up the matter. Two congressmen with access to sensitive intelligence information have also said they have found no evidence to support Trump's claims. The top Democrat on the House Intelligence Committee, Representative Adam Schiff, told ABC's "This Week" that he does not expect to see evidence of wiretapping. House Speaker Paul Ryan, asked directly on CBS News' "Face the Nation" if he had seen evidence of wiretaps, responded, "No." On Sunday, Conway clarified that "surveillance" encompasses more than just phone tapping. "There are many ways to surveil each other," she told the Record, "including through phones, television sets, and potentially other means." Conway also mentioned the possibility of using "microwaves that turn into cameras," stating, "This is a fact of modern life." She reiterated Trump's request that a congressional investigation into the wiretapping claims be included in the investigation into Russia's alleged meddling in the 2016 election.

On ABC's "Good Morning America" on Monday, Conway was asked to clarify her previous comments. She explained that she was discussing "surveillance in general" and not specifically suggesting that Trump Tower was under surveillance. "I have no evidence," Conway said, "but that's why there is an ongoing investigation in Congress." Later, she tweeted that the Record's headline, "Kellyanne Conway suggests even wider surveillance of Trump campaign," was inaccurate. "My response to the Record was about surveillance techniques in news articles, not about the Trump campaign," Conway said. "The headline is just wrong." The article has been updated to reflect these clarifications.

Turkish Foreign Minister Mevlut Cavusoglu expressed frustration in an interview with CNN's Connect the World, questioning why he was deemed a terrorist and unable to attend a rally in Rotterdam over the weekend. The decision was met with a refusal by the Dutch to allow Turkish Family Affairs Minister Fatma Betul Sayan Kaya to enter the Turkish consulate in the city, leading to her forced departure from the country. The move sparked violent clashes in Rotterdam, with Cavusoglu complaining that he had received no explanation from the Dutch for their concerns over public order and safety. "Is there a single radicalized Turkish Turk?" he asked, suggesting that the security concerns were an excuse to hide the real reasons behind the decision. Cavusoglu blamed a rise in racism, Islamophobia, and xenophobia in the Netherlands and other European countries, and accused the Netherlands and other European countries of attempting to obstruct the "yes" campaign for a Turkish referendum on April 16 that would grant new powers to President Recep Tayyip Erdogan. The minister was visiting Rotterdam to rally support among Turkish expatriates who can vote in the referendum. In response to the blocked visit, Turkish President Erdogan compared the Dutch government to Nazis, prompting a response from Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte, who demanded an apology for Erdogan's inflammatory remarks. The Netherlands suffered a significant loss of over 200,000 citizens during its occupation by Nazi Germany in World War II. In a statement that appeared to justify Turkish President Erdogan's controversial remarks about the Nazis, Turkish Foreign Minister Mevlüt Çavuşoğlu said: "Such attitudes, policies, and violations of European standards, values, and Vienna conventions did not occur since World War II. Not even during World War II, and perhaps not even during the Nazi era. That's why we're making the comparison." Çavuşoğlu also announced that he has recommended taking action against the Dutch government in response to the events of the weekend, but declined to specify what this would entail. On Monday, the Dutch government issued a travel advisory on Twitter, warning Dutch citizens in Turkey to avoid demonstrations and remain vigilant amid the escalating tensions between the two countries. However, Çavuşoğlu told CNN that Turkey would not target the Dutch people or harm them, as it was not their fault. He emphasized that the Dutch people are friends of Turkey and that many tourists visit the country each year, citing a 400-year history of friendship between the two nations.

A bitter diplomatic dispute and public unrest erupted as voters in both countries prepared to cast ballots that could fundamentally alter the political landscape. What sparked the conflict? Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has been working to rally the approximately 4.6 million Turkish expatriates living in Western Europe to vote in an upcoming constitutional referendum. If passed, the referendum would transform Turkey's parliamentary system into a presidential one, giving Erdogan's office unprecedented power. Germany, Austria, and Switzerland sought to prevent Turkish referendum rallies from taking place on their soil, citing security and overcrowding concerns. On Saturday, Turkish Foreign Minister Mevlut Cavusoglu attempted to enter the Netherlands to address a rally in Rotterdam, but was blocked by the Dutch due to security concerns. Another minister was also barred from entering the Turkish consulate in Rotterdam. How did the Turks react? Protests broke out in both countries. Cavusoglu vowed "tenfold" retaliation against the Netherlands. According to Turkish state-run news, the Dutch diplomatic missions in Ankara and Istanbul were closed due to security concerns. The Turkish foreign ministry told the Dutch ambassador, who is currently on leave, not to return "for a while." Erdogan condemned the Netherlands, saying it was "sacrificing Turkish-Dutch relations." He accused the country of Nazism and likened it to a "banana republic." He also called for sanctions. "Nazism is still widespread in Europe," he said. Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte responded by calling Erdogan's remarks inflammatory and demanding an apology. The Turkish government's verbal attacks on the Netherlands prompted Denmark's Prime Minister Lars Løkke Rasmussen to postpone a meeting with his Turkish counterpart. The Dutch government's decision to ban Turkish politicians from campaigning in the Netherlands may be linked to its domestic politics, particularly in the run-up to the country's general election on Wednesday. Immigration from Muslim-majority countries is a contentious issue in the election, with populist far-right leader Geert Wilders of the Freedom Party advocating for stricter measures. Wilders has called for the ban on immigration from Muslim countries, the closure of mosques, and the imprisonment of radical Muslims who have committed no crimes. In response, Prime Minister Mark Rutte, who is running for re-election, has shifted his stance to the right, urging immigrants who do not assimilate to "behave normally or leave." Some critics, including freelance journalist David Chesal, have accused the government of engaging in "election-time grandstanding." Chesal believes that Prime Minister Rutte is unlikely to allow a large Turkish campaign in Rotterdam or elsewhere in the Netherlands, as it would be a political liability. Meanwhile, Turkish President Erdogan is using the controversy to demonstrate his influence over Europe and gain support for his referendum on expanding his powers. European governments have been critical of Erdogan's commitment to basic freedoms since a failed coup attempt earlier this year, citing his crackdown on opposition, including journalists, academics, and public servants. The country has shut down nearly 140 media outlets, arrested over 41,000 people, and dismissed about 100,000 public sector workers. Turkey, a NATO member, jailed more journalists than any other country in 2016, according to the Committee to Protect Journalists. Critics have labeled the proposed referendum as anti-democratic, viewing it as a symptom of Erdogan's increasing authoritarian tendencies. Last week, German Chancellor Angela Merkel sounded a warning, stating that Turkey's approach to democracy and the rule of law poses "deeply problematic" challenges to the country's future cooperation with the European Union.

"Turkish President Erdogan has taken on an unprecedented global role, and any hint of humiliation or rejection in the Netherlands is likely to spark backlash at home, where he is accustomed to getting his way. After being rebuffed by Germany and the Netherlands, Erdogan accused both countries of having Nazi inclinations, sparking a sharp rebuke from both nations, with the Dutch reminding him of the 200,000 people killed by Nazi forces. This weekend, Erdogan's ministers were scheduled to address expat Turks in the Netherlands to drum up support for a Turkish referendum that would consolidate his powers. However, Erdogan appears to have underestimated the Netherlands' upcoming elections, where immigration is a key issue. The Netherlands, where Erdogan's Foreign Minister and Minister of Families were denied permission to hold rallies, is set to hold elections on Wednesday. Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte believes Erdogan was not intentionally trying to disrupt the elections, but rather his ministers were attempting to force their way into the country against the direct wishes of the Dutch government. According to Rutte, his government was negotiating with Foreign Minister Mevlet Cavusoglu to speak at a small gathering in Rotterdam, but the talks were halted when Cavusoglu threatened unspecified action if he didn't get his way. This was a red line for Rutte, who stated, 'We stopped talks when the Turkish Foreign Secretary started threatening us with sanctions.' As a result, Cavusoglu was denied permission to land at Rotterdam airport. Undeterred, another of Erdogan's ministers, Families Minister Fatma Betul Sayan Kaya, attempted to drive to Rotterdam from Germany, but was later escorted back to the border by Dutch police." Geert Wilders, a populist nationalist who has built his campaign on an anti-Muslim platform, has been in a dead heat with Mark Rutte's People's Party for Freedom and Democracy. Over the weekend, Wilders attempted to capitalize on the diplomatic tensions by taking to Twitter, where he urged the Dutch Families Minister to "leave and never return" and to take her "Turkish fans" with her. Wilders has long advocated for the Netherlands to withdraw from the EU and close its borders, which he believes allowed Turkish Minister Erdogan's entourage to enter the country without restriction. However, in this extraordinary political climate, what would have been a minor diplomatic incident in the past has taken on a much greater significance. In the wake of Brexit and the Trump presidency, Europe is bracing for a series of elections that could see populist nationalists like Wilders gain power, fueled by anti-immigration sentiment and posing a existential threat to the EU. Meanwhile, Erdogan has emerged as a key global player, partnering with the US on counter-terrorism and Syria, and with Russia in the same conflict. However, his political reforms in Turkey have raised concerns among European diplomats, who see them as benefiting only Erdogan and his allies, rather than moving Turkey closer to EU membership. Since the failed coup attempt in July, Turkey has cracked down on media outlets, arresting 41,000 people and dismissing around 100,000 others from their jobs. As a result, Erdogan now wields significant influence over the continent, a development that is uncomfortable for European governments. The Brexit campaign, which was fueled by concerns over immigration and fueled by images of refugees entering Europe, was also driven by fears of radical Islamist terror attacks. The same fears that drive the populist narrative in the UK are also present across northern Europe. In the Netherlands, Geert Wilders is not alone in his anti-EU sentiments; French presidential candidate Marine Le Pen has also vowed to lead her country out of the EU if she wins, with elections scheduled for next month. As more European countries head to the polls in the coming months, many established parties are facing a decline in support, with nationalist populists gaining ground in various forms. Turkish President Erdogan holds significant sway over Europe's current situation, having brokered a 6 billion euro deal with the EU to stem the flow of refugees from Turkey and cooperating on counter-terrorism efforts to combat ISIS' presence in Europe. However, Erdogan's recent diplomatic spat has raised concerns about his growing authoritarian tendencies, as his actions have reinforced European fears that he is becoming increasingly autocratic.

At the first meeting of his Cabinet at the White House, Trump declared that the upcoming health care negotiation would be a "big, fat, beautiful" one, hoping to come up with a "terrific" solution. Earlier in the day, Trump tempered expectations for immediate drops in health insurance costs, telling a group of Americans affected by the Affordable Care Act that it could take several years for prices to decrease. He explained that increased competition and reduced regulation would eventually lead to lower costs, but noted that it would take time for the marketplace to kick in. Trump acknowledged that it would take a year or two for the effects to be seen, but promised that the outcome would be "a thing of beauty." His comments came as Republicans awaited a crucial score from the Congressional Budget Office on their health care replacement plan, which was unveiled and debated last week. Democrats argue that the American Health Care Act will force millions off their insurance plans and increase costs. The CBO score is expected as early as Monday. Trump expressed frustration that Obamacare's popularity seems to be rising among Americans, placing blame on the media for focusing on the law's success stories without highlighting its flaws, such as skyrocketing premiums and canceled insurance plans. "'The media is suddenly portraying Obamacare in a very positive light,' Trump said. 'I'm watching the news, and it looks great.' Trump also noted that his predecessor, former President Barack Obama, was gaining popularity now that he was no longer in office. 'When he left office, people began to appreciate him more. When he was still in office, people didn't have the same affection for him. That's just human nature,' Trump said."

According to a new report published by the organization, at least 652 children lost their lives in the past 12 months, a 20% increase from 2015. Alarmingly, nearly half of these children were killed in or near their schools. The report only includes verified figures, which means the actual death toll could be much higher. A 6-year-old boy, Ahmad, shared his heartbreaking story, saying, "I wanted to become a doctor, but maybe I won't become anything because our school was attacked. We used to play a lot in the schoolyard, but now I'm afraid of coming here." The report also reveals that in 2016, at least 850 children were recruited to fight in the conflict, more than double the number from the previous year. Children are increasingly being used in combat roles, including as executioners, suicide bombers, and prison guards, leaving them with life-altering scars. According to Geert Cappelaere, the UNICEF Regional Director for the Middle East and North Africa, "Each and every child is scarred for life with horrific consequences on their health, well-being, and future." UNICEF estimates that nearly six million children now rely on humanitarian assistance, a staggering 12 times the number in 2012. Moreover, the organization is unable to access some of the most hard-to-reach areas of the country, where an estimated 280,000 children are living under siege, cut off from humanitarian aid and dying in silence from preventable diseases. Last week, a report by British charity Save the Children highlighted the devastating impact of the civil war on Syrian children, who are suffering from "toxic stress" caused by the war's brutality. "At least three million Syrian children under the age of six have grown up in a war zone, with Save the Children warning that prolonged exposure to conflict could have devastating effects, including self-harm and suicide attempts. According to a report, one father, Firas, shared a heartbreaking story about his 3-year-old son, Saeed, who had been deeply traumatized by the violence. Firas described how Saeed would wake up in the middle of the night, filled with fear, after witnessing a child being slaughtered. He asked, 'How can a child not be afraid after seeing something like that?' The conflict in Syria, which began in 2011, has already claimed an estimated 400,000 lives, making it one of the worst humanitarian crises since World War II, according to the United Nations."

Light snowfall began to dust New York City early Tuesday morning, intensifying as the day went on, according to CNN producer John Griffin. A winter weather emergency declared by Mayor Bill DeBlasio took effect at midnight, and the city remains under a blizzard warning until midnight Wednesday. Meanwhile, Englewood, New Jersey, is also under a blizzard warning until midnight, with CNN producer Sonia Moghe capturing the flurry on her morning commute.

In Philadelphia, officials estimated that the snow was falling at a rate of 1 inch per hour, warning that reduced visibility was a concern. CNN's Lawrence Crook III described the wind and sleet at Spruce Street Harbor Park as feeling like "tiny bullets" hitting his face. Philadelphia remains under a winter storm warning until 6 p.m. Tuesday.

In the Boston area, Massachusetts, the National Weather Service (NWS) is predicting a "wall of snow" between 9 a.m. and 12 p.m. Tuesday. CNN affiliate WHDH captured the early snowfall in Fitchburg, located about 50 miles west of Boston, which is under a winter storm warning until 5 p.m. Tuesday.

In Washington, D.C., streets turned slippery and slushy, with CNN affiliate WJLA's Alex Liggit tweeting a photo of a street with scattered cars. At Reagan National Airport, nearly every flight was marked canceled. Washington is under a winter storm warning until 2 p.m. Tuesday.

Baltimore is also experiencing the storm, with a mix of snow and rain falling from the sky. CNN affiliate WJZ's Ron Matz tweeted a photo of a wet road with sleet and freezing rain. A winter storm warning remains in effect for Baltimore until 2 p.m. on Tuesday. Meanwhile, a statewide travel ban has been implemented in Connecticut, effective from 5 a.m. on Tuesday and will remain in place until further notice. A webcam in Hartford, Connecticut, captured the snowy conditions, showing a blanket of white. Additionally, Hartford is under a blizzard warning until 8 p.m. on Tuesday.

Egypt's prosecution office has ordered the release of Mubarak, according to a news agency report. On March 2, Mubarak was acquitted of charges related to the killing of protesters during the 2011 Arab Spring uprising, a verdict upheld by Egypt's Court of Cassation, the country's highest criminal court. While Mubarak was acquitted of the killing charges, he and his sons were convicted of corruption. On Monday, Ibrahim Saleh, the attorney general of the East Cairo prosecution, accepted Mubarak's request to have time spent in prison pending trial counted towards his sentence in the corruption case, according to state media. State media sources have confirmed that there are no longer any pending court cases against Mubarak. Egyptian media outlets are reporting, citing Mubarak's lawyer Farid al-Deeb, that Mubarak will be released within the next few days and will leave the military hospital where he is being held to return to his home in an upscale Cairo neighborhood.

The deployment of Japan's Izumo helicopter carrier, primarily used for anti-submarine missions, marks a rare display of naval power from Japan amidst escalating tensions in Asia, underscoring the Trump administration's commitment to maintaining a collaborative military presence in the region. The Malabar military exercises, held on a rotational basis in the West Pacific and Indian oceans since Japan joined in 2007, will see the Izumo transit through the contested South China Sea to reach the Indian Ocean. China has already expressed its discontent with the exercises, with a Global Times editorial in December warning that they would "jeopardize the peace and stability in the region." The 2017 exercises coincide with a period of heightened tension in the Asia-Pacific, following North Korea's recent missile tests, which sparked concerns in Tokyo about Kim Jong Un's regime's intentions. The tests were claimed to be carried out by the North Korean military unit tasked with targeting US military bases in Japan. Tensions are also running high between Japan and China over the disputed Senkaku Islands, which Beijing claims as the Diaoyu Islands. Furthermore, the ongoing construction of man-made islands in the South China Sea has escalated tensions with US allies in the region, prompting criticism from President Donald Trump and Secretary of State Rex Tillerson. In his confirmation hearing, Tillerson likened China's actions to Russia's annexation of Crimea, stating that building islands and placing military assets on them is akin to taking territory that others claim. The US is set to send a clear message to China, with Secretary Tillerson's upcoming visit to Asia this week, including stops in South Korea, China, and Japan. Next month, President Trump plans to host Chinese President Xi Jinping at his Mar-a-Lago estate in Florida for a summit. The US has also announced that it will permanently station attack drones in South Korea, a move that comes just days after South Korea received the first parts of the controversial THAAD missile defense system. According to Yvonne Chiu, a professor at Hong Kong University, the US needs to be seen as responsive to developments in the region.

The Japanese navy has added the 816-foot Izumo to its large-scale exercises, which highlights the importance of Japan's anti-submarine warfare capabilities in deterring Chinese expansion in the region. The Izumo, a helicopter carrier, is one of Japan's few tools that allow it to project military power beyond the defense of its own territories. As Corey Wallace, a security analyst at Freie University in Berlin, noted, Japan's subsurface detection and reaction capabilities are a strength, while China's is a weakness, despite China's larger subsurface fleet. Japan has a history of using its submarine hunting vessels, helicopter carriers, and sub-hunting aircraft to great effect, including helping the US keep the Soviet Pacific subsurface fleet "bottled up" in the North Pacific during the Cold War. The Japanese destroyer Izumo was initially planned to participate in exercises with US ships as part of the Malabar exercise, but the US Navy declined to comment on whether the vessel would be deployed to the disputed South China Sea. When asked about the Japanese Navy's movements, a US Navy official simply stated, "The US Navy does not comment on Japanese Navy movements." The Japanese government did not respond to a request for comment on the matter. While Japan does not have any territorial claims in the South China Sea, the country's concerns about China's growing military presence in the area have prompted Tokyo to increase its patrol and training activities in the region. The South China Sea dispute is expected to be a topic of discussion during Secretary Tillerson's trip to Asia this week and during Chinese President Xi's visit to the US in Florida.

The announcement came a week after North Korea launched four ballistic missiles into the Sea of Japan, also known as the East Sea, and amid the annual joint military exercises between the US and South Korea. The US Forces Korea (USFK) stated that the stationing of the company, which will be assigned to the 2nd Combat Aviation Brigade of the 2nd Infantry Division, directly supports the US Army's strategic plan to deploy a Gray Eagle company to each division. The Unmanned Aerial System (UAS) will significantly enhance the intelligence, surveillance, and reconnaissance capabilities of US Forces Korea and its Republic of Korea (ROK) partners. The Gray Eagle UAS can stay airborne for 24 hours and is equipped with Hellfire missiles, according to the US Army's website. Compared to the Predator drones, the Gray Eagle has upgraded reconnaissance and surveillance technology, said Corey Wallace, a researcher at the Graduate School of East Asian Studies at Freie Universit?t Berlin. The system can also integrate with Apache helicopters, which could be useful in navigating bad weather on the Korean Peninsula, where the US military has recently begun rotating 24 AH-64D Apaches. According to Wallace, the US and its regional partners aim to demonstrate their conventional deterrence and readiness, rather than just reacting to a full-scale attack by North Korea. The deployment is likely a show of force in response to increased provocations from North Korea, said Daniel Pinkston, a professor at Troy University in Seoul. North Korea has conducted a series of missile tests in recent months, a concerning development for the US and its allies in the region, as it suggests the country is refining its missile technology. "North Korea's accelerated pace of weapons testing and deployment has been met with a response, and they were wrong to assume otherwise," said Pinkston in an interview with CNN. "Given North Korea's recent behavior and the ongoing Foal Eagle exercise, I believe it's a good time to deploy our forces." This is the first time US forces have publicly announced the movement of drones, according to USFK spokesman Christopher Bush. It's no coincidence, said Yvonne Chiu, a professor at Hong Kong University. The US wants to make it clear to Pyongyang and Beijing that it is a significant player in Asia. "The US needs to be seen as responsive to developments in the region, and North Korea should know that," Chiu told CNN. The timing of the drone deployment may be a reaction to North Korea's missile launches and threatening posture, but it also coincides with political upheaval in South Korea. The country's Constitutional Court upheld the impeachment of former President Park Geun-hye on Friday, who was ousted in the aftermath of a corruption scandal. Park took a hardline approach to dealing with North Korea, but the current front-runner in the race to succeed her, Liberal candidate Moon Jae-in, has historically advocated for improving relations between the two countries. Wallace suggested that the announcement could be a way to ensure that a future government doesn't reverse the decision, much like the controversy surrounding the acceleration of THAAD deployment, which raised concerns that a left-leaning government might be less willing to confront North Korea directly. The Terminal High Altitude Area Defense (THAAD) system, a US-built missile defense system, was agreed upon by Park's government to be deployed in South Korea. At a rally celebrating the impeachment ruling, balloons read "No THAAD! Yes peace!" THAAD is designed to intercept incoming missiles from North Korea, and its first components arrived in South Korea last week. Despite its defensive nature, THAAD's deployment is highly controversial. Some South Koreans support THAAD as a means of protecting themselves from North Korean provocations, although it's not a foolproof system. Others are angry about the damage it has caused to diplomatic relations between Seoul and Beijing, which opposes THAAD due to concerns it poses a threat to its own security interests. China worries that THAAD's advanced radar system could be used for surveillance purposes, and many in the Chinese foreign policy establishment view THAAD as a significant threat, comparable to North Korea's nuclear program. According to Professor John Delury of Yonsei University, the radar and surveillance capabilities of THAAD are a major concern for China. With the announcement of attack drones being deployed in South Korea, Beijing will now have to worry about the presence of military assets in its backyard. Chiu noted that the US has a reputation in China for not being strong or interested in defending its interests, which will likely lead to a negative reaction from Beijing.

The bill, introduced by Rep. Jessica Farrar, a Democrat, would impose a 24-hour waiting period for men seeking certain medical procedures, including colonoscopies, vasectomies, and prescriptions for Viagra. Farrar acknowledges that her bill is unlikely to pass, but she hopes it will spark a conversation about the double standard in healthcare. As an advocate for women's health, Farrar has long been frustrated by Texas's restrictive abortion laws, which have made it difficult for women to access essential healthcare services. Her bill is designed to highlight the obstacles women face in their healthcare journeys, by applying the same standards to men. "Let's examine the challenges women in Texas face," Farrar said. "What if men had to undergo the same intrusive procedures?"

The bill's name, "A Man's Right to Know Act," is a nod to a pamphlet that Texas doctors are required to give women seeking abortions, titled "A Woman's Right to Know." However, Farrar's bill is a jab at the pamphlet's inaccuracies and ideological bias, which has been criticized for linking breast cancer to abortion and discouraging women from seeking abortions. Farrar points out that Texas has the highest maternal mortality rate in the developed world, and that the rate of women who died from pregnancy-related complications doubled between 2010 and 2014. In response, political opponents have launched a backlash against Farrar's bill. Representative Tony Tinderholt expressed disappointment with Representative Farrar's attempt to compare her stance on a recent bill to the abortion issue, stating that it reveals a lack of understanding of human biology. He suggested that Representative Farrar take a high school biology class to better educate herself on the matter before introducing future legislation.

In Texas, women face significant barriers to accessing abortions. The state has strict laws governing the procedure, and the scarcity of clinics further hinders women's ability to obtain an abortion. Under current law, women who are beyond 20 weeks pregnant can only obtain an abortion if their life is at risk, forcing them to carry an unviable fetus to term. Additionally, women must receive state-mandated counseling, undergo an ultrasound, and have the image of the unborn child described to them by their provider.

As of 2014, nearly 96% of Texas counties lacked clinics that provided abortions, affecting roughly 43% of the state's women. Since then, the number of facilities offering abortions in Texas has plummeted from 44 to 18, following the implementation of restrictions on abortion doctors and clinics. Although the Supreme Court later struck down these restrictions, the damage had already been done. Today, women in Texas can only access abortions in seven cities, leaving a vast area of the panhandle and west Texas without a single abortion clinic.

The White House announced that Trump had paid $38 million in additional taxes, on top of tens of millions of dollars in other taxes such as sales, excise, and employment taxes. Journalist David Cay Johnston published Trump's tax returns ahead of his appearance on MSNBC. "You're willing to break the law for ratings when you're pushing a story about two pages of tax returns from over a decade ago," a White House official said on Tuesday. Trump had promised during his presidential campaign to release his tax returns after the conclusion of a routine audit, but the White House has not specified a timeline. Recently, aides have suggested that Trump will not release his returns since winning the election. During the presidential campaign, Hillary Clinton and Trump's Republican rivals attempted to make the returns a campaign issue, but were unable to generate enough pressure to force their release. In October, The New York Times obtained a single year's return anonymously, which showed that Trump declared a $916 million loss and listed tax benefits he used after a turbulent financial period in the early 1990s. According to tax experts, Trump could have used his loss to cancel out an equivalent amount of taxable income for nearly two decades.

As the first round of the French presidential election approaches and Germany prepares for its own election later this year, the Dutch political landscape is under intense scrutiny for signs of broader trends. Conservative Prime Minister Mark Rutte is facing a closely contested battle with far-right challenger Geert Wilders, whose anti-immigrant and anti-Islam rhetoric has sparked controversy and attracted widespread support in a country increasingly divided by issues of austerity and immigration. According to the latest poll by Leiden University's Peilingwijzer, Rutte's Party for Freedom and Democracy (VVD) holds a slim lead over Wilders' Freedom Party (PVV), but the outcome is far from certain. With 28 parties on the ballot, the Dutch system of proportional representation virtually guarantees a coalition government. For Rutte, securing a third term in office will depend on his party's ability to form the largest group in the 150-seat House of Representatives, which would likely require a coalition with at least three other parties. However, many Dutch voters are disillusioned with the status quo and Wilders has gained popularity due to his uncompromising rhetoric and controversial views. Other parties, including Rutte's VVD, have shifted to the right in response. Amsterdam resident Ron Mesland, a musician and actor, expressed concern about the broader implications of Wilders' popularity: "I'm worried about Geert Wilders, but more so about the influence he has on other parties," he said. "It seems like most other parties are adopting his language and ideas, and that's what really troubles me." According to Ruud Koole, a politics professor at the University of Leiden, if Wilders' party secures the most seats in the House of Representatives, it would be challenging for him to govern due to the country's political system, which typically involves coalition governments. Koole explained that Wilders would need to form a coalition with other parties, but these parties are unlikely to partner with the PVV. In an interview, Koole said that Wilders' popularity stems from his ability to address the specific concerns of a particular segment of the electorate, including issues related to unemployment, healthcare, and the Dutch national identity. He noted that voters who support Wilders do not necessarily believe he has the solutions to these problems, but rather appreciate that he acknowledges and expresses their concerns. However, Wilders' popularity has recently declined, with one expert suggesting that this may be due in part to the rise of US President Donald Trump. Quentin Peel, an associate fellow at Chatham House, observed that Wilders' support has slipped below 20% in recent weeks, and that this decline may be attributed to concerns among moderate Dutch citizens about the events unfolding in Washington. Peel noted that predicting the election results is difficult due to the unpredictability of voter behavior. "You have at least 28 parties running in this campaign, and you're likely to end up with a complex coalition, and Mr. Wilders won't be part of it," Geert Wilders said.

Given its bellwether status as the first major election in Europe this year, the Netherlands has taken center stage globally. According to preliminary Eurostat data, the country's economy grew by 2.1% last year, and investors have remained relatively calm throughout the campaign. However, Prime Minister Rutte's tough austerity measures aimed at combating the 2011-2012 recession have disproportionately affected the country's poorest, weighing heavily on their minds as they prepare to vote.

"My biggest concern is that the working class is being pushed down," said Tony Regnerus, a delivery driver. "Immigrants are coming in and getting a better life than working-class people. They're not motivated to do anything with their lives or get a job. Every day, I see people in big cities like Rotterdam and Gouda and Delft wearing expensive Canada Goose jackets, but I, a working man, can't afford it. It's the other way around that should be."

The Netherlands' relationship with the European Union has been a hot topic on the campaign trail. As founding members of the union, attitudes have cooled in recent years, and Wilders has pledged a Brexit-style referendum on whether to leave the EU. Fisherman Jan de Boer is concerned about the future of his industry, which he believes is threatened by EU regulations, and this will be at the forefront of his mind when he casts his ballot on election day. "The rules are very bad for fishermen in the Netherlands," he said. "We want to fish, and our children want to fish." Until now, de Boer has always voted for the Christian Party, but this time, he said, that will change. "Geert Wilders is the only party that fights European rules, and that's important to me."

However, bus company worker Leonard Schaab is skeptical about Wilders' chances: "The polls are often a bit off, and when the real elections take place, most people will vote for other parties." "The man doesn't have the skills to do it," he added. "The only thing Geert Wilders does is shout about problems... he creates problems, but he never has solutions."

Turkey and the Netherlands had already been at odds, with high-level diplomatic relations frozen, when Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan criticized the Dutch for failing to prevent the 1995 massacre of 8,000 Bosnian Muslims by Bosnian Serb forces in Srebrenica. During a speech in Ankara, Erdogan referenced the Dutch UN peacekeepers who were present during the massacre, saying, "We know the Dutch and the people of Holland from Srebrenica. We know how they massacred people there, and we don't need anyone to teach us about civilization." The Dutch Prime Minister, Mark Rutte, responded to Erdogan's comments, calling them a "disgusting falsification of history." In an interview with RTL, Rutte said, "Erdogan continues to push the limits. This is of unbelievably low quality and style. We won't stoop to his level. It's unacceptable and extremely irritating." The Turkish president's inflammatory remarks added fuel to the fire, as tensions between the two countries had already been escalating. The row began over the weekend, when Turkish officials were blocked from addressing political rallies in the Netherlands. The Dutch refused to allow Turkish Foreign Minister Mevlut Cavusoglu to visit Rotterdam, and later stopped Turkey's Family Affairs Minister Fatma Betul Sayan Kaya from entering the Turkish consulate. Violent clashes broke out after the ministers were prevented from speaking. Erdogan had already made angry remarks about the Dutch government, comparing it to the Nazis, since the incidents in Rotterdam. The Netherlands suffered a devastating loss of over 200,000 citizens during its occupation by Nazi Germany in World War II, and Prime Minister Rutte has called for an apology. In response to the escalating tensions, Turkey announced on Monday that it would not allow the Dutch ambassador to return to Ankara and suspended high-level diplomatic relations between the two countries. The escalating diplomatic row has also prompted threats from Turkey to withdraw from the EU-Migrant deal, aimed at stemming the flow of migrants to Europe. The growing tensions come ahead of the Dutch general election on Wednesday, with far-right candidate Geert Wilders' anti-Islam, anti-EU Party for Freedom (PVV) expected to make a strong showing. Wilders has sought to capitalize on the discord between the Netherlands and Turkey to gain political advantage. Meanwhile, it is believed that Turkish President Erdogan is attempting to demonstrate his leadership strength on the world stage. During a speech on healthcare, Erdogan made controversial comments about Srebrenica, which drew loud applause from the audience. Erdogan also urged Dutch voters of immigrant backgrounds not to vote for Wilders, whom he described as an "extreme racist" or Prime Minister Rutte in Wednesday's election.

Rex Tillerson will need a strong diplomatic hand when he embarks on his first trip to Asia on Wednesday, as tensions escalate in the region. North Korea's missile program is rapidly advancing, posing a threat to the United States and its key allies in East Asia, Japan and South Korea. The latter is still reeling from the sudden ousting of its president. To succeed, Tillerson must convince both nations that it's in their best interests to maintain their commitment to the United States and its controversial missile defense system. His biggest test will come when he visits China, becoming the first Trump Cabinet member to do so, and attempts to leverage the country's perceived influence over North Korea. Our Asia correspondents outline the challenges Tillerson faces on each stop: South Korea, China, and Japan.

In Japan, Tillerson's most pressing concern is the growing nuclear threat from North Korea. The country's leader, Kim Jong Un, has test-fired ballistic missiles, including one during a visit by Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and US President Donald Trump in Florida. The timing of this test-fire was seen by some analysts as a message to Tokyo. More recently, North Korea launched four ballistic missiles simultaneously, with state media implying that the launch was a practice run for striking US military bases in Japan, where around 52,000 US service members are stationed. Tillerson will meet with Abe and his counterpart, Foreign Minister Fumio Kishida, to reassure Japan that it remains the United States' closest and most trusted ally in the Asia-Pacific. Although Trump had questioned US alliances in the region during his presidential campaign, the new administration has largely backed off from that rhetoric. As US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson seeks to curb North Korea's nuclear ambitions, he may face a significant hurdle in the form of tensions between Japan and South Korea, two of the region's major allies. The Japanese ambassador was recalled from Seoul in January after a statue depicting "comfort women" who were forced into sexual slavery by Japanese forces during World War II sparked controversy. To address this challenge, Tillerson will need to employ his diplomatic skills to encourage Japan and South Korea to resolve their issues, allowing the three countries to focus on the growing threat posed by North Korea to regional and global security.

When Tillerson arrives in Seoul, his South Korean counterparts will face the daunting task of convincing him that business as usual can continue, despite the country's current state of political turmoil. Park Geun-hye's recent ousting from office has left the country deeply divided, and the government has been largely paralyzed since the corruption scandal broke months ago. However, those in power will work tirelessly to secure the assurances they desire from the US Secretary of State. During his visit, Tillerson will meet with acting President Hwang Kyo-ahn and Foreign Minister Yun Byung-se, whom he previously met at the G20 foreign ministers' meeting in Bonn, Germany. South Korean officials will be looking for reassurances from Tillerson, similar to those offered by US Defense Secretary James Mattis during his recent visit, that Washington is committed to an "overwhelming" response to any North Korean attack. The timing of Tillerson's visit is also significant, as Seoul claims that Beijing is imposing economic sanctions in retaliation for the country's decision to install the US missile defense system, THAAD, which Washington believes is necessary to counter the North Korean missile threat. Now that Park is no longer in power, the new leader of South Korea will also be expected to uphold the agreement. Snap elections are scheduled to take place by the end of May. The first components of the THAAD system arrived in South Korea last week, with the goal of having it fully operational by July at the earliest. In Beijing on Saturday, Tillerson's first priority will be to finalize details for a potential summit between Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping in April. This would be the first meeting between the two leaders, a relationship that many consider the most important in the world. There are many pressing issues to discuss, including the ongoing crisis in North Korea. Since 2016, North Korea has conducted two nuclear tests and dozens of ballistic missile tests, significantly escalating tensions on the peninsula. The Trump administration wants China to take more action to address the threat. China is likely to bring up the THAAD anti-missile defense system and Gray Eagle attack drones in South Korea, which Beijing has strongly disapproved of. Tillerson will likely leave China with a clear understanding of Beijing's disapproval. He will also likely raise concerns about China's military build-up in the South China Sea. During his confirmation hearing, Tillerson suggested that China should be denied access to the artificial islands it has built in the disputed waters. Despite campaign rhetoric, the Trump administration has taken a relatively hands-off approach to China so far, not following through on threats to label China a currency manipulator or impose steep tariffs on Chinese imports. Trump has also endorsed the "One China" policy, which has governed US-China-Taiwan relations for decades, after initially questioning its legitimacy. Tillerson's visit to China sets the stage for the upcoming Xi-Trump meeting and could mark a turning point in the Trump administration's approach to China, potentially marking a shift from calm relations to a more confrontational stance.

Rhode Island Democrat Sheldon Whitehouse claims that FBI Director James Comey made a promise to him and Senator Lindsey Graham, a Republican from South Carolina, during a March 2 meeting. According to Whitehouse, Comey assured them that he would confirm the existence of an investigation and its scope, specifically regarding the Russia-Trump probe, as he had not been able to do so at that point. Whitehouse and Graham have requested evidence from the Justice Department to support President Trump's claims that former President Barack Obama wiretapped Trump Tower. The two lawmakers are leading one of three Congressional investigations into Russia's interference in the US elections. The FBI has not commented on whether Comey will respond to the request by Wednesday. Graham expressed frustration on Tuesday, stating that the Trump administration has not provided any evidence of wiretapping and plans to "go tough" on the administration during Wednesday's hearing. The White House has wavered in its stance on Trump's claims over the past two days. Initially, Press Secretary Sean Spicer said that Trump did not mean his wiretapping claim literally, but on Tuesday, Spicer stated that Trump is "extremely confident" he will be vindicated by the evidence. Without providing specific examples, Spicer mentioned that there is "significant reporting" about surveillance techniques used during the 2016 election. Spicer said that Trump believes he will ultimately be vindicated. Meanwhile, Democrats on the Senate Intelligence Committee, which is conducting a separate investigation, have expressed doubt that Trump has evidence of wiretapping, but the issue could be easily settled if the administration provides the necessary evidence. Senator Mark Warner, the top Democrat on the Senate Intelligence Committee, stated that all concerns could be resolved with a single phone call, before attending a committee hearing on Tuesday. Warner, a Virginia Democrat, said he has seen no evidence to support President Trump's claim that President Obama wiretapped him. Warner expects the first public hearing on Russia from the Senate Intelligence Committee to take place later this month. He expressed a desire to hear from Roger Stone, a former Trump adviser, who had contact with "Guccifer 2.0," the online persona claiming responsibility for hacking the Democratic National Committee. Warner emphasized that Stone's involvement in the investigation is significant, as he has acknowledged being in contact with Russians. Stone has disputed these claims, stating that his contact with Guccifer was limited to a brief Twitter exchange, and any other suggestions are "fabrications."

The House Intelligence Committee has scheduled its first hearing for Monday, during which current and former intelligence chiefs will testify. Senate Intelligence Committee Chairman Richard Burr said on Monday that he has requested information about Trump's wiretap claims from the "appropriate people" and has received "sufficient" responses. However, Senate Democrats on the Intelligence Committee have not yet seen any evidence to support the claims. Senator Dianne Feinstein, a veteran member of the panel, stated that she has heard nothing to support the wiretap claims and is convinced that no wiretapping occurred. Warner also expressed frustration with the administration's response to information requests, saying, "I'm not sure why this is taking any time."

A woman told the Australian Transport Safety Bureau (ATSB) that she was sleeping and listening to music on a flight when she heard an explosion about two hours into the journey. She said she felt burning on her face as she turned around, and then grabbed her face, causing her headphones to wrap around her neck. The woman, who remained anonymous, claimed she ripped off the headphones and threw them to the floor, where she saw sparks and small flames shooting out. She added that as she attempted to stomp on the flames, flight attendants were already there with a bucket of water to extinguish them. The attendants managed to pour the water on the flames and put the headphones in a bucket at the back of the plane, but not before they had melted into the aircraft floor. The passenger said that the cabin was filled with the smell of melted plastic and burnt hair, and that people were coughing and choking throughout the rest of the flight. The ATSB released a statement saying that it was likely the batteries inside the headphones that had caught fire, rather than the headphones themselves. However, the agency refused to disclose the type of batteries or headphones involved in the incident, which occurred on February 19. The incident came just a day after an Airbus A320 made an emergency landing in Nagoya, Japan, after a portable power pack started a fire in an overhead locker. Lithium batteries have been known to cause fires on board planes. In 2016, the US authorities prohibited Samsung Galaxy Note 7 devices from being carried on all US flights due to concerns over their lithium batteries, which were prone to spontaneous ignition. The ban also extended to shipping the phones as air cargo. Samsung attributed the issue to faulty lithium-ion batteries, which were overheating and causing the devices to catch fire. Despite efforts to rectify the problem, the company ultimately ceased production of the device. Meanwhile, Australia's Civil Aviation Safety Authority has reported a significant increase in incidents involving electronic devices in recent years, from just three in 2011 to 106 in 2015, according to Flight Safety Australia. When asked about the specific brand of headphones or batteries involved in these incidents, the authority declined to provide further information.

According to estimates, the People's Party for Freedom and Democracy (VVD) is likely to be followed closely by a three-way tie for second place, with the Party for Freedom (PVV), Christian Democratic Appeal (CDA), and Democrats (D66) all vying for position. Geert Wilders, the PVV's leader, a far-right figure known for his controversial views, tweeted a message of gratitude to his supporters, saying, "PVV voters, thank you. We've won seats, and it's a first victory. Rutte hasn't managed to get rid of me yet." Other parties expected to win seats include GroenLinks (Green Left), the Socialist Party, and the Labour Party (PVDA), led by Deputy Prime Minister Lodewijk Asscher. The election was widely seen as a test of the spread of populist sentiment across Europe, following the victories of US President Donald Trump and the Brexit referendum in the UK. Wilders, a controversial figure known for his anti-immigrant and anti-EU views, had campaigned on a platform of "de-Islamification," calling for the closure of Islamic schools and the ban of the Quran and burqa. His message resonated with many ordinary Dutch voters who have been hard hit by austerity measures and feel that the country has taken in too many refugees and migrants. "The Netherlands is full," said Wilders supporter Jack outside a polling station in Volendam. "If it were up to me, I would have stopped all Turkish people at the border." Others, however, were disturbed by the tone of the campaign and said they had voted tactically to prevent the far right from gaining power or to support parties that align with their values. "I thought it was important to vote strategically," said Amsterdam resident Kathie Somwerwil. "I usually vote more left of center, but with Wilders, I felt that wasn't the Dutch way, so I voted for Mr. Rutte's VVD." Author Bert Nap explained that he voted for the progressive PvdA party because it showed courage by forming a government with Rutte's party, despite being unpopular with many supporters. "I want to support a party that has taken a strong stance," he said. "They will likely suffer heavy losses in this election, but they need to be able to recover for the next election, so they must be sustained." 

The fragmented political landscape in the Netherlands, with 28 parties on the ballot, and the country's system of proportional representation, often lead to coalition governments. However, this can also result in prolonged periods of political instability and uncertainty. According to the House of Representatives website, the average time taken to form a coalition cabinet in the post-war era is 89.5 days. In 1977, it took 208 days for Dries Van Agt's Christian Democrats to reach a power-sharing deal. Voters expect a prolonged period of negotiations before the next government is formed. "I think there will be a lot of negotiations," said research analyst Robin Vanstraalen. "Given the fragmentation and the polls showing it will be a long process. And eventually it will end up in the middle -- which is where we have been for the last few years already."

The support for Rutte, the leader, was boosted by factors that included his move to the right in response to Wilders' popularity. At one stage, Wilders and Rutte were neck-and-neck in the Peilingwijzer poll of polls by Leiden University, but in recent days Rutte had taken the lead. Andre Krouwel, a political scientist at the Free University Amsterdam and owner of the election website Kieskompas, believes that Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan's ongoing feud with the Dutch government has inadvertently boosted support for Prime Minister Mark Rutte. The tensions between the Netherlands and Turkey have been escalating since the Dutch government refused to allow Turkish Foreign Minister Mevlut Cavusoglu to hold a political rally in Rotterdam last weekend. In response, Erdogan accused the Netherlands of being responsible for the Srebrenica massacre in 1995. Traditionally, voter turnout in the Netherlands is high, with nearly 75% of the electorate casting their ballots in the last election in 2012. This year's election is shaping up to be no exception, with reports of long queues forming at polling booths in The Hague's central station as commuters returned home from work. According to NOS, by 5:45 p.m. local time, 55% of the electorate had voted, up from 48% at the same time in 2012. Hanneke Spijker, a volunteer at an Amsterdam polling station, reported that large numbers of people had been coming out to vote since early Wednesday morning. "It's incredible," she said. "I wouldn't be surprised if it's a record turnout. We never have lines like this."

On his first official trip to Asia, Secretary of State Rex Tillerson will navigate a delicate diplomatic landscape, particularly in Beijing, North Korea's closest ally and protector. In Beijing, Tillerson will convey the US's frustration with Chinese companies facilitating North Korea's weapons program, while also seeking Chinese support for a broader effort to curb North Korea's nuclear ambitions, similar to the international coalition that achieved the Iran nuclear deal. This visit will also lay the groundwork for Chinese President Xi Jinping's trip to the US in April. Tillerson will also address other contentious issues between the US and China, including territorial disputes in the South China Sea, trade, Taiwan's status, and the recent deployment of a defensive missile system and drones to South Korea. However, the situation with North Korea is the most pressing and potentially dangerous issue, as Pyongyang has accelerated its nuclear program in recent months with the aim of developing a nuclear weapon and the means to deliver it to the US. "China has been part of the problem rather than part of the solution" in addressing North Korea's nuclear threat, said Bruce Klingner, a senior research fellow at the Heritage Foundation. China has "acted like North Korea's lawyer at the UN Security Council, denying evidence of wrongdoing, insisting on loopholes, and watering down effective resolutions" at the United Nations, Klingner added. "When North Korea engages in provocative or violative behavior, they often respond by urging both Koreas not to escalate tensions, despite being the primary aggressor," said [Name], continuing his thought. Meanwhile, Acting State Department spokesman Mark Toner revealed that discussions between Secretary of State Rex Tillerson and his Chinese counterpart have already begun to explore ways to pressure North Korea. "We're looking at what additional steps we can take to make the regime feel the consequences of their actions and pay a price for their behavior," Toner explained. He acknowledged that the US wants China to play a more significant role in addressing the North Korea issue. "We recognize China's influence over North Korea and encourage it to use that leverage to implement the existing sanctions regime more thoroughly or explore other ways to exert pressure," Toner said. Notably, China's influence over North Korea is significant, as the country accounts for 90% of North Korea's economic activity, according to [Name]. Chinese firms can operate as front companies, allowing North Korea to sell weapons and goods abroad and import goods. The US is considering imposing sanctions on Chinese firms that engage in economic activities with North Korea, given evidence that some of them are facilitating the country's weapons trade. "We can influence Chinese banks and businesses that deal with North Korea, as we have done in the past," [Name] said. In the mid-2000s, the Bank of China took a bold step by cutting off its ties with North Korea to avoid the risk of US sanctions. According to Klingner, this means that even if Beijing doesn't want to comply, we can still influence the behavior of Chinese entities that engage in economic activity with North Korea. The Trump administration has already begun to follow in the footsteps of the Obama administration, which started cracking down on Chinese companies last year. Just last week, the Commerce Department imposed a $1.2 billion fine on ZTE, a Chinese tech firm, for violating sanctions by selling equipment to Iran and North Korea. In September, the Obama administration took a significant step by targeting the Dandong Hongxiang Industrial Development Co. Ltd, a Chinese company, for its ties to North Korea and support of its nuclear program. On the same day, the Justice Department unsealed four indictments for money laundering against the same firm and four individuals, all of whom were acting on behalf of Pyongyang.

A massive hack, initiated in January 2014, compromised at least 500 million Yahoo accounts. The stolen information was used to gain unauthorized access to email accounts at Yahoo, Google, and other webmail providers, including those of Russian journalists, government officials, and private-sector employees from various industries, according to the Department of Justice. The hackers obtained names, email addresses, and passwords, but not financial information, Yahoo announced in a statement about the breach. The two FSB officers, Igor Anatolyevich Sushchin and Dmitry Aleksandrovich Dokuchaev, allegedly conspired with Russian national Alexsey Alexseyevich Belan and Canadian resident Karim Baratov, also known as "Kay," "Karim Taloverov," and "Karim Akehmet Tokbergenov." Dokuchaev was arrested in Russia in December and accused of spying for the US, although a lawyer for one of the men charged with Dokuchaev said the agency has not confirmed this. Baratov was arrested without incident in Ancaster, Ontario, on Tuesday morning. Acting Assistant Attorney General Mary McCord described the hacking as "beyond the pale" at a news conference in Washington. The stolen Yahoo data is being sold on the dark web. Yahoo CEO Marissa Mayer publicly thanked US authorities on Wednesday, expressing her gratitude to the FBI and DOJ. The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) in San Francisco has scheduled a news conference for later on Wednesday afternoon to discuss undisclosed topics. Yahoo has suffered at least two breaches, with a 2014 attack attributed to state-sponsored hackers, although the company declined to name the responsible party. The latest cyberattack, attributed to Russian hackers, comes at a time of strained relations between the US and Russia. This announcement is the latest in a series of cyberattacks blamed on Russia, which has been a point of tension between the US and Russia under President Donald Trump's administration. Previous attacks attributed to Russian hackers include the exposure of Hillary Clinton's campaign chairman, John Podesta's, emails and the internal workings of the Democratic National Committee. Russia's cybercrime underworld has traditionally focused on financial crimes rather than economic espionage. However, the recent indictment marks a significant shift, as it links the cybercrime operation to the Russian government's intelligence apparatus - a connection that has long been suspected by cybersecurity experts but not explicitly acknowledged by the US government. The Department of Justice's national security division has previously maintained that traditional government-to-government espionage is not criminal, but economic espionage crosses a line. Wednesday's indictment appears to blur the lines between government espionage and cybercrime more broadly. Russia has consistently refused to extradite or cooperate in the arrest of cybercriminals indicted in the US, although the DOJ has been able to apprehend many of them while they were traveling abroad. The Department of Justice has previously brought a comprehensive indictment against state-sponsored hackers, specifically Chinese military hackers in 2014. The indictment accused China of orchestrating economic espionage, targeting the theft of corporate secrets. The US has repeatedly urged China to cease its sponsorship of economic espionage against American companies. Despite this, the Chinese military hackers remain at large, and the DOJ has stated that it does not expect to be able to apprehend them unless Beijing chooses to extradite them or they travel abroad. The indictments were part of a broader strategy to publicly expose and condemn the cyber activity, making it clear that the US is aware of the actions and willing to hold perpetrators accountable. This story has been updated to reflect new developments.

An adviser to a senator who attended the meeting said that the acknowledgment from the White House was essentially that the House GOP bill in its current form lacks the necessary votes to pass in the Senate. The meeting was attended by a small group of conservative senators who have expressed significant concerns about the bill. According to multiple aides, Vice President Mike Pence made a brief visit to the closed-door briefing with lawmakers. A senior Republican aide to a senator in the room said that the White House is considering significant changes to the Ryan bill. "It's unrealistic to think that a single individual or a small group can impose their will on 535 people," said a Republican senator, emphasizing that revising the bill is a normal part of the legislative process. Senator Ted Cruz of Texas described the talks as "productive" and said that discussions are ongoing with the White House, the administration, the House, and the Senate. Cruz also expressed his dissatisfaction with the current House bill, stating that it doesn't adequately address the issue and that more work is needed. A senior administration official confirmed that the White House has continued to advocate for changes to the bill, including some tailored to moderate concerns, in an effort to secure conservative votes in the House. However, the official also noted that the White House did not challenge the claim that the House bill cannot pass the Senate in its current form. A White House official stated that they believe significant progress has been made in shaping language that will be appealing. However, the official declined to specify which changes have already been implemented, noting that the White House's private stance remains to advocate for an earlier sunset of the Medicaid expansion.
