The House bill is currently facing significant challenges. Following a warning from the non-partisan Congressional Budget Office that 24 million Americans could lose insurance coverage over the next decade if the bill is passed, moderate Republicans Reps. Leonard Lance and Rep. Ileana Ros-Lehtinen have publicly expressed their opposition to the legislation, and others have shared their concerns. 

Moderates are not the only obstacle to overcome, however. House conservatives, particularly members of the Freedom Caucus, have been vocal in their opposition to the bill in its current form, and House Speaker Paul Ryan can only afford to lose 21 of his own members on the bill. 

If House leaders address conservatives' concerns by rolling back Medicaid expansion sooner than 2020, they risk alienating moderates. Conversely, if they attempt to win over moderates by making tax credits more generous for older Americans, they may lose more conservatives. 

Another pressing concern from the White House is whether the House bill can even pass through the Senate under reconciliation rules or the Byrd Rule. Lawmakers have long agreed that the best way to repeal and partially replace Obamacare is through the process of budget reconciliation, which only requires a simple majority vote in the Senate. However, budget reconciliation comes with strict requirements. Members cannot simply pass anything through reconciliation. "A senior Republican aide to a senator present at a meeting on Tuesday revealed that there is a growing awareness that certain aspects of the House bill may not comply with the Senate's reconciliation rules. If this is the case, the Senate parliamentarian could potentially disallow certain parts of the legislation. Some conservatives are urging the White House to override the parliamentarian's decision, but if they are willing to take that political risk, they should do so with a bill that they truly believe will lead to lower premiums in the future, rather than the Ryan bill. According to the Republican aide, some senators are advocating for a more comprehensive package that would allow states to sell insurance across state lines, make additional changes to Medicaid, and help reduce drug prices, rather than overriding the parliamentarian to pass the House package."

A 28-year-old woman's lifeless body was discovered in a field near Deobagh Beach in Canacona, a popular tourist destination in Goa, according to Police Inspector Fiolmeno Costa. The body was found in a pool of blood with severe head injuries, Deputy Superintendent of Police Sammy Tavares revealed. The case is being treated as a murder, and an investigation is underway. One person has been arrested in connection with the woman's death, and authorities are also investigating whether she was sexually assaulted. The suspect had visible marks on his face that could have been inflicted by the victim during a struggle, Police Superintendent Kartik Kasyap told CNN. The results of the post-mortem examination have not been released yet. The woman was found to be carrying a British passport. The British Foreign Office has confirmed that a British-Irish woman has died in Goa, India, and is providing support to her family during this difficult time. Indian police are conducting an investigation, and the Foreign Office is in close contact with them.

Goa, known for its beautiful beaches and vibrant nightlife, is a popular tourist destination that attracts visitors from around the world. In 2016, over 6.3 million tourists visited the state, according to the Goa Department of Tourism. Last year, two men were acquitted of the rape and murder of British teenager Scarlett Keeling, whose body was found on Anjuna beach in Goa in 2008. Initially, police suggested that Keeling had drowned after taking drugs, but her mother disputed this account and launched a campaign for a second autopsy. The investigation later confirmed that Keeling was sexually assaulted before her death. Local media and a state minister had previously alleged that police had covered up the killing to protect Goa's tourism industry.

Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte took to the stage in The Hague on Wednesday night, basking in the adoration of his enthusiastic supporters as they cheered and whistled loudly. "Tonight belongs to the Netherlands," he declared, "after Brexit and the American elections, where we stood up against the wrong kind of populism." According to the Netherlands' state broadcaster NOS, voter turnout reached an impressive 81%, the highest in three decades. With 94% of the votes counted, Rutte's VVD party is projected to win 33 seats out of a total 150, narrowly ahead of Wilders' PVV party, which secured 20 seats, just one more than the mainstream Christian Democratic Appeal and D66 parties. Despite the celebrations, Rutte's party won eight fewer seats than in the 2012 election, when it claimed 41. The election was widely seen as a test of populist right-wing sentiment in Europe, ahead of the French Presidential election in April and the German national vote in September. Wilders, a vocal critic of mass immigration and the European Union, delivered a defiant speech, claiming he was "part of the winners." "Rutte says the elections have put a stop to the wrong type of populism," he said, "but he hasn't gotten rid of me yet." In his speech to supporters, Rutte revealed that many European leaders had already contacted him to congratulate him on his victory. French President Francois Hollande issued a statement the next morning, hailing the result as a "clear victory against extremism." "The values of openness, respect for others, and faith in Europe's future are the only true response to the nationalist impulses and isolationism that are shaking the world," he said. French Foreign Minister Jean-Marc Ayrault congratulated the Dutch on Twitter, saying, "Congratulations to the Dutch for preventing the rise of the far right and for their willingness to work towards a stronger Europe." Germany's foreign ministry echoed the sentiment, stating, "The large majority of Dutch voters have rejected anti-European policies, which is good news. We need the Netherlands to be strong partners in a united Europe." Italian Foreign Minister Paolo Gentilioni tweeted that the "anti-EU right" had suffered a defeat in the Netherlands, adding, "Let's work together for change and revitalize the European Union." Notably, Wilders' anti-EU allies across the continent, including French presidential candidate Marine Le Pen, remained silent on the issue. Wilders, who had been leading polls for much of 2016, had campaigned on a platform of "de-Islamification," calling for the closure of Islamic schools and the ban of the Quran and burqa. Despite his election loss, Wilders remained optimistic, saying, "I still expect to see a 'European spring' for my supporters. Our influence has been immense, and our patriotic spring will continue to unfold. If the parties need me or the PVV for coalition talks, I'm happy to participate. If not, then they haven't seen the last of me." The Netherlands is deeply divided, according to Andre Krouwel, a political scientist at the Free University Amsterdam and owner of election website Kieskompas. "The only conclusion from the election result is that the Dutch are deeply divided," he said, noting that the result is a very polarized outcome, with people abandoning centrist parties and the left-wing project. The left-wing parties together won 37 seats in the 150-seat parliament, Krouwel said.

Despite his slight gain in seats, Krouwel believes that Geert Wilders, the leader of the Party for Freedom, will be almost powerless in the new political environment. "The very vocal minority that dominated the elections and focused on Wilders has now abandoned him," Krouwel said, adding that nobody wants to form a coalition with him.

The election took place against the backdrop of heightened tensions between the Netherlands and Turkey, which had escalated over the Dutch government's refusal to allow Turkish ministers to address political rallies inside the country. Krouwel suggested that the war of words between Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan and the Dutch government may have boosted support for Mark Rutte, the leader of the People's Party for Freedom and Democracy.

The Netherlands has a complex political landscape, with over 28 parties participating in the vote. Since no party won a majority of seats, a multi-party governing coalition will need to be formed. The final results may not be known until Friday, with 22 of 388 municipalities still to report.

Once the results are official, Rutte will begin negotiations to form a government. Potential coalition partners include the GroenLinks (Green Left) Party and the Socialist Party, which are poised to win 14 seats each. The PVDA (Labour) party, which had previously partnered with Rutte's party in government, suffered a significant decline in support, losing 29 seats.

In his victory speech, Rutte emphasized the need to unite the country and form a stable government. "In the next couple of weeks and months, it is important to unite the country, to make sure that we form a stable government so that the country can be governed wisely for the next four years," he said.

US District Court Judge Derrick Watson issued a scathing 43-page ruling just hours before President Trump's revised travel ban was set to take effect on Thursday. In his ruling, Watson criticized the government's arguments, saying they were "palpably illogical." The revised ban would have temporarily barred travelers from six Muslim-majority countries from entering the United States.

Watson's ruling came after he heard Hawaii's case against the revised ban, which replaced the original ban signed by Trump in January that was blocked by another federal judge.

Here are five key facts about Judge Derrick Watson:

* He was nominated by President Barack Obama in 2012 to serve on the US District Court for the District of Hawaii.
* Obama described Watson and six other nominees as "qualified and ready to serve" and praised their "talent, expertise, and fair-mindedness."
* The Senate unanimously confirmed Watson with a 94-0 vote.
* Watson was born in Honolulu, Hawaii, and graduated from Harvard Law School in 1991. He attended Harvard College, graduating in 1988.
* Watson made history as the fourth person of Native Hawaiian descent to serve as an Article III judge in the United States, according to the Congressional Asian Pacific Americans Caucus. Congresswoman Tulsi Gabbard praised Watson's confirmation, saying he would "serve Hawaii with distinction and honor." Article III judges serve on the US Supreme Court, federal courts of appeals, and district courts. President Trump's travel bans are a significant topic in the news. Watson, a seasoned lawyer, has a strong background in the law. Prior to becoming a judge at the US District Court, Watson worked as an assistant United States attorney in the District of Hawaii and Northern District of California. Before that, he was a partner at a San Francisco law firm, where he focused on product liability and environmental cost recovery litigation. Additionally, Watson served as a US Army Reserve captain. Watson has also done pro bono work throughout his career. In his confirmation hearing questionnaire, Watson revealed that he spent hundreds of hours representing pro bono clients while in private practice. Specifically, he supervised a team of attorneys and paralegals who brought human trafficking and wage and hour claims on behalf of two Mexican nationals against a chain of Bay Area taquerias. After conducting extensive discovery, including much of it in Spanish, they recovered significant sums for both plaintiffs and their families. Watson has also worked on landlord/tenant cases and partnered with a civil rights group to challenge a high school district's electoral system, which prevented the election of a Hispanic member.

The 297-foot MS Caledonian Sky crashed into the coral reefs at Raja Ampat on March 4. Raja Ampat, known for its stunning and untouched coral reefs, is often included on lists of the world's most beautiful beaches. The destruction of the coral reefs, which took nature hundreds of years to develop, was caused by the Caledonian Sky and its captain in just one day, according to Djoko Hartoyo, of the Information and Law Bureau of the Coordinating Ministry for Maritime Affairs. "It's impossible to restore that part of Raja Ampat," Hartoyo said. "All the fish that normally inhabit that area were gone." The ship destroyed nearly 140,000 square feet of reef, making it one of the worst environmental disasters in the area, said Ketut Putra, vice president of Conservation International Indonesia. The ship crashed into one of the best diving spots in the region, Putra added. Noble Caledonia, the cruise company operating the vessel, apologized for the incident and acknowledged that the ship had gone aground, but did not provide a reason for the accident. The company said it is working with local experts to help restore the reef and is establishing a fund to support the local economy and repair efforts. However, local residents are outraged by the damage, which not only harms the environment but also threatens the livelihoods of communities that depend on healthy reefs, said Doug Meikle, who runs a website supporting the local Papuan community's tourist accommodation association. "It's astonishing that the ship was so close to the reef," said Ruben Sauyai, owner of the nearby Koranu Fyak Bungalows and president of the professional divers association in Raja Ampat. Sauyai was approximately 200 feet away with some divers when the incident occurred. "You could hear the ship crushing the reef," he recalled.

Meikle believes there is a strong case for banning ships of this size from the area. "In addition to the risk of accidents, anchoring such large ships causes immense damage to reefs," he said.

The incident has raised questions about potential criminal charges. While insurance may cover some of the environmental damage, Indonesian authorities believe the captain committed a crime and could face prison time if convicted. "Insurance coverage may pay for environmental damages, but it does not excuse the captain's criminal actions," authorities stated.

The company described the master on duty at the time of the crash as one of the world's leading expedition captains, with many years of experience.

The incident highlights a larger problem affecting the local tourism industry and economy. Putra, a local official, expressed concern that the damaged reef will deter tourists and reduce the number of fish in the area due to their damaged habitat. "I'm genuinely worried," he said.

Cruise ships are also a source of pollution that threatens coral reefs, particularly in Southeast Asia, according to Marine Insight. The ships often dispose of massive amounts of sewage, food waste, and oily bilge water into the ocean. A 2016 study published in Nature found that the shipping industry is a significant contributor to carbon dioxide emissions in Asia. "While coral reefs worldwide face ongoing environmental threats, the Great Barrier Reef experienced its worst mass bleaching event on record last year, according to a report from the ARC Centre of Excellence for Coral Reef Studies. The report attributes the surge in devastating bleaching events to rising water temperatures."

The National University of Singapore (NUS) has been named the best university in Asia by the Times Higher Education supplement, outperforming strong competition from China, which otherwise dominated the top three spots. According to Phil Baty, editor of the Times Higher Education Rankings, NUS has set a benchmark for the continent, and in his opinion, "Asian universities can now rightfully challenge the traditional Western elite universities in the US and UK." The influential London-based guide evaluates universities based on 13 performance indicators, including research output and teaching environment. Peking University took second place, followed by Tsinghua University, both located in Beijing, China. While the top five institutions remained largely unchanged, with Singapore's Nanyang Technological University and the University of Hong Kong coming in fourth and fifth respectively, there were significant movements elsewhere in the rankings. India made a notable effort, with its representation more than doubling from 16 to 33 institutions, while Pakistan's presence tripled from two to seven. For the first time, Japan emerged as the most-represented nation, with 69 universities featured in the ranking, accounting for nearly a quarter of the 300-strong list. Thailand was the most represented country in Southeast Asia, with 10 universities ranked. However, the researchers noted that Malaysia showed the greatest potential among emerging university nations, with the University of Malaya taking a top-60 position in its first appearance on the list. The university attributed its success to increased international enrollment and the introduction of English-language programs to cater to this shift. Mohd Amin Jalaludin, vice-chancellor of the University of Malaya, expressed a different view, suggesting that smaller countries like Malaysia should be compared with giants like China, given their differing strengths and challenges. "Singapore has celebrated another triumph in the realm of education, marking its second recent achievement in the field. In December, the Programme for International Student Assessment (PISA) survey revealed that Singaporean teenagers are globally top-ranked in math, science, and reading. Notably, Singaporean students showcased knowledge and skills equivalent to almost two extra years of education compared to their peers in the US, France, and Sweden. For more on what Asian schools can teach the world, click here to read the full list."

Kim Jong Nam was fatally attacked on February 13, according to Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak, who described the incident as an assassination attempt. At the time of the attack, Kim was at Kuala Lumpur International Airport, en route to Macau, when two women used the highly toxic VX nerve agent to wipe his face, resulting in his death within 20 minutes, according to Malaysian police. Both South Korea and Malaysia have accused North Korea of being responsible for Kim's murder, while North Korea has vehemently denied the allegations.

Malaysian authorities did not publicly identify Kim's body until last week, after obtaining a DNA sample from the child of the deceased, according to Malaysian Deputy Prime Minister Ahmad Zahid Hamidi. However, Hamidi declined to elaborate on how the DNA sample was obtained. Kim's family is believed to be in hiding, with his son, Kim Han Sol, making a rare public appearance in a 40-second video posted online by the Cheollima Civil Defense group last week. The identity of the son was verified by a South Korean National Intelligence Service spokesman to CNN.

The dispute over Kim Jong Nam's body has escalated into a diplomatic row between Malaysia and North Korea. North Korea demanded that Malaysia hand over the body, citing Kim's nationality, but Malaysian authorities refused, insisting on a DNA match before releasing it. This led to both countries imposing dual travel bans, prohibiting Malaysians from leaving North Korea and North Koreans from traveling out of Malaysia. Nine Malaysians are currently in North Korea, while the number of North Koreans in Malaysia is unclear. Malaysian police believe that three individuals wanted for questioning in connection with Kim's murder are hiding in the North Korean Embassy in Kuala Lumpur. Four suspects are still at large and are believed to have returned to North Korea, while two individuals are currently in custody in connection with the case. Siti Aisyah of Indonesia and Doan Thi Huong of Vietnam are both facing murder charges and could face the death penalty if convicted. According to authorities from both Indonesia and Vietnam, the women were led to believe they were participating in a prank TV show. However, Malaysian authorities have disputed this claim, suggesting that the women's involvement was not as innocent as initially thought.

A group of dairy drivers claimed they were entitled to overtime pay for certain tasks they had completed, but the company disagreed. The issue ultimately came down to a matter of punctuation, specifically the Oxford comma. An appeals court ruled in favor of the drivers, stating that the ambiguity in the guidelines was due to the lack of an Oxford comma. The relevant section of the law reads: "The canning, processing, preserving, freezing, drying, marketing, storing, packing for shipment or distribution of: (1) Agricultural produce; (2) Meat and fish products; and (3) Perishable foods." The court's decision hinged on the interpretation of "packing for shipment" - was it a distinct activity or simply a part of the larger process of "distribution"? The drivers argued that they distributed perishable food, but did not pack it. The court agreed, finding that the lack of an Oxford comma led to ambiguity and, under labor laws, ambiguity is often resolved in favor of the laborers. As the judge noted, "For want of a comma, we have this case." The irony of the situation is that Maine state guidelines for drafting documents do not include Oxford commas, despite the importance of clarity in legal language. "For the sake of fairness, it's worth noting that there are guidelines available to help prevent unclear language, which could potentially benefit even the most fastidious drivers seeking to receive what they're owed. (To all you Oxford comma enthusiasts, feel free to revel in your triumph. We're proud to follow AP Style at CNN, which doesn't use the Oxford comma.)"

I made some minor changes to improve clarity and flow, while also maintaining the original tone and humor. Let me know if you have any further requests!

A 17-year-old, armed with a rifle, handgun, revolver, and two grenades, entered the Alexis de Tocqueville school around lunchtime and opened fire on the headteacher, according to reports from CNN's French affiliate BFMTV. Eight people were injured, including those with shock, with the headteacher among the wounded, a French Interior Ministry spokesman told BFMTV. The arrested individual was not known to the police, the spokesman said. Authorities have ruled out the possibility of terrorism being involved in the attack.

Andreas, a student, described the chaotic scene to BFMTV, saying that someone he knew had suffered a hand injury. "I heard four shots. It was complete pandemonium. We rushed upstairs to find safety. It was like being in a movie. We're not used to this kind of thing happening," he said. "We hear about incidents like this in Paris, but now we understand."

The school has been evacuated and is currently being searched by authorities, BFMTV reported. An elite police operations unit is on the scene, according to the Prefecture of Alpes-Maritimes. The French Interior Ministry tweeted that the security situation is ongoing and urged people to stay away from the area. The Alpes-Maritimes Civil Protection agency warned people to avoid the school and remain calm.

The French education ministry tweeted that schools in Grasse are in lockdown and asked students' families to stay away. Education Minister Najat Belkacem is en route to the scene, the ministry said.

The authors of a new paper are sounding the alarm, warning that the resilience of the world's largest living structure, the Great Barrier Reef, is rapidly declining. A series of aerial and underwater surveys has revealed that a severe heatwave in 2016, which saw record-breaking sea temperatures in Australia, triggered the most devastating and widespread coral bleaching event on record. A staggering 50% of the reef is now severely bleached, with a further 91% showing signs of bleaching, according to Sean Connolly, a leading expert on coral reefs. "In just 27 years, coral cover on the Great Barrier Reef has halved," Connolly said. "It's gone from 28% to 13%, and our preliminary estimates suggest we've lost half that amount again in the past year. This level of mortality is unprecedented." Rising sea temperatures, linked to global warming, are causing coral bleaching, where the expulsion of algae turns the reefs white and deprives them of their main energy source. If left unchecked, sustained bleaching will lead to coral death. The recent heatwave's impact was worse than expected, sparking serious concerns about the future of the reef ecosystem. The study highlights the bleaching of hardy, century-old reefs as a particular cause for concern, as slow-growing corals may not have time to recover. "If all the coral bleaches and dies, it's no longer a coral reef," Connolly warned. Coral skeletons are rapidly colonized by algae, which turns them dark in color, according to David Baker, an assistant professor at the University of Hong Kong's Swire Institute of Marine Sciences. Eventually, these skeletons collapse, resulting in the complete loss of the natural habitat for fish and other marine life, Baker added. The paper's authors also concluded that the reef has not adapted to high temperatures over time, whether it was bleached or not. Connolly noted that as temperatures continue to rise, reefs will eventually die off and be replaced by more stress-tolerant species, such as seaweeds. "We've known for decades that this would happen, and unfortunately, our international system of government and policy has failed to take relatively inexpensive action to mitigate the potentially catastrophic effects of climate change, not just on reefs, but on other ecosystems we rely on," he said. The United Nations estimates that around 275 million people globally rely directly on reefs for their livelihood and sustenance, and reefs provide nurseries for about a quarter of the world's fish. The Great Barrier Reef is worth approximately $3.7 billion annually to the Australian economy through fishing and tourism, and supports around 70,000 jobs, according to Connolly. "If reefs are unable to provide the same source of livelihood, we're looking at a potentially unfolding human tragedy over the decades," he added. Last year's mass coral bleaching event was the third on record for the Great Barrier Reef, and scientists suspect that a fourth may already be underway. The Great Barrier Marine Park Authority is currently conducting aerial surveys of the reef, and last week, Greenpeace released photos and video footage highlighting the ongoing damage. "Greenpeace has recently conducted a documentation mission to the Great Barrier Reef with a marine biologist, and the findings are deeply disturbing," said Alix Foster Vander Elst, Campaigner for Greenpeace Australia Pacific. "We expect to learn the full extent of this year's disaster in the coming days or weeks."

Speaking in Tokyo ahead of stops in Seoul and Beijing, US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson criticized the past 20 years of diplomatic efforts to denuclearize North Korea, saying they have been unsuccessful. "The approach of the past 20 years has failed, so we have 20 years of a failed approach," Tillerson stated at a press conference with Japanese Foreign Minister Fumio Kishida. China is set to present its own plan to Tillerson on Saturday, according to a senior Chinese diplomat who spoke to CNN on Thursday. The Chinese proposal calls for North Korea to suspend its ballistic missile tests and nuclear activities, as well as for the US and South Korea to halt large-scale military exercises that have been a source of tension with Pyongyang. According to Xiao Qian, director general of the Asian Affairs Department of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, North Korea wants to see the US take action first to demonstrate its commitment, and vice versa. China's proposal suggests doing these things simultaneously, Xiao Qian told CNN in an exclusive interview. This is the second time in as many weeks that China has floated this plan, which was previously rejected by the US State Department. "There is no equivalence between North Korea's illegal missile and nuclear activities and our lawful, longstanding joint security exercises with our allies in the region," said Mark Toner, acting State Department spokesman, in response to China's initial proposal. North Korea has also rejected the proposal, with Pak Myong Ho, chargé d'affaires at the North Korean embassy in Beijing, rebuffing China's proposal in a rare and hastily called press conference on Thursday. The North Korean government has stated that it will continue to strengthen its defense and preemptive strike capabilities in response to the US and its allies' continued nuclear threats and military drills along the country's border. Speaking together in Tokyo, US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson and Japanese Foreign Minister Fumio Kishida reaffirmed their commitment to standing united against North Korea's provocations. Kishida emphasized that Japan will take on a greater role in the alliance, while Tillerson suggested that the US needs to stop pouring money into a solution that isn't working. He noted that the US provided $1.35 billion in assistance to North Korea between 1995 and 2008, primarily for food aid and energy assistance, but that this effort has been met with North Korea's continued development of nuclear capabilities and increased missile launches. Analysts say that there are few new options for North Korea policy, and that Secretary Tillerson's comments lack a clear vision for the future. According to John Delury, a professor at Yonsei University's Graduate School of International Affairs, the US policy towards North Korea is complex and cannot be reduced to a simple talking point about the lack of progress. The US, South Korea, Japan, China, and Russia have repeatedly attempted to negotiate a solution with North Korea through the Six-Party Talks, which began in 2003, but have so far been unsuccessful. The sanctions imposed on Pyongyang are among the most severe in history, yet North Korea's nuclear and missile programs seem to be accelerating. In a CNN interview, Xiao addressed criticism that China is not doing enough to stop North Korea, arguing that the situation is complex and cannot be resolved simply. Xiao suggested that the key to resolving the issue lies in direct talks between the US and North Korea, rather than relying solely on economic pressure. "This is a very complicated situation," Xiao said. "The North Korean government has long claimed that it is the US threat that forces them to consider alternative options, including nuclearization. So, to a large extent, it is up to the US and North Korea to sit down and talk, and find a way to resolve the issue." Xiao also denied allegations that China has been systematically retaliating against South Korean businesses in response to its opposition to the THAAD missile defense system. However, he warned that if the US and South Korea proceed with the deployment, there will be consequences, which will ultimately be borne by the Americans and South Koreans.

Benoit Loeuillet, a regional councilor for the National Front in Provence-Alpes-Cote d'Azur, was suspended after being caught on camera denying the Holocaust. In a secretly recorded video, Loeuillet downplayed the systematic murder of six million Jews during the Holocaust, claiming that there were not six million deaths. He made these comments in a documentary that will be shown in France. Loeuillet has denied the allegations and threatened to take legal action against the journalists involved. However, his statement has been met with criticism, as French law strictly prohibits Holocaust denial. In response to the controversy, the National Front's Secretary-General, Nicolas Bay, suspended Loeuillet and announced that he will face a disciplinary hearing, where he could potentially be expelled from the party. This is not the first time that the National Front has been embroiled in controversy over anti-Semitic comments. In 2011, Le Pen, who is now the party's leader, sought to distance herself from allegations of anti-Semitism by expelling her father, Jean-Marie Le Pen, from the party. Her father had made comments denying the Holocaust, and referred to the gas chambers used by the Nazis as "a detail of history." The expulsion caused a significant public rift between the two. Meanwhile, Le Pen is facing increased scrutiny ahead of the French presidential election, with allegations that several members of her staff were paid for non-existent jobs at the European Parliament. Initially, she admitted to the payments, but later denied making the statement. Marine Le Pen's already strained relationship with Europe was further complicated when European Parliament members voted to strip her of her parliamentary immunity in a case involving violent images she posted on Twitter. The inquiry was launched under a French law that prohibits the distribution of violent images, following Le Pen's December 2015 tweets featuring images of ISIS militant killings. Under French law, the maximum penalty for distributing such images is three years in prison and a fine of up to 15,000 (approximately $79,000). It's worth noting that the loss of her immunity only applies to this specific case and does not affect the investigation being conducted by OLAF.

President Trump was questioned by a German reporter about why his White House had cited a Fox News report claiming that the British surveillance agency GCHQ had wiretapped Trump Tower during the election campaign. The President did not apologize to the British government after they dismissed the report as "ridiculous." Turning to Chancellor Merkel, who was previously revealed to have had her phone tapped by the US National Security Agency through Edward Snowden's leaks, Trump remarked, "At least we have something in common." Trump seemed irritated to be asked the question by the German reporter, amidst a two-week controversy sparked by his earlier tweets claiming that former President Barack Obama had ordered wiretaps against him last year. Senior members of the intelligence committees in the House of Representatives and the Senate have confirmed that there was no wiretapping of Trump Tower. Trump also criticized NATO nations that do not pay their "fair share" for defense, as he stood alongside Merkel. He stated that many nations owe "vast sums" of unpaid dues to the organization, adding, "These nations must pay what they owe." However, the President also expressed strong support for the NATO alliance, despite previously questioning its relevance during his election campaign. The German government fell short of its NATO target of 2% last year, reaching only 1.19%, and although it has committed to increasing defense spending this year, it will still not meet the target. President Trump welcomed German Chancellor Angela Merkel to the White House, following his earlier criticism of her. Trump also emphasized the importance of respecting "historic institutions," which may have been a nod to the European Union, a key player in Western security. However, Trump's administration has previously expressed skepticism about the EU. In her remarks, Merkel acknowledged past tensions with Trump and sought to build a new relationship with the third US president she has encountered as German Chancellor. She emphasized the importance of direct communication, saying, "It's always much better to talk to one another than about one another." Merkel also expressed relief that Trump supports NATO and has committed to the Minsk process, which aims to monitor the ceasefire in Ukraine and find a solution to the crisis. The meeting comes at a critical time for US-German relations, which have been strained by Trump's political views. Merkel had previously congratulated Trump on his election win, while also defending Western values, which she felt were under threat due to his stance on issues like immigration. Germany, the most influential power in the European Union, has also been concerned about Trump's criticism of NATO and the skepticism within his administration about the EU. The meeting aims to foster a personal connection between the two leaders, who have distinct temperaments and instincts. German Chancellor Angela Merkel, known for her cautious and analytical approach to politics, formed a strong bond with President Barack Obama, with whom she shared a similar outlook. In contrast, President Donald Trump is more outspoken and impulsive, with little patience for diplomatic formalities. Trump has been vocal in his criticism of Merkel's decision to allow hundreds of thousands of refugees into Germany, a move that has been a contentious issue in her re-election campaign. Despite past tensions, both sides are likely to try to put their differences aside and move forward. Merkel, a pragmatic leader, is now dealing with her third US president and is seeking to establish a working relationship with Trump without compromising her own values. An administration official stated before the meeting that Trump hopes to seek Merkel's counsel on how to navigate his relationship with Russian President Vladimir Putin, who allegedly ordered cyber-meddling in the 2016 presidential election and attempted to support Trump's campaign. Merkel plans to appeal to Trump's business-focused mindset by bringing the CEOs of Siemens and BMW to Washington, companies that employ thousands of American workers. She hopes to leverage this point when discussing trade issues, including Germany's trade surplus, which has been a point of contention with the Trump administration.

In a recent interview with an American magazine, Angela Merkel, the former businesswoman, shared her philosophy on life and her political views. One characteristic that defines Merkel is her meticulous preparation and her ability to understand her opponents. It's unlikely that meeting with Donald Trump would intimidate her, as she has a track record of dealing with strong personalities. Throughout her career, she has clashed with leaders such as Vladimir Putin, Silvio Berlusconi, Gerhard Schröder, and Alexis Tsipras, all of whom have attempted to assert their dominance over her. However, Merkel has consistently demonstrated a calm and composed demeanor, even in the face of intimidation.

For instance, during her 2007 visit to Russia, Putin famously brought his dog Koni into the meeting room, which Merkel reportedly found unsettling. Nevertheless, she used small talk to diffuse the situation and later imposed economic sanctions on Russia, which had a significant impact on the country. Merkel's approach to dealing with these leaders is often likened to that of an older sister who is accustomed to handling the mischievous behavior of her younger brothers.

Despite her tough exterior, Merkel is known for being warm, personable, and charming when meeting with other leaders. During my research for my book, "Angela Merkel: Europe's Most Influential Leader," I heard stories about how she won over both David Cameron and Barack Obama by teaching them how to swear in German. Additionally, she is said to have a impressive impression of former Pope Benedict, which Putin reportedly found particularly amusing. We caught a glimpse of this more human side of Merkel in 2012, when she unexpectedly broke off G8 talks on Syria to watch the penalty shootout of a Champions League final. However, Merkel is also notorious for her attention to detail. German Chancellor Angela Merkel, a holder of a doctorate in quantum mechanics, is renowned for her meticulous approach and unwavering patience. Unlike Donald Trump, who often tweets in the early hours of the morning, Merkel typically takes days or even weeks to respond to matters. When faced with a problem, she meticulously gathers facts before making a decision. As she has acknowledged, she has honed the art of cautious deliberation. In fact, the Germans have coined a verb, "Merkeln," which means to be indecisive or to withhold opinion, and it was named the Youth Word of the Year in Germany in 2015. However, Merkel will not be swayed or intimidated by Trump's bombastic posturing. As a pastor's daughter who grew up under communist rule and speaks Russian, she is unlikely to welcome Trump's overtures towards Putin. Similarly, Germany, a significant exporter of goods, is unlikely to be enamored with Trump's protectionist policies. Should Trump be concerned? Should he accommodate his awkward German ally? Or could he simply ignore her? It would be unwise to do so. Despite Trump's desire for a more cordial relationship with Moscow, the European Union is a vital trading partner for the US. Millions of American jobs rely on trade with the EU. Damaging this relationship would make it challenging to bring back jobs to the American Rust Belt, the region that elected Trump. To establish positive relations with Germany, Trump must adopt a very different approach. Upsetting Europe's strongest power is simply not an option.

National Security Adviser H.R. McMaster had a "cordial" conversation with his British counterpart on Thursday to discuss Press Secretary Sean Spicer's comments about a Fox News report that alleged British intelligence helped wiretap Trump Tower during the 2016 campaign. According to a White House official, McMaster described Spicer's comments as "unintentional" and assured his counterpart that their concerns were heard and would be relayed to the White House. The official added that there were at least two calls from British officials on Thursday, including a conversation between Spicer and the British ambassador to the United States, Kim Darroch. A senior administration official told CNN that Spicer and McMaster effectively apologized to the British government for the comments.

The White House later confirmed that Darroch and Sir Mark Lyall Grant, national security adviser to Prime Minister Theresa May, had separate conversations with Spicer and McMaster on Thursday. According to one official, Spicer and McMaster explained that Spicer was simply pointing to public reports and did not endorse any specific story. The UK government had earlier protested to the Trump administration, calling the claims "ridiculous" and urging them to be ignored. According to May's spokesman, the US administration has since provided assurances that the allegations will not be repeated. During a Thursday press briefing, White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer read aloud allegations made by legal analyst Andrew Napolitano on Fox News the previous Tuesday. According to Napolitano, three intelligence sources had informed Fox News that President Obama had ordered surveillance on Trump, bypassing the NSA and CIA by using the UK's Government Communications Headquarters (GCHQ) instead. Spicer quoted Napolitano as saying, "President Obama went outside the chain of command... he didn't use the NSA, he didn't use the CIA... he used GCHQ."

The strong statement from Downing Street, which followed a rare and blunt statement from GCHQ itself, indicated that the British government was outraged by the US's incendiary allegations. GCHQ quickly responded, calling the claims "nonsense" and urging them to be ignored. The agency rarely comments on specific operations, and its blunt language was unusual.

Later, during a regular press briefing, a Downing Street spokesperson said that the UK had sought and received assurances that the allegations would not be repeated. The spokesperson noted that this development showed the administration did not take the allegations seriously. The spokesperson also emphasized the close special relationship between the White House and Downing Street, which allows for concerns to be raised and addressed as needed.

Britain is particularly sensitive to the suggestion that the US would use GCHQ to keep "American fingerprints" off its surveillance activities. The UK's intelligence agencies work closely with their US, Canadian, Australian, and New Zealand counterparts as part of the "Five Eyes" intelligence sharing agreement. The spokesman for May argued that the pact precludes the kind of spying alleged by Napolitano, stating, "In fact, under the 'Five Eyes' intelligence agreement, we cannot use each other's capabilities to circumvent the law. It's a situation that wouldn't arise." The controversy over GCHQ's relationship with the NSA was sparked by claims made by Edward Snowden, a former NSA contractor. In 2015, a UK tribunal censured GCHQ for not being transparent enough about how it shares internet surveillance data with the NSA. Susan Rice, former national security adviser in the Obama administration, expressed concern that Spicer's claims could damage the intelligence-sharing relationship between the US and UK, tweeting, "The cost of falsely blaming our closest ally for something this consequential cannot be overstated." Tim Farron, leader of the UK Liberal Democrat party, described the White House claim as "shameful" and warned that it could harm US and UK security, tweeting, "Trump is compromising the vital UK-US security relationship to try to cover his own embarrassment." The Senate Intelligence Committee had previously stated that it found no evidence of Trump Tower being under surveillance in 2016, contradicting Trump's earlier claims. Committee chair Richard Burr said, "Based on the information available to us, we see no indications that Trump Tower was the subject of surveillance by any element of the United States government either before or after Election Day 2016." On the same day, House Speaker Paul Ryan told CNN that he had not seen any evidence of a wiretap or surveillance order against Trump Tower. Representative Tom Cole, R-Oklahoma, called for an apology from Trump for his "reckless" comment on wiretapping, while Representative Charlie Dent, R-Pennsylvania, warned that Trump's comments and the White House's decision to stand by them were undermining the President's credibility and depleting his political capital at a critical time. Trump originally made the allegations against Obama on March 4, tweeting, "Terrible! Just found out that Obama had my 'wires tapped' in Trump Tower just before the victory. Nothing found. This is McCarthyism!" Two weeks later, in an interview with Fox News, Trump appeared to walk back his original wiretapping allegations, stating, "Wiretap covers a lot of different things. I think you're going to find some very interesting items coming to the forefront over the next two weeks."

Former Pennsylvania Senator Rick Santorum, a longtime supporter of President Donald Trump, expressed concerns about Trump's decision to stand by his wiretap allegations. During an appearance on CNN's Erin Burnett "Outfront," Santorum warned that Trump's actions are causing more harm to himself than to his political opponents. "We're no longer in an election cycle, and Trump's behavior is not directed at his opponents," Santorum said. "Instead, he's throwing himself off course." As president, Trump has no rival to blame, and his actions are only hurting his own reputation, Santorum argued. "People don't care about Barack Obama anymore; they care about the president, and that's Trump," he said. Santorum suggested that Trump focus on issues that resonate with Americans, such as immigration, healthcare, taxes, and trade. "I'd like to see the president speak from a position of authority, based on what he knows, rather than what he's read in the news," he added. As president, Trump is expected to have access to better information than what's reported in the media, Santorum noted, and he should be communicating with the public based on his own knowledge and expertise.

A highly encrypted laptop containing sensitive information, including Trump Tower's floor plans and evacuation protocols, has been stolen from an agent's car. The stolen laptop cannot be traced or erased remotely, leaving the confidential data at risk of being discovered. The agent described the incident as a compromise of national security, according to an official. In addition to the laptop, the thief also stole the agent's lapel pins, which granted access to security details protecting prominent figures such as Hillary Clinton, Donald Trump, the Pope, and the United Nations General Assembly. The stolen items were found in a backpack taken from the agent's driveway. Although the backpack has been recovered, the laptop remains missing. The Secret Service has confirmed the theft and launched an investigation. In a statement, Secret Service spokeswoman Cathy Milhoan emphasized that the stolen laptop was equipped with multiple security layers, including full disk encryption, and should not have contained classified information. The investigation is ongoing, and the Secret Service is urging anyone with information about the crime to contact the New York Police Department and the US Secret Service New York Field Office.

At a joint press conference in Seoul with South Korean Foreign Minister Yun Byung-se, US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson announced that Washington's policy of "strategic patience" had come to an end. When asked about the possibility of military conflict, Tillerson emphasized that the US does not seek a conflict, but would respond appropriately if North Korea's actions threaten South Korean or US forces. He also stated that if North Korea's weapons program poses a significant threat, the US would consider taking action. Later that day, President Donald Trump tweeted about North Korea's behavior, accusing it of "playing" the US for years and criticizing China for not doing enough to help. Tillerson's remarks come as US intelligence officials and the Defense Department anticipate that North Korea may soon conduct new missile and nuclear tests. The Secretary of State is currently on a three-country tour of the region, amid heightened tensions on the Korean peninsula following recent North Korean missile launches and fears of an impending nuclear test. In Tokyo, Tillerson had previously stated that efforts to halt North Korea's nuclear development over the past 20 years have been unsuccessful, and it is time for a new policy. He did not provide details, but it is clear that he sees China, his next destination, as a key part of Washington's new approach. A senior Chinese official told CNN that Beijing plans to present its own plan to Tillerson during his visit. Despite Beijing's suggestion that the US should suspend joint military exercises with South Korea as a gesture of goodwill towards Pyongyang, Tillerson rejected the idea. The US does not believe that the conditions are right for talks to resume, whether they are five-party or six-party talks. "Conditions must change before talks can resume," Tillerson emphasized. He also urged China to abandon its opposition to the Terminal High Altitude Area Defense (THAAD) system or take steps to address the threat that makes THAAD necessary. The missile defense system is currently being deployed in South Korea's south. Additionally, Tillerson called on Beijing to refrain from any retaliatory action against South Korea, citing allegations that businesses and the tourism industry are being targeted for Seoul's stance on the issue. "China's economic retaliation against South Korea is inappropriate and troubling," he said. Earlier in the day, Tillerson visited the demilitarized zone, the heavily fortified border between North and South Korea, becoming the highest-ranking US official to do so since President Barack Obama in 2012. During his visit, he met with some of the over 28,000 US troops stationed in the region and toured the Joint Security Area, where North and South Korean soldiers stand facing each other. A Military Armistice Commission briefing room straddles the border. Tillerson's visit to South Korea comes at a sensitive time, as the country is preparing for a snap election on May 9 following the impeachment of President Park Geun-hye last week. The election has raised questions about the future of the THAAD system, with some candidates calling for its deployment to be reviewed by the National Assembly. The US is looking forward to a productive relationship with the next President of South Korea, whoever the people may elect, said Secretary of State Rex Tillerson. He also expressed his expectation that the new government in South Korea will continue to support the THAAD system. Tillerson emphasized the need for a new approach in North Korea policy, stating that the US has spent $1.3 billion in assistance since 1995, yet North Korea has detonated nuclear weapons and launched ballistic missiles in return. During his presidential campaign, Donald Trump suggested that he would be willing to talk to North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, but Tillerson ruled out the possibility of talks at this time. Instead, he called on China to fully implement UN-approved sanctions against North Korea and stated that the US will urge other countries to join future actions against the regime.

"I've spent 32 years, three months, and 14 days behind bars," Wilson told CNN. He was just 30 years old when he was first imprisoned, convicted of murder. Now, at 62, he is finally a free man after evidence emerged that the prosecution had withheld crucial information in his case all those years ago. A Superior Court Judge, Laura Priver, ruled that Wilson's constitutional right to a fair trial had been violated, leading to the vacating of his conviction and his immediate release. Just one day later, Wilson walked out of prison a free man.

"I always say, don't stop fighting, don't give up," Wilson emphasized. "It seems like that's what the justice system wants you to do, but I never lost hope. And I owe it all to the grace of God, who brought me in contact with Loyola Law School." Wilson's attorneys and students from the Loyola Law School Project for the Innocent worked tirelessly to uncover the new evidence, which revealed that the prosecution had withheld critical information during his trial.

Throughout his 32-year ordeal, Wilson maintained his innocence, despite being arrested for the 1984 stabbing death of a 21-year-old man who was sleeping in his truck. His girlfriend, Saladena Bishop, was also in the truck at the time of the murder. Wilson's attorneys pointed out that the prosecution had withheld key evidence related to the main witness, Bishop, who had picked Wilson out of a lineup only after a police officer pointed to his photo and asked, "What about him?" Before Wilson's trial, police had deemed Bishop an unreliable witness due to her history of filing false reports, including one accusing someone of kidnapping and attempted rape. Bishop's friend had testified in court that Bishop had a history of violence, revealing that he had stabbed his girlfriend in the past and was likely responsible for the crime. However, Loyola's innocence project claims that none of this crucial evidence was shared with Wilson's defense attorney. As a result, Wilson has spent half his life behind bars, missing out on 32 years of milestones, including Christmas dinners, graduations, and even the birth of his granddaughter. Yet, despite his ordeal, Wilson remains unbroken, saying, "I'm past it. I just want to get something to eat right now and love my family." His sister, Gwen Wilson, chimed in, "Anything he wants."

The emotional reunion was palpable as Wilson walked out of the LA County jail, flanked by his daughter and sister, and surrounded by a sea of cameras and reporters. Wilson's daughter, Catrina Burke, struggled to contain her tears when asked about the moment she heard her father was finally free. "I couldn't breathe. I started crying," she said, her voice trembling. "I don't have words. I don't have words at all. But I still have a parent." Wilson's granddaughter snuggled up against him, her eyes welling up with tears as he spoke. Meanwhile, his sister, Gwen Wilson, beamed with pride, choosing to focus on the joy of her brother's release rather than the injustice he had faced. "We just needed to love on him and keep him encouraged through it all. All we can do is keep our heads up and trust that God's grace has brought us to this day," she said. Wilson's 96-year-old mother, who had fought tirelessly for her son's release from her home in Missouri, was overjoyed to finally see her son walk free. She had always believed in her son's innocence. As he walked out, he knew he had to call her right away. "I spoke with her," he said with a smile, "and let me tell you, my 96-year-old mother is a force to be reckoned with - she's a pit bull in the best sense of the word." Wilson's sister Gwen jumped in to provide evidence, repeating their mother's exact words when Wilson called her after his release: "I didn't ask if you were okay. I asked, 'Are you out?' And indeed, he was."

Despite growing bipartisan agreement that the wiretapping allegations are unfounded, President Trump has refused to back down, leaving his aides and allies scrambling for excuses and explanations. In a recent news conference, Trump even brought up the notion of "spying microwaves" - a claim made by White House counselor Kellyanne Conway - to justify his claims. This move not only embarrassed German Chancellor Angela Merkel, whose phone was once tapped by the NSA, but also reinforced Trump's affinity for conspiracy theories. This is not a new phenomenon for Trump, who in 2011 launched a precursor to his presidential campaign by embracing the birther movement. He spent years clinging to the theory that President Obama was not born in the US, despite the release of his birth certificate. Now, Trump appears to have found a new conspiracy theory that may have equal staying power. His recent wiretapping claims have drawn parallels to birtherism, with Trump positioning himself as the great unmasker of Obama, a fraudulent figure who is not who he says he is. For Trump's base, Obama has become the embodiment of the "deep state," a villain who is supposedly working against the President's interests. "Despite widespread skepticism from Congress, the press, even Fox News hosts, and intelligence agencies, Trump finds himself isolated, a familiar comfort zone. Like his birtherism claims, Trump is pitted against nearly everyone, allowing him to maintain the persona of the embattled, populist outsider, even from the White House. The Justice Department has provided wiretap documents to Congress. Key to his wiretapping claims is the promise of a big reveal, just as it was with birtherism. Initially, Trump claimed investigators had been sent to Hawaii to uncover the truth. As that narrative wore thin, his relationship with birtherism devolved into a constant cliffhanger, and the same is true now with his wiretapping claims. Does Trump genuinely believe Obama wiretapped or spied on him at Trump Tower or elsewhere? For now, Trump seems content to string the public along, repeating what he's said for five years about Obama's origins: 'tay tuned.' Let the countdown begin."

Sources familiar with the classified report's contents spoke on condition of anonymity, saying that the report does not support President Trump's unsubstantiated claims. When asked if the report would confirm Trump's allegations, House Intelligence Chairman Devin Nunes told CNN, "I don't think so," as he entered a room to review the report. Ranking member Rep. Adam Schiff, a California Democrat, expressed absolute confidence that the report would not back up Trump's claim. "There's no question about this," Schiff said. "The president's previous statements and tweets have no basis in fact." The Justice Department declined to comment on the report's contents, but earlier in the day, a spokeswoman confirmed that the department had delivered the document to the relevant committees. The department's spokeswoman, Sarah Isgur Flores, said that the Justice Department had complied with requests from the House and Senate Intelligence and Judiciary Committees seeking information about surveillance during the 2016 election. The House Intelligence Committee has scheduled a hearing for Monday, featuring National Security Agency Director Mike Rogers and FBI Director James Comey. The Senate Intelligence Committee announced that it will hold a hearing on March 30 to investigate Russia's meddling in the US election. House Intelligence Chairman Devin Nunes released a statement confirming receipt of the report from the Justice Department and part of the information requested from the National Security Agency. However, he noted that the committee still has not received information requested from the CIA and FBI, which is necessary to determine whether information collected on US persons was mishandled and leaked. Before receiving classified documents from the DOJ, both Nunes and Schiff had already explicitly stated that Trump Tower was not wiretapped. However, Nunes has left open the possibility that communications between Trump's aides and others may have been incidentally collected. 

According to Nunes, "We need to figure out what happened here, there are a lot of unanswered questions. I don't want anyone jumping to conclusions on either side of this, except for the fact that we know Obama didn't physically wiretap Trump Tower. But everything else is still unknown." The bipartisan leaders of the Senate Intelligence Committee have also stated that there was no surveillance of Trump Tower during or after the 2016 election. 

Republican Rep. Will Hurd, speaking on CNN's "OutFront," stated that while he hadn't yet read the DOJ report, he believes "there's no evidence to suggest" Obama wiretapped Trump Tower. Trump has continued to stand by his claim, repeating it again on Friday while standing alongside German Chancellor Angela Merkel. "At least we have something in common, perhaps," Trump said, referencing the US National Security Agency's past tapping of Merkel's phone.

Security forces opened fire, killing the attacker during the morning assault at the airport. The attacker, who was known to the police and intelligence services, had been involved in a shooting at a police traffic stop north of Paris earlier that morning, according to Interior Minister Bruno Le Roux. He fled the scene, leaving a police officer injured, who is currently undergoing treatment. At the airport, the attacker attempted to overpower a soldier and seize her weapon, but was shot dead by two of her colleagues, French Defense Minister Jean-Yves Le Drian said. This marked the fourth attack against security forces deployed as part of France's Operation Sentinel, which was launched in response to the Paris terror attacks in January 2015. Le Roux praised the swift response of security forces at the airport, where no one else was injured. An investigation is underway. The airport was evacuated as an elite operations unit and bomb squad officers rushed to the scene, and a search for explosives was completed. Air traffic at both Orly South and Orly West terminals remains suspended, with some flights being rerouted to Paris Charles De Gaulle Airport, according to Augustin de Romanet, president of Paris Airports. De Romanet also discouraged people from coming to the scene and urged travelers to avoid the airport and follow instructions. With roads around the airport closed, some travelers had attempted to walk to the airport with their luggage, but the police have urged the public to avoid the area and not cross the security perimeter.

The boat, carrying up to 160 people, was attacked early Friday by an unknown assailant, according to International Organization for Migration (IOM) spokesman Joel Millman. At least 24 of the injured are receiving treatment at nearby hospitals, while dozens more remain unaccounted for, Millman said. Witnesses have provided conflicting accounts of whether a helicopter or a military vessel opened fire on the boat, but the IOM has not received any claims of responsibility for the attack. Civilians are disproportionately affected by the violence, with many of the victims believed to have originated from Somalia, although the exact number is still unclear, according to Ahmed Abdi Hassan, the General Consul for the Somali General Consulate in Yemen. The attack occurred in a "military area," Hassan said. The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) reported that the refugees were being transported across the Red Sea to Sudan when the attack occurred. On Saturday, UNHCR's spokeswoman in Yemen, Shabia Mantoo, told CNN that 39 people were injured, with some suffering critical injuries. "Those injured are receiving medical treatment and are understandably shaken by this traumatic event," Mantoo said. "Our staff have visited them and are providing necessary support." Due to the ongoing conflict in Yemen, medical supplies for the survivors are limited, Mantoo said. The UNHCR is working with authorities to determine the next step for the Somali refugees, with the top priority being to ensure they receive proper medical and psychological treatment. Yemen has been embroiled in a civil war since 2015, when Houthi rebels, a minority Shia group from the north, ousted the US-backed government led by President Abdu Rabbu Mansour Hadi and took control of the capital, Sanaa. The crisis in Yemen rapidly spiralled out of control, creating a multi-faceted conflict that inadvertently allowed al Qaeda and ISIS, rival groups of the Houthis, to gain strength in the midst of the chaos. The Houthis, backed by Iran, are pitted against a coalition led by Saudi Arabia, which supports the government of President Hadi. As the humanitarian crisis and conflict in Yemen worsen, refugees and asylum seekers are increasingly fleeing the country, following established migration routes, including across the Red Sea to Sudan, with the ultimate goal of reaching Europe. The UNHCR lamented the latest incident, which adds to the tragic toll of innocent civilians, including Yemenis, refugees, asylum seekers, and migrants, who are disproportionately affected by the conflict in Yemen. According to the UNHCR, Yemen is currently hosting over 255,000 Somali refugees. In February, the organization launched a campaign to raise awareness about the dangers of crossing the Gulf of Aden and Red Sea from Africa to war-torn Yemen.

US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson arrived in Beijing on Saturday, delivering the administration's most direct warning to North Korea yet. The warning included the possibility of military action, which Tillerson said was not off the table. For two hours, Tillerson met with his Chinese counterpart, Wang Yi, who urged the US to return to negotiations to resolve the North Korean crisis. Tillerson described the tensions with North Korea as "dangerous" and said China had agreed to work together to change Pyongyang's course, but he did not provide further details. Beijing was the final stop on Tillerson's first official trip to Asia, following visits to Japan and South Korea. The trip comes amid concerns over North Korea's recent missile launches and its plans for another nuclear test. China is North Korea's sole ally and main economic benefactor, accounting for 70% of the country's trade. US President Donald Trump has repeatedly called on China to use its influence over North Korea, tweeting on Friday that China has done little to help. On Sunday, Tillerson will meet with Chinese President Xi Jinping, who is expected to meet with Trump next month. Tillerson is expected to discuss the possibility of financial penalties on companies and banks that do business with North Korea. According to Ashley Townshend, a research fellow at the United States Studies Centre at the University of Sydney, the Trump administration is counting on threats of US military action in South Korea and tougher sanctions on Chinese entities to pressure Beijing into changing its policies. On his trip, Secretary of State Rex Tillerson has signaled a shift in the US approach towards North Korea, stating that the policy of "strategic patience" has failed to halt the country's nuclear development over the past 20 years. China, however, has been upset by the suggestion that it is not doing enough to reduce tensions in the region.

Wang, a Chinese official, noted that China has made significant contributions to supporting US engagement with North Korea, but emphasized that the issue is ultimately between the US and North Korea. An opinion piece in the Global Times, a state-run Chinese newspaper, echoed this sentiment, arguing that the US and South Korea are trying to shift the responsibility of resolving the North Korean nuclear issue onto China and involve it in their strategy towards Pyongyang.

However, this approach could have unintended consequences, the piece warned, including the possibility of China and North Korea becoming enemies, further complicating the conflict. The North Korean nuclear issue is rooted in the confrontation between the US and North Korea, and China has no obligation to take on all the responsibilities, the article stated.

Wang also expressed hope that the US would re-examine its plans to reduce tensions, although Tillerson has already rejected the proposal to suspend joint military exercises with South Korea as a gesture of goodwill towards North Korea. Tillerson stated on Friday that the US does not believe the conditions are right for talks at this time. However, on Saturday, he did not rule out negotiations entirely, saying that he would work with China to bring North Korea to a point where a dialogue could begin. Tillerson's visit to Beijing is also aimed at finalizing the details of a proposed summit between Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping, scheduled to take place in April. This would be the first meeting between the two leaders, which many consider to be the most important bilateral relationship in the world. Despite Trump's fiery rhetoric during the campaign and early days of his presidency, his administration has taken a relatively cautious approach to China so far. Tillerson's visit has the potential to set the tone for the relationship and may influence the trajectory of US-China relations.

The Syrian Arab News Agency, a state-run outlet, is reporting that the first group of "gunmen and their families" has begun leaving Al-Waer, the last opposition stronghold in Homs city. This marks the end of another rebel enclave that has endured some of the worst bombardment and attacks. The Syrian government's "reconciliation agreements" allow civilians and fighters to evacuate to other rebel-held areas in exchange for surrendering. These initiatives aim to bring an end to the country's long-running civil war and restore stability to former war zones. Critics and opposition groups have denounced these agreements as forced displacement, part of the government's "starve or surrender" strategy, where rebel-held areas are besieged and bombarded until surrender is reached. In recent weeks, the area has been subject to intense bombardment. The evacuation of Al-Waer is being supervised by the Syrian Arab Red Crescent, Russian, and Syrian officials. The Al-Waer reconciliation agreement was reached last week, according to state media. Russia is a key ally of the Syrian government, led by President Bashar al-Assad. The Homs Media Center, an activist group, reports that 2,000 residents, including 400 rebel fighters, have left Al-Waer and are headed to Jarablus in the Aleppo countryside. Sources from the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights say at least 10 buses have entered the neighborhood. This reconciliation agreement comes as Syria enters its seventh year of conflict and as the capital, Damascus, has faced deadly attacks in recent days, including one at a courthouse and another targeting Iraqi Shiite pilgrims near a historic cemetery.

Kazakh native Alexsey Baratov, who was recently indicted by a US grand jury for his alleged involvement in a massive Yahoo hack, recently shared a Facebook post about his teenage years. In the post, Baratov wrote that he was suspended from high school after making a threat to his ex-friend, which he claimed was just a joke. Initially, he was upset by the suspension, but he saw it as an opportunity to focus on his online projects full-time, which ultimately helped him advance his business. Baratov's social media profiles showcase his thrill-seeking personality and his luxurious lifestyle in Ancaster, a wealthy community just outside of Toronto. While still in high school, he was able to afford a BMW 7 Series and pay off the mortgage on his first house. In his Facebook post, Baratov wrote that his suspension marked a turning point in his life, after which he changed his entire plan. However, the exact nature of his online work remains unclear, with his attorney, Amedeo DiCarlo, describing him only as an "entrepreneur." DiCarlo refused to elaborate on Baratov's business ventures or how he was able to afford his lavish lifestyle. However, federal prosecutors in Northern California have alleged that Baratov made his fortune by hacking into at least 500 million Yahoo accounts, along with three other individuals, including two Russian intelligence officers. The hackers allegedly used the stolen information to gain access to accounts from other internet companies, such as Google. DiCarlo maintains that his client is innocent. Since his arrest by Canadian authorities on Wednesday, Baratov's Facebook and Instagram accounts have been made private. **Early social media posts reveal lavish lifestyle**

Photos on his social media accounts show Baratov posing with luxury cars, including an Aston Martin, outside his home, which is valued at around $700,000. The property is now on the market. Neighbors believe he lived alone in the house. His lawyer acknowledged that Baratov was not secretive about his life, with everything publicly visible.

**A life of luxury and speed**

Baratov's YouTube page features dozens of videos showcasing his love for luxury and adrenaline. One video shows his cerulean Lamborghini Gallardo performing donuts on a snow-covered field near his home. Other videos capture point-of-view shots of him speeding his luxury cars through upscale neighborhoods.

**Forfeiture allegations and charges**

US authorities are seeking to forfeit certain assets if the four defendants are convicted. The allegations specifically mention a black Mercedes and a gray Aston Martin with the license plate "MR KARIM." Baratov faces four charges, including conspiracy to commit computer fraud and abuse, and aggravated identity theft.

**Court appearance and extradition battle**

Baratov made a brief court appearance in Canada and a bail hearing is scheduled for April 5. US authorities claim the hack began in January 2014 and was used to access unauthorized accounts at Yahoo, Google, and other webmail providers, including those of Russian journalists, government officials, and private-sector employees. The indictment alleges that Baratov was paid to access target email accounts, with a focus on Google accounts belonging to Russian government officials. His lawyer, DiCarlo, described the extradition battle as a "political uphill battle." Karim Baratov has not been charged with any crimes in Canada. According to DiCarlo, this is an attack and a challenge by the US government. A search of domains registered to Baratov reveals multiple sites, including one advertising "email hacking on demand." The domain registrations include an Ontario area code and an email address that features aliases Baratov allegedly used, such as "Kay" and "Taloverov." When asked about these websites, DiCarlo declined to comment, stating only that everything previously reported had been unfounded.

Despite flaunting his wealth on Facebook and Instagram, accounts from friends and neighbors show that Baratov not only shared his wealth but also showed generosity. For example, a fellow auto enthusiast, who wished to remain anonymous, owns an auto body shop called Autokloak that Baratov frequently visited. The auto enthusiast described Baratov as "generous" and said that he was well-respected and often paid for others' outings.

One neighbor, Silvia, who lives near Baratov, recalled that last Halloween, her grandson and a group of friends went trick-or-treating at Baratov's house. Baratov answered the door and threw handfuls of American dollars at the children, saying "Take it, take it, get off my property, take it!" The money was blown away by the wind, and Silvia described the scene as unusual.

Other social media posts show Baratov spending time with friends. In a YouTube video posted to his "Mr Karim" account in February 2016, Baratov is seen at a restaurant table with a friend. He asks the friend to record him as he grabs a knife and nimbly stabs it between his fingers. When his friend asks if he has practiced this feat, Baratov responds that he has not, and they both laugh as he completes the stunt without injury.

Ukrainian prosecutors in Kiev have made seven separate appeals over the past two years to obtain assistance in questioning Paul Manafort, President Donald Trump's former campaign manager. The appeals, which included letters to FBI Director James Comey and US Justice Department officials, were sent in accordance with a mutual legal assistance treaty between the two countries. However, Ukrainian officials claim that the US has not responded to these requests. Under the treaty, the two countries agree to regularly cooperate in law enforcement efforts, including gathering statements and evidence for prosecutions. US authorities have confirmed receipt of the requests, but declined to comment further.

Paul Manafort served as Trump's campaign chief until August 2016. The official requests from a special prosecution unit in Kiev began in December 2014 and are related to a corruption case involving Ukraine's former Justice Minister, Oleksandr Lavrynovych. Although Manafort has not been charged with a crime, Ukrainian prosecutors want him to testify in their investigation. The prosecutors allege that Lavrynovych illegally diverted over $1 million in government funds to the law firm Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom. Lavrynovych had hired Skadden to review the 2011 jailing of former Ukrainian Prime Minister Yulia Tymoshenko, who was sentenced to seven years in prison for allegedly harming Ukraine's interests in gas supply negotiations with Russia.

Tymoshenko was a political rival of the Kremlin-backed President Viktor Yanukovych, whom Manafort advised until Yanukovych was ousted in 2014. Tymoshenko was released from jail at the same time as Yanukovych's ousting. Many saw her sentencing as politically motivated by the pro-Russian government. In 2012, Ukraine faced the possibility of an unfavorable ruling from the European Court of Human Rights due to the sentencing, which led to US lawmakers considering sanctions. In response to the deteriorating international climate, Ukrainian prosecutors claim that Paul Manafort drafted a public relations strategy, which included hiring Skadden to review the Tymoshenko case and demonstrate the conviction's legal legitimacy. However, a US State Department spokeswoman in 2012 criticized the report Skadden ultimately produced, saying it was incomplete and did not provide an accurate representation. Prosecutors told CNN that Ukraine's Justice Ministry had signed an agreement with Skadden to provide legal services for a fee equivalent to $12,000, which was below the threshold requiring a public competition to award a government contract.
