Prosecutors provided CNN with documentation showing that on May 30, 2013, the Justice Ministry transferred more than $1 million ($1,075,381.41) to a Citibank account allegedly belonging to Skadden. This payment is what prosecutors accuse was a misappropriation of government funds. According to prosecutors, Ukrainian officials likely undervalued the contract to avoid a time-consuming competition to hire the law firm legally, and then paid the true fee in cash. When Tymoshenko's legal team publicly pointed out the impossibility of securing Skadden's services for just $12,000, Skadden allegedly requested that Ukrainian officials draft a second contract reflecting a more realistic fee. In response to CNN's inquiry about its involvement in the matter, Skadden issued a statement saying it would continue to cooperate with relevant requests. Members of Gorbatyuk's office showed CNN a record of seven separate occasions when they sought assistance from US authorities. In December 2014, a letter was sent to the US Justice Department's Office of International Affairs, requesting an interview with Skadden partner Gregory Craig, who had previously served as White House counsel under President Obama. In December 2015, the Ukrainian prosecutor's office sent a follow-up letter to the Department of Justice, asking to question Paul Manafort. The request was triggered by two emails discovered by prosecutors, which included one between Craig and Manafort, in which Craig asked Manafort to help obtain necessary documents from Ukraine for Skadden's report, and another between a Skadden employee and a Ukrainian official, mentioning Manafort's presence at a meeting with the Justice Minister. The prosecutors also provided documentation to the DOJ, stating that their investigation had established that Manafort was implicated in the relationship between Skadden Arps and the Ukrainian Justice Ministry. The letter alleged that Manafort likely advised Ukrainian officials to hire Skadden and was present during discussions about the matter. Manafort declined to comment on the allegations.

The final letter was sent in September 2016, when Ukraine's Prosecutor General, equivalent to the US Attorney General, wrote directly to FBI Director James Comey, seeking clarification on why the US authorities were not cooperating with the investigation. Some of the attempts to question Manafort coincided with a period when the FBI was deciding whether to subpoena him as part of its separate investigation into his business dealings in Ukraine, which took place last summer. Comey has faced criticism for his handling of legal matters related to the Hillary Clinton campaign, including his decision to send a letter to Congress announcing the FBI's renewed interest in her use of a personal server just 11 days before the election. Manafort is currently under FBI investigation for allegedly receiving millions of dollars in payments while working for Yanukovych. He has denied the allegations.

The US-Mexico border wall requirements, released by the federal government late Friday, have kicked off a bidding process that will lead to one of the largest government construction projects in US history. According to the notice for contractors, the wall design should be "physically imposing in height," with a minimum height of 30 feet, although designs with a height of at least 18 feet may also be acceptable. The wall must be designed to prevent climbing without a ladder and make it difficult to use common or sophisticated climbing aids, such as grappling hooks. Additionally, the wall must be able to withstand attempts to penetrate through or under it. Specifically, the wall must be able to resist attempts to bore through it with hand-held tools, such as sledgehammers, car jacks, pick axes, chisels, and battery-powered tools, for at least 30 minutes, and ideally more than four hours. The requirements also state that the wall should be "aesthetically pleasing in color" and blend in with or match the surrounding landscape on the US side, with no specific guidelines for the Mexican side. Initially, the government suggested that the wall be made of concrete, but later widened the call to consider other designs, which may not be entirely solid and could feature a see-through component to provide situational awareness to border patrol agents. Contractors now have about two weeks to develop and submit their proposals, which will outline their design ideas for the border wall. A federal contracting expert told CNN that this approach is typical when the government has a general idea of what it wants, but is open to different ideas for achieving its goals. The government will select several 30-foot-long prototypes to be built, with each prototype expected to cost between $200,000 and $500,000, according to the government notice. In addition to the full-scale prototypes, companies will also build smaller 10-foot models for penetration testing. The prototypes will be used to determine the final design for the border wall. The wall, which was a central promise of President Donald Trump's 2016 campaign, is expected to be tall and "beautiful," with a provision requiring contractors to use American materials whenever possible. The government's proposal did not address the overall cost of the wall, which has been estimated to range from $10 billion to $25 billion. Trump's recent budget proposal requested $1 billion to begin the project. In recent weeks, hundreds of companies have expressed interest in the project. However, a construction contracting expert told CNN that there are only a handful of construction firms with the size, capability, and experience to handle a contract of this magnitude. The expert noted that federal requirements require contractors to set aside significant funds as a guarantee that the project is completed satisfactorily. The selection process will be handled by a secretive committee, which will evaluate proposals based on the merits of the design and the contractors' ability to complete the job. The committee will select up to 20 plans to move to the next phase, where contractors will provide detailed cost estimates and answer additional questions. "The government plans to issue multiple contracts to build wall prototypes, with the possibility of reopening the bidding process in the future. The current process is not designed to cover the entire procurement of the border wall solution with Mexico, officials clarified."

The Secret Service released a statement on Friday, providing details about the incident and confirming that an investigation is ongoing. The agency said that so far, more than 50 interviews have been conducted and a review of radio transmissions and video footage has been completed. The review revealed that the intruder, who was identified as Jonathan Tran, climbed a five-foot fence, an eight-foot gate, and then a three-and-a-half foot fence while Secret Service agents struggled to locate him. According to the review, Tran even managed to rattle a door handle at the South Portico entrance to the White House, but did not make it inside. House Oversight Chairman Jason Chaffetz expressed concern about the breach, saying that despite the agency's significant resources, the intruder was able to get close to the White House and evade capture for 17 minutes. "That's unbelievable," Chaffetz said. In response to the incident, the Secret Service took immediate steps, including adding additional posts, enhancing technology, and modifying response protocols. The agency also acknowledged that its agents were "extremely disappointed and angry" about the breach. According to a source, Tran, a 26-year-old man from California, was able to avoid detection by setting off multiple alarms and sensors, and jumping multiple fences at the White House complex. He was eventually discovered just steps from a main door to the mansion. House Oversight Committee Chairman Jason Chaffetz has launched an investigation into the incident, citing new allegations that were not included in the original affidavit. According to Chaffetz, the committee has learned that triggered alarms were ignored, and the suspect may have moved undetected on the White House grounds for an extended period. Additionally, the suspect may have attempted to enter the building. Chaffetz expressed concern that if these allegations are true, they raise questions about the adequacy of the Secret Service's security protocols. He has requested that Acting Director William Callahan provide documents and video footage related to the incident and brief the committee on Monday at 5 p.m. ET.

Separately, a Secret Service source revealed that the suspect, Tran, was observed loitering on Pennsylvania Avenue as early as 6 p.m., nearly six hours before his arrest on the White House grounds. Surveillance footage shows Tran jumping a fence in the Northwest corner of the Treasury Building, adjacent to the White House, and activating a sensor alarm in the Treasury Moat. Secret Service officers responded to the alarm, but Tran had already moved beyond one post and closer to the White House before an officer arrived to investigate. The source believes Tran then crossed the East Executive Drive, jumped the White House gate near an unstaffed East Wing guard post, and activated another alarm sensor while hiding behind a pillar. Tran then jumped a low wall and traversed along the East Wing, triggering multiple sensors, although it is unclear if they were properly investigated. The White House complex is surrounded by a network of detection systems that operate in overlapping zones, primarily utilizing infrared and microwave technology. However, these systems are not foolproof and can be prone to malfunction or false alarms. The incident occurred just before midnight on March 10, when President Donald Trump was at the White House. According to reports, the President was not notified about the intrusion until late Friday night. In a statement, Trump described the suspect as "disturbed" and praised the Secret Service for their swift response, calling their work "fantastic." During a lunch meeting with Cabinet officials at the Trump National Golf Club in Potomac Falls, Virginia, the President characterized the situation as "sad" and emphasized the importance of the Secret Service's role in maintaining the safety and security of the White House.

During a meeting with Tillerson, Xi Jinping emphasized that there are more shared interests between the two countries than disputes, and stressed the need for increased communication and coordination on regional hotspots, according to a statement from the Chinese foreign ministry. The meeting took place just hours after North Korea announced that it had successfully tested a new type of rocket engine, with leader Kim Jong Un overseeing the test. The event was hailed as having "historic significance" and potentially marking the "new birth" of North Korea's indigenous rocket industry. Beijing was the final stop on Tillerson's first official trip to Asia, which also included visits to Japan and South Korea. The trip came amid escalating tensions on the Korean Peninsula, following a series of North Korean missile launches and fears of another nuclear test. China, North Korea's only major global ally, provides a significant political and economic lifeline to Kim's increasingly isolated regime, with bilateral trade accounting for 70% of North Korea's total trade. US President Donald Trump has repeatedly called on China to use its influence over North Korea, singling out the country again on Friday in a tweet that read, "North Korea is behaving very badly. They have been 'playing' the United States for years. China has done little to help!" Despite earlier warnings that all options, including military action, remained on the table in dealing with Pyongyang, Tillerson refrained from using harsh language during his visit to Beijing, instead adopting a more measured tone. Following his meeting with Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi on Saturday, US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson emphasized the "renewed determination" of both Beijing and Washington to collaborate in persuading the North Korean government to adopt a better path and future for its people. However, Tillerson did not provide any specific details. Although neither side publicly addressed the issue, it was expected that Tillerson would bring up the possibility of imposing financial penalties on Chinese companies and banks that conduct business with North Korea. According to Ashley Townshend, a research fellow at the United States Studies Center at the University of Sydney, the Trump administration is counting on threats of US military action in South Korea and stricter sanctions on Chinese entities to intimidate Beijing into changing its policies. During his trip, Tillerson signaled a shift in Washington's approach towards North Korea, stating that the policy of "strategic patience" pursued over the past 20 years aimed at halting North Korea's nuclear development had failed. The US and North Korea have been at odds, with Beijing expressing frustration over being asked to do more to reduce tensions in the region. Wang noted that China had made "important contributions" to supporting US engagement with Pyongyang, but emphasized that the issue ultimately lies between the US and North Korea. A recent opinion piece in the Global Times, a Chinese state-run tabloid, made a similar point, stating that Washington and Seoul are trying to shift the responsibility of resolving the North Korean nuclear issue entirely onto China and include it in their strategy towards Pyongyang. However, the piece warned that this approach would only serve to complicate the conflict, as China and North Korea would become enemies. The North Korean nuclear issue, the piece argued, is primarily a result of the confrontation between Washington and Pyongyang, and China has no obligation to shoulder the entire burden of responsibility. Chinese Foreign Ministry Spokesperson Wang reiterated China's stance that the US should return to the negotiating table for a peaceful resolution. Wang also expressed hope that Washington would consider Beijing's proposals to ease tensions, despite US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson's earlier rejection of the idea that the US should suspend joint military exercises with South Korea as a gesture of goodwill towards North Korea. Tillerson stated on Friday that the US does not believe the conditions are right for talks at this time, but left the door open on Saturday, saying he would work with China to bring North Korea to a point where dialogue is possible. Meanwhile, Tillerson was in Beijing to finalize details for a potential summit between Presidents Trump and Xi Jinping in Florida in April, which would be the first meeting between the two leaders and a significant event in the world's most important diplomatic relationship. According to a Chinese foreign ministry statement, Tillerson said that Trump expects the two leaders to meet as soon as possible, although the April summit was not confirmed. Additionally, Xi Jinping extended an invitation to Trump to visit China. Despite his campaign rhetoric and early statements, President Trump and his administration have taken a relatively hands-off approach to China, failing to follow through on threats to label China a currency manipulator or impose steep tariffs on Chinese imports. Trump has also endorsed the "One China" policy, which has governed US-China-Taiwan relations for decades, after initially questioning its legitimacy shortly after his election.

Secretary of State Rex Tillerson made it clear that the US is no longer pursuing a policy of strategic patience with North Korea. He also ruled out the possibility of negotiating with Pyongyang until it has dismantled its weapons of mass destruction, and left the door open to military action if the US believes the North's nuclear program advances too far. While Tillerson's statements may seem radical, they do not necessarily signal a coherent strategy for the region. The "strategic patience" policy, which was implemented during the Obama administration, was not simply a policy of inaction. It involved supporting the US alliance with South Korea, approving a free trade agreement with Seoul, and deploying the THAAD missile defense system. In contrast, the Trump administration's devaluation of the US-South Korea alliance makes the Obama-era policy seem more sensible. It is unrealistic to expect North Korea to eliminate its nuclear program as a precondition for negotiations. Tillerson likely recognizes this, which is why he has ended the possibility of negotiations. In reality, North Korea's nuclear program is the only thing that keeps the regime afloat, and it is more important to Pyongyang than its relationship with China. Even if North Korea were to agree to give up its weapons, it would require an intrusive inspections regime to ensure compliance, which is unlikely. Critics may point out that similar concerns were raised about Iran, but the situation with North Korea is different in two key ways. Firstly, the Iranian government has a degree of concern for its own people, whereas North Korea does not. Secondly, Iran sought to rejoin the international community, whereas North Korea prefers to remain isolated. Tillerson's suggestion of a preemptive strike on North Korea presents another problematic option. It raises further questions about America's commitment to its alliances. The implication is that North Korea's ability to target American interests is unacceptable, but it can already strike South Korea, which the US is obligated to defend. The time for a preemptive strike ended when North Korea first detonated a nuclear device. Even if the US could guarantee the simultaneous destruction of every nuclear weapon in North Korea, tens of thousands of artillery shells would still be pointed at Seoul, making it impossible for South Korea and American forces to escape a conflict unscathed. From the outside, it appears that there is no clear American policy on North Korea. Tillerson's statement, "all options are on the table," is a standard diplomatic phrase, but it raises two crucial questions. First, how effectively is the interagency process functioning? Are Tillerson's remarks part of a well-thought-out or poorly conceived foreign policy towards North Korea? Has that policy been debated and discussed among North Korea experts at the State Department, Defense Department, CIA, and other agencies, and filtered through the National Security Council? The fact that many positions in these agencies remain unfilled suggests not, as do Trump's previous statements about speaking directly to Kim Jong Un and his claims that he could "talk him out of having his nukes." More importantly, does Tillerson speak for Trump? His absence from key meetings with foreign leaders, unlike Jared Kushner and Steve Bannon, suggests that he may not be fully "in the loop." "Tillerson's statement in Seoul may have carried more weight if it had come from someone else, or perhaps even from the President himself. The Korean Peninsula is a hotbed of turmoil. The next president of South Korea may be more open to dialogue and economic cooperation with North Korea. Against this backdrop, Tillerson's visit is significant, given the ongoing controversy surrounding the deployment of THAAD in South Korea, which has led to economic retaliation from China. His next stop is Beijing, where he will likely seek China's assistance in curbing North Korea's actions. However, it's unclear what incentive China has to help an administration that has consistently clashed with it at every turn."

The significance of Chuck Berry's "Maybellene" lies in its ability to defy categorization. It topped the rhythm and blues charts, where most black recording artists, including Berry, were typically found. Yet, its rhythm and sensibility were equally rooted in the country blues and western swing traditions, which were predominantly white. This crossover was unprecedented, as it was customary during the Jim Crow era for white artists to "cover" African-American hits. However, "Maybellene" transcended these boundaries, making them less imposing. It's difficult to imagine how anyone could "cover" this song, as it was too monumental to contain within a single genre or style. Its impact was enormous, embracing generations, continents, and changing the world. In short, "Maybellene" was rock and roll, and Chuck Berry was its chief architect, mastermind, and – as the evidence suggests – one of its inventors. Berry's passing at 90 was announced on Saturday.

Of the founding fathers of rock 'n' roll, who brought the simmering 1950s culture to a boil, Fats Domino, Little Richard, and Jerry Lee Lewis – an improbable survivor – are now the only ones still alive. It's worth noting that during a rock-star revue, Lewis was so incensed that Berry was chosen to close the show that he gave a set that ended with him setting his piano on fire. As Lewis stormed off, he passed Berry and muttered, "Top that!" And, as Lewis reportedly said later, "He damn near did, too!" Chuck Berry's stage presence was undiminished by age, and his guitar playing was a major part of his enduring appeal. He didn't need flashy pyrotechnics to electrify his audiences; his iconic duck walk and mastery of the guitar were enough to send them into a frenzy. Rolling Stone magazine has declared that Berry was the starting point of rock guitar, and it's hard to argue with that assessment. His licks and riffs were fluid, supple, and multi-dimensional, inspiring generations of guitarists to explore the blues and experiment with rhythm. Berry's influence can be heard in every guitarist who followed in his footsteps, from Keith Richards to countless others.

Berry's songs are a testament to his enduring legacy. His "great twenty-eight" recordings for Chess in the 1950s and 1960s are more than just catchy pop hits - they're anthems of adventure, mischief, and possibility. Songs like "Roll Over, Beethoven," "Back in the U.S.A.," "Johnny B. Goode," "You Never Can Tell," and "School Days" are invitations to explore, to take risks, and to push boundaries. Their titles alone convey a sense of excitement and freedom, and the songs themselves carry listeners on a journey of discovery and exploration. Every lyric roars, spins, and takes curves into the listener's mind, much like Berry's fiery red Cadillac, now on display at the National Museum of African American History and Culture in Washington. "'Chuck Berry's legacy, rooted in the innovation he pioneered or contributed to, liberated us from the past, leaving behind a lasting American icon. The challenge with true originals, like 45-RPM records, is that they arrive as individual releases. For the rest of us, the best we can do is harness his influence to propel our own paths to exhilarating discovery. The time is now.'"

A mysterious incident occurred at 11:05 p.m. at a security checkpoint, with no confirmation on whether a device was present in the vehicle. The Secret Service immediately upgraded security at the White House, and the vehicle is currently being checked. The checkpoint remains blocked, but streets have reopened, and bomb technicians and additional security personnel have left the area. The Secret Service is conducting an "ongoing criminal investigation" into the incident. At the time of the incident, President Donald Trump was at his Mar-a-Lago estate in Florida, where he typically spends his weekends. Earlier that day, another individual was arrested after attempting to jump over a bicycle rack in front of the White House. The man, who did not make it to the White House fence, was carrying a document he wanted to deliver and did not possess a weapon, according to a law enforcement official. This incident follows a previous breach of the White House grounds, which occurred a week ago and allowed a man to remain on the grounds for over 15 minutes.

Rodney James Hess, 36, of New Orleans, was streaming on Facebook Live when he was shot on Thursday afternoon, according to a statement from his family on their own Facebook page. The video does not show the officers shooting, and his relatives have asked anyone who witnessed the incident to come forward. According to a statement from the Tennessee Bureau of Investigation (TBI), Hess was shot after Crockett County sheriff's deputies approached his sport utility vehicle, which was parked at a perpendicular angle along Highway 412 near the town of Alamo in west Tennessee. The deputies had responded to the vehicle because it was parked in an unusual location. Officers reported that Hess refused their commands, made erratic statements, and attempted to strike them with his vehicle at least twice. As the situation escalated, at least one Crockett County deputy fired his service weapon through the front windshield of the vehicle, striking Hess. The TBI has stated that they do not believe Hess was armed during the incident. In the video, Hess can be seen standing outside his vehicle, with officers nearby, and he can be heard saying, "I would like the higher commands to come out." The video then becomes distorted, capturing sounds of a commotion and a loud, sharp noise, followed by a man's screams. The video shows the interior of the vehicle and passing scenery until a crashing sound is heard, indicating that Hess drove for a distance before wrecking his vehicle. The video ends with an image of broken glass and the sound of a woman's voice, apparently coming from a phone. According to Hess's family attorney, Don Rouzan, Hess was asking to speak with a ranking officer when he used the phrase "higher commands." Rouzan stated that Hess was not acting aggressively or raising his voice at the time and that there was no apparent threat. "He was requesting a supervising officer, and they opened fire on him," said the Tennessee Bureau of Investigation (TBI). Rodney Hess, who was airlifted to a hospital in Memphis, died shortly after the incident. No law enforcement officers were injured, and the officers involved in the shooting have not been identified, according to the TBI.

Hess' family members took to Facebook, asking anyone with information about the shooting to come forward. "We're praying that justice will be served and that if there's anything covered up, it will be brought to light," said Lee Smith, Hess' grandfather. "All we're asking for is justice."

Hess was a father of three children, aged 14, 3, and 18 months. According to the TBI, Hess grew up in the Memphis area and had been living in Texas and New Orleans before his death. He was likely traveling to Memphis to visit family when the shooting occurred.

The TBI is gathering evidence and will present it to the district attorney general. Dash cam and body camera footage has been obtained, and agents are working to determine the timeline of events. "In all investigations, the TBI acts solely as fact-finders," said the TBI's statement. "The decision on whether the deputy's actions were justified rests solely with the district attorney general."

The use of Facebook livestreaming was a factor in a similar police shooting in Minnesota last year, in which Philando Castile was fatally shot by a St. Anthony police officer during a traffic stop. Castile's fiancée livestreamed the aftermath of the shooting, and the officer has pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter charges.

George Conway, a corporate lawyer, is expected to lead an office that would handle legal challenges to major Trump administration initiatives, including the controversial travel ban, if confirmed by the Senate. The Wall Street Journal was the first to report that Conway was being considered for the position. Previously, Conway was a contender for the role of US solicitor general, according to sources who spoke to CNN in December.

As a partner at the corporate law firm Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz, Conway has spent 28 years honing his skills in securities, contract, and antitrust litigation. He is currently a partner in the firm's litigation department, where he has represented high-profile clients such as the National Football League and Philip Morris, which he successfully defended in a defamation lawsuit against ABC News.

Throughout his career, Conway has argued before the Supreme Court, including a case in 2010, Morrison v. National Australia Bank. He also has experience representing high-profile clients, including Paula Jones, who he helped represent in her sexual harassment lawsuit against then-President Bill Clinton in the 1990s. Conway's work on that case established a legal precedent for a sitting president to be sued in civil court.

Conway graduated from Yale Law School in 1987 after attending Harvard College. He also clerked for US Circuit Judge Ralph Winter, Jr. of the Second Circuit Court of Appeals, who was nominated to the court by President Ronald Reagan.

In response to a loudspeaker announcement, teachers and students quickly drop to the ground, awaiting further instructions. "This is a drill," the voice echoes, "a missile has been launched." Moments later, the entire school body rushes from the athletic field into the school gym, joined by elderly volunteers who line up in rows beside the children seated quietly on the wooden floor. This is Japan's first evacuation exercise, simulating a scenario in which a North Korean missile attacks the country. "A missile fell approximately 20 kilometers off the coast of Oga, within Japan's territorial waters," another announcement states. "The extent of the damage is unknown, so please remain sheltered inside the gym." Following the drill, a government official thanks participants in the gym, tactfully avoiding any specific mention of North Korea. "The government is making every effort to maintain good relations with other countries to prevent a missile attack," says Chief Cabinet Counselor Atsushi Odani. "If a missile is launched, our self-defense forces will attempt to intercept it," he adds, referring to Japan's military. Japan is not defenseless against ballistic missile threats. Recently, guided missile destroyers from the US, Japan, and South Korea participated in trilateral naval exercises aimed at improving missile defense. The warships are equipped with the Aegis missile defense system, designed to detect missile threats early on. These ships can also fire interceptors to destroy the ballistic missile early in its flight, or transmit tracking data to other ships along the missile's path, allowing it to be destroyed at its highest point. Despite the close military ties between Japan, the US, and South Korea, North Korea was able to launch four ballistic missiles on March 6, with three of them landing in the sea just 370 kilometers off Japan's western coast. The United Nations has repeatedly banned North Korea from developing nuclear weapons and ballistic missile technology, but Pyongyang has continued to defy these resolutions. In 2016, the country conducted at least two nuclear tests and fired over a dozen missiles. In the small fishing port of Oga, locals are growing increasingly concerned about the threat from North Korea. "It's terrifying," says Zen-ei Nishikata, who hauls in freshly caught octopus at the local docks. "You never know what the North Koreans might do next." For some residents of Oga, the recent missile evacuation drill brought back painful memories of World War II, when sirens would sound and people would hide in air raid shelters. "If a war breaks out with North Korea, Japan will be the target," says 89-year-old Reinosuke Ishigaki, who helped coordinate the town's disaster preparations. "And they have their finger on the nuclear button." The principal of Oga's elementary school believes the missile evacuation drill provided his students with a valuable lesson. "Even though they're still young, they're starting to understand the potential threat from a missile," says Shin Kikuchi. "It's beyond their imagination." The school's hallway is decorated with fearsome masks representing the namahage, a mythical ogre that serves as the community's mascot on the Oga peninsula. "In this region, a long-standing tradition on New Year's Eve is for actors to don eerie straw costumes and menacing masks, all in an effort to frighten children into behaving. However, as North Korea's ballistic missile program becomes increasingly advanced, residents now face a very real and far more terrifying threat to keep them up at night."

According to the state-owned Korean Central News Agency, a recent test evaluated the thrust power in the combustion chamber, the structural safety and reliability of the engine, and the movement of the turbine pump. The test took place at the Sohae Satellite Launching Ground in North Pyongan Province, as reported. The North Korean media hailed the test as a historic achievement that could revive the country's indigenous rocket industry. Kim emphasized that the world would soon witness the significance of this achievement, according to KCNA. The announcement was made just hours before US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson met with Chinese President Xi Jinping in Beijing, with whom North Korea has a major global alliance. Although neither side publicly mentioned the test, Tillerson was expected to discuss the possibility of imposing financial penalties on Chinese companies and banks that do business with North Korea during their meeting.

On Sunday morning, Israeli Defense Minister Avigdor Liberman made a stern warning on Israel's public radio, saying, "The next time Syria uses its air defense systems against our planes, we will destroy them all without hesitation." This threat comes after Syria fired anti-aircraft missiles at Israeli military jets overnight on Thursday into Friday. The Syrian military claimed the jets struck a military site near Palmyra, while Israel maintains they targeted a weapons shipment to Iran-backed Hezbollah. Syria alleged that their missiles downed one Israeli jet and hit another, but Israel rejected this as "completely false."

Liberman emphasized that Israel's main concern is the transfer of advanced weapons from Syria to Lebanon. "Every time we identify a transfer like this, we will work to prevent the transfer of game-changing weapons. On this issue, there will be no compromise," he stated firmly. This is not the first time Liberman has used threatening rhetoric since taking over the Defense Ministry last year.

The recent encounter between Israel and Syria marks the most serious clash between the two countries since the start of the Syrian civil war six years ago. While tensions between the two nations had decreased as the conflict progressed, they have increased in recent months, along with Israel's reported strikes. An airstrike near Palmyra would be one of the deepest inside Syria since the beginning of the fighting.

The military actions did not go unnoticed, both in the Middle East and internationally. In a sign of Russia's displeasure with the strike, Moscow summoned Israel's ambassador to Russia, Gary Koren, within 24 hours of the incident. For the first time in recent years, Moscow has summoned Israel's ambassador over a strike in Syria, a move that comes just a week after Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu met with Russian President Vladimir Putin to reaffirm their countries' military coordination in Syria. The two nations established this coordination last year to avoid conflicts in Syrian airspace, allowing them to operate freely in the region. Palmyra, a strategic location once held by ISIS and later retaken by the Syrian government, is crucial to both the regime and its opponents. An intercepted Israeli strike triggered alarm sirens in the Jordan Valley and sent shrapnel from the explosion landing in western Jordan, which was heard as far south as Jerusalem, according to the Jordanian military. Most of Israel's reported strikes have targeted areas around Damascus, the Syrian capital, which is approximately 60 kilometers (37 miles) from the Israeli-occupied Golan Heights, seized from Syria during the 1967 Six-Day War. Israel has long focused on preventing the transfer of weapons from Syria to terrorist groups. In December, Defense Minister Liberman told European Union envoys that Israel will "prevent the smuggling of sophisticated weapons, military equipment, and weapons of mass destruction from Syria to Hezbollah." This statement marked another acknowledgment of Israel's ongoing operations in Syria. Last April, Netanyahu confirmed that Israel had launched strikes against Syria "dozens of times," breaking with the policy of remaining silent about its involvement in the war-torn region. In a video statement released Friday, Netanyahu defended Israel's actions, stating, "When we identify attempts to transfer advanced weapons to Hezbollah and we have intelligence and it is operationally feasible, we act to prevent it. That's how it was yesterday and that's how we shall continue to act." "We are fully committed and our actions are evidence of that. Everyone must take that into account." Hezbollah, a Lebanese militant group and political party backed by Iran, has been at odds with Israel over territory along their shared border. The group has also supported the Syrian government of President Bashar al-Assad, deploying thousands of fighters to battle alongside his forces. While the United States, Israel, and the Arab League classify Hezbollah as a terrorist organization, the European Union only considers its military wing to be a terrorist group. Recently, Syrian media reported that Israeli jets targeted military positions and weapons convoys near Damascus. In November 2012, Israel fired warning shots at Syria after a mortar shell hit an Israeli military post, marking the first time Israel had fired on Syria since the 1973 Yom Kippur War. Israeli jets have been striking targets in Syria since at least 2013, when US officials believed IDF jets had attacked Syrian territory. In 2014, both the Syrian government and an opposition group claimed that an IDF strike had hit Damascus' suburbs and airport. Israeli strikes have also targeted ISIS fighters in Syria. Last year, IDF troops operating in the disputed Golan region came under fire from ISIS militants affiliated with the Khalid ibn al-Walid Army. The soldiers returned fire, sparking an exchange of gunfire. An Israeli airstrike later destroyed a vehicle carrying four militants, according to Israeli military spokesman Lt. Col. Peter Lerner.

A president's golf game is typically uncontroversial, as it's a common pastime among leaders. However, before running for office, Trump was a vocal critic of President Barack Obama's frequent golf outings with friends, aides, and advisors, arguing that it showed a lack of seriousness about addressing the country's problems. Now, Trump's own golf habit is coming back to haunt him. In the first two months of his presidency, Trump has visited his two nearby golf courses - Trump International Golf Course in West Palm Beach and Trump National Golf Course in Jupiter - a total of 10 times. Trump's top aides have been trying to downplay the frequency of his golf outings, particularly given his previous comments about the sport and the White House. "I'm going to be working for you; I'm not going to have time to go play golf," Trump said during a 2016 event in Virginia. Despite this, aides have been reluctant to confirm that Trump plays golf on weekends in Florida, instead repeatedly stating that the President "may" hit a few balls at his course, but they're not sure. However, multiple instances of Trump's golf games have been publicly documented, including a recent sighting of him driving up the 12th hole on his championship course at Trump International Golf Course. Additionally, it has been revealed that Trump has played with top professional golfers such as Rory McIlroy, one of the world's top-ranked golfers. During a recent visit from Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, Trump even played a full round of golf with the foreign leader and professional golfer Ernie Els. President Trump's favorite golf course is the one closest to his Florida home, Trump International Golf Club. He has visited the course every time he has golfed since taking office, a total of 10 times. On only one occasion, when hosting Japanese Prime Minister Abe, did Trump also visit Trump National Golf Club in Jupiter. Additionally, he stopped by his course in Sterling, Virginia, on March 11 for a meeting, although it's unclear whether he played a round. During his 2016 presidential campaign, Trump criticized his predecessor, Barack Obama, for golfing, saying, "I love golf, but I don't have time." Trump also tweeted about Obama's golfing habits, calling them "worse than Carter." Now, citing the President's privacy, Trump's aides are struggling to keep his frequent golfing outings out of the public eye.

There is a significant amount to pay attention to, but the fate of this story will largely depend on the testimony of five key individuals. Firstly, James Comey, the enigmatic figure, will likely shed more light on the controversy surrounding his "October Surprise" and its impact on Hillary Clinton's electoral chances. Although Comey's neutrality is questionable, he has already confirmed that Trump's claims of wiretapping have no basis in fact. The crucial question is whether he will confirm or sidestep a direct inquiry about whether there is a criminal investigation into the Trump team's potential collusion with Russia during the election. If he confirms, the political landscape will be significantly altered.

Secondly, Sally Yates, the "rock star" of the story, will take the stand on Monday to address the controversy surrounding her early firing as Acting Attorney General. Yates' brief tenure was marked by her warning to the White House about the potential compromise of National Security Adviser Michael Flynn due to his ties to Russia. The White House failed to act on this information until it was leaked to the press. Yates' testimony is likely to shed more light on what she told the White House about Flynn's situation. The Intelligence Committee's power duo, Chairman Devin Nunes and Ranking Member Adam Schiff, have taken center stage in the investigation into Russia's alleged interference in the 2016 election. Nunes, who was part of Trump's transition team, has expressed skepticism about Russia's involvement, while Schiff has been a vocal critic of the President, accusing him of downplaying the issue. Schiff has also made it clear that he intends to call former MI6 officer Christopher Steele, author of the unverified dossier containing allegations about Trump's ties to Russia, to testify before the committee. The dynamic between Nunes and Schiff is complex, with Schiff determined to keep Nunes in check and ensure that the questioning remains focused. This was evident when Nunes recently acknowledged that there was no evidence to support Trump's wiretap claims, a significant departure from his earlier stance. Meanwhile, Schiff has emerged as a party star, refusing to let Nunes dominate the questioning.

One notable absentee from the March 20 hearing will be Michael Flynn, a key figure in the investigation due to his ties to Turkey and Russia. Flynn, a former national security advisor, received significant payments from Russia for speeches and consulting work, and it's only a matter of time before he is called to testify before either the House or Senate Intelligence Committee. Although Flynn won't be present at the hearing, his absence will likely be a topic of discussion among other witnesses.

Finally, President Donald Trump is likely to be watching the proceedings closely, given the intense scrutiny he has faced over his campaign's ties to Russia. "His provocative tweets have dominated the national conversation, but it's essential to remember the true significance of the Russia scandal. The real story is not about Trump's tweets, but about Russia's interference in our elections and what the President knew about it. This investigation will unfold gradually, with no dramatic breakthroughs expected. Today's hearing is just the beginning, and there will be many more to come, including a comprehensive review by the Senate Intelligence Committee. Unlike some in Congress, few have bought into the administration's claims that these reports are 'fake news.' As the Russia issue continues to unfold, the narrative will shift from partisan squabbles to bipartisan demands for transparency and accountability. Unfortunately, it seems the President is not yet prepared to face the consequences."

House Intelligence Committee ranking Democrat Adam Schiff expressed his thoughts on NBC's "Meet the Press," stating that he believes there is circumstantial evidence of collusion and direct evidence of deception. He emphasized the need to determine whether these findings are indicative of more. Schiff's comments contradict those of former Director of National Intelligence James Clapper, who recently stated that he had not seen any evidence of collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia. Schiff responded by saying he was surprised by Clapper's claim, as he does not believe it can be made so categorically.

The congressman's remarks came as his committee prepares to take testimony from FBI Director James Comey and National Security Agency Director Mike Rogers regarding the administration's investigation into Russia's attempts to influence the US election and any relationships between Russian officials and Trump's associates. Sen. Tom Cotton previewed the upcoming House hearing on CNN's "State of the Union," stating that Comey's testimony will address "unsubstantiated allegations" of dealings between Moscow and President Donald Trump's campaign. Cotton emphasized the importance of considering the broader context, noting that the House committee hearing will focus on unsubstantiated allegations of collusion between Trump associates and Russian intelligence.

The US intelligence community has concluded that Russia was responsible for hacking the Democratic National Committee and former Hillary Clinton campaign chairman John Podesta, which it believes was part of an effort to aid Trump in the election. The Russian government has denied any wrongdoing. According to CNN and other reports, current and former law enforcement, intelligence, and administration officials have revealed that there were communications between Trump's associates and Russians known to US intelligence during the campaign. Michael Flynn, a retired Lt. Gen., resigned as Trump's national security adviser after media reports surfaced about his post-election conversations with Russian Ambassador Sergey Kislyak. However, Devin Nunes, Chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, stated on Fox News Sunday that there is "no evidence of collusion" between Russia and the Trump campaign. In a CNN interview, Tom Cotton cited James Clapper and Michael Morell, who have both publicly stated that they have seen no evidence of collusion. Morell, a former acting CIA Director who supported Hillary Clinton in the 2016 election, emphatically denied any connection between the Trump campaign and Russia, saying, "On the question of the Trump campaign conspiring with the Russians, there is smoke, but there is no fire. There's no little campfire. There's no little candle. There's no spark." Meanwhile, lawmakers from both parties largely echoed each other in dismissing Trump's unsubstantiated claim that President Barack Obama wiretapped his phones at Trump Tower during the campaign. Republicans such as Cotton, Nunes, House Speaker Paul Ryan, and Maine Sen. Susan Collins reiterated that they have seen no evidence to support Trump's accusation, which has been refused to be corroborated by the administration. On Friday, the House Intelligence Committee received a classified report from the Department of Justice regarding the claim, which is expected to be discussed at Monday's hearing. According to sources, the report is unlikely to back up Trump's accusation. Nunes, a California Republican, stated on Sunday that, based on his briefing with the Department of Justice, there were no physical wiretaps of Trump Tower. He added that a classified report from the department on Friday reinforced his belief that Trump's claims were "literally" incorrect. Nunes also said that there was no evidence of collusion between Russia and the Trump campaign.

Cotton, a member of the Senate Intelligence Committee, expressed skepticism about Trump's wiretap claims, stating that he had seen no evidence to support them. When asked if Trump should apologize to his predecessor if Comey's testimony contradicts his claims, Cotton deflected the question, saying, "We'll see what Director Comey testifies about."

Meanwhile, Senator Ted Cruz, a Texas Republican, seemed to back Trump's claims, saying that they were "not necessarily outlandish." However, he also emphasized the need for the administration to provide evidence to support the claims. Cruz also brought up the IRS scandal involving conservative groups and accused the Obama administration of politically motivated behavior.

Cotton, a veteran and member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, discussed major military issues, including the influx of Marines and other service members into Syria. He did not advocate for a specific policy, but stated that the US should not set arbitrary troop caps. Cotton also called for the defeat of ISIS and emphasized the need to counter Iran's activities in the region, which he blamed for the rise of ISIS. He assured the public that those responsible for the nude photo scandal in the Marine Corps would be identified and punished.

Let me know if you have any further requests!

NATO's Secretary-General, Ursula von der Leyen, released a statement on Sunday, clarifying that there is no debt account in NATO and that the 2% defense spending target is not solely related to the alliance. Von der Leyen emphasized that defense spending also goes towards UN peace missions, European missions, and counter-terrorism efforts against ISIS. Her statement was in response to claims by US President Trump that some NATO allies owe money for not meeting defense spending targets. Germany, for instance, spent 1.19% of its GDP on defense last year.

In a joint press conference with German Chancellor Angela Merkel, Trump reiterated his support for NATO and emphasized the need for allies to pay their fair share of defense costs. He claimed that many nations owe vast sums of money from past years and that it is unfair to the US. Trump demanded that these nations pay what they owe.

However, NATO members have committed to a defense spending target of 2% of GDP, but this is not a debt obligation. According to the alliance's annual report, only five members (the US, Greece, Poland, Estonia, and the UK) currently meet this target, while many others plan to reach it by 2024. Trump also thanked German Chancellor Merkel for her commitment to increasing defense spending during their meeting. In a Twitter rant, Donald Trump took aim at media reports that his summit with Angela Merkel had gone poorly. He also reasserted his incorrect claim that NATO member countries, such as Germany, owe "vast sums" of money to the alliance and that the US must be "paid" for its defense contributions. Trump tweeted, "Despite what you've heard from FAKE NEWS, I had a GREAT meeting with German Chancellor Angela Merkel. Nevertheless, Germany owes vast sums of money to NATO & the United States must be paid more for the powerful, and very expensive, defense it provides to Germany!"

In response, former US Ambassador to NATO Ivo Daalder pushed back against Trump's claims, explaining how NATO's treaty commitments actually work. "Sorry, Mr. President, that's not how NATO works," he tweeted. "The US decides for itself how much it contributes to defending NATO." Daalder went on to clarify that NATO member countries are increasing their defense budgets, a development he viewed as positive.

Before taking office, Trump had raised concerns about NATO, calling the organization "obsolete" in a joint interview with the Times of London and the German publication Bild. "I said a long time ago that NATO had problems," he said. "Number one, it was obsolete, because it was designed many, many years ago. Number two, the countries weren't paying what they're supposed to be paying." Trump claimed that this was unfair to the US. "Following the president's statement, several members of his administration, including Vice President Mike Pence, have reaffirmed the United States' unwavering commitment to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO)."

Fierce clashes erupted in Damascus, the Syrian capital, which had not seen such intense fighting in months, possibly even years, according to Rami Abdel Rahman, director of the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights. The rebel fighters launched their attack from the Jobar district in northeastern Damascus, an area that is divided between rebel and government control. The rebel factions appear to have been preparing for this offensive, said Rahman. The Syrian regime and its allied militias have maintained a firm grip on the capital since the start of the conflict. The opposition holds only a few isolated pockets of control around Damascus, including a portion of Jobar. The assault was led by Islamist groups, including Ahrar al-Sham and Hayat Tahrir al-Sham, a recently formed umbrella organization that includes Jabhat Fatah al-Sham. Syrian state media reported that government forces had repelled an attack by jihadist fighters, who also used tunnels to target government positions. The status of the fighting on Sunday evening was unclear, and there was no immediate word on casualties. The assault comes after a series of suicide bombings in March, which targeted a courthouse and restaurant in Damascus, killing more than two dozen people and injuring others, according to Syrian state news.

The Indus Water Treaty, a 57-year-old agreement that governs the sharing of water resources between India and Pakistan, has been under threat due to rising tensions in the disputed region of Kashmir. The treaty, brokered by the World Bank, is set to be discussed again on Monday, following a period of heightened tensions between the two nations. The Indus River system, which supports livelihoods across Pakistan and northern India, originates in Tibet and flows through China and Indian-controlled Kashmir before reaching Pakistan. The treaty has been a crucial component of the relationship between India and Pakistan, governing how the two countries manage the vast volume of water that is vital to both nations. However, the talks in Islamabad come after Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi suspended water talks with Pakistan seven months ago. The discussions are expected to focus on India's plans to use the rivers to generate hydropower, which Pakistan has strongly objected to. Modi's decision to review the terms of the treaty has been seen by some analysts as a threat to the deal. The 1965 and 1971 Indo-Pakistani wars, as well as numerous subsequent standoffs between the two nations, have not deterred the treaty from remaining a crucial part of their relationship. However, recent tensions between the nuclear-armed neighbors have once again put the treaty's strength to the test. In September, militants infiltrated an Indian army base in Uri, a garrison town near the de facto border, killing 18 soldiers in one of the deadliest attacks on an army base in the region since 1989. The aftermath saw tensions escalate on both sides of the disputed border, with India launching a "surgical attack" across the Line of Control with Pakistan. The repercussions were far-reaching, with India evacuating villages along the border and Pakistan temporarily restricting Indian film imports. Following the Uri incident, Prime Minister Modi met with officials to review the water treaty's provisions. At the meeting, it was announced that India would utilize to its maximum capacity the water from Pakistan-controlled rivers, including the Jhelum, while remaining within the treaty's historical boundaries. Pakistan appeared unsettled by the move and subsequently approached the World Bank to express its concerns. In November, Modi reiterated India's rights over the eastern rivers, as stipulated by the treaty. "This water belongs to India's farmers," Modi said. "It is not intended for your farms, but rather flows to Pakistan and ultimately to the ocean. I am committed to bringing every drop of that water back to the farmers of Punjab, Jammu and Kashmir... for India's farmers." The Indus Water Treaty, according to analyst Rebecca Keller from Stratfor, provides a crucial level of consistency for a vital natural resource shared by both Pakistan and India, despite being situated over disputed borders. The Indus river basin is essential for Pakistan's agriculture, supporting a massive 75% of its irrigated land, making it the largest contiguous irrigation network in the world, Keller notes. Agriculture is a significant contributor to Pakistan's economy, accounting for roughly a quarter of its GDP and a major source of foreign exchange earnings. While India has other river basins that support its agricultural sector, the Indus remains a vital component for regional farming. The dam dispute has been ongoing, with India seeking to harness the rivers for hydropower, a move Pakistan initially objected to a decade ago. In 2010, Pakistan filed a complaint with the Permanent Court of Arbitration in The Hague, citing concerns that India would gain control over the water flow into Pakistan's agricultural heartland. However, the court ruled in India's favor three years later, allowing the construction of the Kishanganga dam to proceed. Pakistan has since renewed its opposition to the dam, arguing that it would draw too much water from the Indus River Basin, exceeding India's allotted share under the treaty. India, on the other hand, claims it utilizes only a fraction of its allocated water for hydropower and agricultural projects, with estimates suggesting it uses only 4% of its total allocation. Despite the ongoing dispute, experts believe it is unlikely that either country will seek to abandon the treaty when they meet this week. However, negotiations are likely to be tense, with both nations keen to protect their interests, especially with general elections on the horizon. "Both countries can use the dispute as a tool to advance their political aims in the coming year," Keller says. "This is not the first dispute that has occurred under the Indus Water Treaty, and it won't be the last."

As Haider Abadi departed Iraq for the United States on Sunday, he announced that Iraqi forces were nearing the end of their campaign against ISIS and planned to discuss the final stages of the operation with the US administration. In a video statement, Abadi declared, "We are in the final chapter, the last stages of eliminating ISIS militarily in Iraq." He expressed hope that the US and its allies would continue to provide economic assistance to Iraq, which is facing a financial crisis due to the war against ISIS. Meanwhile, President Trump recently announced a $54 billion increase in defense spending, with over $3 billion allocated to the fight against ISIS, including a flexible fund worth $2 billion to support the Pentagon's new counter-ISIS strategy.

The upcoming meeting between Trump and Abadi may touch on sensitive topics. The Iraqi government had objected to its citizens being included on the January executive order banning travel from certain Muslim-majority countries to the US. However, after intense lobbying from Baghdad, Iraq was removed from the revised order. This followed a phone call between Trump and Abadi on February 10, as well as an in-person conversation between Abadi and Vice President Mike Pence in Munich on February 18. The discussions were further fueled by talks between Secretary of State Rex Tillerson and Iraqi officials about vetting measures in place to prevent suspected terrorists from leaving Iraq and entering the US. While Iraq did not implement new measures, the country provided more details to US officials about its traveler screening process. According to a readout of the phone call from Baghdad, President Trump told Abadi that he intended to find a solution to his counterpart's concerns about Iraqi citizens being unable to enter the United States. Trump asked Secretary of State Tillerson to provide more clarity on the vetting measures in Iraq, a US official said. However, the move was criticized by some US veterans who argued it would harm Iraqis who had applied for asylum in the US after helping American forces in Iraq as translators and contractors. Additionally, some American national security officials pressed Trump to remove Iraq from the travel ban, citing the restriction's burden on a key partner in the fight against ISIS. Notably, over 5,000 US military personnel are currently stationed in Iraq, providing critical support in the war against ISIS. In January, Trump had suggested that if the US had kept Iraq's oil after the invasion, ISIS would not have emerged, stating, "We should have kept the oil when we got out. And you know, it's very interesting. Had we taken the oil, you wouldn't have ISIS, because they fuel themselves with the oil. That's where they get their money." However, ahead of his visit to Baghdad, US Defense Secretary James Mattis clarified that the US was not in Iraq to seize oil, saying, "All of us in America have generally paid for our gas and oil all along, and I'm sure that we will continue to do so in the future."

Nadia Murad, accompanied by her counsel, renowned international human rights lawyer Amal Clooney, recounted her harrowing experience to Zakaria. Her ordeal began in 2014 when ISIS militants invaded her village in Sinjar, Kurdistan. "On August 3, 2014, at dawn, they launched a brutal attack," Murad recalled. "In that single day, nearly 6,500 women and children from the Yazidi community were abducted, and approximately 5,000 people were killed. For eight months, we were forcibly separated from our mothers, sisters, and brothers, and some were killed, while others vanished." Murad's mother and six of her brothers and stepbrothers were brutally executed. As an unmarried woman, Murad was taken as a sex slave and repeatedly passed around various ISIS militants. She recounted that as punishment for a failed escape attempt, she was gang-raped until she lost consciousness. Murad emphasized that under ISIS's twisted rule, which justified the enslavement of Yazidis on religious grounds, the brutal treatment was deemed legal. "They sold underage girls, believing it was permissible under Islamic law," Murad said. "ISIS didn't just target specific individuals; they came for all Yazidis." The violence against the Yazidi community continues to this day, Clooney, who represents Murad, pointed out. Over 6,000 Yazidis are believed to remain in captivity, including some from Murad's own family, according to Clooney. It's time, she said, to hold ISIS accountable for committing some of the worst crimes of our generation. "We know that there's a military campaign underway to defeat ISIS on the battlefield. What we're seeking is to see ISIS members face justice in a courtroom." No court has attempted to prosecute ISIS for the crimes it committed against the Yazidi people. Not a single prosecution has taken place against ISIS in any court worldwide for the international crimes it committed against the Yazidis. Last week, Clooney addressed the UN, urging the Security Council to establish an investigation in Iraq to collect evidence of ISIS's atrocities. "ISIS is a global threat, and it requires a global response," Clooney said. "We cannot defeat ISIS solely on the battlefield, as we must also address future recruiting. Trials and exposing the brutality of ISIS through the media can help counter their propaganda and show that it's not a holy war." Clooney emphasized the importance of an investigation to ensure that evidence is properly collected and preserved. "ISIS has established a bureaucracy for its slave trade, complete with committees, courts, and documents, including DNA samples and mass graves. Unfortunately, nobody is collecting this evidence, and if it's lost, we'll never be able to have trials or achieve justice." Clooney noted that a resolution is already drafted and ready, and she is asking the Iraqi government and the UN to establish a thorough investigation. To make this happen, Iraq only needs to send a letter to the Security Council requesting an investigation. She explained, "A resolution is already drafted and ready. If Iraq simply sends a letter, a vote will be held. From my conversations with the Russian ambassador, the United States ambassador, and others, it appears that there is broad support in the Council. Therefore, this should move forward. It aligns with the Iraqi government's interests, as they are targeting ISIS."

Murad, who now resides in Germany, expressed her hope that ISIS would finally face justice. She then switched to a halting English, saying, "I wonder... maybe if I can speak English, maybe the UN will understand... what we want. But I can't." Zakaria responded, "We can hear you regardless of the language you speak."

When his initial threats didn't have the desired effect, President Trump escalated his rhetoric, warning Republicans that if they didn't vote with him, they'd never get another chance to reform healthcare. The Republicans gathered for an emotional pre-vote meeting in the Capitol's basement, where many described it as one of the most impressive conferences they'd ever attended. However, the sense of defeat was palpable when House Speaker Paul Ryan delivered a brief statement and hastily departed without answering reporters' questions. Trump, who had relied on his usual method of deal-making, then walked away from the arduous process of political negotiation. Despite White House spokesman Sean Spicer's assertion that there was no "plan B," Trump's confidence seemed to wane. As Ryan struggled to rally his party, Trump climbed into a tractor parked outside the White House, honked the horn like a child, and pretended to drive, appearing happier than he had in weeks. Despite these displays of confidence, the Republicans who run Washington were unable to unite behind Trumpcare. Just hours before the vote, The Daily Beast reported that Trump's top adviser, Steve Bannon, had suggested the President make a list of his House GOP enemies to punish. When this tactic failed, Trump and Ryan abruptly canceled the showdown vote. CNN and other networks broadcast the debacle in real-time, leaving both men humiliated and diminished. It's no surprise that Trump's first major legislative initiative collapsed in chaos. Aside from the development of his enormous ego, nothing in Donald Trump's life experience prepared him to effectively serve as President of the United States. During the presidential transition, it became clear that Trump was unable to bring the country together. Instead, he immediately began spreading falsehoods and distortions about various topics, from the size of the inauguration crowd to claims of widespread voter fraud in the recent election. One of the most striking aspects of the Trump presidency is how we expected him to behave differently. Trump's propensity for dishonesty and deception began to manifest in his early years, when he would boast about his accomplishments before they had even happened. Despite experiencing four major corporate bankruptcies, Trump continued to assert his business acumen, claiming to be a great leader despite his limited experience. In reality, he was a successful entrepreneur who controlled family-held companies with an iron fist, dismissing anyone who disagreed with him. As President, Trump's inability to fire members of Congress proved a significant obstacle. His campaign promise to repeal and replace Obamacare was met with resistance, as few voters liked the proposed Trumpcare. Perhaps it was the plan's proposed cuts to healthcare coverage, which would have left 24 million people without insurance, or the elimination of essential coverage requirements for policies, including pregnancy care, drug benefits, and mental health coverage. House members, who must face re-election every two years, were more concerned with facing angry constituents than dealing with a President whose approval rating had plummeted to 37%. "As Trump's withdrawal from his healthcare bill unfolded, it seemed like a significant defeat. However, with the passage of time, the magnitude of the loss has become even more apparent, and it's striking to compare it to Trump's self-image. This is a man who touts himself as a dynamic winner with unparalleled abilities. During his campaign, he famously declared, "Only I can fix" America's problems. He also viewed his primary opponents and President Obama as losers and failures. In contrast, most of the other Republican candidates in 2016 had successful government careers before running for office. Moreover, Obama managed to pass his healthcare bill despite significant opposition. Trump's inability to pass his own bill raises questions about his understanding of the legislative process and his willingness to listen to those around him who do. It also highlights his lack of leadership skills when dealing with hundreds of powerful lawmakers. Furthermore, Trump's temperament appears to be at odds with that of respected presidents like Johnson, Reagan, and Clinton, who valued the legislative process. The weak bill and clumsy vote-seeking tactics suggest a lack of conviction from Trump and Ryan. As a result, it's likely that Trump will deflect blame, targeting Ryan and others in the administration. Eventually, Trump will likely try again, but the problem is that Congress has shown that his usual approach of intimidation won't work. Moreover, Trump has yet to demonstrate an alternative leadership style."

Americans were sharply divided on the meaning and implications of the bill, and their reactions to its withdrawal were varied. Here are some reactions from individuals after House Republicans pulled the bill:

Debby Goodwin, a 63-year-old from Arkansas, expressed disappointment and shame at her decision to vote Republican, stating that she was relieved the House did not vote on the bill. "Our family is experiencing undue stress due to Trump and the Republicans' lack of concern for people in our economic situation, and they need to start listening to us," she told CNN.

Goodwin's son, Nathan Dodson, who is not covered by Obamacare, welcomed the lack of a vote. "It shows that the citizens' voices have been heard. The polls and town hall meetings indicated that this was a major issue," he said.

The CEO of a Kentucky-based healthcare company, Mike Caudill of Mountain Comprehensive Health Corporation, viewed the bill's withdrawal as an opportunity for President Trump to work across party lines. "This gives President Trump the chance to reach out to the other side," he told CNN. "I hope he bridges the divide between the parties." Caudill, whose company employs over 300 people, described the development as encouraging, stating that it would prevent immediate adverse effects on the people they serve under the Affordable Care Act.

Susan Levin, a resident of Los Angeles, hailed the decision as a victory for women. "Hooray, it didn't pass!" she exclaimed. "I think it was very masochistic." Levin, a woman of the 1960s, reflected on the difficulties she faced during that era and emphasized the need for a thorough overhaul of the healthcare system. "The current system is deeply flawed, with significant shortcomings, including a lack of provisions for women and inadequate maternity care," she said. "If they want to make meaningful changes, they need to take the time to carefully consider all the implications."

Romero, a staffing professional in California, expressed hope that Republicans would continue to work towards replacing Obamacare. "The Affordable Care Act has had a negative impact on my business, forcing us to pass the cost on to our associates," she said. "Unfortunately, many of them can't afford the coverage even with the subsidy, so they're still forced to buy it." Romero believes Trump anticipated the challenges the GOP would face and is prepared to present an alternative plan.

Stack, a 34-year-old bartender in Denver, was critical of Trump's healthcare plan, calling it "horrible." For now, she relies on her employer for health insurance, but she thinks the government should focus on more pressing issues, such as resolving the situation with Russia. As a first-generation American, Stack expressed frustration with the country, saying, "I hate this country." However, she noted that her support for Brexit has led her to consider the possibility of moving to the UK, pending the outcome of events there.

Eidenberg, president of an insurance company in Chicago, was relieved that the healthcare bill did not pass and warned against manipulating Medicaid. "I've been glued to the TV, following the developments closely, and I'm glad the bill didn't go through," she said. "We need to focus on creating a healthcare system that works for everyone, not just a select few." Eidenberg, a critic of the Affordable Care Act, expressed concerns about the bill's effectiveness, citing high rates and issues with Medicaid. "I don't think the ACA is working as intended, and the Ryan-Trump bill would have had significant negative impacts on communities and states," she said. Despite the setback, Eidenberg remains hopeful that the failure to pass the bill will ultimately lead to positive change. "The turmoil in healthcare is finally sparking a national conversation, and I believe we may see meaningful reforms emerge from this chaos."

A 65-year-old business owner from Nashville, Tennessee, Nick Patel, believes that Obamacare needs to be strengthened. "The healthcare bill needs significant revisions to benefit everyone," he said. Patel, who works in the hospitality industry, suggested two key changes: reducing the cost of medicine and insurance. "The bill needs to be overhauled to make healthcare more accessible and affordable for all," he said.

Curtis Chipley, a California resident, felt that pulling the bill without a vote was a lack of transparency. "If you're going to claim you were close to passing the bill, then let the vote happen and deal with the consequences," Chipley wrote on Facebook. "Instead, the administration is leaving the American people in the dark about how close they really were to success."

After nearly three months in office, Speaker Paul Ryan is now facing a significant challenge that could define his tenure: deep divisions among his fellow Republicans. "Transitioning from an opposition party to a governing party comes with its challenges," Ryan said in a press conference on Friday. "And right now, we're feeling those challenges." The setback was particularly tough for Ryan, who rose to prominence in Washington as a conservative policy expert committed to repealing the Affordable Care Act and became House speaker in 2015. The bill that failed to pass was based on Ryan's signature policy agenda, "A Better Way." "I don't know what else to say - Obamacare is the law of the land, and it will remain so until it's replaced," he said. "We'll be living with Obamacare for the foreseeable future." This reality check is a stark reminder that life is different for Ryan now that Trump is in office. During the Obama administration, the Republican-controlled House could pass symbolic bills repealing Obamacare, knowing they would die in the Senate or be vetoed by the President. "This is how governing works when you're in the majority," Ryan said. "We need to get 216 people to agree on legislation, not 210 or 215. We were close, but we didn't have 216. That's how legislation works." Democrats were jubilant after the healthcare bill's defeat, while Republican lawmakers had expressed concerns about the potential consequences of a defeat even before the bill was pulled. Representative Chris Collins of New York warned on Friday that if the healthcare bill failed, it would leave a "black eye" on his party's ability to govern. "If we don't pass this, I don't think we'll pass a 2018 budget," he said. "We couldn't pass a 2017 budget, and if we couldn't pass a 2017 budget and this happens today, how will we pass a 2018 budget?" Collins added. "This bill is also the vehicle for tax reform, and if we don't do tax reform, where will the money come from for infrastructure? That's how critical this vote is." However, both President Trump and Speaker Ryan have announced plans to move on to tax reform. Ryan delivered a solo statement from behind the podium, without any Republican colleagues or White House officials who had worked tirelessly with him to pass the healthcare legislation. Despite questions about Ryan's relationship with Trump, the two have publicly insisted that they have a healthy dialogue. Ryan said he had informed Trump directly that he didn't have the votes, and Trump accepted his recommendation to withdraw the bill. Trump publicly blamed Democrats for the failure, rather than Speaker Ryan. "I like Speaker Ryan, he worked very hard," Trump said from the Oval Office. However, it will take more than words to unite the Republican Party, especially after both conservative and moderate factions demonstrated their strength this week. The GOP's internal divisions were Ryan's greatest challenge, and one he never managed to overcome. The Freedom Caucus, a group of conservative lawmakers, refused to support the bill, calling it "Obamacare Lite" and arguing it didn't go far enough in dismantling the Affordable Care Act. However, when Speaker Ryan and his team attempted to placate the Freedom Caucus by proposing even more significant changes to Obamacare, they only alienated more moderate members of the House conference. In the final days, Ryan worked tirelessly to bridge the gap between the two factions, holding marathon meetings and one-on-one sessions. Despite his efforts, the differences proved insurmountable. "We came very close today, but ultimately fell short," Ryan said at a press conference. "I won't sugarcoat it - this is a disappointing outcome for us."

As Martin walked by the Houses of Parliament in Westminster, she couldn't help but notice the police officer standing guard. She approached him and asked if she could take a photo with him. Little did she know, just moments later, the area would be plunged into chaos and tragedy, and the smiling officer who had posed for her picture would lose his life. Martin, a tourist from West Palm Beach, Florida, was visiting her son who was studying abroad in London. During a guided tour of the city, her son showed her the Parliament building, and Martin was drawn to the officer's hat. She asked if she could take a photo, and he politely agreed. "I asked the officer if it was okay to take a photo, and he said yes," Martin recalled. "I also asked him if this happened often, and he told me it happened quite frequently." After taking the photo, Martin and her family left to grab lunch at a nearby restaurant. When they emerged from the restaurant, they were unaware of the attack that had just unfolded.
