"We hailed an Uber and were heading back to our hotel when the driver suddenly stopped and a man came up to the window, yelling that there had been a shooting," Martin said. "It was a chaotic and panic-filled moment." Later that day, back at the hotel, Martin caught up on the news and was shocked to see the photo of the officer she had taken a picture with earlier. "We saw the news footage and thought, 'That looks like the same officer.' We zoomed in on the photo and realized it was indeed Keith Palmer, the officer who had smiled for our photo," Martin said. "I want to get this photo to his family and share with the world what a kind person he was, and how quickly life can change."

Among the recent fatalities were five Russian diplomats, including a prominent politician who had spoken out against the Russian government. While some deaths have been deemed natural and governments have ruled out foul play, questions still linger in other cases. The uncertainty has been filled by online speculation, with some claiming that the deaths are connected to Russia's interference in the 2016 US presidential election, despite the lack of concrete evidence. Here's a summary of the eight deaths and one near-fatality:

One of the most notable fatalities was Denis Voronenkov, a 45-year-old Russian politician who was shot dead outside a hotel in Kiev, Ukraine. Voronenkov and his wife had spoken out against Russian President Vladimir Putin after fleeing Russia for Ukraine in October. Voronenkov had also testified in a treason trial against a former Ukrainian president who was seen as a puppet of Putin. Ukraine's president described the shooting as a "Russian state terrorist act," while Russian authorities denied the accusation.

Two other high-profile Russian officials died under circumstances that have raised questions. Vitaly Churkin, the 64-year-old Russian ambassador to the United Nations, died on February 20 of an apparent heart attack while working in his office. Alexander Kadakin, the 67-year-old Russian ambassador to India, died on January 26 after a brief illness. The Russian embassy in New Delhi described his death as unremarkable, with no extraordinary circumstances surrounding it. Kadakin had served in India since 2009. Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi praised him as a "great friend of India" who made significant efforts to foster stronger ties between the two nations.

Andrey Malanin, a senior diplomat at the Russian embassy in Greece, was found dead in his Athens apartment in early January. The 54-year-old head of the Russian embassy's consular section in Athens had not reported to work for a few days, prompting worried colleagues to alert authorities. Police discovered his body on January 9th and initially suspected that he died suddenly from natural causes, with no signs of foul play.

Oleg Erovinkin, a former intelligence official with ties to Russian intelligence, was found dead in his car on December 26 in Moscow. The 61-year-old, who had previously served as a general in the FSB and as chief-of-staff to Igor Sechin, president of state-owned oil giant Rosneft, had no official cause of death announced by Russian government agencies.

Andrey Karlov, the 62-year-old Russian ambassador to Turkey, was fatally shot in the back on December 20 while speaking at an art exhibition in Ankara. The gunman, who struck at point-blank range, was identified as the assassin. A Turkish police officer assassinated the Russian ambassador to Turkey, Andrey Karlov, in an attack that occurred on December 19. Karlov was shot multiple times as he was opening an art exhibit in Ankara. The shooter, who was later killed by police, shouted "Do not forget Syria" during the attack.

On the same day, Petr Polshikov, a 56-year-old senior Russian diplomat, was found dead in his Moscow home. According to reports, his wife discovered his body with a pillow over his head, and police found a head wound underneath the pillow. The Russian Foreign Ministry initially stated that Polshikov's death was likely an accident and unrelated to his official duties.

On November 8, the day of the US presidential election, Sergei Krivov, a 63-year-old Russian diplomat who served as duty commander at the Russian consulate in New York City, was found dead at the consulate. The initial report stated that he was found with an unknown trauma to the head, but the autopsy later revealed that he died from bleeding in the chest area, likely due to a tumor. The police investigation did not suspect foul play, as Krivov had been in poor health.

In a separate incident, Nikolai Gorokhov, a 53-year-old Russian lawyer who represented the whistleblower Sergei Magnitsky, fell from the fourth floor of his Moscow apartment and suffered severe head injuries. He remains in the intensive care unit of a Moscow hospital. Gorokhov has been a vocal advocate for Magnitsky, who was jailed and beaten to death in a Moscow detention center after exposing Russia's largest tax fraud.

During an appearance on CNN's "The Situation Room with Wolf Blitzer", Nunes stated that he had to review the classified documents at an Executive Branch location because the intelligence community had not yet provided them to Congress. Nunes emphasized that the issue was that Congress had not been given access to this information, and that it was a matter for the Executive Branch. He explained that his sources, which he stressed were unrelated to Russia, were unable to provide the documents to his committee, so he had to obtain them himself. Nunes said that there was no other way for him to view the documents, as they couldn't be delivered to the House Intelligence Committee.

At the Economic Times Global Business Summit in New Delhi, India, former US Vice President Dick Cheney stated that Russian President Vladimir Putin and his government had made a concerted effort to significantly interfere with the United States' fundamental democratic processes. Cheney characterized this interference as a serious threat, noting that in some cases, it could be considered an act of war. While emphasizing that he was speaking only for himself, Cheney warned that Russia would likely continue to attempt to influence the US's internal political processes in the future. He also accused Putin of trying to sway the outcome of elections in Baltic countries, but did not suggest that Russia had compromised the legitimacy of President Donald Trump's electoral victory. Cheney acknowledged that the Russian government's efforts to interfere in US politics carried significant weight, given the importance Americans place on protecting their internal political processes. In contrast to his former boss, President George W. Bush, Cheney expressed support for Trump and was happy to do so. The US intelligence community has publicly attributed several hacks and information dumps, including those targeting the Democratic National Committee and John Podesta, to Russian activity. Russia has denied these allegations, which are central to ongoing investigations in the US House and Senate, as well as the Trump administration. Cheney also warned of Russia's military aggression and the potential destabilization posed by Putin, noting that the Russian president was actively seeking ways to undermine NATO. Reflecting on the post-Cold War period, Cheney nostalgically recalled the initial optimism, but lamented that times had changed for the worse in some respects. "In the early years of the Bush administration, the US enjoyed a relatively strong relationship with Russia, but it significantly deteriorated by the end of his presidency and Cheney's tenure, largely due to the Iraq War, NATO's expansion since the Soviet Union's collapse, and Russia's aggressive actions in Eastern Europe."

I made some minor changes to improve clarity and sentence structure, while maintaining the original meaning. Let me know if you have any further requests!

A representative for the group responded to CNN's KFile, denying any claims that Roger Stone had a backchannel with them. The representative, who remained anonymous, wrote in an email from a group-associated address: "No communications, no channel. Stone is manipulating Democrats and journalists to boost his public profile and promote his books. He's thrilled to be in the spotlight because he has no real expertise and was dismissed from the Trump team long ago for his opportunistic behavior." The representative added that Stone is happy to be scrutinized because he knows he's not knowledgeable about anything and was pushed out of the Trump team for his self-serving actions.

WikiLeaks has also denied any contact with Stone on Twitter, repeatedly stating that they have no connection with him.

Stone claimed throughout the final months of the campaign that he had backchannel communications with Assange and knew about forthcoming document dumps from WikiLeaks. At times, he said Assange had emails that Clinton aides Huma Abedin and Cheryl Mills deleted. Later, Stone clarified that he only knew of forthcoming document dumps in a general sense.

In response to WikiLeaks' charges, Stone told CNN's KFile: "Since I never communicated with WikiLeaks, I must be innocent of charges that I knew about the hacking of Podesta's email and the timing or scope of their subsequent disclosures. So, I'm either clairvoyant or a good guesser, because the limited things I predicted (October disclosures) all came true."

WikiLeaks also accused Stone of leaking his own direct messages, which showed interactions with the hacker Guccifer 2.0. A recent article on The Smoking Gun featured direct messages (DMs) that showed Stone telling the hacker he was "delighted" that Twitter had reinstated his account. The screenshot also reveals that Stone (or someone with access to his device) is the source feeding misinformation to the hackers, who then spread false information, mistakenly believing they are uncovering a major scandal and bringing down Stone and the President, when in reality, they are simply perpetuating Stone's propaganda efforts.

According to officials, the latest engine trial is the third such test in recent weeks, utilizing similar technology. An initial assessment suggests that the engine technology may potentially be used in an intercontinental ballistic missile, although it is unclear whether any adjustments would be required to make it compatible with an ICBM. If North Korea were to acquire an intercontinental ballistic missile, it could potentially threaten the continental United States. Developing ICBM technology is considered challenging, as it requires advanced rocket design. The US is also uncertain about North Korea's ability to miniaturize a nuclear warhead to mount on a rocket, such as an ICBM, although Pyongyang claims to have achieved this capability and US officials factor it into their planning assumptions.

In a separate development, the US announced on Monday that it has deployed F-35B fighter jets to South Korea for the first time as part of a training exercise that began on Friday. According to Pentagon spokesman Captain Jeff Davis, this marks the first time the F-35B has been operated in the Republic of Korea. The new stealth strike fighter, capable of short takeoff and vertical landing, was only declared operational in July 2015. The deployment is part of a training exercise with the South Korean military, which Davis described as "defensive in nature." "It goes without saying that we are committed to defending the Republic of Korea and Japan against any North Korean aggression," Davis added.

A powerful storm, classified as a Category 3 cyclone by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center, is expected to make landfall near the town of Ayr on Tuesday morning, according to the Australian Bureau of Meteorology. Cyclone Debbie is forecast to bring sustained winds of up to 150 mph (240 kph) and potentially catastrophic storm surges of up to four meters, as well as flash flooding. Queensland Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk has announced that 3,500 residents have already been evacuated, with an additional 2,000 people in the Bowen area ordered to leave as the cyclone's trajectory has shifted farther south than initially predicted.

Palaszczuk warned that the cyclone will be severe and urged residents to take immediate action, stating, "This is going to be a nasty cyclone. There is no time for complacency... the window of opportunity to leave is drastically closing." She pleaded with residents to heed the warnings and prioritize their safety and the safety of their loved ones.

Cyclone Debbie is expected to be one of the largest and most destructive storms to hit Queensland since Cyclone Yasi in 2011, which caused widespread devastation and loss of life. Palaszczuk warned that Debbie could potentially be as severe as Yasi, which ripped homes from their foundations and destroyed farmland.

According to John D Ginger, research director at the Cyclone Testing Station at James Cook University, coastal buildings are particularly at risk, particularly those in low-lying areas that are prone to storm surges. "Houses in these areas will be vulnerable to significant damage," he warned. Cyclone Debbie is expected to make landfall at a time when a 12-foot tide is forecasted in Bowen, one of the highest tides of the year, according to CNN affiliate 7 News. Queensland police are urging those in storm surge zones to evacuate immediately, stating that it is not possible to shelter from a storm surge. The severe weather has already claimed one life, a 31-year-old woman, who died in a fatal car crash on Sunday night near Proserpine, according to Queensland Police Commissioner Ian Stewart. In preparation for the storm, over 1,000 emergency service workers have been deployed to the affected region, and all schools remain closed until further notice, 7 News reports.

The White House has requested $999 million in its budget supplement for defense and border security spending, which would only cover 48 miles of new wall construction, according to documents obtained by CNN from the Department of Homeland Security. The documents outline the administration's plan to allocate the funds, which would include building 14 miles of new wall in San Diego, 28 miles of levee wall barriers, six miles of new wall in the Rio Grande Valley, and replacing 14 miles of fencing in San Diego with concrete elements. Despite President Donald Trump's campaign promise to build a wall along the entire US-Mexico border, the initial funding request has been modest, with the administration asking for $1 billion in 2017 and $2.6 billion in 2018 for border infrastructure and technology. Estimates for a full wall along the Southern border have ranged from $12 billion to over $20 billion. The budget request also reveals the administration's plan to increase border security measures elsewhere, including funding for detention facilities and legal support for building the wall. According to the documents, the Trump administration claims that its executive orders on immigration enforcement have already had an impact, with arrests up 50%, charges up 40%, and requests to detain deportable individuals up 80%. However, ICE was unable to provide information on what baseline was used to measure these increases. The distinction between a "wall" and a "fence" remains unclear. During his presidential campaign, Trump touted the idea of a tall, concrete wall along the border. However, career officials at the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) recommended a more secure option: see-through fencing, which would provide visibility on the other side. The government is currently seeking bids for two types of construction: one focused on concrete designs and another focused on alternative designs. W. Ralph Basham, a former Customs and Border Protection commissioner under the Bush administration, suggests that instead of building a concrete border wall, the government should invest in surveillance technology and strategic fencing construction, as recommended by DHS. "What does border patrol need to get the job done?" Basham asked. "A lot of people think a concrete wall is a good idea, but when you break it down, it may not be the most effective use of taxpayer dollars." Homeland Security Secretary John Kelly testified to Congress in February that some border patrol agents expressed concerns about a solid, concrete wall, preferring see-through fencing instead. Experts at a House Homeland Security Committee hearing also noted that a border fence could have advantages over a concrete wall, as agents could more easily see across the border. Kelly acknowledged that the wall would take time to construct, saying, "We're not going to be able to build a wall everywhere all at once." He did not provide a clear timeline or cost estimates, but suggested that the government could make progress on the wall within two years. "This is going to take some time, but there are areas where we can address this problem immediately," Kelly said.

Police believe that the suspects may have altered the escalator's components after the Saturday incident, which caused shoppers to fall. The malfunctioning escalator at Langham Place in Mong Kok sent 18 people to the hospital, with one man suffering a severe head injury and being listed in serious condition, according to CNN affiliate CCTV. The two mechanics, aged 22 and 52, are facing charges of obstruction of justice, police said. Both have been released on bail and are required to report back to police in mid-April. Ian Fok, a spokesperson for Otis Elevator Company, which employs the two mechanics, stated that the arrest was unexpected. "While the mechanics were assisting the EMSD, the agency called the police to have the mechanics arrested. Our legal team is working with law enforcement to clarify the situation and intends to defend our mechanics," Fok said. The company has committed to cooperating with the investigation and ensuring the safety of its customers.

The new executive order marks a stark contrast between the views of President Trump and his predecessor, Barack Obama, on the role of the United States in addressing climate change. The order drastically shifts the government's approach to rising sea levels and temperatures, two consequences of climate change. According to a White House official briefed on the plan, the administration believes the government can simultaneously serve the environment and increase energy independence by focusing on its core mission: ensuring clean air and water. The official emphasized that protecting American jobs takes precedence over regulating climate change. "Climate change is an issue that warrants attention," the official said, "but the President has been clear that he will not pursue policies that jeopardize the US economy. It's a simple matter." The order, set to be issued on Tuesday, will initiate a review of the Clean Power Plan, lift the moratorium on coal mining on federal lands, and instruct federal agencies to identify regulations that hinder American energy independence. Specifically, the order will rescind at least six executive orders issued by Obama aimed at curbing climate change and regulating carbon emissions, including an executive order from November 2013 instructing the federal government to prepare for the impacts of climate change and a presidential memorandum from September 2016 highlighting the threat climate change poses to national security. "The previous administration undervalued workers through their policies," the official said. "We're saying that we can protect the environment and provide people with work." A White House official recently argued that the most effective way to protect the environment is to have a robust economy, citing countries like India and China as examples of nations that prioritize economic growth over environmental protection. "When the economy is thriving and growing, that's the best way to safeguard the environment," the official stated. The executive order has also sparked widespread concern among climate change advocates, who had long feared that a Trump presidency would lead to this kind of rollback. "These actions are a betrayal of American values and pose a threat to the health, safety, and well-being of every American," said Tom Steyer, president of NextGen Climate, in a statement. "By gutting programs that create jobs and safeguards that protect our air and water, Trump is putting corporate polluters' profits ahead of the public's interests." Andrew Steer, CEO of the World Resources Institute, criticized the executive order, saying it demonstrates Trump's failure to lead on issues crucial to Americans' health, the environment, and the economy. While Democrats and climate advocates will undoubtedly criticize the order, it is consistent with Trump's past comments on climate change. Although Trump claimed to have an "open mind" on addressing climate change during his presidential campaign, he has also previously referred to it as a hoax. In 2012, Trump tweeted, "The concept of global warming was created by and for the Chinese in order to make U.S. manufacturing non-competitive." In 2016, he pledged to cancel all wasteful climate change spending from the Obama-Clinton administration. The Trump administration's changes do not signify a complete abandonment of environmental protection, but when asked about the human impact on climate change and the President's beliefs, officials were hesitant to confirm that all government officials in the White House acknowledge the role of human activity in climate change. Instead, they emphasized the enforcement of existing regulations that provide for clean air and water. According to the official, the President has made it clear that he wants the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to focus on its core mission, as defined by Congress. This shift in policy also reflects the views of EPA Administrator Scott Pruitt, who has a history of suing the EPA as Oklahoma's Attorney General. In a recent interview, Pruitt incorrectly stated that carbon dioxide is not the primary cause of climate change, contradicting the majority of scientific research. The executive order is also intended to fulfill the Trump administration's promise to revive the coal industry. Officials claimed that Obama's regulations were detrimental to the coal industry, and that the reversals are the President honoring his pledge to the coal industry. In a March 2017 event in Kentucky, Trump vowed to put coal miners back to work, stating that they had not been treated well but would be treated better now. He also declared, "The miners are coming back."

Jared Kushner, President Donald Trump's son-in-law and a close adviser, is likely to face intense scrutiny from congressional investigators probing ties between Trump associates and the Russian government following his meeting with the chairman of a state-run Russian bank. In December 2016, Kushner met with Sergey Gorkov, the chairman of VneshEconomBank (VEB), which has been under US sanctions for three years. The meeting raises further questions due to VEB's sanctions status and Kushner's own efforts to secure financing for a Manhattan building project. The White House claims Kushner was acting as a Trump adviser, not a private developer, during the meeting. White House press secretary Sean Spicer explained that Kushner was serving as a "conduit" to leaders, essentially a go-between until the State Department was fully functional. VEB confirmed the meeting in a statement to CNN, describing Kushner as the head of Kushner Companies, rather than a representative of Trump. According to VEB, the meeting was part of a series of discussions with top financial officials from around the world, including Kushner Companies' head, Jared Kushner. Experts agree that the meeting does not violate US sanctions, as the prohibitions only apply to doing business with sanctioned banks, not to having conversations with them. Paul Saunders, executive director of the Center for the National Interest, a Washington, D.C. think-tank, stated, "I don't see any problem with having a meeting. The prohibitions relate to doing business, not to talking." During his presidential campaign, Trump expressed willingness to reconsider the sanctions against Russia. The US sanctions had a significant impact on Russia's financial sector, as they prohibited American individuals and companies from purchasing debt from Russian financial institutions, thereby limiting their ability to access capital. According to Alevtina Guseva, a Russian finance expert at Boston University, there was a widespread expectation in Russia that the sanctions would be lifted shortly after the election. VEB, a state-owned Russian corporation established in 2007, is closely tied to the Russian government and has a chairman appointed by the president. The Russian prime minister serves as the chairman of the bank's supervisory board. VEB has played a crucial role in rescuing financially struggling oligarchs and financing high-risk infrastructure projects, such as the 2014 Sochi Winter Olympics. Last year, the bank restructured approximately $3.5 billion in debts associated with Sochi projects. It was revealed on Monday that Kushner agreed to testify before the Senate intelligence committee as part of its investigation into whether the Trump campaign colluded with the Russian government to influence the 2016 presidential election. Lawmakers also want to question Kushner about his December meeting with Sergey Kislyak, the Russian ambassador to the US. In 2014, President Barack Obama imposed sanctions on Russian financial institutions in response to Russia's annexation of part of Ukraine.

A recently discovered track, measuring an astonishing 1.15 meters long (nearly 3 feet 9 inches), has set a new record for the largest footprint found from a carnivorous dinosaur. The remarkable find was unearthed in Bolivia last July and belongs to a sauropod, a long-necked herbivore. According to Dr. Steve Salisbury, lead author of the study and professor at the University of Queensland, the giant footprints are truly spectacular. "There's nothing that comes close to this length," he exclaimed. This incredible discovery is just one of many amazing finds in the area, which Dr. Salisbury has dubbed "Australia's Jurassic Park." In an unprecedented find, his team discovered 21 different dinosaur tracks across the Dampier Peninsula, with some rocks dating back as far as 140 million years. The ideal conditions on the Dampier Peninsula allowed for both the creation and preservation of these tracks, making the find so spectacular. After five years of work in the area, Dr. Salisbury's team can proudly say that they have uncovered the most diverse dinosaur track fauna ever recorded. "If we traveled back in time 130 million years ago, we would have seen all these different dinosaurs roaming this coastline," he said. "It must have been a breathtaking sight." Additionally, the team made a groundbreaking discovery, uncovering the first confirmed evidence of stegosaurs in Australia.

A massive coin, weighing over 200 pounds and measuring more than 20 inches in diameter, was stolen from the Bode Museum in Berlin at 2 a.m. local time. According to German media reports, the coin is currently valued at 3.7 million euros, equivalent to approximately $4 million. Known as the "Big Maple Leaf," the coin was minted by the Royal Canadian Mint in 2007 to commemorate Queen Elizabeth II's state visit to Germany. With a face value of over $1 million and a gold purity of 999.99/1000, the coin has been part of the Bode Museum's collection since 2010. Following the theft, Berlin police discovered a ladder near railway tracks close to the museum and are investigating whether it was used in the burglary. The coin features a portrait of Queen Elizabeth II on one side and a maple leaf on the other.

In the formal letter informing the European Union of Britain's intention to leave, Theresa May warned that failing to reach a deal on their future relationship would have significant consequences for security. According to the letter, a failure to agree on a future relationship would weaken cooperation in the fight against crime and terrorism. May mentioned security 11 times in the six-page letter. Tim Farron, leader of the Liberal Democrats, who oppose Brexit, criticized May's link between trade and security, calling it a "shameful" and "blatant threat." "Security should not be used as a bargaining chip," he said, predicting that it would backfire in negotiations and leave Britain even more isolated. Labour MP Yvette Cooper echoed the concerns, tweeting, "Completely irresponsible to threaten, gamble or bargain on national security." In the House of Commons, Labour MP Stephen Kinnock read from the letter and asked, "Is she really suggesting that the security of our country would be traded like a bargaining chip in these negotiations?" May responded that negotiating a future deal on security was crucial. "We have a relationship with the European Union in justice and home affairs, and we need to negotiate what the future relationship will be," she said. "It's a simple and pragmatic approach aimed at ensuring cooperation on these matters." Britain is a member of Europol, the EU's law enforcement agency, which coordinates the sharing of intelligence on terrorism and organized crime between member states. According to the Institute for Government, the union's strongest defense power is arguably the UK's. The institute notes that the UK is one of only two member states with "full-spectrum" military capabilities, including a nuclear deterrent, and one of only five countries that allocate 2% of their GDP to defense. Additionally, the UK holds a permanent seat on the UN Security Council and has the largest military budget within the EU.

A Downing Street spokesperson declined to elaborate on the letter, stating that the Prime Minister's words speak for themselves. They emphasized that if the UK leaves the EU without a deal, the arrangements currently in place as part of its EU membership will cease to exist.

The official start of the Brexit process occurred nine months after the UK's contentious referendum, which revealed deep divisions across the country. In her letter, Prime Minister May expressed the UK's desire to pursue a "bold and ambitious" free-trade agreement with the EU in forthcoming talks.

If the UK fails to secure a trade deal with the EU and defaults to trading under World Trade Organization rules, it is estimated that the country will lose 7.5% of its GDP over 15 years, according to the UK's own official estimates. May has made it clear that the UK will not remain in the EU's single market or customs union, which would have required keeping its borders open to all EU citizens.

In her letter, May sought to strike a conciliatory tone with the EU, reiterating her hopes for the UK and the union to remain the closest of allies and to establish a "deep and special partnership." In addition to her previous statements, she emphasized her desire to avoid a no-deal scenario and proposed several guiding principles for negotiations. The key points from her letter are as follows:

The UK will not seek membership in the single market, a free-trade zone, but instead aims to negotiate a "bold and ambitious" free-trade agreement. The UK hopes to avoid a cliff-edge separation and ensure business certainty. It warns that European security will be at risk if a deal is not reached. The UK expects to grant greater powers to the devolved regions of Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland. The government plans to repeal EU laws and automatically adopt them into UK law for review, with a White Paper outlining the process to be published on Thursday.

Tusk expressed a somber tone after receiving the Article 50 letter. "Today is not a happy day, neither in Brussels nor in London," he said. "Most Europeans, including nearly half of British voters, wished we would stay together, not drift apart. As for me, I won't pretend to be happy today." However, he noted that Brexit has strengthened the determination and unity of the 27 remaining EU nations. "What can I add to this? We already miss you," he said.

The tumultuous marriage between Britain and the European Union has finally come to an end, with the triggering of Article 50 marking the beginning of a two-year formal process. The divorce is expected to cost Britain tens of billions of pounds, but there is no turning back. The relationship between the two had been strained for years, with Britain repeatedly seeking concessions from the EU but ultimately feeling starved of compromise. The final blow came on June 24, when 51.9% of British voters chose to leave the EU. The marriage, which had been on again, off again since the early days of the Common Market, had once seemed promising. Britain had initially been wooed by the EU, with French President Charles de Gaulle being a major obstacle to the union. However, his death paved the way for Britain to join the EU in 1973. The early years of the marriage were marked by prosperity and a growing sense of equality between Britain and the founding members of the EU. However, over time, the relationship began to sour. The Common Fisheries Policy, which allocated dwindling sea stocks to the EU's benefit, became a major point of contention. Britain's fishermen, farmers, and car manufacturers were among those who felt they were being unfairly treated, leading to growing resentment and a sense of disillusionment. The marriage, which had once seemed so promising, had ultimately become a source of frustration and division. The British naval fleet suffered significant damage, ports were left idle, and European vessels approached British shores closer than ever before. What began as a minor national issue quickly escalated into a festering wound, particularly in fishing communities where the problems in the relationship could simmer and find expression. For farmers in 1984, the Common Agriculture Policy was a source of frustration, as they felt that European subsidies and pricing were undermining their livelihoods and transforming the British countryside. Meanwhile, the industrial landscape was rocked by factory closures, including the once-mighty British Leyland, which fell victim to European competition. It's difficult to pinpoint exactly when the relationship began to deteriorate, but gradually, dissatisfaction and disillusionment grew. For some, the relationship became increasingly uncomfortable as the European Community evolved into the EU. In 1990, after years of political resistance, Britain finally joined the European Exchange Rate Mechanism, which aimed to stabilize currency fluctuations and facilitate trade between member states. However, two years later, Britain was forced to withdraw from the mechanism due to its inability to prevent a pound crisis. The introduction of the single market and open borders in 1993 proved to be a catalyst for a long-dormant issue, as it enabled the free flow of goods, services, money, and people across the EU. While the union's goal was to promote economic integration, it also created an opportunity for economic migrants to leave behind their challenging circumstances and seek a better life in Europe. Regardless of its validity, many in Britain felt that their country was the one bearing the brunt of the relationship. What was once a harmonious partnership had devolved into a strained and unbalanced arrangement, with wounds, sores, disease, and inequality taking their toll. Following his unexpected victory in the 2015 general election, David Cameron was forced to keep a campaign promise and issued an ultimatum to Brussels, hoping to salvage the relationship. However, his decision ultimately led to the demise of the partnership, leaving the EU to limp along without Britain. The EU, determined to hold on to its remaining members, is now struggling to maintain a sense of unity and cohesion.

David Cameron, the former British Prime Minister who lost the Brexit referendum, may be perplexed by the unexpected outcome of his defeat. His request for a "variable geometry" arrangement, which would have allowed the UK to opt out of certain EU principles, was rejected by Germany and France. However, as a direct result of Brexit, Germany and France are now embracing the concept of variable geometry as a potential solution for the EU. This paradox is more understandable when viewed through the lens of the traditional European practice of finding a silver lining in failure. German Chancellor Angela Merkel, who had long opposed the idea of a multi-speed Europe, where some countries are less integrated than others due to their domestic political situations, has now seemingly changed her stance. With the EU's legitimacy weakened by the euro crisis and Euroskeptics gaining momentum, Merkel and other EU leaders believe a multi-speed Europe is crucial to keeping the bloc together. Over the weekend, as EU leaders gathered to mark the 60th anniversary of the Treaty of Rome, the remaining 27 member states signed the Rome Declaration, which states that they will "act together, at different paces and intensity where necessary, while moving in the same direction, as we have done in the past." The EU's failure to maintain a unified path towards shared values, a single market, and a common currency will be rebranded as a new beginning, leading to a Europe where a coalition of willing members pursues the original goals, while others form outer circles connected to the core through unclear bonds. This multifaceted EU would enable Eastern countries to maintain their illiberal democracies, refusing to accept refugees or adhere to standards of press freedom and judicial independence considered essential by other European nations. Countries like Austria could erect electrified borders, and the door could remain open for the UK to rejoin as part of an outer circle. Whether one agrees with this vision or not, its prospects depend on a crucial prerequisite: a consolidated and stable eurozone. Recognizing this reality reveals the second paradox of our post-Brexit world: the current eurozone is unable to provide the stability the EU and Europe need to thrive. The European establishment's failure to address Greece's bankruptcy is a telling indicator of their capacity to stabilize the eurozone. Unfortunately, the prospects for a stabilized eurozone are bleak. The status quo – the establishment's preferred option – could soon lead to a major Italian crisis that the eurozone cannot withstand. The only alternative being discussed is a watered-down eurozone federation, featuring a tiny common budget that Berlin would agree to in exchange for direct control over French, Italian, and Spanish national budgets. Even if this scenario were to unfold, which is unlikely given the current political climate, it would likely come too late to salvage the eurozone. The harsh reality facing Europe today is that a unified federal government of 27 member states is no longer feasible, given the intense centrifugal forces tearing the continent apart. Meanwhile, a confederacy with a variable geometry, as proposed by David Cameron and potentially desired by the UK after 2019, would require a consolidated eurozone. However, this too seems an impossible feat in the current climate. The EU's approach of allowing member states to move at different speeds and pursue different policies is misguided, as it fails to address the diverse concerns of Europeans living in different countries and instead perpetuates divisions. In reality, Europeans are already united by two existential threats: involuntary under-employment, a consequence of austerity-driven underinvestment, and involuntary migration, a result of the concentration of investment in specific regions. To revive the European Union, each and every country must be stabilized and empowered to thrive. Europe cannot survive as a free-for-all or as an austerity-driven union built on depoliticized economic decision-making, where some countries are condemned to perpetual depression and debtors are denied democratic rights. Instead, Europe needs a New Deal, similar to the one proposed by my organization DiEM25 in Rome, which would span the continent, encompassing all countries regardless of their EU or eurozone membership.

As the UK prepares to leave the EU, the impact will not only be felt by British citizens, but also by the 3.2 million EU nationals living in Britain, as well as the 27 other EU member states. In Germany, newspapers are already reacting to the news, with Die Welt featuring a front-page image of Prime Minister Theresa May waving from a paper boat made of the Union flag as the sun sets over the sea, with the headline "Farewell" and the caption "Today, the British Prime Minister officially announces the divorce of the EU. For the United Kingdom, it is a journey into the unknown." The Berliner Zeitung's front page shows a tattered UK flag against the EU flag, accompanied by a "Letter to London" that begins, "Dear Theresa May!" and continues, "Great Britain is announcing its departure today. However, not all is lost yet." The Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung describes the divorce as "painful," stating, "No one knows what this means or what will happen in the coming two years. However, one thing is certain: it won't be easy. As is often the case with divorces, it's all about the money. Some Brits are worried that Brussels might demand, 'I want my money back,' as Margaret Thatcher once said." Les Echos, a center-right business-focused newspaper, has the headline "Brexit: Day One" and highlights "four traps" that those negotiating the terms of Brexit will face in the coming months. Le Figaro's front page features a picture of Theresa May leaving 10 Downing Street, captioned "March 29, 2017: The day the United Kingdom bid farewell to Europe." The front page of the French newspaper Libération features a striking image: a black bearskin cap, traditionally worn by the soldiers who guard Buckingham Palace, bears the headline "Brexit: We miss you already" in bold letters. The headline is followed by a subtle addition: "Or not...". The newspaper has envisioned two possible scenarios for Britain's future, one negative and one positive. Meanwhile, the Belgian newspaper L'Echo proclaims, "Britain cuts itself off from the Union to dive into the unknown", accompanied by a graphic depicting the iconic Elizabeth Tower, home to the famous Big Ben bell, being disconnected from a socket emblazoned with the EU's yellow stars on a blue background. In Belgium, La Libre's front page reads, "Brexit: The cost of the divorce", promising 12 pages of special coverage. Le Soir's headline is more dramatic: "Theresa May signs the end of the Europe of 28", featuring an image of the British Prime Minister signing the letter to be delivered to Brussels triggering Brexit. In Italy, La Stampa's front page declares, "Brexit, the day of the divorce". La Repubblica and Il Messagero, also from Italy, highlight the possibility that Brexit could lead to Scotland's exit from the United Kingdom. Finally, the question lingers: "Brexit: How did we get here?"

Chairman Richard Burr, a North Carolina Republican, stated at a press conference alongside committee vice-chairman Mark Warner that this investigation is one of the largest the Hill has seen during his time in the Senate. Burr has been serving in the Senate since 2005 and in the House since 1995. The committee leaders plan to interview 20 witnesses and have already scheduled five interviews. Burr and Warner expressed satisfaction that President Donald Trump's son-in-law, Jared Kushner, and former campaign chairman Paul Manafort have agreed to testify, although they have not yet determined the dates for their appearances. "To date, we have made 20 requests for individuals to be interviewed by the committee," Burr said. "As of today, five have already been scheduled, and we anticipate that the remaining 15 will have a scheduled date within the next 10 days. We may also invite additional individuals to be interviewed, and some of those interviewed may eventually become private or public hearings, but that has not been decided." The committee has reportedly spoken with former National Security Adviser Michael Flynn, who resigned after misleading administration officials about his communications with the Russian ambassador to the United States. "It's safe to say we've had conversations with many people, and it's safe to say General Flynn is one of them," Burr said. The Senate Intelligence Committee's investigation has gained momentum as the House investigation has stalled due to partisan disagreements surrounding its chairman, Rep. Devin Nunes, and his communication with the White House regarding the incidental collection of President Donald Trump and his aides. "A chorus of Democratic voices is urging Representative Devin Nunes to relinquish his position, whereas a majority of Republicans in the chamber are standing behind him. The committee is scheduled to convene its inaugural public hearing on Thursday."

Russian President Vladimir Putin was asked directly on Thursday whether Russia had interfered in the US election. In response, he said, "I'm telling you, no." This is the most forceful denial he has made of the allegations to date, and the first time he has directly addressed the issue since Donald Trump took office in January. Despite Putin's denial, Russian officials and spokespeople have repeatedly dismissed the claims as a political "witch hunt". The denial comes as US intelligence committees from both the House and Senate investigate alleged Russian interference in the election, including possible ties between Russian officials and members of Trump's campaign team. The FBI is also conducting its own investigation. Putin also downplayed a meeting between Jared Kushner, Trump's son-in-law and close adviser, and Sergey Gorkov, the chairman of the Russian state development bank VneshEconomBank, which has been under US sanctions since 2014. Kushner is expected to give voluntary testimony to the Senate Intelligence Committee. Putin dismissed the meeting, saying, "American bankers come to Russia and talk to us, don't they? It's only natural that they would hold meetings." He went on to say, "I think it's not in the interest of the American people to take Russian-American relations to the point of absurdity, just to benefit the inner political agenda." Putin asked, "What do we want? To break off diplomatic relations? Force the situation to the point of crisis? And what's next?" He warned that reckless behavior could lead to a repetition of the 1962 Cuban missile crisis. Putin expressed hope that the situation would normalize "and the sooner the better". The Russian leader also expressed his willingness to meet with Trump on the sidelines of an Arctic summit in Finland in September, stating that his country would be pleased to participate and he would be happy to take part in the event. Despite Trump claiming they have never met, both leaders have repeatedly expressed their openness to a meeting. The US government publicly accused Russia of orchestrating the hacking of the Democratic National Committee (DNC) and other political organizations affiliated with the Democratic Party in the run-up to the election, a claim they reiterated in October. In January, just before Trump took office, the US intelligence community concluded that Putin had authorized an "influence campaign" aimed at undermining Trump's rival, Hillary Clinton, the Democratic Party's presidential candidate. The hacked DNC emails, which were publicly released, contained damaging revelations about the Democratic Party and Clinton's campaign. Trump has changed his stance on the issue, initially dismissing the possibility of Russian involvement but later conceding that "I think it was Russia." Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov responded to the allegations in January, saying they were not supported by evidence and were presented in a "very amateurish and emotional" manner. Peskov characterized the situation as a "full-scale witch hunt." Before leaving office, former President Barack Obama ordered a comprehensive review of hacking aimed at influencing US elections dating back to 2008.

The trailer for "An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth to Power" was unveiled on Tuesday, starting with a clip of Trump on the campaign trail. "It's supposed to be 70 degrees today, but it's freezing here," he quips. "We need some global warming, don't we?" The joke may have resonated with rally attendees, but for Gore, the film's narrator and star, it's a serious issue. The trailer continues to show devastating images of wildfires and floods, accompanied by audio clips of Trump promising to slash climate change funding, effectively positioning him as the film's antagonist. Coincidentally, Trump signed an executive order the same day the trailer was released, limiting the federal government's enforcement of climate regulations, giving the film's tagline - "Fight like your world depends on it" - a chilling new relevance. While it's premature to predict the box office performance of the sequel, its predecessor, "An Inconvenient Truth," earned over $24 million domestically and even won two Academy Awards.

Katie Walsh, the White House's deputy chief of staff, is leaving to join a nonprofit organization that supports the President's agenda, according to the President's top aides, who made the announcement on Thursday. This marks the second high-level departure from the White House in the first few months of the administration, following the forced resignation of national security adviser Michael Flynn last month. The move also signals a significant shift in the leadership dynamics within the West Wing, as Walsh was a close ally of White House Chief of Staff Reince Priebus. Prior to joining the administration, Walsh served as Priebus' chief of staff when he was chairman of the Republican National Committee. She is set to become a senior adviser to America First Policies, a nonprofit group founded by former Trump campaign officials that has struggled to gain traction in the first months of Trump's presidency. A senior White House official emphasized that Walsh was not being forced out, and a source close to the White House described her departure as a "tremendous loss." The source noted that frustration has been building inside the White House over the administration's failure to unite Republicans behind a health care bill supported by Trump and House Speaker Paul Ryan. According to the source, Walsh recognized the need to better organize external support for the White House's initiatives. "It was a collective conversation that we could have moved the health care message more effectively," a White House official said. Two senior White House officials dismissed the idea that Walsh's departure might signal Priebus' own departure, with one official stating, "Reince is not next." During Thursday's daily briefing, White House press secretary Sean Spicer was asked if there would be further staff changes following Katie Walsh's departure. Spicer responded firmly, "No." Top White House officials, including Reince Priebus, Steve Bannon, and Jared Kushner, praised Walsh during a briefing in Priebus' West Wing office, where they met with a small group of reporters. Bannon described Walsh as "the vital link that makes things happen," while Kushner referred to her as "one of the unsung heroes of the campaign" and commended her "sacrifice." Priebus explained that the decision for Walsh to leave the White House for the outside political group, America First Policies, was made after it became clear that they lacked sufficient support during the health care debate. "Nobody can fix this problem better than Katie Walsh," Priebus said. The three top presidential advisers revealed that they jointly agreed on Walsh's departure, but stated that the idea originated with Walsh herself. America First Policies, initially envisioned as the primary outside group to support Trump's political goals, has struggled in its early months, failing to air television advertisements in support of Trump's Supreme Court nomination and only beginning to spend on the final day of the health care debate. Just this week, the Mercer family, expected to be the group's primary funders, defected to a rival nonprofit, Making America Great, taking with them Dave Bossie, a Mercer operative who had served as deputy campaign manager.

A US District Court judge, Derrick Watson, blocked the core provisions of a revised executive order two weeks ago, ruling that it likely violates the Establishment Clause of the Constitution by unfairly targeting Muslims. However, Watson's initial decision was only a temporary restraining order, and the plaintiffs subsequently asked him to convert it into a longer-term preliminary injunction. Watson agreed, effectively blocking the President's 90-day ban on foreign nationals from six Muslim-majority countries and the 120-day ban on all refugees entering the country indefinitely, unless a higher court intervenes or the lawsuit is resolved. The Justice Department has announced that it will continue to defend the executive order, stating that it is within the President's lawful authority to protect national security. However, the department may now choose to immediately appeal the ruling to the 9th Circuit Court of Appeals. The implications of the decision are unclear, as the timeline for any appeals is uncertain. In his decision, Watson relied on Supreme Court precedent to conclude that the executive order is unconstitutional due to Donald Trump's campaign statements about Muslims. Watson wrote that the court cannot ignore the evidence and must take a stand against the order's discriminatory nature. A federal court has blocked Trump's new travel ban, ruling that the plaintiffs have a strong likelihood of success in their claim that the ban violates the Establishment Clause. The court's decision is significant, as it comes after Trump's own comments about his "Muslim ban" were cited as evidence in the case. Separately, the Department of Justice has appealed a different court's decision to halt the 90-day travel ban to the 4th Circuit Court of Appeals.

President Donald Trump's eldest daughter, Ivanka Trump, will serve as an "adviser" to the President and will file her own Form 278, subjecting her to ethics rules. Critics argue that Trump's hiring of his daughter violates federal nepotism laws. On CNN's "New Day" program, Alisyn Camerota questioned Jason Miller, a Trump surrogate, about the appointment, asking, "How is this not nepotism?" Miller responded, "It's not nepotism because she's not being paid." Camerota countered, "She's the President's daughter, that's nepotism." Miller argued, "She's volunteering her time and effort for the good of the country, and everyone from the White House counsel to the Department of Justice has said this doesn't violate any nepotism rules." Norman Eisen, former White House ethics czar, noted that both the Obama and Bush administrations interpreted the 1967 federal nepotism law to include the White House. The law prohibits public officials, including the President, from hiring or promoting relatives. However, it does provide an exemption for appointees who violate the law, stating that they are "not entitled to pay" from the federal government. This loophole allows Trump and Jared Kushner, Ivanka's husband, to forgo paychecks while still serving the administration. Kushner, a top Trump aide, is also serving as an unpaid government employee. According to a CNN source, the decision to make Ivanka Trump an official employee was made after concerns were raised about the nature of her voluntary role. "I've taken note of the concerns some have raised about my advising the President in my personal capacity, and I will instead serve as an unpaid staff member in the White House Office, subject to the same ethical standards as all other federal employees. Throughout this process, I've been working collaboratively and in good faith with the White House counsel and my personal legal team to navigate the unique circumstances of my role."

The 51-50 vote ends Trump's toughest confirmation battle yet. Senate Democrats debated through the night and into Tuesday morning in a last-ditch attempt to derail DeVos, buoyed by support from Republican Sens. Lisa Murkowski of Alaska and Susan Collins of Maine. Throughout the fight, Democrats argued they needed "Just one more!" to lure away another Republican vote. But ultimately, the efforts fell short as DeVos was confirmed as the new Secretary of Education, despite strong opposition from Democrats and some Republicans. The confirmation marks a significant milestone for Trump's administration, with DeVos becoming the first cabinet member to be confirmed in a 51-50 vote.

The intense debate surrounding DeVos' nomination has been fueled by concerns over her lack of experience in public education and her support for charter schools and school vouchers. Democrats have also criticized her views on special education and her role as a philanthropist, which they argue has given her an unfair advantage in the education sector.

Throughout the confirmation process, DeVos has faced fierce opposition from teachers' unions, education advocacy groups, and even some Republicans who have expressed concerns over her qualifications and ideology. In the end, however, it was not enough to sway the vote, and DeVos will now take up her new role as Secretary of Education.

The confirmation battle has been seen as a test of Trump's ability to navigate the Senate and push through his agenda, and has raised concerns over the future of public education in the United States. The outcome is likely to have significant implications for the education sector, with DeVos' confirmation paving the way for a major overhaul of the nation's education system.

In a statement, Trump congratulated DeVos on her confirmation, saying "I am thrilled to announce that Betsy DeVos has been confirmed as the new Secretary of Education. She will be a fantastic Secretary and will do a tremendous job of promoting and protecting our nation's schools."

DeVos is set to take up her new role immediately, and is expected to face a range of challenges as she works to implement Trump's education agenda. The confirmation battle has been a long and contentious one, but in the end, it was not enough to derail DeVos' nomination.

The limited scope of DeVos' education policy experience has raised questions for many about whether she is suited to run the federal agency charged with making American public education first-rate for all children. But there is another subterranean element to this debate, which now should be surfaced, especially given our racially charged environment and the role that segregated schools have long played in our politics. Racial animus was a primary catalyst of the move toward private and religious K-12 education almost 50 years ago, and racial segregation remains a dominant factor in all schooling, public and private, today. DeVos' track record suggests that as secretary, she will do little to combat these trends. In the wake of the 1954 Brown v. Board Supreme Court decision, which famously declared that separate schools for black and white children were not equal, the federal government began -- albeit slowly -- to desegregate. This applied to schools in the South that were previously forbidden by law from educating children of different races together and to schools in the North plagued by de facto segregation. The backlash, now infamous but perhaps too familiar even today, was fierce. From Alabama Governor George Wallace's stance in the schoolhouse door and his proclamations of "segregation now, segregation forever" to Louise Day Hicks leading the Boston antibusing movement, the reaction to desegregation roiled American politics. But the Brown ruling did not apply to private schools. and therefore, private schools were able to maintain their segregated status. This created a two-tiered education system, where public schools were forced to integrate, while private schools remained segregated. This dichotomy has had lasting consequences, perpetuating racial and socioeconomic segregation in education.

Betsy DeVos' support for voucher programs and charter schools, which often draw students away from public schools, raises concerns that she may inadvertently exacerbate this problem. Her emphasis on school choice, while touted as a means to increase competition and improve education, may ultimately lead to further segregation and a widening of the achievement gap.

Moreover, DeVos' limited experience with education policy, combined with her lack of understanding of the historical and ongoing impacts of segregation, may lead to a lack of effective solutions to address these issues. Her confirmation hearings have already highlighted her unfamiliarity with the nuances of desegregation and integration, as well as her dismissive attitude towards the concept of systemic racism.

The implications of DeVos' policies on racial segregation in education are far-reaching. If implemented, they may lead to a further erosion of public schools, disproportionately affecting low-income and minority communities. This would not only perpetuate existing inequalities but also undermine the very fabric of our democratic society.

In light of these concerns, it is essential that we, as a society, demand more from our education leaders. We need individuals who understand the complex interplay between education, segregation, and systemic racism. We need leaders who are committed to promoting equity and access, rather than perpetuating the status quo.

The confirmation of Betsy DeVos as Secretary of Education is a critical moment in our nation's history. It is a moment that requires us to reflect on our values and priorities. Do we value equality and justice, or do we prioritize the interests of the privileged few? The answer to this question will have far-reaching consequences for the future of American education and the future of our democracy.

Khamenei told a gathering of Iran's air force commanders in Tehran that the new US administration has shown the world "the depth of corruption in US government," according to quotes published by Iran's semi-official MEHR news agency. Khamenei reportedly told the commanders: "We however thank this new guy in the White House, since he largely did the job we had been trying to do in the past decades: to divulge the true face of the US. We had been working to show the world the depth of corruption in US government and ranks and files of the ruling elite; Trump did it in few days after coming to the White House." He added: "Their claims to human rights are no longer tenable." Khamenei also made an apparent reference to the five-year-old son of an Iranian mother who was detained at a US airport following Trump's ban on visas for seven Muslim-majority countries, including Iran. According to the MEHR news agency, Khamenei said that the detention of the five-year-old boy, whose mother had been planning to visit her family in the United States, was a stark example of the "brutality" of the US government. He called it a "child's blood" and a "crimes against humanity" and said that it was a "clear manifestation of the American government's hypocrisy and racism".

Khamenei's comments come at a time of heightened tensions between Iran and the United States, following Trump's decision to withdraw from the Iran nuclear deal and re-impose sanctions on the country. The Iranian supreme leader has been a vocal critic of Trump's policies, and his comments are likely to be seen as a further escalation of the rhetoric between the two nations.

The Iranian air force commanders who were present at the gathering were reportedly left stunned by Khamenei's remarks, with one commander telling the MEHR news agency that it was "unprecedented" for the supreme leader to speak so bluntly about the US government.

The Iranian government has been working to present itself as a champion of human rights and a defender of Muslim communities around the world, and Khamenei's comments are likely to be seen as a challenge to that narrative. The US government has accused Iran of violating human rights and supporting terrorism, and Khamenei's remarks are likely to be seen as a further escalation of the rhetoric between the two nations.

The comments also come as the US is preparing to impose new sanctions on Iran, which could have significant economic implications for the country. The Iranian government has warned that it will respond to the sanctions with "firm and decisive" action, and Khamenei's comments are likely to be seen as a warning to the US that Iran will not be intimidated by the sanctions.

Overall, Khamenei's comments are likely to be seen as a significant escalation of the rhetoric between Iran and the US, and could have significant implications for the future of relations between the two nations.

In an 11-minute recording, AQAP leader Qassim al-Rimi condemned the January 29 raid, saying, "The new fool of the White House received a painful slap across his face." The message was released online Saturday and translated by the SITE Intelligence Group. In the recording, Rimi also claimed "dozens of Americans were killed and wounded," a number starkly at odds with the US account, which reported the death of one Navy SEAL, Chief Petty Officer William "Ryan" Owens. Three additional SEALs also were wounded. Rimi acknowledged the deaths of 14 men and 11 women and children in the raid, a joint counterterrorism effort between the United States and United Arab Emirates. A senior US military official told CNN on Monday that Rimi was a target of the operation. The recording was released after last week's raid. The message, which was laced with vitriol and anti-American rhetoric, was a stark reminder of the escalating tensions between the US and AQAP. Rimi, who has been the leader of AQAP's Yemen branch since 2015, accused the US of launching the raid in an attempt to assassinate him, and vowed to exact revenge.

The US military has been carrying out a campaign of drone strikes and special operations raids against AQAP in Yemen for several years, but the January 29 raid was particularly intense and resulted in significant casualties on both sides.

The raid, which was authorized by President Donald Trump, was intended to gather intelligence on AQAP's plans and disrupt its ability to launch attacks against the US and its allies. However, it quickly went awry when the SEALs encountered heavy resistance from AQAP fighters, and the mission descended into chaos.

In the recording, Rimi also accused the US of "spilling the blood of Muslims" and said that the raid would only serve to increase AQAP's resolve to fight against the US and its allies. He called on Muslims around the world to rise up against the US and its allies, and vowed to continue to wage jihad against them.

The release of the recording is likely to further inflame tensions between the US and AQAP, and may also have implications for the ongoing conflict in Yemen. The war in Yemen, which has been raging for several years, has created a humanitarian crisis and has drawn in a number of foreign powers, including the US, Saudi Arabia, and Iran.

In the meantime, the US military is reviewing the circumstances surrounding the raid and the subsequent release of the recording. The Pentagon has not commented publicly on the contents of the recording, but a senior military official told CNN that the US is "evaluating the situation and considering its next steps."

The release of the recording is also likely to raise questions about the effectiveness of the US military's counterterrorism strategy in Yemen. The raid was intended to disrupt AQAP's ability to launch attacks against the US, but the group has already claimed responsibility for a number of attacks in recent months, including a bombing at a military parade in Yemen's capital city.

In the face of these challenges, the US military is likely to continue to rely on a combination of drone strikes and special operations raids to target AQAP's leadership and disrupt its ability to launch attacks. However, the release of the recording serves as a reminder of the complexities and challenges of the conflict in Yemen, and the need for a more nuanced and effective approach to counterterrorism.

On Monday, the White House issued a list of 78 terror attacks to underscore President Donald Trump's assertion that the media is failing to adequately report them. Trump told enlisted service-members at MacDill Air Force Base in Florida that attacks were happening "all over Europe" and that "it's gotten to a point where it's not even being reported." "And in many cases, the very, very dishonest press doesn't want to report it. They have their reasons, and you understand that," Trump added. Later, the White House distributed a list of the attacks Trump was citing, saying "most did not receive adequate attention." The list of 78 terror attacks, released by the White House, spanned several years and included incidents in Europe, Asia, Africa, and the Middle East. Many of the attacks were not well-known outside of their local communities, and some had received minimal media coverage.

The list included attacks such as the 2015 Charlie Hebdo shooting in Paris, which killed 12 people, and the 2016 Nice truck attack, which killed 86 people. It also included lesser-known attacks, such as a 2017 stabbing in a Munich shopping center that injured several people, and a 2018 suicide bombing in a Kabul restaurant that killed 14 people.

The White House claimed that many of the attacks had been underreported or ignored by the media, and that the list was intended to provide a more comprehensive picture of the threat posed by terrorism. However, many media outlets and terrorism experts questioned the accuracy and usefulness of the list, pointing out that it included a number of attacks that had been widely reported and others that were not necessarily related to terrorism.

The list also included a number of attacks that had been carried out by individuals or groups that were not considered to be terrorist organizations, such as a 2017 shooting in a Texas church that killed 26 people. This has led some to criticize the White House for using the list to further its own political agenda, rather than providing a genuine effort to inform the public about the threat of terrorism.

The controversy surrounding the list has also highlighted the ongoing debate about the role of the media in reporting on terrorism. Some argue that the media has a responsibility to report on all terrorist attacks, no matter how small or isolated, in order to provide a comprehensive picture of the threat posed by terrorism. Others argue that the media should focus on reporting on the most significant and impactful attacks, and not waste resources on minor incidents.

The White House has continued to defend its list, saying that it is an important tool for understanding the threat posed by terrorism and that it will continue to release similar lists in the future. However, many have questioned the usefulness and accuracy of the list, and the controversy is likely to continue for some time.

The lawsuit, brought by attorneys general of Washington and Minnesota, has captivated the nation since last Friday when a federal district court judge put a stop to Trump's executive order restricting travel for foreign nationals, and as a result, temporarily opened US borders to immigrants once again. The hearing will be by telephone and livestreamed; here's what to listen for: What's the hearing about? US District Court Judge James Robart upended Trump's executive order nationwide Friday by temporarily halting the key provisions restricting travel for foreign nationals from seven Muslim-majority countries (Syria, Iran, Iraq, Yemen, Sudan, Somalia and Yemen) and refugee admissions. The central question for the appellate court is whether Robart abused his discretion by putting a temporary hold on the travel ban. No court has addressed the constitutionality of the executive order thus far. The players The attorney general of Washington state, Bob Ferguson, filed the case and was later joined by the attorney general of Minnesota, Lori Swanson. The suit is being defended by lawyers at the Civil Division of the Department of Justice in Washington, DC. The randomly assigned three-judge panel includes Judge William C. Canby Jr, an appointee of President Jimmy Carter; Judge Michelle T. Friedland; who was appointed by President Barack Obama; and Judge Richard R. Clifton, an appointee of President George W. Bush. When is this hearing? The appellate court has set an hour-long telephonic oral argument in the case for Tuesday at 6 p.m. The hearing is expected to focus on the legal merits of the executive order, with the judges questioning both sides on the constitutionality and legality of the travel ban. The attorneys general of Washington and Minnesota will likely argue that the order is discriminatory and violates the Establishment Clause of the First Amendment, which prohibits the government from promoting one religion over another.

The Department of Justice, on the other hand, will likely argue that the order is a legitimate exercise of the president's national security powers and that it is necessary to protect the country from potential terrorist threats.

The judges may also ask questions about the impact of the travel ban on individuals and families who have been affected by it, including those who have been detained or deported, as well as those who have been unable to travel to the United States due to the ban.

In addition to the legal arguments, the hearing may also focus on the procedural issues surrounding the case, including whether Judge Robart overstepped his authority by issuing a nationwide injunction against the travel ban.

The outcome of the hearing is difficult to predict, but it is likely that the appellate court will issue a ruling in the coming weeks or months. If the court upholds Judge Robart's decision, the travel ban will remain blocked, and the US borders will remain open to immigrants. However, if the court reverses Judge Robart's decision, the travel ban will go back into effect, and the US borders will be closed to immigrants from the seven affected countries.

Regardless of the outcome, the hearing is likely to have significant implications for the ongoing debate over immigration and national security in the United States.

President Klaus Iohannis said it is time for Romania to decide whether it wants to be a "strong prosperous" nation or a "weak despised one" -- and he called for a referendum so the people can have their say. Half a million citizens took to the streets on Sunday in the largest of a series of demonstrations over a bill that would have protected many politicians from being prosecuted for corruption. The Social Democrat-led government announced that day in a statement that it was repealing the decree, which had been approved last week without input from Parliament. However, Prime Minister Sorin Grindeanu indicated that he still planned to push through the amendments to the criminal codes via legislation that would be put to Parliament for approval. Protests continued over the issue Monday night -- albeit on a smaller scale -- with calls for the government to be removed. 'Transparent government' In his speech on Tuesday, Iohannis, a former National Liberal Party politician, said withdrawing the decree is too little. Although he stopped short of calling for a fresh election, he told members of the center-left government, which has been in power since December, "Your first worry was to take care of the files of the convicted (politicians). Romanians are appalled. "The withdrawal of Ordnance 13 is too little. Early elections, at this point, is too much. Who needs to come up with a solution? The Social Democrats, as they created the problem." The Romanian President's words were met with a mixed reaction from the government and opposition parties. Social Democrat leader Liviu Dragnea, who is also the Speaker of the Chamber of Deputies, accused Iohannis of "interfering" in the legislative process and called his remarks "unpresidential". Dragnea claimed that the President's comments were an attempt to undermine the government's efforts to reform the criminal code.

In response, opposition parties, including the National Liberal Party, the Democratic Union of Hungarians in Romania, and the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats, welcomed Iohannis' call for a referendum, saying it was a necessary step to restore public trust in the government.

The leader of the opposition National Liberal Party, Raluca Turcan, said that the government's decision to repeal the decree was a "PR stunt" and that the people wanted a genuine change in the way politics was done in Romania. "The government is trying to buy time, but the people will not be fooled," she said.

The protests that began on Sunday continued throughout the week, with thousands of people taking to the streets in major cities across the country. The demonstrations were largely peaceful, but there were reports of clashes between protesters and police in some areas.

As the political crisis deepened, international organizations and foreign governments began to take notice. The European Union's Commissioner for Justice, Vera Jourova, said that the situation in Romania was "concerning" and that the EU was closely following developments. The United States Embassy in Bucharest also issued a statement, calling for "greater transparency and accountability" in Romanian politics.

In the midst of the turmoil, Prime Minister Sorin Grindeanu met with his cabinet to discuss the government's next steps. While he did not rule out the possibility of a referendum, he made it clear that the government would not be swayed by public pressure alone. "We will not be dictated to by the streets," he said. "We will continue to work towards our goals, and if that means facing opposition from the President or the opposition parties, so be it."

As the standoff between the government and the opposition continues, one thing is clear: the future of Romanian politics hangs in the balance. Will the government be able to push through its reforms, or will the people's desire for change ultimately prevail? Only time will tell.
