And it's been this way for more than a century. But a new injectable gel that blocks sperm inside the body, preventing them from leaving while allowing seminal fluid to pass through, has proved effective in trials using monkeys. The researchers behind the product, known as Vasalgel, hope it could get trials in humans within a few years. "What was important here was that this worked and was safe in animals similar to humans," said Elaine Lissner, executive director of the Parsemus Foundation, the medical research organization behind Vasalgel that is also leading the trials. A new study, published Tuesday, involved 16 male monkeys receiving injections of Vasalgel who were released into social outdoor housing with females. Any adverse effects, as well as their ability to impregnate females, was compared with a historical sample of monkeys that had received vasectomies. "It was a simple efficacy study," Lissner said, meaning the researchers merely set out to see whether the gel was safe and worked to prevent pregnancy. The social groups were monitored for at least one breeding season, and the team reported in its paper that none of the females in the group conceived during that time. One monkey had the gel inserted incorrectly, and another developed a sperm granuloma, or lump of sperm, but the majority tolerated the gel and saw little inflammation, Lissner said, adding that rates of granuloma and inflammation are usually higher after a vasectomy. The breakthrough comes at a time when vasectomy, a surgical procedure that cuts and seals the vas deferens, the tubes that carry sperm out of the body, has become increasingly popular as a form of birth control. However, the procedure is not without its drawbacks, including the risk of complications and the fact that it is not reversible.

Vasalgel, on the other hand, is a non-surgical, non-hormonal, and reversible form of birth control that could offer a more appealing option for men. The gel is made up of a polymer that is designed to block the vas deferens, preventing sperm from leaving the body while allowing seminal fluid to pass through.

According to the researchers, the gel is easy to administer and can be inserted into the vas deferens using a simple injection. The procedure is also relatively quick, taking around 10-15 minutes to complete.

The team behind Vasalgel is now planning to move forward with human trials, which they hope will begin within the next few years. If the results are positive, the gel could potentially become a new option for men who are looking for a more effective and reversible form of birth control.

"We're excited about the potential of Vasalgel to provide a new and improved option for men who want to take control of their reproductive health," said Lissner. "We believe that this could be a game-changer for men and their partners, and we're looking forward to seeing the results of our human trials."

The development of Vasalgel is part of a growing trend towards the development of new and innovative forms of birth control. In recent years, there has been a surge of interest in developing new methods of birth control that are more effective, reversible, and user-friendly.

The Parsemus Foundation is a non-profit organization that is dedicated to advancing the field of medical research and developing new treatments for a range of conditions, including infertility and birth control. The organization has been working on the development of Vasalgel for several years and is committed to bringing the product to market as soon as possible.

Overall, the development of Vasalgel is an exciting breakthrough that could potentially offer a new and improved option for men who are looking for a more effective and reversible form of birth control. The results of the human trials will be closely watched by researchers and medical professionals around the world.

Japan controls the chain and calls them the Senkaku Islands, while China calls them the Diaoyu Islands. There is art in science -- the artistic precision of the scalpel, the cool aesthetics of the laboratory, and the intimate observations undertaken by scientists to discover new materials and microbes living unseen in the world. Bio-art, an artistic genre that took hold in the 1980s, solidifies, extends and enriches this organic relationship. According to the artist and writer Frances Stracey, it represents: "a crossover of art and the biological sciences, with living matter, such as genes, cells or animals, as its new media." Bio-artists might use and incorporate imaging technologies within the artistic space; bringing living and dead matter into the gallery. They draw upon biology metaphors to imbue artwork with healing and wounding propensities. wounding propensities. This fusion of art and science has given rise to a new wave of creatives who are pushing the boundaries of traditional mediums. Bio-artists are no longer content to simply depict the natural world, but instead, they are actively engaging with it, manipulating its very essence to create works that are both beautiful and thought-provoking.

One such artist is Heather Dewey-Hagborg, who has gained international recognition for her work "Grow Your Own Brain". This installation features a series of glass jars filled with a gelatinous substance that resembles the human brain. However, upon closer inspection, it becomes clear that the "brain" is actually a collection of 3D-printed neurons, grown from the artist's own DNA.

Another notable bio-artist is Chiharu Shiota, who has created a series of intricate installations using thousands of red yarns to represent the neural connections in the human brain. Her work, "The Key in the Hand", is a testament to the beauty and complexity of the human mind.

Bio-art is not limited to visual art forms alone. Musician and composer, Christina Kubisch, has created a series of sound installations that use electromagnetic fields to generate music. Her work, "Electrosmog", uses sensors to detect the electromagnetic radiation emitted by the city, translating it into a symphony of sounds that are both haunting and beautiful.

As bio-art continues to evolve, it is clear that its impact will be felt across multiple disciplines. From medicine to environmental science, bio-art is pushing the boundaries of what we thought was possible, and challenging us to rethink our relationship with the natural world.

In the words of Frances Stracey, "Bio-art is not just about making art, it's about making a difference. It's about using art to understand the world, and to change it for the better." As we move forward into an uncertain future, the fusion of art and science may just hold the key to unlocking new possibilities, and redefining what it means to be human.

Wheelchair-bound and barely able to talk in his later years, the South Africa legend Joost van der Westhuizen passed away on Monday at the age of 45. Motor neurone disease had left him a shadow of the gladiator who helped the Springboks win the World Cup in 1995, but his contribution to the game will never be forgotten, says former teammate Cobus Visagie.

Van der Westhuizen's impact on the game went beyond his impressive playing career. He was a trailblazer, paving the way for taller players to take on the traditionally smaller position of scrumhalf. His legacy continues to inspire new generations of rugby players, and his passing has sent shockwaves through the rugby community.

The South African Rugby Union has paid tribute to van der Westhuizen, describing him as "a true Springbok legend" and "a pioneer of the modern scrumhalf position". The union has also announced plans to hold a memorial service in his honor.

But nature is not always kind. Fifty percent of the world's lion population lives in East Africa -- and lions like to eat livestock. Historically the Maasai would use deadly force to protect their herds, often heading out in revenge parties to hunt and kill lions. There were ritual killings also, known as "Ala-mayo." Killing a lion, a symbol of strength and power, was a rite of passage for Maasai initiates into "Morani," the warrior class. Armed with a spear, these youths became men in the process, returning to the tribe to be treated with new-found respect. The Tanzanian government banned ritual killing in the 1970s, but certain pockets of activity were silently condoned. In Ngorongoro Crater, north west of Tarangire National Park and a conservation area since 1959, the practice was judged sustainable due to the high lion concentration and low human presence. In the 1960s the tribe claimed no more than 10 animals per year, but as with so much of the world in the 20th century, the Maasai's population grew in Ngorongoro. Forty lions, if not more, are now under threat annually in the conservation area, and all over Tanzania lion numbers are declining. Conservationists know the problem needs to be addressed, and in a remarkable turnaround they've enlisted the very best gamekeepers to patrol the Maasai Steppe: the Maasai themselves. At around 5am the Maasai "Wildlife Warriors" rise to birdsong, nature's alarm clock. A bowl of porridge and cup of chai to start the day. Slipping on a pair of sandals, their soles recycled from old car tires, the Warriors head out of their "kraal," a small sheltered community, to begin tracking. As they venture into the vast expanse of the Maasai Steppe, the Warriors' keen eyes scan the horizon for any sign of movement. Their mission is clear: to protect the lions that roam this land, while also safeguarding the Maasai's own livestock. It's a delicate balance, one that requires patience, skill, and a deep understanding of the natural world.

The Warriors move with a quiet purpose, their footsteps light on the dusty earth. They know every inch of this terrain, every rock, every tree, every watering hole. They've grown up here, learning the ways of the land from their fathers and grandfathers.

As they track, they're on the lookout for any signs of lion activity. They know that these majestic creatures can be unpredictable, and that a sudden attack on a Maasai herd can be devastating. But they also know that the lions are an integral part of the ecosystem, and that their loss would have far-reaching consequences.

After several hours of walking, the Warriors come across a small herd of cattle grazing peacefully in a green valley. They move in quietly, not wanting to startle the animals or attract any unwanted attention from the lions. As they approach, they notice that one of the cows is limping, its leg injured from a recent attack.

The Warriors know that they need to act quickly to prevent further attacks. They carefully move the injured cow to a safe location, where it can receive medical attention. As they work, they're aware of the lions watching from a distance, their eyes fixed intently on the Maasai.

The Warriors know that they're not just protecting the livestock, but also the very fabric of their community. They're fighting to preserve a way of life that's been passed down through generations, a way of life that's deeply connected to the land and its creatures.

As the sun begins to set, the Warriors make their way back to their kraal, tired but triumphant. They know that their work is far from over, but they're determined to continue fighting for the future of their people and the animals they love. More than 50 rooftops designed by some of the world's most renowned and up-and-coming architects and landscape designers is featured in "Rooftops: Islands in the Sky," Taschen's photography book releasing February 15 in the United States. The book features forests reaching for the skies, blooming gardens, pools flowing to a building's edge, art installations and outdoor spaces that switch easily from serving lunch to pouring drinks as nighttime hot spots. The book, edited by Phaidon's Publisher, Stefano Boeri, is a visual journey that showcases the creative and innovative designs of rooftops from around the world. From the lush greenery of a rooftop garden in Tokyo to the sleek, modern lines of a poolside bar in Miami, each photograph is a testament to the imagination and skill of the architects and designers who brought these unique spaces to life.

The book's introduction, written by renowned architecture critic, Michael Sorkin, explores the concept of rooftops as "islands in the sky," highlighting their role as tranquil oases in the midst of bustling cities. Sorkin notes that rooftops have become increasingly important as public spaces, providing a sense of community and connection for city dwellers.

The photographs themselves are stunning, with each image carefully curated to showcase the unique features and design elements of each rooftop. From the intricate stone carvings on a rooftop in Barcelona to the vibrant street art on a rooftop in Brooklyn, every detail is captured in exquisite detail.

The book also includes essays and interviews with the architects and designers featured in the book, providing insight into their creative processes and inspirations. Readers will gain a deeper understanding of the challenges and opportunities of designing rooftop spaces, as well as the ways in which these spaces can be used to bring people together and enhance the urban experience.

"Rooftops: Islands in the Sky" is a must-have for anyone who loves architecture, design, and the urban landscape. The book's stunning photographs and engaging text make it a perfect coffee table book or a valuable resource for architects, designers, and urban planners. Whether you're a design enthusiast or simply someone who appreciates the beauty of a well-designed space, this book is sure to inspire and delight.

Trump was defending the Russian President after Fox's Bill O'Reilly called Putin a "killer." His response, "You think our country is so innocent," reveals Trump's dismissive attitude toward the most fundamental democratic norms that America has aspired to embody. Clearly, the United States has made many grave mistakes throughout history, but the country's guiding principles have remained unchanged: the fierce defense of individual liberties and an unshakeable commitment to democratic ideals. In Russia, by contrast, Putin has decimated the opposition, imprisoned critics and taken control of all branches of government. The free press is a faint shadow of its former self, and Putin's critics, including journalists, continue to turn up dead under suspicious circumstances. It is precisely this stark contrast between the two nations that makes Trump's defense of Putin so disturbing. By minimizing the atrocities committed by the Russian leader, Trump is not only condoning his actions but also eroding the very foundations of American democracy.

The President's response, "You think our country is so innocent," is a classic example of moral equivalence, a tactic often employed by authoritarian regimes to justify their own abuses of power. It is a cynical attempt to shift the focus away from Russia's egregious human rights violations and towards perceived American shortcomings.

But Trump's words are not just a betrayal of American values; they are also a reflection of his own authoritarian tendencies. His administration has been marked by a consistent pattern of attacking the free press, silencing critics, and undermining the rule of law. The erosion of democratic norms is a global phenomenon, and Trump's defense of Putin is a stark reminder that the United States is not immune to this trend.

As the world watches in horror, Trump's words have sent a chilling message to would-be critics of authoritarian regimes: that the United States will no longer be a beacon of democracy and human rights, but rather a willing accomplice in the erosion of these fundamental values.

In the face of such blatant disregard for human rights and democratic norms, it is imperative that the American people demand more from their leaders. They must hold Trump accountable for his actions and demand that he uphold the values that America has always aspired to embody. The world is watching, and the future of democracy hangs in the balance.

"Whataboutism" was a favorite Kremlin propaganda technique during the Cold War. It aimed to portray the West as so morally flawed that its criticism of the Soviet empire was hypocritical. Any criticism of the Soviet Union (the war in Afghanistan, martial law in Poland, persecution of dissidents) was met with a list of Western abuses (supporting fascist dictatorships, trampling trade unions, racial oppression). It was well encapsulated in a joke about the fictional Radio Yerevan (a staple of Soviet-era humor) in which a caller asks what is the average wage of an American manual worker. The real answer would undermine Soviet claims to economic superiority, so after a pause, the pundit replies: "Over there they lynch Negroes." By the time the system collapsed, that phrase had become a derisive synecdoche for Soviet propaganda as a whole. As the Cold War drew to a close, the term "whataboutism" seemed to fade into obscurity, replaced by new challenges and controversies in the post-Soviet era. However, in recent years, it has experienced a surprising resurgence, particularly in the realm of social media and online discourse.

In the age of Twitter and Facebook, "whataboutism" has evolved into a potent tool for deflecting criticism and discredit opponents. It's often employed by individuals and groups seeking to shift the focus away from their own actions or policies, and onto perceived wrongdoings of others.

The tactic has been used by politicians, pundits, and even ordinary citizens to respond to criticisms, accusations, or simply to silence opposing viewpoints. By asking "What about...?" or "But what about...?", proponents of "whataboutism" aim to create a sense of moral equivalence, implying that the original criticism is invalid or hypocritical.

The revival of "whataboutism" has been attributed to various factors, including the proliferation of social media, the rise of populist politics, and the increasing polarization of society. Critics argue that this tactic undermines constructive dialogue, fosters a culture of blame-shifting, and diverts attention from real issues.

In recent high-profile cases, "whataboutism" has been employed to deflect criticism of everything from political scandals to social injustices. For instance, in response to allegations of corruption, a prominent politician might say, "What about the corruption in other countries?" or "What about the corruption in the past?" Similarly, in discussions about racial inequality, some individuals might counter with "What about the racial discrimination against white people?" or "What about the injustices suffered by other groups?"

While "whataboutism" may have originated as a Soviet propaganda technique, its modern iteration is a more nuanced and insidious phenomenon. It's no longer limited to the realm of geopolitics, but has become a ubiquitous feature of online discourse, social media, and even mainstream politics.

As we navigate this increasingly complex and divided world, it's essential to recognize the dangers of "whataboutism" and to develop strategies for combating it. By promoting critical thinking, empathy, and respectful dialogue, we can work towards creating a more informed, engaged, and civically responsible public sphere.

The discovery upends a decades-old theory in the archaeological community that Dead Sea Scrolls were only found in certain caves at the Qumran cliffs, which are managed by Israel in the West Bank. "Until now, it was accepted that Dead Sea Scrolls were found only in 11 caves at Qumran, but now there is no doubt that this is the 12th cave," said Dr. Oren Gutfeld, one of the project's lead archaeologists. Pottery shards, broken scroll storage jars and their lids -- even neolithic flint tools and arrowheads -- littered the cave's entrance. Farther in, there appeared to be a cave-in. After a bit of work with a small pickax, the team made a monumental find: an unbroken storage jar with a scroll. and it was perfectly preserved, with no signs of damage or decay. The team was ecstatic as they carefully extracted the jar from the cave, taking care not to disturb any potential evidence.

As they made their way back to the surface, the team couldn't contain their excitement. "This is a game-changer," said Dr. Gutfeld, his eyes shining with enthusiasm. "We've been searching for decades to find new Dead Sea Scrolls, and now we've got one that's in near-perfect condition. It's a treasure trove of information about the people who lived in the region over 2,000 years ago."

The team spent the next several hours carefully examining the jar and its contents, taking detailed notes and photographs. They discovered that the scroll was written in Hebrew, and initial translations suggested that it was a previously unknown text from the Second Temple period.

News of the discovery quickly spread, sending shockwaves through the archaeological community. Experts from around the world began to flock to the site, eager to catch a glimpse of the remarkable find.

"This is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity," said Dr. Rachel Elior, a renowned Dead Sea Scrolls expert from Hebrew University. "To find an unbroken scroll in such a remote location is a miracle. It's a testament to the incredible preservation of the Dead Sea Scrolls and the importance of continued archaeological research in the region."

As the team continued to study the scroll, they began to uncover more secrets about the people who lived in the region during the time of the Second Temple. The discovery was hailed as a major breakthrough, and it was clear that the excavation of the 12th cave would be a major milestone in the history of Dead Sea Scrolls research.

'Parasitic twin' Polymelia is a genetic disorder, which can be caused by chromosomal abnormalities or environmental agents, according to a paper in the Journal of Clinical Imaging Science. The condition can occur when an embryo develops into conjoined twins, but then one twin stops growing but continues to develop extra limbs or organs, which remain attached to the other twin. This was the case for the boy in Bangalore, according to Rao, and it's referred to as "parasitic twins," according to a press release from the hospital. The presence of an extra twin made the surgery, which took place last week, all the more complex, Rao told CNN. The surgical team at Narayana Health City spent over five hours in the operating room to remove the extra limbs and organs, which were attached to the boy's lower abdomen. "It was a challenging surgery, but we were determined to give the boy a normal life," Dr. Rao said. "The extra limbs were not only causing physical discomfort but also affecting his mental well-being. We had to carefully detach the parasitic twin without causing any harm to the boy's vital organs."

The boy, who is currently recovering in the hospital, is expected to make a full recovery. His parents are overjoyed with the outcome of the surgery and are grateful to the medical team for their expertise and care.

"We are thrilled that our son is doing well," said the boy's mother, who wished to remain anonymous. "We were devastated when we first learned about his condition, but the doctors at Narayana Health City gave us hope and reassurance throughout the entire process. Bill Gates is a man on a mission. The 61-year-old co-founder of Microsoft, who has an estimated fortune of nearly $85 billion according to Forbes, is well known for his philanthropic work. Autism is considered a neurodevelopmental condition, which means symptoms begin early and children fail to achieve typical milestones of maturity at appropriate ages. Common symptoms include difficulty with communication and repetitive behaviors. In the United States, about one in 68 children has been identified with autism spectrum disorder, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The term "spectrum" refers to the fact that symptoms, levels of disability and positive skills may vary from person to person. For example, some people along the spectrum cannot make eye contact or follow simple directions, while others may be exceptional at math. And, as they age, some children with autism will learn to function more or less normally, while others will require substantial support to perform basic activities. Autism spectrum disorder is two to five times more common in males than in females, according to Christine Ecker, lead author of the new study and a professor at Goethe University in Frankfurt, Germany. The researchers used magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans to analyze the brain structure of 84 women and 84 men with autism, as well as 84 women and 84 men without the condition. They found that women with autism who had more "male-like" brain structures, particularly in regions involved in social cognition and language, were more likely to have the condition.

In contrast, men with autism did not show a similar association between brain structure and autism risk. The study suggests that women with autism may be more likely to have a combination of "male" and "female" brain traits, which could contribute to their increased risk of developing the condition.

The findings could have implications for understanding and diagnosing autism in women, who are often underdiagnosed and undertreated. "The results highlight the importance of considering the potential impact of sex and gender on the brain structure and function in autism," said Ecker.

The study's authors also note that the results do not necessarily mean that men with "female-like" brain structures are immune to autism. More research is needed to determine whether there is a similar association between brain structure and autism risk in men.

For investigators attempting to track down sex traffickers and their victims, these online advertisements can contain critical clues. The smallest of details in a room could give away its location, but there are too many ads for law enforcement to scan each of them for clues. That's where TraffickCam comes in. It's a simple phone app that uses crowdsourced snapshots of hotel rooms to help law enforcement locate victims and prosecute sex traffickers. Any travelers pit stopping at a hotel can turn on their phone's GPS location and upload photos of the room from four different angles to TraffickCam's database. The idea is that law enforcement agencies can then check adverts featuring suspected trafficking victims in hotel rooms against TraffickCam's database of photos. Stand up to modern slavery on March 14 -- #MyFreedomDay TraffickCam's image analysis tools transform the photos into a number of data points, using features such as patterns on the carpet, paintings on the wall and landmarks out of the window. The various data points in the photos play an important role in matching the location. TraffickCam is the brainchild of Exchange Initiative and a team of researchers at Washington University. Since its launch, TraffickCam has gained significant traction, with thousands of users downloading the app and uploading photos of hotel rooms. The app's database now contains over 1 million images, making it a valuable resource for law enforcement agencies worldwide.

The app's impact has been significant, with several successful prosecutions already linked to TraffickCam's database. In one notable case, a sex trafficking victim was rescued after law enforcement used TraffickCam to match a suspect's hotel room advertisement to a photo uploaded by a traveler.

The app's creators are working closely with law enforcement agencies to ensure that TraffickCam is integrated into their operations. "TraffickCam is a game-changer in the fight against sex trafficking," said Detective James Smith of the St. Louis Police Department. "It's an invaluable tool that has already helped us to identify and rescue victims."

The app's success has also sparked interest from governments and organizations around the world. The US Department of State has recognized TraffickCam as a best practice in the fight against human trafficking, and the app has been adopted by several international organizations, including the International Justice Mission.

Despite its success, TraffickCam's creators are aware of the challenges that lie ahead. "We know that there is still much work to be done to combat sex trafficking," said Sarah Williams, executive director of the Exchange Initiative. "But we are committed to using technology to make a difference, and we believe that TraffickCam can be a powerful tool in this fight."

As the fight against sex trafficking continues, TraffickCam remains a crucial tool in the effort to identify and rescue victims. By empowering travelers to take action and provide critical information to law enforcement, the app is helping to bring hope to those affected by this devastating crime.

Every woman has experienced something like this: being ignored in a meeting, not included in a client dinner, interrupted while speaking, told she's being "emotional" when she disagrees or feels strongly about something, passed over for opportunities, or asked to grab the snacks for the meeting. "I've been to meetings where the men have been discussing deals and strategies, and I've been asked to take notes," she said. "It's like I'm not considered part of the decision-making process."

The event was attended by thousands of women, all of whom were eager to learn from the experiences of the panelists and to share their own stories of struggle and triumph. It was a powerful reminder that, despite the challenges, women are capable of achieving great things when given the opportunity.

As the event came to a close, the panelists left the audience with a message of hope and resilience. "We may face obstacles, but we must not let them hold us back," said one of the CFOs. "We must continue to push forward, to demand respect and to create a world where all women can thrive."

In his previous US visits, Trudeau found a leader almost exactly aligned with his liberal worldview and youthful image. The dam, which is the nation's tallest, remains intact. But the emergency spillway, which helps to ensure that the water does not rush over the top of the dam when the levels are high, was eroding Sunday. The damage prompted a mandatory evacuation for cities and counties near Lake Oroville amid fears it could endanger communities living downstream. Those orders remain in effect and Butte County Sheriff Kory Honea said he did not know when they would be lifted. "I'm not going to lift the evacuation order until I have better idea of what that means and what risk that poses," he said in a press conference late Sunday night. California Governor Jerry Brown issued a state emergency order to help local authorities with the situation and evacuations. What led up to the Sunday emergency This winter, heavy rainfall in Northern California has filled Lake Oroville to the verge of overflow. The lake also gets water from the northern Sierra Nevada mountain range which is experiencing one of its wettest seasons. This has triggered concerns over whether the water could overflow the dam and flood nearby communities. The Oroville Dam provides flood control for the region and is located about 75 miles north of Sacramento. As the situation unfolded, officials scrambled to assess the damage and determine the best course of action to mitigate the risk of catastrophic flooding. A team of experts from the California Department of Water Resources and the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) was dispatched to the scene to inspect the dam and emergency spillway.

"We're working around the clock to get a better understanding of the situation and to develop a plan to address the erosion," said Mark Ghilarducci, Director of the California Governor's Office of Emergency Services. "We're doing everything we can to ensure public safety and to prevent any potential disasters."

Meanwhile, residents of Butte, Yuba, and Sutter counties were left to navigate the uncertainty of their situation. Many were forced to leave their homes and businesses behind, unsure of when they would be able to return.

"I've lived in this community my whole life, and I've never seen anything like this," said Karen Sullivan, a resident of Oroville who was evacuated from her home. "I'm just hoping that the dam holds and that we can get back to normal soon."

As the situation continued to unfold, officials warned that the risk of flooding was still present, and that residents should remain vigilant and prepared for any potential evacuation orders.

"We're doing everything we can to prevent a disaster, but we also need the public's cooperation," said Sheriff Honea. "We urge everyone to stay informed and to follow any instructions from local authorities."

The situation at Lake Oroville remained fluid, with officials working around the clock to address the crisis. As the days went by, residents held their breaths, hoping that the dam would hold and that their communities would be spared from the worst of the flooding.

The US Attorney's Office for the Eastern District of New York said the 13 members of La Mara Salvatrucha, known as MS-13, face offenses including seven murder charges, racketeering, attempted murder, assault, obstruction of justice and arson in the 41-count indictment unsealed Thursday in federal court in Central Islip, New York. "Law enforcement was determined that these brutal murders wouldn't turn into cold cases," US Attorney Robert L. Capers told reporters. Two of the students -- Nisa Mickens, 15, and Kayla Cuevas, 16 -- were beaten with baseball bats and a machete, Capers said. The girls attended Brentwood High School in Brentwood, a working-class community in Suffolk County, about 45 miles east of New York City. At the time, police said there appeared to be gang involvement in the girls' deaths and the deaths of two others, whose skeletal remains were found after they had been missing for months. Police have not announced arrests in the latter two deaths. "The Brentwood family has spent the last six months in mourning, but today marks the beginning of the healing process for this beautiful and resilient community," Suffolk County Police Commissioner Timothy Sini said. Kayla was involved in a "series of disputes" with MS-13 gang members and associates months earlier, authorities said. She and friends then became involved in an altercation at Brentwood High a week before the girls' deaths, authorities said. MS-13 members vowed to seek revenge. According to the indictment, the MS-13 gang members used violence and intimidation to maintain control over the streets of Brentwood and surrounding areas. The indictment alleges that the gang members, including some who were students at Brentwood High School, committed a range of crimes, including murder, attempted murder, assault, and obstruction of justice.

The indictment also alleges that MS-13 members used social media and other forms of communication to spread fear and intimidation, and to recruit new members. The gang members are accused of using violence and threats to silence witnesses and intimidate potential victims.

The indictment was the result of a long-term investigation by the Suffolk County Police Department, the FBI, and other law enforcement agencies. The investigation was led by Suffolk County Police Detective Michael Hoffman, who has been working on the case for over a year.

The indictment is a major breakthrough in the investigation, and it marks a significant step towards justice for the families of the victims. The families of the victims have been vocal in their demand for justice, and they have been working closely with law enforcement to bring the perpetrators to account.

The indictment is also a testament to the strength and resilience of the Brentwood community, which has been deeply affected by the violence and gang activity. The community has come together to support the families of the victims, and to demand an end to the violence and gang activity.

The case is now headed to federal court, where the defendants will face trial. If convicted, they could face up to life in prison. The indictment is a major victory for law enforcement, and it marks a significant step towards bringing an end to the violence and gang activity in Brentwood.

A government act on Thursday reintroduced compulsory military service in the country for the first time since 2010, and for the first time on a gender-equal basis. Peter Hultqvist, Sweden's minister of defense, cited Russia's annexation of the Ukrainian territory of Crimea in 2014 as one of the triggers for the decision. "After the Russian annexation of Crimea against international law, and their increased military exercises close to the border, we have a new security situation," Hultqvist said. Hultqvist added that Sweden is "strengthening its military cooperation with Finland and with the NATO partners." Sweden is not a NATO member but it has contributed to NATO-led operations and enjoys bilateral ties with the alliance through the Partnership for Peace and the Euro-Atlantic Partnership Council. The country suspended conscription in 2010 and instead adopted a recruitment system which relied on volunteers. The new law, which takes effect in 2023, requires all Swedish citizens between the ages of 18 and 47 to serve in the military for a minimum of 265 days. This includes both men and women, who will be treated equally under the new system. The previous conscription law, which was suspended in 2010, only applied to men.

The decision to reintroduce conscription was met with mixed reactions from the public and politicians. Some argue that it is necessary to strengthen Sweden's national defense and deter potential threats from neighboring countries, while others see it as a step backward in terms of individual freedom and autonomy.

"The government's decision is a clear sign that they are taking the security situation seriously," said Carl Bildt, a former Swedish prime minister and foreign minister. "However, it's also important to ensure that the conscription system is fair and does not disproportionately affect certain groups of people."

Critics of the decision argue that it will lead to a decrease in the number of volunteers joining the military, as some may see conscription as a less desirable option. They also point out that the country's military is already facing challenges in recruiting and retaining personnel, and that conscription may exacerbate these problems.

Despite these concerns, the government remains committed to the decision. "We believe that a strong and well-prepared military is essential for Sweden's security and stability," said Hultqvist. "And we are confident that our new conscription system will help us achieve that goal."

The reintroduction of conscription is also seen as a sign of a shift in Sweden's foreign policy, which has traditionally been focused on peacekeeping and humanitarian efforts. The country's increased military cooperation with NATO and its neighboring countries is also seen as a response to the changing security landscape in the region.

In related news, the Swedish military has announced plans to increase its troop levels and modernize its equipment in response to the new security situation. The country is also planning to invest in its cyber defense capabilities and intelligence gathering infrastructure.

The reintroduction of conscription is set to take effect in 2023, and the government has promised to provide more details on the new system in the coming months. In the meantime, many Swedes are left wondering what this means for their country's future and whether the decision will ultimately make them safer.

"There is no such thing as absolute privacy in America; there is no place outside of judicial reach," Comey said at a Boston College conference on cybersecurity. He made the remark as he discussed the rise of encryption since 2013 disclosures by former National Security Agency contractor Edward Snowden revealed sensitive US spy practices. "Even our communications with our spouses, with our clergy members, with our attorneys are not absolutely private in America," Comey added. According to FBI Director James Comey, the notion of absolute privacy in the United States is a myth. He made this statement at a cybersecurity conference hosted by Boston College, where he addressed the growing use of encryption in the wake of Edward Snowden's revelations about the National Security Agency's (NSA) surveillance practices in 2013.

Comey's comments sparked controversy among privacy advocates, who argue that the government's increasing reliance on surveillance and data collection is a threat to individual liberties. The FBI director, however, emphasized that the need to balance national security concerns with the need to protect individual privacy.

"We need to find a way to make sure that we can access the communications of terrorists and other criminals while also respecting the privacy of law-abiding citizens," Comey said. "This is a difficult challenge, but it's one that we must face head-on."

Comey's remarks come as the FBI and other law enforcement agencies face growing challenges in accessing encrypted data. Many technology companies, including Apple and Google, have implemented strong encryption methods to protect their users' data, making it increasingly difficult for authorities to intercept and analyze communications.

The debate over encryption and privacy has taken on new urgency in recent years, with many experts warning that the proliferation of unbreakable encryption could make it difficult for law enforcement to track and prevent terrorist attacks. At the same time, privacy advocates argue that the government's efforts to compromise encryption could have far-reaching consequences for individual privacy and civil liberties.

In his speech, Comey acknowledged that the FBI's efforts to access encrypted data had been met with resistance from technology companies. He called on Congress to pass legislation that would require technology companies to provide law enforcement agencies with access to encrypted data in certain circumstances.

"We need to work with Congress to pass legislation that will allow us to access the communications of terrorists and other criminals while also respecting the privacy of law-abiding citizens," Comey said. "This is a complex issue, but I am confident that we can find a solution that balances our national security needs with our commitment to individual privacy."

The win sets up a mouth-watering quarterfinal tie against Manchester City, who had earlier overcome a 2-1 deficit to defeat Monaco 3-2. For now, though, Barcelona will bask in the glory of their incredible comeback, and the knowledge that they have written themselves into the annals of Champions League history. With the first round of the French presidential election just over a month away and Germany headed to the ballot box later this year, the Dutch battle is being closely watched for clues to wider political trends. Conservative Prime Minister Mark Rutte is facing a tight battle with far-right rival Geert Wilders, whose anti-immigrant, anti-Islam tirades have landed him in court -- but also won him widespread support in a country that is increasingly polarized by austerity and immigration issues. The election is also being closely watched by European leaders, who are eager to see how the outcome will affect the continent's politics. The European Union is facing a number of challenges, including the ongoing Brexit negotiations and the rise of nationalist movements across the continent.

The 297-foot (90.6 meter) MS Caledonian Sky crashed into the reefs at Raja Ampat on March 4. Raja Ampat is frequently included on lists of the the world's most beautiful coral reefs and is often described as an "untouched" beach paradise. "The destruction of Raja Ampat coral reefs, which were developed by nature for hundreds of years, was done in less than one day by Caledonian Sky and its captain," Djoko Hartoyo, of the Information and Law Bureau of the Coordinating Ministry for Maritime Affairs, said in a statement. "It is simply impossible to restore that part of Raja Ampat. Fish that were normally seen in that particular area were all gone." Nearly 140,000 square feet (more than 13,000 square meters) of reef were destroyed, Ketut Putra, the vice president of Conservation International Indonesia, told CNN. The ship crashed into one of the best diving areas, he said. Noble Caledonia, the cruise company that operates the vessel, apologized for the incident. It said in a statement that the ship went aground, but did not give a reason why. The incident has sparked widespread outrage and concern among marine conservationists and local communities. Raja Ampat is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and is home to an incredible array of marine life, including over 1,500 species of fish, 600 species of coral, and many other creatures.

The destruction of the reef has also had a significant impact on the local fishing industry, with many fishermen reporting a significant decline in their catch. The reef was also a popular destination for tourists, with many scuba diving and snorkeling trips being offered to the area.

Conservation International Indonesia has called for an investigation into the incident and is urging the government to take action to protect the remaining coral reefs in the area. The organization is also working with local communities to develop sustainable tourism practices that can help to support the conservation of the reef.

The incident has also raised questions about the safety of cruise ships and the measures that are in place to prevent such incidents from happening in the future. The captain of the Caledonian Sky has been criticized for his role in the incident, with some calling for him to be held accountable.

The Indonesian government has promised to take action to prevent similar incidents from happening in the future. The country's Minister of Maritime Affairs, Luhut Pandjaitan, has said that the government will work to improve safety measures and to increase awareness among cruise ship operators about the importance of protecting the country's marine environment.

The incident is a reminder of the importance of protecting our oceans and the marine life that call them home. It is also a reminder of the need for greater cooperation and coordination between governments, conservation organizations, and the private sector to protect the world's most vulnerable ecosystems.

According to Malaysian police, the women were part of a group of 11 people who were hired to carry out the assassination, and were paid a total of $100,000 to complete the task.

The motive behind the assassination is still unclear, but it is believed that Kim was killed due to his involvement in a plot to overthrow North Korean leader Kim Jong Un.

The assassination has sent shockwaves throughout the region, and has raised concerns about the potential for further violence and instability in the region.

A group of dairy drivers argued that they deserved overtime pay for certain tasks they had completed. The company said they did not. An appeals court sided with the drivers, saying that the guidelines themselves were made too ambiguous by, you guessed it, a lack of an Oxford comma. This is what the law says about activities that do NOT merit overtime pay. Pay attention to the first sentence: The canning, processing, preserving, freezing, drying, marketing, storing, packing for shipment or distribution of: (1) Agricultural produce; (2) Meat and fish products; and (3) Perishable foods. That's a lot of things! But if we're getting picky, is packing for shipment its own activity, or does it only apply to the rest of that clause, i.e. i.e., to the agricultural produce, meat and fish products, and perishable foods listed in the preceding clauses? The drivers' union argued that "packing for shipment" was a distinct activity that required separate consideration, and that the lack of an Oxford comma made the sentence unclear.

The appeals court agreed, stating that the ambiguity was a result of the company's failure to include the Oxford comma, which would have clarified the intended meaning of the sentence. Without it, the sentence could be read as either "packing for shipment or distribution" or "packing for shipment, or distribution."

The court ruled that the drivers' union was correct in their interpretation, and that the drivers were entitled to overtime pay for the task of packing for shipment. The company was ordered to reclassify the drivers' work and provide the necessary compensation.

The decision has sent shockwaves through the dairy industry, with many companies re-examining their overtime policies in light of the ruling. The Oxford comma, once a subject of grammatical debate, has emerged as a key factor in determining the rights of workers. As one lawyer involved in the case noted, "This ruling highlights the importance of clarity in language, particularly in legal documents. The Oxford comma may seem like a minor issue, but in this case, it made all the difference."

The paper's authors warn that the resilience of the planet's largest living structure is waning rapidly. Data from a series of aerial and underwater surveys shows that a heatwave in summer 2016, which saw sea temperatures in Australia reach record levels, triggered the most damaging and widespread coral bleaching event on record. Almost 50% of the reef is now "extremely" bleached and 91% shows at least some signs of bleaching, Sean Connolly, program leader of a government-funded coral reef center at James Cook University, Queensland and the paper's co-author told CNN. "Coral cover [on the Great Barrier Reef] has halved over the last 27 years," Connolly said. The devastating impact of climate change on the Great Barrier Reef is not limited to the recent coral bleaching event. According to the study, the reef's overall health has been declining steadily over the past three decades.

Researchers analyzed data from a network of underwater cameras and monitoring stations to track changes in the reef's coral cover, sea grass, and fish populations. The results are stark: the study found that the reef's coral cover has declined by 50% since 1990, with some areas experiencing losses of up to 90%.

"This is a catastrophic decline," said Dr. Terry Hughes, a co-author of the study and a professor at James Cook University. "We're not just talking about a decline in coral cover, we're talking about a collapse of the reef's ecosystem."

The study's findings are particularly concerning given the reef's importance to the Australian economy and the global environment. The Great Barrier Reef is not only one of the most biologically diverse ecosystems on the planet, but it also provides a vital source of income for thousands of people through tourism and fishing.

Conservation efforts are underway to protect the reef, including the establishment of marine protected areas and the development of more sustainable fishing practices. However, experts say that more needs to be done to address the root cause of the problem: climate change.

"We need to take immediate action to reduce our carbon emissions and transition to renewable energy sources," said Connolly. "If we don't, we risk losing this incredible ecosystem forever."

The study's authors are calling on world leaders to take urgent action to address the crisis facing the Great Barrier Reef. They are urging governments to set aside differences and work together to develop a global plan to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and protect the world's most vulnerable ecosystems.

"The fate of the Great Barrier Reef is a global issue," said Hughes. "It's a wake-up call for all of us to take action to protect our planet's most precious natural resources."

Curious about the police officer standing guard outside the Houses of Parliament in Westminster, Martin asked for a photograph with him. Soon after, the area would be engulfed in horror, and Keith Palmer, the 48-year-old police officer who smiled politely for her photograph would be dead. The officer, Keith Palmer, a 48-year-old veteran of the Metropolitan Police Service, smiled politely and agreed.

The two of them posed for a brief moment, with Martin beaming from ear to ear. She thanked Keith and continued on her way with her son, unaware of the tragedy that was about to unfold.

Just minutes later, a loud explosion rocked the area, followed by the sound of gunfire. Martin and her son quickly sought cover, unsure of what was happening. As they peeked out from behind a nearby pillar, they saw chaos and panic spreading throughout the area.

Tragically, Keith Palmer, the police officer who had just smiled for Martin's photo, lay on the ground, mortally wounded. The attack, which was later attributed to a terrorist, had claimed the lives of three people, including Keith, and injured many more.

Martin was left stunned and shaken, struggling to process the horror that had unfolded before her eyes. She and her son quickly made their way back to their hotel, where they were met with a mix of shock and sadness from the other guests.

As news of the attack spread, Martin found herself thinking of Keith, the police officer who had so briefly and kindly posed for her photo. She couldn't help but wonder what had gone through his mind in those final moments, and how his family and colleagues would cope with the loss of such a brave and dedicated public servant.

The attack on Westminster would go down in history as one of the most devastating and tragic events in recent British history, and Martin's chance encounter with Keith Palmer would serve as a poignant reminder of the human cost of terrorism.

The $999 million requested by the White House in its budget supplement for just defense and border security spending would cover just 48 miles of new wall, according to justification documents from the Department of Homeland Security obtained by CNN. The administration is also seeking to bolster legal support for its border wall efforts, requesting $10 million to hire additional lawyers and $5 million to fund legal assistance for the Department of Homeland Security.

In addition to the physical barriers and detention facilities, the administration is also seeking funding for technology and surveillance systems to support border security efforts. The request includes $120 million for surveillance cameras, $50 million for motion sensors, and $20 million for radar systems.

The budget request also highlights the administration's efforts to improve the processing of asylum seekers and migrants at the border. The request includes $30 million to fund additional asylum officers and $20 million to support the expansion of the Central American Minors Program, which allows minors from El Salvador, Guatemala, and Honduras to apply for lawful permanent residence in the United States.

The Trump administration's border security request has been met with criticism from some lawmakers and advocacy groups, who argue that the funding is insufficient to address the root causes of migration and that the administration's focus on physical barriers and detention facilities is misguided. The budget request is expected to be debated in Congress in the coming weeks, with lawmakers likely to offer amendments and alternative funding proposals. The outcome of the debate remains uncertain, but one thing is clear: the Trump administration's border security priorities will continue to be a contentious issue in Washington.

"Security is too important to be used as a bargaining chip and this will backfire in any negotiations, which rather than building up alliances will leave Britain even more isolated," he said. Labour MP Yvette Cooper echoed the concerns. "Completely irresponsible to threaten, gamble or bargain on national security," she wrote on Twitter. Speaking in the Commons, Stephen Kinnock of the opposition Labour Party read out an excerpt from the letter and asked, "Is she really saying the security of our country will be traded like a bargaining chip in these negotiations?" May replied that it would be important to negotiate a future deal on security. May's comments came as a surprise to many, as the UK and EU had previously agreed that security would not be directly linked to trade negotiations. The move has been seen as a sign of desperation by the British government, which is facing increasing pressure to deliver a successful Brexit deal.

Despite the backlash, May's office maintained that the letter was simply a reflection of the government's commitment to national security. "The Prime Minister is absolutely clear that the security of our country is of the utmost importance, and we will do everything in our power to protect it," a spokesperson said.

However, many experts have expressed concern that the link between trade and security could have serious consequences for the UK's relationship with its allies. "This is a classic example of a 'divide and conquer' strategy, where the UK is trying to drive a wedge between the EU and its member states," said Dr. Emma DeAngelis, a security expert at the University of Oxford.

Meanwhile, the EU has refused to comment on the letter, but sources close to the negotiations have indicated that the UK's demands are unlikely to be met. "The EU will not be bullied into accepting a deal that is not in its best interests," said a senior EU official.

As the negotiations continue, the UK and EU are facing increasing pressure to reach a deal. With the deadline for Brexit looming, time is running out for the two sides to come to an agreement. Will the UK's threat to link trade and security be enough to persuade the EU to make concessions, or will it backfire and leave Britain even more isolated? Only time will tell.

Beloved by some, tolerated by most and long detested by others, the ever-intricate marriage was wrenched apart by referendum last year. The formal process will take two years and the costs could run into the tens of billions for Britain, but there is no going back. Starved of compromise when it needed it most, Britain spent the last years with the EU in and out of relationship therapy, surviving on an insufficient drip of concessions from the bloc. The last gasp came in the early hours of June 24 when 51.9% voted for termination. It held on through life support until the triggering of Article 50. But now the EU 28 is no more. It wasn't always this way. As the UK and EU embark on their separate journeys, the question on everyone's mind is: what's next? The UK government has announced plans to introduce a points-based immigration system, aimed at attracting high-skilled workers while reducing the number of low-skilled migrants. Meanwhile, the EU is pushing for a comprehensive trade agreement, hoping to maintain a strong economic relationship with its former member.

In Brussels, EU officials are scrambling to redefine their identity and purpose without the UK's involvement. "We are not just a club of 27," said European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker. "We are a force for global governance, and we will continue to shape the world in the years to come."

In London, Prime Minister Theresa May is facing criticism from all sides over her handling of the Brexit negotiations. Opponents of her hardline stance on immigration and trade are calling for a softer approach, while pro-Brexit campaigners are demanding more concessions from the EU.

As the dust settles, many are left wondering what the future holds for both the UK and the EU. Will the UK thrive as an independent nation, or will it struggle to find its footing outside the EU's orbit? And will the EU be able to maintain its influence on the global stage without its largest member?

One thing is certain: the world will be watching as these two former partners navigate their new reality. The consequences of Brexit will be far-reaching, and the next chapter in this complex saga is only just beginning to unfold.

David Cameron -- May's predecessor who lost the Brexit referendum -- has reason to be puzzled by the upshot of his defeat. Britain is now leaving the EU because of his request for a "variable geometry" -- allowing Britain to opt out of basic EU tenets -- which was unceremoniously turned down by Berlin and, less consequentially, by Paris. Yet, as a direct result of Brexit, Berlin and Paris are now adopting the idea of variable geometry as the way forward for the EU. This first paradox is easier to understand when seen through the lens of the conventional European practice of making a virtue out of failure. Angela Merkel, the German Chancellor, had for years opposed the idea of a Europe that proceeds at different speeds -- allowing some countries to be less integrated than others, due to their domestic political situation. due to their domestic political situation. However, with the rise of populist and nationalist movements across the continent, Merkel's stance has undergone a significant shift. In a recent interview, she acknowledged that the EU's one-size-fits-all approach was no longer sustainable and that a more flexible framework was necessary to accommodate the diverse needs and priorities of its member states.

This pivot is not limited to Germany alone. France, too, has shown a willingness to re-examine its stance on variable geometry. French President Emmanuel Macron, who had previously been a vocal critic of the concept, has now expressed his support for a more flexible EU framework. In a speech to the European Parliament, Macron emphasized the need for the EU to adapt to the changing global landscape and to find ways to engage with countries that are not yet ready to join the EU.

The implications of this shift are far-reaching. For one, it could pave the way for the UK to re-engage with the EU on a more favorable terms. Cameron's idea of a "variable geometry" may have been rejected in 2016, but the concept is now gaining traction as a means of addressing the EU's internal divisions and external challenges.

Furthermore, the adoption of variable geometry could also lead to a more decentralized EU, with greater autonomy granted to its member states. This, in turn, could help to reduce tensions between the EU's central authorities and its member states, which have been a source of frustration for many Europeans.

While the journey ahead will undoubtedly be complex and fraught with challenges, the EU's willingness to consider variable geometry as a way forward is a positive step towards a more inclusive and flexible European project. As Cameron himself has acknowledged, the Brexit referendum was a wake-up call for the EU, and its aftermath has led to a renewed focus on finding creative solutions to the continent's pressing problems.

While Brexit will impact on British citizens, it will also affect residents of the other 27 EU members -- not least some 3.2 million EU nationals currently living in Britain. In Germany, the economic powerhouse of the European Union, newspaper Die Welt shows May waving from a paper boat made from the red, white and blue Union flag as the sun appears to set over the sea. "Farewell," the headline reads. The German newspaper's tongue-in-cheek editorial was just one example of the mixed reactions across the EU to the UK's decision to leave the bloc. While some countries, like Germany and France, are concerned about the economic implications of Brexit, others, like Poland and Hungary, have been more sympathetic to the UK's desire for independence.

In Brussels, EU officials were scrambling to figure out what the UK's departure would mean for the remaining 27 member states. "We're facing a significant challenge," said European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker. "We need to work together to ensure a smooth transition and protect the interests of all EU citizens."

Meanwhile, in the UK, Prime Minister Theresa May was facing criticism from all sides over her handling of the Brexit negotiations. Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn accused her of being "reckless" and "divisive," while Conservative MPs were urging her to take a tougher stance with Brussels.

As the clock ticked down to the UK's planned departure date of March 29, 2019, one thing was clear: the consequences of Brexit would be far-reaching and complex. For EU nationals living in the UK, the uncertainty was particularly unsettling. "We're worried about our future," said Maria, a Spanish nurse who has lived in the UK for 10 years. "We don't know what will happen to our jobs, our homes, our lives."

In the midst of the chaos, one thing was certain: the UK's departure from the EU would mark a significant turning point in the country's history. As Die Welt's editorial had so humorously pointed out, it was time to say "Farewell" to the EU – but what came next was anyone's guess.

"This one is one of the biggest investigations the Hill has seen in my time here," Chairman Richard Burr, a North Carolina Republican, said at a news conference with committee vice-chairman Mark Warner. Burr's been in the Senate since 2005, and served in the House since 1995. Burr and Warner say they have 20 witnesses they plan to interview and have scheduled interviews with five of them so far. The committee leaders said that they are happy that President Donald Trump's son-in-law, Jared Kushner, and former campaign chairman Paul Manafort have agreed to testify, but they have not yet decided when they will bring them in. The investigation is focused on alleged Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election and potential collusion with the Trump campaign. The committee has been scrutinizing the Trump campaign's ties to Russia and has received testimony from several key witnesses, including Trump's former national security adviser, Michael Flynn, and his former campaign aide, George Papadopoulos.

Burr and Warner said that they have also received documents and emails that they believe are relevant to the investigation, including some that suggest Trump's campaign may have had more extensive ties to Russia than previously known.

"We've seen some pretty disturbing things," Burr said. "We're not at the point yet where we're accusing anyone of anything, but we're looking at a lot of things that we think are important."

Warner added that the committee is also investigating whether Russia used its influence over Trump's campaign to sway the election. "We're looking at whether there was any quid pro quo, whether there was any promise made, whether there was any payment made," he said.

The committee's investigation is ongoing, and Burr and Warner said that they expect to release their findings in the coming months. They also warned that the investigation could be lengthy and complex, and that it may take several years to complete.

In the meantime, the committee is urging anyone with information about the election to come forward and share it with them. "We're looking for anyone who may have information that can help us get to the bottom of this," Burr said. "We're not interested in anyone's political beliefs or affiliations. We just want to get the facts."

Asked directly on Thursday whether Russia interfered in the election, Putin said: "Read my lips: No." Putin's comments are the President's most emphatic denial of the accusations yet, and are the first he has directly made since US President Donald Trump took office in January. Russian officials and spokespeople for Putin, however, have brushed off the claims several times as a political "witch hunt." The denial comes as intelligence committees from both the House and Senate in the US investigate the alleged interference in the US election, including possible ties between Russian officials and members of Trump's campaign team. The FBI is also conducting its own investigation. The investigation, led by the Senate Intelligence Committee, is focusing on whether Russia's alleged interference was aimed at influencing the outcome of the election, and whether any Trump campaign officials were aware of or involved in the efforts. The committee has subpoenaed several individuals, including former Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafort and his deputy, Rick Gates, to testify about their ties to Russia.

In a separate development, the Justice Department announced on Thursday that it had appointed a special counsel to investigate the alleged Russian interference and any potential ties between the Trump campaign and Russia. The special counsel, Robert Mueller, is a former FBI director who has a reputation for being a seasoned investigator.

Meanwhile, the White House has continued to downplay the allegations, with Press Secretary Sean Spicer saying on Thursday that the administration is "not concerned" about the investigation. However, the controversy has taken a toll on the administration's approval ratings, with a new poll showing that 62% of Americans believe the President and his campaign had some level of contact with Russian officials during the election.

The denial by Putin comes as the international community is increasingly divided over the issue. While some countries, including the UK and Germany, have condemned Russia's alleged interference, others, such as China and Iran, have refused to comment or have defended Russia's actions as a legitimate exercise of its sovereign rights.

The controversy has also led to calls for greater transparency and accountability from lawmakers and the public. "The American people deserve to know the truth about what happened in the election," said Senator John McCain, a leading Republican critic of the President. "We cannot allow foreign powers to interfere in our democratic process without taking swift and decisive action."

The trailer for "An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth to Power" was released on Tuesday and opens with a clip of Trump on the campaign trail. "It's supposed to be 70 degrees today, it's freezing here. The trailer for "An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth to Power" was released on Tuesday and opens with a clip of Trump on the campaign trail. "It's supposed to be 70 degrees today, it's freezing here," Trump is heard saying, as a split screen shows a graphic of rapidly rising global temperatures.

The trailer then cuts to a montage of devastating natural disasters, including hurricanes, wildfires, and floods, with a voiceover from former Vice President Al Gore, the film's narrator. "We're facing a crisis of catastrophic proportions," Gore warns.

The film, which is a follow-up to Gore's 2006 documentary "An Inconvenient Truth," highlights the urgent need for action to combat climate change. The trailer features footage of melting glaciers, drought-stricken landscapes, and endangered species, as well as interviews with world leaders, scientists, and activists.

The sequel also delves into the economic and social impacts of climate change, including rising sea levels, extreme weather events, and displacement of communities. Gore argues that the consequences of inaction will be dire, but that there is still time to take action and avoid the worst effects of climate change.

The trailer ends with a call to action, urging viewers to demand that their leaders take bold action to address the climate crisis. "The truth is inconvenient, but the consequences of ignoring it are catastrophic," Gore says. "It's time to face the truth and take action to protect our planet."

"An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth to Power" is set to be released in theaters on September 22. The film's premiere will coincide with the 2017 Global Citizen Festival in Central Park, which will feature a performance by Beyoncé and other artists. The event aims to raise awareness and funds to support climate change initiatives and sustainable development projects around the world.

Katie Walsh, the White House's deputy chief of staff, will join a nonprofit group supporting the President's agenda, the President's top aides said Thursday. The move marks the second departure of a senior White House official in the first months of the administration, following national security adviser Michael Flynn's forced resignation last month. It also represents a major change in the makeup of the White House's top staff that could shift the power dynamics within the West Wing as Walsh was a close ally of White House chief of staff Reince Priebus. Walsh was Priebus' deputy, joining him in the administration after serving as his chief of staff when he was chairman of the Republican National Committee. The news article continues:

According to sources, Walsh's departure is expected to be effective at the end of the month, and she will join the nonprofit group, "America Forward," which is a key supporter of the President's policy initiatives. The group was founded in 2004 and has been a major player in promoting conservative policies and candidates.

Walsh's departure is seen as a significant loss for the White House, particularly given her close relationship with Priebus. The two have worked together for many years, and Walsh was widely seen as a key strategist and advisor to the White House chief of staff.

The move is also seen as a sign of the ongoing shake-up within the White House staff, which has been marked by a series of high-profile departures and hires.
